name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission Declarations on the intensification of the terrorist threat (2016/2519(RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on this occasion, ten weeks after the Paris terrorist attacks, I would like to be able to say that most probably we will never again witness such a heinous attack in Europe. Unfortunately, I am not convinced that this is true. On the contrary, judging from recent events, the terrorist threat seems to be increasing in the European Union, but also in its vicinity and further afield, as the recent attacks in Istanbul, Jakarta, Ouagadougou and Charsadda in Pakistan have shown. As the Presidency, we will do everything within our powers to improve the Union’s capacity to counter this threat and to protect our citizens. In this context, counter—terrorism will be a key topic at the informal meeting of the Justice and Home Affairs Ministers next week in Amsterdam. The Presidency also attaches great importance to the rule of law and to getting the balance right in this respect in the fight against terrorism. Obstacles to the exchange of information on foreign terrorist fighters and the way forward to clear these obstacles will be first and foremost on the agenda. Another issue that we will address is information sharing between Member States on firearms and explosive precursors. Implementation of the measures agreed is key, as indicated in the EU Internal Security Strategy 2015-2020.  The Heads of State and Government statement on counter-terrorism of 12 February 2015, after the Charlie Hebdo attacks, remains the framework the European Union needs to implement urgently, as called for by the European Council. You can be assured that the Presidency will spare no effort to promote rapid progress in its implementation. Progress has been made over the past months and was set out in a public report by the European Union Counter—Terrorism Coordinator in late November.  Information sharing and operational cooperation are top priorities identified by the Council. Progress has been made. The agreement on the European Union PNR Directive will support police and intelligence agencies in tracking down possible terrorists and criminals by accessing travel details of passengers.  On 1 January, Europol launched the European Counter—Terrorism Centre (ECTC). This is a more robust platform through which Member States can increase information sharing and operational coordination. This includes the monitoring and investigation of foreign terrorist fighters, as well as the trafficking of illegal firearms and terrorist financing. In November 2015 Member States committed to seconding counter-terrorism (CT) experts to the ECTC to form an enhanced cross-border investigation support unit. Europol is actively engaged in supporting ongoing CT investigations in several Member States. The progress of contributions to the various EU databases is being monitored and discussed in the Council.  Outside the European Union context, cooperation and information sharing among security services will be stepped up in the context of the Counter Terrorist Group (CTG), and the Commission will soon present its proposal on updating the European Criminal Records Information System for the systematic sharing of criminal records data for people connected to terrorism.  Furthermore, we have started discussing the proposal to amend to framework decision on combating terrorism. On 2 December 2015, the Commission presented a draft directive with a view to collectively implementing UN Security Council Resolution 2178 and the additional Protocol to the Council of Europe Convention. Negotiations on this directive are already under way and we hope to be in a position to achieve an agreement in June this year. Apart from enhancing the exchange of law enforcement information, countering radicalisation and recruitment remains a priority. An EU approach is needed, taking into account that over 5 000 citizens have left to fight for terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria. Concerning integration and non-discrimination, we should create opportunities for all. We should do much more on tolerance and anti-Muslim hatred, further inter-religious dialogue and communicate our values. Education is key and we look forward to Commission initiatives in this context.  But prevention alone is not enough. The return of well—trained radicalised individuals poses a genuine security threat. At European Union level, the main tool we have for sharing best practices is the Radicalisation Awareness Network. This network has made impressive strides in recent months, facilitating the flow of best practice and expertise between Member States. We can also begin to share expertise with third countries. The immediate focus here will be the Middle East, the North Africa region and Turkey.  It is a fact that the internet is one of the primary channels for radicalisation, publishing and proliferating illegal content. The establishment of an Internet Referral Unit within Europol’s Counter—Terrorism Centre has improved our ability to obtain the removal of terrorist threats. On 3 December 2015 the EU Internet Forum was launched. The objective is to identify and remove terrorist content and to develop effective counter-narratives. In this context, cooperation with the providers is obviously important.  The discussion of the Commission’s proposal for an EU action plan against illicit trafficking in and use of firearms and explosives has begun. The Presidency aims to reach a general approach on this new proposal. Finally, I would like to mention the border police package, which is also important in the context of the fight against terrorism, as we have to strengthen controls at the EU’s external borders. Border security is not a top priority under our Presidency. On this issue one should of course be careful about mixing migration and terrorism. We cannot turn our eyes away from the threat, but let us not forget that the vast majority of migrants are fleeing situations of conflict and even fleeing from terrorism themselves. The close cooperation with key partners, such as the United States, is continuing. Furthermore, we will continue to strengthen our counter-terrorism engagement with partners in North Africa, the Middle East, Turkey and the Western Balkans.  Let me conclude by saying that I think we all share the same objectives. Among other things, this was demonstrated by your resolution of February last year on anti-terrorism and the reports adopted by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs at the end of last year. We look forward to a fruitful cooperation.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as you all know, 2015 has been a turning point in Europe’s experience of terrorism. Terror has claimed the lives of 150 innocent people – too many lives lost, and too many lives scarred. We have to be realistic: the terrorist threat in the European Union is high. The terrorist threat is there. We are determined to respond with resolve and resilience, and at the same time to uphold our values of tolerance, democracy and respect for fundamental rights. From day one of this Commission, we stressed that combating terrorism was a common European responsibility. Our European Agenda on Security has been on the table, as you know, since last April. We have drastically accelerated its delivery with the political agreement on the EU PNR, the proposal for a directive on terrorism, the November firearms package, the action plan on firearms trafficking, the EUROPOL Regulation adopted in December, the reinforced RAN Centre of Excellence to counter radicalisation, the launch of the EU internet forum to counter harmful content online and, just this week , the proposal to exchange the criminal records of non-EU nationals.  These are all tangible measures to strengthen our security across borders, and more is coming. 2016 will be the year when we go after terrorist money. We need to deprive terrorists of their financial resources. In early February, we will put our ideas forward with a concrete timetable. Our Borders Package of last December is also a critical piece of the puzzle, because it will allow the systematic security checks of all people leaving and entering the EU. It is clear that we need to improve the management of our external borders in order to enhance internal security and safeguard Schengen. I want to be clear, once again, on a related point: refugees, who are crossing our borders because they need international protection, and who are entitled to international protection, are not terrorists. I want to reaffirm that we will never equate refugees with terrorists. We cannot, and we must not, allow fear to prevail.  Let me finally turn to information sharing: this is a sensitive, but as you will understand, a very crucial issue. As you know, it is one of the central pillars of our Security Agenda. The EU tools are there to facilitate the exchange of information between national law enforcement authorities. The Schengen Information System, Europol’s databases and the Prüm framework should be used to the maximum by the Member States. Member States need to trust each other more: they need to share more information, between themselves and also with Europol. Law enforcement authorities across Member States, including specialised law enforcement agencies, all work for the same purpose: the security of our citizens. We need to understand that, collectively, we are all safer. The threats we face are common. Our approaches to the threats need to be common too. This is not a competition. We reinforce each other if we cooperate. Information is already being exchanged at various levels – but we need more of it, not less.  Next week, we will officially launch the European Counter Terrorism Centre at Europol. It has been operational since 1 January 2016. The Centre can become the hub of our counter-terrorism operations if we make the best use of it, and if Member States share information. This centre can only succeed in its mission if we all help it to succeed. The support provided by Europol to French and Belgian investigators after the Paris attacks is the best example of the role that the European Counter Terrorism Centre could play: cross-checking data, facilitating information-sharing and providing analytical and operational assistance to the national services on the ground. One year ago, following the Charlie Hebdo attacks, we stressed that our response would not be dictated by fear or driven by hasty conclusions. The Commission proposed several concrete actions which are part of a comprehensive approach, and in this collective effort we have made progress. But recent events remind us that we still need to do much more. Now is the time to act and to strengthen our cooperation. Let us make 2016 a turning point for Europe to tackle terrorism decisively, head-on, in all its aspects.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, today Dabiq magazine entitled 'Just terror' writes: 'Let Paris be a lesson for those nations that wish to take heed.' But the policy of terrorism cannot pass into the European Union, because the European Union is inspired by the principles and rules of the policy of democracy. Today, according to Europol's research, some six or five thousand European citizens are terrorists. Are we going to allow this to continue? How can we control it? What have the European Union and the Council done? We've taken steps, very important. Our answer to the terrorists is that fear will not prevail. But how can this phenomenon be controlled? There are structured groups, there are networks of terrorists, there are targets: human lives, marginalisation of Europe, closure of borders. The policy we are pursuing is very correct and we cannot confuse immigration with terrorism, because it has nothing to do with one phenomenon with the other, regardless of whether the uncontrolled flow of migrants often also involved terrorists. But there is no way for the European Parliament, for the European Union, for the European concept of the world, to identify these two phenomena. Ladies and gentlemen, what we must be very careful about, and indeed very seriously, is how we manage to control the phenomenon. We will check it through the Internet, we will check it through the cooperation of the Member States, we will control it through cooperation with third countries, because terrorism has a face, an extremely repugnant person, to whom the European Union's response can only be more Democracy. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Both in what you said and in what Commissioner Avramopoulos said, there is a lot of reason. There should be no link between exile and immigration, immigration with support for terrorism or even support for terrorism. But do you not really see that it is the presence of multimillion-dollar Muslim communities that has created a subsoil for terrorism in Europe, which, unfortunately, is already a European phenomenon, not an exotic one, not an imported one?

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), answer with "blue card". Mr President, as long as we do not combine the two phenomena, we should have a strategy for controlling Europe's external borders. To this end, the European Union is working to prevent such phenomena. The choice of preventing people from coming to the European Union does not characterise us. The European Union can control its external borders, but the movement of citizens and goods through Schengen and the circulation of ideas are the principles that are precisely our Union.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The terrorist attacks in recent months in Europe – but also elsewhere – are not directed against certain people. Their aim is to spread fear and thus destroy freedom and democracy. That is why it is clear that we have a clear edge against terrorism, that our free societies are being defended.  What does that mean? Firstly, current terrorism is not a national phenomenon. That is why the existing European tools for identifying and exchanging information need to be made much better. Better prevention: this includes debunking terrorist propaganda on the Internet, deleting illegal content and identifying its authors; Terrorists are turning the tap on the money and, above all, countering radicalisation in Europe, through integration and comprehensive counselling and exit programmes.  Protecting people, condemning perpetrators and instigators: our Member States are called upon to make the personnel and factual equipment of the police and the judiciary adequate. There must be no lawless spaces. Investigations must be carried out in an analogous and digitally effective manner, and judicial proceedings must be commenced in a timely manner.  Effective European law enforcement needs comparable definitions of crime and penalties for terrorist acts across the EU. The Commission has, of course, put forward a proposal on this. And also: fair procedures must always be guaranteed, also so that proceedings do not fail due to inadmissible evidence. Finally, prevent, protect and track. The instruments of the rule of law must be used consistently. Only in this way will we maintain confidence in the rule of law and, at the same time, successfully counter terrorism.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that the terrorist threat is perhaps the biggest challenge facing the Member States today. Islamic State and other terrorist organizations have long been underestimated, as have the processes of self-isolation and radicalization among young Muslims in many European slums after the failure of integration and multiculturalism theories. Some European leaders, however, continue the reckless policy towards countries that openly finance, organise and treat terrorist organisations such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. It is time for this hypocrisy, this policy of wide-closed eyes, to be ended.  Countries that finance terrorism, which treat and train terrorists, should not be paid a ransom, as the European Union has done with Turkey, but should be suspended membership negotiations and sanctions imposed. Those who organise it, such as Saudi Arabia, should be given trade sanctions, not traded hypocritically with them. It is high time to stop talking, especially after Paris and after Cologne, if we do not want this to become our daily life. It's a matter of civilisational and value choice.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, terrorism has spread into our lives, values, societies and our way of living. The scope of the threat is broad and thus requires a European response in close cooperation with our partners around the world.  A European riposte to the asymmetric war should focus in my view on the following issues: terrorism financing, internal and external security, and the root causes of terrorism.   We must adapt our legislation to better prevent and track terrorism financing. It is not expensive to conduct attacks such as those in Paris. We need tighter rules on tools like prepaid cards and stricter anti-money-laundering rules. Regarding ISIS there are some ten sources of its financing. We must strangle them all, starting with oil trafficking.  Europe cannot be insecure. We must reinforce security measures at all levels, from local to EU-wide. Of course they should be effective but not excessive. At European level, cooperation between Member States, their police and other law enforcement services is the key. We must not repeat the mistakes of the past. At the same time, we must better protect and control our external borders. The alert is high. It is crucial that all our border and coast guards and police know who enters and leaves Europe. External border control is also the best way to fight arms trafficking effectively and limit terrorists’ access to arms.  There is, however, a long-term task. Many radicalised people were born and raised in Europe and some then became foreign fighters and some conducted attacks against their own country. Teams with expertise and on-the-ground experience should develop integration projects which local authorities should then implement.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Union's deliberate strategy in the fight against terrorism is to be a ceasing of democratic freedom and individual freedoms. Insisting on the pilgrim thesis of the false dichotomy freedom/security, supporting a militaristic view of the alleged fight against terrorism that, instead of weakening, strengthens the logics of hatred and war.  The recurrent imposition of increased measures of fundamental rights and freedoms, which always accompanies the increase in the escalation of militarisation of international relations, of war and of interference and destabilisation of sovereign states, fuels the growth of racist, xenophobic and fascist forces and their action of terror.  Heinous crimes, such as those committed in Paris or those that have been perpetrated in various places around the world for years, what they demand is a policy of peace in international relations and respect for international law, which puts an end to interference and aggression against sovereign states, particularly in the Middle East region, which have led to the resurgence of terrorist groups.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President,  I am delighted to hear the Presidency outlining most of what the Commission proposes and I would be very happy if it were possible to work more quickly towards solutions on fighting terrorism than was possible in the past. It was Member States that blocked many measures to set common standards in the area of criminal proceedings, cooperation on organised crime and terrorism, and especially information sharing between institutions and authorities of the Member States and Europol or other agencies at the European level, and it is still not working.  Information sharing, especially when it comes to information on suspects and risks, is still not working, and it is this that we need to strengthen: not gathering loads of data on individuals who are not relevant at all for investigators, but concentrating on the quick exchange of information on persons who are suspicious and areas where there are risks.  That is also needed not only for effectiveness, but because we are still in rule-of-law-based democracies and we have to respect the fundamental values which we defend here against the terrorists. It was reiterated just days ago by the Strasbourg Court of Human Rights, with regard to a case in Hungary, that you always need to have a suspicion or risk in order to retain data on individuals. So we should stick to that and strengthen that and not build further information-gathering measures.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the first rule of any government is the protection of its people, and the protection of the people of Europe from terrorism is at least something, I recognise, you understand as being serious. But in order to deal with the problem of terrorism you must at first know who your enemy is and who your friends are. You must know where they share your values and where they come from and this is where the analysis of the European Union is failing. You have to understand the problem, you have to understand where they are, and you have to understand what they are doing here.  The first part of the problem, Minister, is that in the language of yourself and of the Commissioner – I quote from you: ʻthe vast majority of migrants are fleeing terrorism’ – that quite frankly is not true. We know that the vast majority of migrants are economic migrants; the vast majority of asylum seekers are genuinely people fleeing terrorism: that is the first part of the problem you must address.  The second part of the problem, you must understand, is that the open borders that you have created and are not willing to challenge – you do not know who has come in, you do not know where they are and you do not know how they get here – creates the last form of terrorism, the internal terrorism that the women in Cologne and Bonn and Berlin and Sweden and all other parts of Europe that suffered over New Year’s Eve will have to face. That is your problem. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: blue-card question. – (Due to a technical problem the speaker agreed to ask the question in English) You said many things and I agree with you, but do you agree with me that terrorism is a universal threat? We also have terrorism inside Europe – you remember what happened in Northern Ireland, in Germany, in Italy, in Norway or in other countries in Europe. That is our European problem – it is European terrorism. We are not speaking only and just about the terrorists who are coming into Europe. I think that terrorism is a universal threat for us and that we have to combat all types of terrorism. Do you agree with me?

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card answer. – Sir, may I add that your English is excellent in comparison to my understanding and knowledge of your language, and I welcome that. You are quite right that terrorism is an international problem. It stretches and hurts and pains families across the globe, and yes, we have our own problems with individuals here – and we have that on a home-grown basis. But the issue that we are facing today is ISIS and the evil ideology that is attempting to turn man against man and woman against woman, and we have to have a solution – not just a European Union solution, but a global solution. That is the way forward, and the only way that we can tackle it.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Today we are talking about the heightened terror threat and it seems to many of you that Europe is the target of Islamic terror. This is because, despite the attacks in Paris, Copenhagen, Brussels, Madrid and London, the wrong analysis is still being made of why the West is under attack from those who have supplied it to us. Despite the many deaths that have already been killed in the name of the Islamic State, you deny that these terrorists take their inspiration from the Koran. Despite the fact that it has been established that terrorists are using the asylum invasion to enter the European Union, some here still dismiss it as hysteria. And despite the acute threat of attacks across Western Europe, the political elite here still believe in the utopia called multiculturalism. Mr President, the only correct analysis must be that Islam is the greatest danger, Islam is out for world domination. But there is another great danger in Europe: the danger of the cowardly politically correct elite, who dare not call it by name, but who, through an open-border policy, are flooding the European continent with the Islamic invasion.  It is therefore incomprehensible to me that the many victims of terror, sexual assaults and rapes are still not a reason to put an end to this invasion. In fact, only in the first few weeks of this month, thirty-one thousand asylum seekers arrived in Greece, among them surely jihadists and hordes of testosterone bombs full of contempt for women. And they make grateful use of Schengen. Without borders, there is no security and the question is not if, but when we can expect the next attack or organised mass assault. So, if you really take this heightened terror threat and the security of the people of our European countries seriously, then it is time for you to recognise that the only solution in the fight against terror is to close down national borders, to send all those so-called asylum seekers back to where they come from, and to stop the Islamisation of the European continent.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, suddenly Europe discovered terrorism. Both our Golden Dawn movement and other nationalist movements across Europe have been warning for too many years about what was going to happen. You're accusing us of Islamophobic. Tell that to the parents of the children who went to the Bataclan to have fun and never went home. "We will not succumb," you say, "to terrorism", when capitals of European countries have the army on the streets to deal with the threat. You have lost touch with the reality and everyday life of the European citizen. Your policies of open borders, the collapse of values and unprecedented racism against indigenous peoples could only provide fertile ground for the seed of Islamic fundamentalism. No matter how much you try, through the media to hide it, terrorism in Europe has an Islamic identity. The organized attack in Cologne on the 1st of the year against women is a terrorist attack. They sent the message: "we are here and we will ..... your wives, daughters and sisters!" and you recommend that women do not dress provocatively and wear perfumes. Most of the mosques currently operating in Europe are nothing but terrorist nurseries. What's the solution? Abandon your ideological anchorages, shield our continent from the millions that flock every year illegally.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Minister, commissioner, thank you for the words you have said and for the attempt you share with us, members of the European Parliament, to tackle with intelligence, dignity and foresight the great tragedy of terrorist violence in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and on many world scenarios. The news is not comforting these days and, all the more so, we expect to be able to say, as the European Parliament, that the action we are taking in the European Union, both on pnr data management policies and in an attempt to share a reasonable but firm defence policy on our continent, is heading in the right direction. But that is not enough. We see it: there are many fronts on which our weakness, inevitable weakness, is expressed, there are many and they also have to do with the issue of immigration.  I agree with those who, even during this debate, have rightly decided to deny a causal link between immigration and terrorism. It is wrong to associate the two phenomena in a general way, but it is equally wrong to deny that the two phenomena may have common causes. It is wrong to think that if Islamic areas normally produce terrorist phenomena such as those that have dramatically affected our continent, it is wrong to believe that that front, where we often find men who use the Koran as a breviary to administer violence, can be left in a position to continue to do so. Let us stop thinking that we can avoid bringing democracy to countries where it is not there, because the lack of democracy and the lack of civilisation that our Christian tradition has given us are the main cause of those terrorist phenomena.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – The world is being rocked by new and new terrorist attacks. This week's attack rocked Pakistan, last weekend's Burkina Faso. Unfortunately, 2015 will be remembered in Europe with bitterness. It worries about the growing phenomenon of terrorism. Young people born in Europe who succumb to radicalisation as a result of their exclusion from society. The challenges are exceptional.  Terrorism is a threat to peace and world order, but it is important that we separate and emphasise once again: we must not connect refugees with terrorism! Most refugees are fleeing terrorism and war. People's safety is essential, but only measures to strengthen security are doomed to fail unless we adequately accompany them with social policies at home, but also outside Europe, to prevent radicalisation. We must address the causes of the crises at its origins. Europe also urgently needs a clear strategy on how to deal with returnees. Information sharing, yes, that's the key. Until it works between countries, then, unfortunately, no action will help. That is why building trust is also key. Member States should cooperate more actively in the exchange of information on crime, tracing and financing of foreign fighters, terrorist cells, arms tracking and other threats to European security. I am surprised by the Council's stance, which has not agreed to the mandatory exchange of information on potential terrorists in the new PNR Directive, despite the fact that it could prevent many tragedies. We must stand up more forcefully against radical Islamist propaganda on social media, empower parents and enforce parental permits for young people's travel, give more voice to victims, more effectively identify and rehabilitate the society of troubled, radicalised individuals. The fight against terrorism must cover security measures in full respect of human rights.  (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Article 162(8)).

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. To my mind, it was the Socialists who were one of the groups that slowed down the work on the PNR directive. A few weeks ago, the Commission came up with a new draft anti-terrorism directive. This is a good directive. I would like to ask you, as a representative of the Socialist Group, whether the Socialists will support the anti-terrorism directive tabled by the Commission, or will we, as in the case of the PNR directive, have to deal with blocking work on it?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, thank you for your question. At the moment, it is important to stress, above all, that the exchange of information is necessary, but we must not go too far in the direction of encroaching on our own privacy. There is something about the exchange of information on terrorism, organised crime, so it will all depend on what the proposal will bring and how the negotiations will take place.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the increased threat of terror. Paris was terror. Cologne was also terror. Cologne in figures: 883 suspects, 30 suspects, half of them asylum seekers and 11 of them have entered Germany since September. We cannot talk about terror without also talking about the migrant crisis. One of the perpetrators of Paris was an asylum seeker in Germany. Eight to ten million refugees are now on their way from Syria and Iraq to Germany, our development minister says. Nobody says they are all terrorists. But the terrorists among them are abusing our open borders. And there are too many. Those who are responsible for open borders are also responsible for their actions, and that is mr Seehofer, who speaks a great deal, the CDU Group, which writes a great many letters, and that is our Chancellor. She will go down in history as a destroyer of Europe, even if she is about to resign.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, the Council and the Commission I believe have agreed very much on the list of tasks that are necessary to be more effective in the face of the growing terrorist threat. And that's all very well, I think it's very well on track. And we thank you for being consistent and consistent. Now, there are weaknesses. And I, as far as you have said, see two fundamental weaknesses. On the one hand, there is a need for will because, in the face of a global threat, we also need a comprehensive and perfectly well-connected response, and there are countries that do not cooperate sufficiently in databases, there are countries that do not cooperate in the exchange of information or information agencies. And that's a clear weakness, because they're connected and we have to be perfectly connected to be effective. And the second weakness is prevention and early detection. It will be a global threat, but the performance has to be local and we don't have a hot spots mapping. We don't have a protocol on what actions are good practice or not. You're going to have a meeting because somewhere there's been good practice. No. We have to be a lot more systematic. Local action is essential to avoid risks and to avoid added problems, and they have to work much harder on what is the greatest weakness: prevention and early work in the local network.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have talked about two very important challenges, although I would like to ask you about a third one. Are you not afraid that some governments are overreacting to dangers and challenges? I could give you a concrete example, the Hungarian Government, which is preparing to introduce a state of emergency. How do you actually assess this, that some governments are not necessarily using the right tools, thereby also endangering the security and freedom of European citizens?

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Szanyi, I love that you ask me this question. Logically, one of the temptations and risks is that governments, in dealing with fanaticism, in dealing with terrorists, may exceed the limits of the law. Of course we always have to act in accordance with the law, avoiding impunity, but also defending human rights, our fundamental rights and our rule of law because otherwise we would have lost the battle against terrorism, which is the battle of our freedoms and what we have conquered: our rule of law. The law, the whole law and no impunity, but no abuse. None of that works. Abuse always works like a boomerang.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, the fight against terrorism does not go through a false choice between our security and our rights and freedoms. We are facing a challenge that requires both increasing the effectiveness of state action and reaffirming an unquestionable commitment to democracy and human rights, both within and outside our borders. Islamic State's funding and logistical supply routes need to be cut off. We must support democratic forces in the Arab world and strengthen civil society in Syria and Iraq. Recruitment networks need to be neutralized, improving the coordination systems of our intelligence services. And it is also our responsibility to protect refugees fleeing terror. Of course, the best way to combat extremism is to make people feel part of a cohesive society and cultivate social and economic opportunities in vulnerable communities. Many terrorists have been born in Europe and this phenomenon is only combated with social inclusion policies, especially through education.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: I heard the Commissioner talk about a proposal he wants to make to combat terrorist financing. You have already announced this a few times, but I would like to understand what its purpose actually is. If you look at the attacks in New York, nine eleven, they were actually at a bargain. It's a strange thing to say, but all in all, they didn't cost much. The Boston marathon bombings were also a bargain. Moreover, the Paris attacks did not cost much in the end. Of course, a lot of money is being nailed down by Daesh, for example, but this is particularly the case in Syria, in the Middle East, to pay the salaries of its own fighters, for example.  So what do we want? Do we want to organise a method of detection by following terrorist financing? Unfortunately, little money leaves very little trace, so I don't understand. Or do we want - and I would understand that - to have some sort of "pick them" policy? Take the money away, deprive them of the opportunity to commit terrorism. If it costs little, it's not effective. So explain it to me, because I'm interested in what the purpose is.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Plus they use a feudal Arabic system of transferring the money.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the increase in the terrorist threat must not lead to a high price being paid in terms of having freedom and rights squeezed in order to obtain greater security from threats, especially within Europe and not just outside its borders. Although the responsibility for combating this phenomenon mainly concerns the Member States, the European Union can make an important contribution.  It is therefore necessary to ensure an efficient and coordinated exchange of information, to improve the dialogue between databases and national intelligence services, otherwise what is happening remains as an alternative, namely the use of the reintroduction of internal border controls by the Member States. In short, we need to improve the use of the tools that you already have and not continue to collect more and more data. Terrorist organisations are fighting each other with their political isolation, identifying and cutting their channels of funding and data supply. Achieving these results is not impossible, all that is needed is the political will to achieve them.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank those who represent the Dutch Government today. I am sorry and now, as I speak, I will get, because there are 751 of us in this Chamber, 751, there will be 30 of us in here, there are more officials than Members! And is this the Europe that is trying to solve the problems, that is talking about such an important issue as terrorism? But fuck, I rebel against this Europe, but how does there be such a Europe! What shame is that? What do we say to the people of Europe? When the attacks happen, everyone weeps like crocodiles! What happened in Paris, what happened in London, in Madrid and what happened in New York.  And what do we say? Ehh, yes, there are Islamists, there is terrorism! What shame is this? Is this the Europe that wants to fight? Is this the Europe that wants to defend Europeans? This is the Europe of zombies! They're zombies! Because the ones in charge have bodyguards, they have armored cars, they have everything, and they're never going to attack them! It is the people who are being attacked and what do we say? Thanks to Islam. In the meantime, we are giving billions and billions to Turkey and we want it inside Europe. 90 % of Turkey is made up of Islamists. I am not with the Islamists, we would miss something else, but we are Europeans, we are Westerners we show that we have balls! (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Blue card question. Since you have accepted my 'blue card', I will say it in Italian so that you will understand me more easily. Do you not think it is 'hypocrisy' when you arrive now, just now, here in the Chamber and then leave immediately? Because I am here every day from morning until evening and you come here, as does your President Salvini, and you say that there is no one in the Chamber and then you leave. This is hypocrisy. Do you agree with me?

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Answer to a blue card question. To all those who applaud, I say go and look at my figures: there are 751 Members in 16th place for production, for attendance in the Chamber, for votes. So you don't have to tell me these things here, because I come here, I work, I get busy, I'm in 16th place and I'm also mayor. You don't know what you do from morning to night, but I know what I'm doing. Clear? (The speaker agreed to answer a question "carton bleu" (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Buonanno, with all due respect, I do not know if you have met terrorists, I do. I have lived thirteen years with a police escort and my brother was killed by terrorists. And I assure you that what we need here is not to put on any shows and to be very, very effective, and for that we have to have a spirit of collaboration.  You've talked about a Europe of zombies, of course I'm not a zombie. I've come here to work and contribute everything I know. Because I do know how terrorists are fanned and radicalized and I have met terrorists of all styles because I have worked on it for many years. Don't insult us who we're working here, we don't have to be three hundred people talking nonsense, what it takes is for us to say sensible things and you, sir, have been hit by an effect, but that's not serious and I'm telling you with all affection.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Well, I did not have it, my dear colleague, with you, because those who are here are obviously not in the criticism I was making, we would miss you! But I am angry with those who govern this Europe, who will certainly never be touched, who will certainly not have their wives touching his butt, perhaps some Islamic as in Cologne, or raping them, these things are not there. I'm not here. Sure, and everyone who claps here, like four monkeys, there like that, but get busy, go around working, don't stay here like some dolls!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the people now have a great deal of experience. From the mujahideen, Osama bin Laden and al-Qaeda, to the Islamic State, all of them were nurtured by NATO, the United States, the European Union and the Gulf monarchies for their own interests. All of these are over time the convenient pretext for imperialist interventions where land. You sow Arab opens that turn into a heavy winter for the people, and you reap imperialist interventions that baptize counterterrorism campaigns with complex suppression and envelope mechanisms. The European Union is deliberately trying to root out the radicalisation of peoples and refugees along with terrorism so that it can strengthen its legal arsenal vis-à-vis the labour movement and to put labour rights and freedoms in the plaster. She wants to incriminate the struggle to overthrow a capitalist barbarity that she herself defends. In the face of the barbaric anti-labour attack promoted by the European Union and the governments, it is predicted that the people will stand up. If they decide, they'll show their strength.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, on a point of order. I would ask the President of the House that when Members of the House issue insults and incite against the Heads of Government of our countries and their wives, allegedly on behalf of the people, they should be told that this is not a parliamentary way of dealing with each other. Turning now to the factual question, terrorism is one of the greatest threats. And, ladies and gentlemen, I can join you in saying that for twenty years I was accompanied by bodyguards and our family was threatened by terrorists. That's why I know pretty well how people feel who are threatened. But this blow to terrorism has another dimension. It is directed against people, all those who do not follow the crude, confused and erroneous understanding of ISIS or al-Qaeda. It is aimed at young people who visit restaurants, go dancing, visit a football stadium or celebrate in a square.  That is why it is important for me to say very clearly: dear Member States, the exchange of data really needs to improve. Legal gaps that may have arisen in well-intentioned data protection must be corrected in such a way that the data can be exchanged consistently. We must also compare Eurodac data with the data of the perpetrators, so that terrorists cannot simply mix with refugees, so that others cannot say again that the border should be closed. No, if a terrorist hides somewhere in a plane, we do not ban air traffic, but we try to prevent them from getting on planes or mingling with refugees. We also need to significantly speed up and develop the methods of mutual legal and investigative assistance and the possibilities for doing so. We must transfer the offenders and dangerous persons fully into European databases, and not only in part, so that every country knows who is a criminal and who is a danger, and that we can act accordingly and inform the police authorities.  However, we must strengthen the backs of the police officers and not distrust them, because they have to fight these serious criminals on a daily basis and they need our trust, our support and not constant information about what they are doing wrong. Because it's easier to judge things from the sofa than actually standing outside and having to act. We must make use of the new technologies, and I would ask the Presidency of the Council to adopt both PNR and Europol quickly and all the issues relating to data protection and the data protection package and directive. One point is really important: drying up financial sources is a building block and the many building blocks that we need to address. The fight against terrorism will only work if we have to concerted and united it and oppose it in a constitutional and democratic manner.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague, how will you comment on the information in the media that German police officers, German security officers have been ordered politically to cover up crimes because of the origin of their perpetrators? I'm talking about the events of New Year's Eve.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Dzhambazki, I would like to thank Mr Dzhambazki for his First of all, we need to uncover the offence and not, first and foremost, identify nationalities. You can do that after that. And if nationalities play a role in relation to crime, then this is included accordingly. But I do not mention nationality and then I discuss the offence, and I do not just assign crimes to nationalities, but I want crimes to be punished. My problem is that there are too many no-go areas, that there are too many banlieues, that there are too many Molenbeeks, and that there are too many zones where too little intervention is being made, where petty crimes are no longer punished, and that a culture develops that is a culture that is unculture and destroys human rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you how you also assess the fact that the events in Cologne were not presented to the media for four to five days at all, that there was no public debate on it, that not only, as Colleague Dzhambazki said, the police were given orders to stop the information, but that german public opinion in general, including opinion throughout Europe, was therefore , was not informed of these facts? How does this compare to the problem we are currently discussing – the problem of terrorism?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Krasnod-bski! There has been criticism that a public broadcaster did not report until two days later. Most media outlets have already reported relatively promptly. What is relatively difficult is that we are having a debate in Germany about – I say quite honestly, this did not happen in Munich – that such conditions as in Cologne do not occur if no-go-areas and petty crimes are sufficiently punished and prosecuted at an early stage. For this reason, it is important to be preventively consistent and also to put a stop to petty offenders and those who organise them, because that is the only way to create the problems, and not by other things.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Europe has been under threat of terror since the horrific Paris attacks. Fear is understandable, danger is not underestimated. Yet I must say that even in this situation, we must maintain our sanity. We must insist on the freedom that underskers of liberal democracies. We must not give in to far-right and populist parties that vilely exploit people's fears, scare, and inciting fear and xenophobia. We must say that there is no terrorist threat that entitles anyone to severely curtaily fundamental rights, citizens' rights. The fear of terrorism often encourages us to take security measures that go against the principles of liberal democracy, the pillars and achievements of our own European culture. But that's what terrorists want, that's what populist, far-right politics wants. Destroying the free world we've built for the last 60 years. And we say that security is inseparable from respect for fundamental rights, freedom. It should therefore be made clear that even more data, even more mass surveillance, will not work. We need no more, but much more effective, rather cooperative secret service work than ever before, and, above all, a joint European secret service. But that won't be enough. We must do everything we can to make sure that the second and third generation of immigrants do not become radicalised, but find their future here in European societies. Education and training! Inclusion and integration! It's a real chance to thrive. These are the main means of combating terrorism. It must be made clear that social inclusion does not mean violent cultural assimilation, but also that there is no alternative to integration. Europe, freedom, an open society will always be protected. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Do you not think that this language: 'populism', 'extremism' is simply a language of exclusion? This is hate speech against millions of Europeans, their democratically expressed views, their democratically elected representatives. Are you really able to build any social dialogue about the biggest crisis europe is experiencing today and the problems that we must solve together?

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Blue card answer. – I think it was very clear in today's debate who here, among Members of Parliament, is talking about terrorism, who is talking about the threat, who is talking about prevention. And who are those who take this opportunity to argue against Islam, immigration, refugees and the Koran. I do not think this type of speech is necessary in this Parliament. We need to talk about the facts, the problems, not the fear and xenophobia.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, can I first of all say that 2015 has brought back to us the serious problems we face with terrorism and especially in Europe. I think we have to face the reality that Europe has a serious problem with its borders, especially the Schengen borders. That has got to be dealt with because nowhere in Europe is completely safe anymore, while we may like to think it is.  Where I come from in Northern Ireland we suffered over four decades of terrorism. I survived an assassination attempt myself and I want to make it very clear in this House that I am not a zombie, and those who talk the way they talked in this debate should, I think, really hang their heads in shame. The victims of terrorism have been forgotten about time and time again. They are not thought about, they are forgotten about, as we go on to the next atrocity, the next crime. That is what cannot be allowed to happen. Can I say above all else we need in Europe good information exchange and cooperation right across borders and between all the police forces in Europe to combat this.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, the terrorist threat is global, global, domestic and external. In the face of this threat, we need unity, will and, above all, action today — not tomorrow, not the day after tomorrow, but today — and to act in four directions. First, we must control, like all the great powers of the world, and effectively monitor our borders. Secondly, we must make the exchange of information compulsory between European countries. Otherwise, stories are told. Thirdly, we must put on track a common European defence policy, because the threat is at Europe's doorstep. Fourth, we need to have a foreign policy strategy to try to find ways out of conflict, particularly in Syria and Libya. In conclusion, I say to you, if we can do all this at 28, let us do it, but if we cannot all act together, then let us decide to act on a few: let a few countries take the initiative to move forward. From this point of view, I hope that France and Germany will regain the inspiration and vision that the European Union is sorely lacking today.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In Pakistan, armed drones are being used in the fight against terrorism, and a large number of civilians have already died. In a village where this has happened, people have spoken to children who have said that we are really happy, if the sun is not shining and everything is covered, then nothing can happen to us. If you think about children being afraid of some anti-terrorism measures, then something is wrong. What I want to say is that our measures and means of combating terrorism are often – not always, but often – not anti-terrorism measures at all, but are deterrents. And that is the problem. They are not so much a deterrent to Da'esh, now the richest murder squad in the world, for example, but to deter ordinary people, children in this case. I say to you: we will not make any progress in the fight against terrorism, we will not do a iota if we fight fire with fire only. What we need to do is finally dry up the sources of terrorism. Not as one of many measures, but as a priority measure. I am not just talking about the financial resources and about the fact that we have been watching for many years, for example, that Saudi Arabia is doing the arms transport for Da'esh, that Turkey would rather bomb the PKK than Da'esh. We need real consequences from such a desolate policy. And we need to do something that people do not support and decide to participate in terrorism, and that the people do not support Da'esh, because no one else supports it. That is where the problems lie. We need conflict resolution strategies and reconciliation strategies. Restricting fundamental rights is more likely to weaken our civil society forces. That is probably not what we can do about it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, let us be blunt about the current situation: the terrorist threat is effectively civil war – incoming individuals joining already internally—based dissidents, targeting key infrastructure to create maximum fear and disruption within our societies. We must, however, recognise that terrorists now control territory from which to export their violent ideology and have access to millions of dollars to fund their activities. Within the EU, as well as the UK, their best resource is Schengen. Borderless travel facilitates weapons, explosives and unfettered terrorist—ideology exportation as well as people. Second only to Schengen is a banking network that facilitates the financing of terrorism. So, Commission, in your deliberations please face the facts. Isolate by ending Schengen, and starve by taking steps to tackle the financing as two key means of combating this terrorist threat.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I think that our response to terrorist attacks must in any case be prudent, but also decisive and consistent. I call on us to make sure that the current ones are no longer sufficient before introducing new standards into our legal system. For example, I asked the Czech Minister of the Interior how information is exchanged between states, and he told me that there are a number of problems. Indeed, frontex's multiple and repeated counting of refugees is evidence of this. I think that, above all, we must not remain idle, because inaction plays into the hands of terrorists who are enemies of democracy, of our societies, of Christian-Jewish roots. However, inaction and inconsistency also play into the hands of the populists and extremists of our societies, who are associated with terrorists with condemnations to liberal democracy, but also to the European Union. I am 100% convinced that today we are obliged to defend our union of values, however difficult it may be, and however politically disadvantageous it may seem in the short term. I have no doubt that, in the longer term, we will defend these values of ours, because intolerance, prejudice, hatred and terrorism will never defeat a free person. They can break us in the knees, but they won't break our values because they're proven and proven in history. As it turns out, populist and extremist political forces in Europe are receiving financial support from Russia. I think we should not overlook this moment. We should also be decisive here on this matter, and I regret a little that we did not take the opportunity to appeal to the Commission to examine this issue. After all, this examination is now being carried out by the Congress of the United States of America, and I think that we, too, should return to this. Unfortunately, the main enemy of russia's current leaders is not IS, Chechen radicals, or Ukrainians. Russia's main enemy is our common unity in Europe.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, in the face of terrorism, Member States can no longer act alone. The Union must ensure the coordination and coherence of national policies, because it is European security that is at stake. In the face of terrorism, the Socialists and Democrats are calling for more Europe. More than Europe, this requires a systematic sharing of information between the police, judicial and intelligence services of the Member States. Europol, with its new counter-terrorism centre, must become a full-fledged European agency. Fighting terrorism also means attacking its funding. Strengthening and harmonising the powers of financial intelligence cells or improving the effectiveness of the European terrorist asset freeze system are all measures on which to move forward as soon as possible. Finally, in the face of the recruitment of young Europeans, ever more numerous, by the Islamic State, we must tackle the roots of terrorism, through a systemic policy to prevent radicalisation. Europe and its Member States need to invest more resources to develop and finance preventive measures, from local to European level, at school, in neighbourhoods, in businesses, but also on the internet. We have an ardent obligation to demonstrate through our public policies that our young people - all our young people - have a place in our society. We must strongly recall our common values of respect and solidarity with all religions, including the Muslim religion, that make up our European community.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to say that I agree with colleagues who have said that terrorism is also an intra-European problem. I would remind you that isis is now supported by one in ten Britons and one in six people in France. Research also shows that there is less support for ISIS in Arab countries than in European countries. Among the countries sending the largest number of ISIS fighters per capita, alongside countries such as Saudi Arabia, Uzbekistan, Albania, Belgium is also at the fore front, which also includes the European Parliament, the European institutions, Sweden, France – and this should be the subject of our reflection. First of all, the fact that the main target of recruitment by terrorists are young people deprived of a sense of identity, social roots and patterns, children of immigrants, often in the second, third generation, people torn between the homeland of ancestors and the country of residence, in none of them feeling at home, as well as children from broken houses, patchwork families looking for a sense of stability, attitudes unencumbered by relativism and therefore succumbing to the charm of radical ideologies or religious fundamentalism. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. – Well, ladies and gentlemen, you are referring to Belgium, to my country, as the foreign fighters would be sent mainly from our country. I do not, of course, dispute that there are indeed foreign fighters who are leaving our country, and we are really committed to that.  But I would very much like to hear from you what about the whole of Europe - because the problem is occurring in all European countries - your action points are to prevent young people who are growing up in Europe from actually going to war there that is not theirs.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I would first get acquainted with the problem and i therefore have a proposal for you and also for our colleagues. We spend many hours in the European Parliament, and just a few kilometres away in a district close to the European Parliament, people gather and then plan attacks. Maybe we would have done an ethnographic tour one day and went there all together and saw the reality of Europe, and then we would go back to reality, because returning to reality is the basis for getting the right diagnosis and finding solutions to the problem that you are talking about.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: I would very much like to invite the colleague to come with me to Mechelen, where we have a liberal mayor. No foreign fighter has left from Mechelen. We're committed to integration to include people in the community so they feel involved here! So, my colleague, I would very much like to invite you to ride with me next week to visit the city of Mechelen, where they have fought the battle. And for the colleagues who want to join us, you are of course also welcome!

name: Ana GOMES
text: – (2) we have not been able to protect citizens, our citizens, from the terrorist threat and related organised crime, which does not surprise us and requires us to work in coordination at European level, because no country alone will be able to overcome it.  We are paying the price for uncoordination in Syria, Iraq, Libya and the Palestinian issue. We need to work for peace and security in the neighbourhood and attack sources of terrorist financing, such as trafficking in human beings, arms, oil and drugs, including by governments that claim to be our allies, such as Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Qatar. We need to coordinate in support of the forces that resist on the ground, such as pesmerga, and provide more effective aid to displaced and refugee populations to reoccupy and rebuild liberated areas, such as Sinjar, because it is not with walls and the end of Schengen, the closure of borders, that we will prevent those fleeing barbarism from coming.  Internally we suffer from disunity and mistrust; we resist sharing information against terrorism and taking action against organised crime; we have failed to create an effective European PNR, to counter recruiter propaganda; and, with neoliberal policies creating more unemployment and ghettos, we even facilitate the radicalising campaign of the young Europeans themselves who join the ranks of the so-called Islamic State, within our borders and even within our prisons. In addition to the disconcert we have exhibited, we have helped terrorists with the wave of xenophobia, which now miserably attacks refugees fleeing terrorism and war and which we have an obligation to welcome. We don't need to invent anything; we need political will and a sense of strategic interest in a world governed by rule of law and human rights. The solutions are in an intelligent and coherent articulation of our internal and external security policies. What we need is for our governments to work together. This is a European problem and the main weapon we need is unity, the European Union. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: question ("blue card"). I should like to hear what Mrs Gomes says about what we also discussed in the speech of the last speaker, in which Mr Krasnodębski mentioned, for example, the fact that the european Union is a member of the European Parliament. Sweden and that we have many young people who have gone to fight together with ISIS. Integration and the better distribution of refugees must surely be the basis for this. If Krasnodębski's homeland received more young men and women fleeing, then perhaps there would be less of this kind of activity. What do you say, Mrs. Gomes?

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card answer. – Well, my country has actually volunteered to accept up to 5 000 refugees in these coming months, but they are not coming because the system is not working. But those who have come are, actually, indeed properly supported to be socially integrated. Having access to work, for instance, is very important apart from other aspects – to actually work according to the rules in our society. Social inclusion is the most important thing, and all the economically liberal policies that have only been fostering social exclusion and discrimination, in particular in communities of migrants, is actually what has been helping the terrorists recruit young people within our borders and to fight both abroad and against us.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In Germany alone, the number of terror cases has tripled in the past year. Among them are more and more cases against IS supporters. People who have often come to us in the flow of refugees. Unfortunately, the networking of the authorities does not work, for which I would like to give you an example: on 7 January 2016, the anniversary of the Charlie Hebdo attack, a man was shot dead in Paris who had attacked two policemen with the butcher's hatchet. The man was later identified as Tarek Belgacem.  The Moroccan Belgacem had been in Germany and assumed at least seven different identities: he was registered as syrian, Georgian and Tunisian. He has committed a number of crimes in Germany and other European countries. Known: drug trafficking, abuse of welfare, insult, threat, theft, violation of the Arms Act, bodily harm, robbery and sexual harassment. The walls of his apartment were decorated with IS symbols.  Despite these offences, Belgacem was obviously able to move freely throughout Europe. My country, Germany, is a factor of uncertainty in the European fight against terrorism.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the These terrorist attacks are becoming more frequent, more threatening, more brazen and effective because they destabilise the foundations of our liberal order and because they also subsequently jeopardise the existence of this Union. The fight against this terrorist threat is necessary and important and deserves all our attention. But this terrorist threat has its name: Da'esh-IS. We should talk about it. We should not abuse this discussion for polemics. Many people also have the impression that there is a lot of talk, but not efficient action.  In this House, we have adopted two measures and discussed them vigorously. One was the report on de-radicalisation, the other the EU PNR. I still have doubts as to whether this really will not lead to a heap of information - but we have adopted these measures. What we need now are short-term action. We should consider whether this data is really well analysed, whether it is well processed. We need more and better trained police personnel. We should also consider why the national intelligence services continue to keep their information with them, why they do not cooperate with each other.  I know that we cannot oblige you, Commissioner, but perhaps you can come up with ways of getting the secret services to share the knowledge they have. I believe that would be the most important thing to achieve in the near future.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, we know that 2015 was the year of greatest terrorist death in Europe's history after the horrific massacre in Madrid in 2004. So the question is not whether they're going to hit us again, but where and when. And they will do so against all of us, the citizenship of a civilization governed by law and freedoms, which is Europe. That she cannot be sacrificed at the altar of uncoordinated national security. Therefore, we must know how to use the cold head sensibly, as has been said, and not to make the mistake of thinking that aliens, immigration or refugees are simply a threat to security, nor, of course, that panic or fear are an answer. They're not. The right way is to complete Schengen, the European Border Guard. The right path is a European intelligence community with shared information. The right way is to complete European criminal law and a European police agency. And the protection of the victims of terrorism. And finally, be very clear that you don't have to give in. The way, moreover, is to know that the jihadisation of social exclusion requires recovering the European fight against marginalisation and inequality and dialogue with the communities that have been particularly affected by this recessive austerity, which has extremed and exasperated inequalities in Europe, and which is behind it, is the background, of this increased marginalization of exclusion that has led to many European Europeans , born in Europe and European residents, to commit terrorist attacks in Europe.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, just several decades ago different parts of Europe were plagued by internal conflicts with various nationalistic groups. Those times are over. The advent of the globalisation age has removed any meaningful boundaries. Terrorism is no longer linked to any borders; it is both global and much more radical than even before. Like in Northern Ireland or Spain, there can be no peaceful resolution. The only reasonable way to combat the current wave of radicalisation in Europe, including active propaganda and ISIS membership, is a complete overhaul of the existing policies on integration, judiciary and prosecution, and security of financial transactions, as well as counter-propaganda in the case of those susceptible to such radicalisation, not to mention a more assertive foreign policy in relation to those who openly or allegedly contribute to these processes. I mean Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Qatar or anywhere else. I am not proposing to forsake and abolish our core values. Our first and foremost objective is to guarantee the safety of our citizens, not endanger them even more.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – First of all, we need to know very clearly and say what are the key reasons for the terrorist attack. Firstly, many young Europeans are disappointed, with no future. Large ghettos are being created in Europe's metropolises, which are the real breeding sites of terrorist cells. From there, young Europeans go to Islamic State as well as carry out terrorist attacks across Europe. The removal of dictatorial regimes in Libya, Iraq, events in Syria and Afghanistan results in the emergence of a terrorist Islamic State, a large flow of migrants and refugees that have destabilised Europe. The Islamic State, as well as some Arab countries, are funding terrorism and have announced the Islamisation of Europe and terrorist attacks on Europe.  Terrorism has no borders, so there must be a full exchange of information and full cooperation from the security services and a common fight against terrorism. The causes of terrorism must be eliminated. In taking action, honourable Commission, however, be proportionate and do not disturb honest Europeans, as you are upsetting them with the current arms directive, where you have tackled, in particular, those who have legal weapons, but forget that illegal trade is the true source of terrorism.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: No, the request for a blue card came at the end of the speech, I don't accept it. I think MEPs can understand what the speaker is saying before it is over. I would ask that the request for a blue card be made in good time or I will not accept it, all the more so because we are in the catch-the-eye process.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, in times of crisis it is best to try whether an organisation, a family, a union lasts or not. More than ever, the European Union needs unity to ensure the safety of our citizens, and this must be on the agenda of the Council and the Commission at all times. The Representative of the Council has told us here that hatred against Muslims must be improved, but at the same time you must also propose, Commissioner, solutions to make Muslims understand the conditions of acceptance in Europe, to understand us and to accept European culture, whether they have chosen to live in Europe or if they have been forced to do so because of conflicts and economic problems. This is where the refugee crisis began.  More coherence is needed in communication at national and European level, especially from the Council. The Commission and the Council must present a clear plan for European citizens to manage the problem of refugees in conflict zones and economic migrants. We cannot leave the refugee issue to chance and interpretation, nor can we move entire states to Europe. That is why the Commission and the Council must work together and present a coherent plan of measures to the European Parliament and the Member States. Poorly managed solidarity can undermine security.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the fight against the terrorist threat will only become effective when its starting point is recognised, namely the accession of large portions of the population, especially young people in the Middle East, to fundamentalism. At the same time, the causes of this political and social phenomenon need to be thoroughly investigated. Moreover, the adventurism with which some European states, and above all France, have been intervening militarily in the Middle East since 2011, must be recognised. Finally, the countries of Europe themselves must recognise the enormous failure of Muslim integration policies, restart the relevant programmes abandoned for ideological reasons after the 1980s and rid the hate speech of political confrontation, through which the theory of cultural and cultural conflict is self-fulfilling. It is time for Europe to follow another model in international and intercultural relations with the countries of the Middle East and North Africa.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – (20) Mr President, the fight against terrorism begins with the fight against racism, xenophobia and fanaticism, and continues with an unceasing struggle for democracy, the rule of law and individual freedoms, especially for the freedom of movement of all European citizens. The Europe in which I believe and for which Mourning is, as George Steiner teaches, a Europe that is the daughter of Athens and the Enlightenment, but also the daughter of Jerusalem and the three revealed religions, that is, a Europe culturally built from the three religions of Jerusalem: Christianity, Judaism and Islam. For centuries, Europe has persecuted and even tried to exterminate many of its citizens, the Jews, and now, under the pretext of combating terrorism, it is preparing to segregate, persecute and expel Muslims. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, the fight against radicalisation must begin with the fight against intolerance which is dangerously developing within Europe.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, because you have been in the debate and because we are now applying a catch-the-eye procedure, I do not think it is right to give you the floor with a 'blue card'. Speakers who were not on the list are currently being given the opportunity to speak as well.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, 2015 was marked by terrorist attacks by the Islamic State and its sympathizers around the world, and according to the latest information from the intelligence community in 2016, it will unfortunately not be any calmer. These announcements should not be reacted to in panic, but also nonchalantly. Europe needs to step up security measures to protect its citizens, and our security forces must have their hands open to treating all those who are dealing with extremists and terrorists on our soil in a timely way. Interstate cooperation has never been more important and we need to pave the way for it to the maximum. This means that the competent services of the Member States should be in coordination with each other without supranational authorities with undefined powers creating noise in their communication channel.  These are the moments when we have to be operational, fast and efficient for the safety of our citizens, and everything remains secondary. I expect future decisions by the Council and the Commission on this topic to be on this track.

name: José Inácio FARIA
