text: – Mr President, the recent terrorist attacks in Turkey and Burkina Faso, after the 2015 attacks, reinforce the evidence not only of the increased terrorist threat, but also of its transnational nature and of its universalist claims, which require a comprehensive and holistic response in order to prevent and combat it.  In the fight against terrorism, the European Union must not only strengthen cooperation in the military and security components, but also in the prevention of radicalisation, in order to end sources of funding, as well as logistical support and medical care—hospital to combatants who on the war fronts defend with their own lives our values and our civilizational model. Ladies and gentlemen, it is therefore a shame to hear from the mouth of a pesmerga soldier that wounded and in need of medical and hospital care in Europe have to pay out of their own pocket for the treatments carried out here in Europe, and that they need, because they do not have enough help from the European Union. Mr President, I once again call for the European Union's fight against terrorism not to mean the sacrifice of human rights and not to allow refugees to become the collateral victims of terrorists who are in fact precisely the ones at the very level of the atrocities committed.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Μέλος της Επιτροπής. – Κύριε Πρόεδρε, έλεγα να επωφεληθώ της ευκαιρίας για να θυμηθώ λίγο τα ελληνικά μου - αφού προεδρεύετε - αλλά προτιμώ να μιλήσω στα αγγλικά. Ευχαριστώ γι' αυτό. Mr President, I am following this debate with great interest, as you will understand, and I want to express from the very beginning my thanks for your full support for our engagement and commitment to fight terrorism. This is a topic that leaves no one indifferent or uninterested and I believe that in this room we really foster a common consciousness beyond the fact that we are committed politically to fight terrorism.  Ms Sargentini, I would like to answer your question which is of great importance, although at the beginning in my introductory remarks I was very clear on that. Terrorist attacks, even the ones that are not organised by a wider network, cost money – money for equipment, for logistics, for falsified documents. I want to assure you that we shall follow that money to help and support the prevention and investigation of terrorist attacks. Soon we shall come back in order to discuss this issue further. I do not think I need to demonstrate or prove once more our commitment, as I said at the beginning, to the fight against terrorism and for the security of our citizens. I think we can all agree that much progress has been made to deliver our European Agenda on Security, but we are of course not there yet as long as the terrorist threat is still out there.  The threat we face is tangible and we need actions that can make a difference at all levels of our societies. We need each other to achieve results – the European Union institutions, Member State governments, national and also local authorities, law enforcement authorities, intelligence services, but also civil society.  I would like to come back to what I said at the beginning. Member States need to trust each other more. They need to share more information between themselves but also with Europol. On a personal basis I can say that I am not happy with their cooperation so far. Unfortunately, most of the Member States, I am sorry to say, keep the best of the information for themselves. Now is the moment to make a step forward.  Our work is not over. The Commission will enhance and redouble its efforts in this area in 2016. Concrete actions are on the horizon, particularly as regards terrorist financing. I count on your support in these efforts. We need to move forward quickly and effectively with European solutions to the common European problem of terrorism. Thank you very much for your attention and once again thanks for your support for our efforts.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr. President, I wanted to thank the Members of the European Parliament for a very interesting debate on terrorism. Let us start by saying that terrorism is a very multifaceted monster that requires a range of answers. There is not one simple answer to the threat of terrorism. I also fully understand the range of emotions that we have in this Parliament on this issue today. Let us remember first of all the victims and their families and their children, and I take that very seriously. In their honour, let me assure you that the Council very active in ensuring that we cooperate better, I will say something about that in a second. I would also caution against using the issue of terrorism for simple political agendas, be they from one side or from the other. We must be united in the fight against terror and understand that it is a very complex phenomenon – like an octopus – where we have to work on prevention and repression, on law enforcement and sharing, on trust between countries and on fighting Islamic State. If we do not work on that together and we just make this an element of political agendas then we are not going to move forward. I heard the words ‘political elite’ from – I think – Mr Buonanno. I am here representing not the Dutch Government but the Council, which is based on governments of different political persuasions and this is very difficult for me to hear. The Members here probably make EUR 100 000 per year, I do not know exactly. With all due respect parliamentarians and ministers make money, but if Mr Buonanno is part of the political elite then I am as well, and neither he nor I has a greater right to talk on behalf of the people than anyone else. Everybody is working, so am I. We are representing our people, we might have different views, but we are not going to have this debate on the basis of simplifications. We cannot accept that, the issue of terror is much too complicated. Let me say as well that if we are cool-headed and dare to analyse what is going on and we cooperate, then together we can move forward. But if we are going to work towards division, that is exactly what the terrorists want from us, namely to see us divide into opposing camps. Terrorism is a strategy that entails inspiring fear in the population and among politicians; if divisions between us appear then we are not going in the right direction. So let us be cool-headed, let us think through what we have to do. Yes that is prevention, yes that is repression, yes that is working together and yes that is fighting Islamic State. The Commissioner was very right to say this, and this is also what the Council is trying to do. We had a conference 10 days ago in the Netherlands which was based on the anti-ISIS coalition and the global coalition against terrorist fighters. What is the issue there? The issue is that we have to combine trust, share and stop.  We have to trust each other in ensuring that an exchange of information is taking place, and ask why it does not always happen and why should it happen more often. Everybody here has said that. The Council is in agreement with the Members on this. But it is very understandable to ask why we have to share information. That means, and that was the lesson from last week, cooperation between law enforcement, between intelligence, between civil society and others. It is a working method and we have to improve and increase and strengthen it. The strongest answer our societies can provide is resilience. Resilience and belief in our values, which are based on democracy and the rule of law. I say that not just to applaud these values; they are the only way to fight terror and come up with very, very concrete answers.  Let me say few things on that, because in the end it boils down to implementation. I agree with this. We can have all these debates. The Council is working in different areas to strengthen our cooperation. It is important that we reached an agreement between Parliament and the Council last December on PNR. Like the majority of MEPs in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Council is confident that an EU PNR will have a major impact on detecting terrorist suspects. The European Union has already adopted a number of measures for the collection and exchange of personal data between law enforcement authorities, and the transfer and processing of PNR data aims to complement the existing tools. Organised crime and terrorist activities involve international travel and finance. This includes the smuggling of persons or drugs, or terrorists having access to training camps outside the European Union. PNR data will allow law enforcement authorities to identify persons who were previously not suspected of being involved in organised crime. It was – I think – Ms Hohlmeier who brought up the issue of a link between the agreement on the PNR directive and on the Data Protection Directive. I am aware of these concerns. I share them, President Schulz has passed them on to us, and we have replied to him. Our two institutions agree on the need to ensure that this vitally important legislation will be adopted and enter into force as soon as possible. You can be sure that the Council has taken and will continue to take all action required to ensure that these files are adopted with all due diligence, while also ensuring that their translation and legal linguistic revision are conducted in such a manner as to render the text as clear, consistent and legally sound as possible. We will ensure that our institutions continue to work as closely as possible – you have my commitment on this – and ensure that no avoidable delay occurs in the conclusion of these crucial dossiers. We have reached agreement on both files: PNR and data protection. Let me assure you we will not backtrack on our commitments. I said already something about the need to cooperate, whether obligatory or not. In my view, that is not the issue. As we know, under Article 42 of the TEU, national security remains the sole responsibility of each Member State. There is, accordingly, no legal basis for an EU intelligence agency. This does not mean that there is not an enormous need for this element of trust, share and stop. We are in the process of working in many different Council formations that sit on this. Let me also assure those who are worried about this that we are constantly talking about balance. I say to anybody who wants to have a simple agenda between privacy and repression, between thinking that it is all about the Qur’an or it has nothing to do with fundamentalist tendencies and that the issue is Islam: ‘Go ahead, it will not solve the issue’. The Council is working on a combined effort on prevention and repression. It is important that we take very seriously the issues of rule of law and of our values because that is exactly what is being attacked. The way we fight this awful scourge has to be within the limits. That is why we constantly continue to work on this issue. Yes, that means also prevention. That is not a soft policy. That is a very hard policy. It is ensuring that people do not get radicalised, and that also has to do with economic opportunity and discrimination. I say, not as a defence, that if we want to be effective we have to look at the whole chain of radicalisation and de-radicalisation. The closing of frontiers is not an answer to that. The same person who said we have to close the frontiers said that we need more international cooperation with the rest of the world right now. Let us do that. Our meeting last week included countries that are aware of this issue. We also have to strengthen our cooperation in the intelligence field, with countries in North Africa and elsewhere. In respect of the timetable for our cooperation it is important we have these debates regularly, and this is the case. It is also necessary that we as an executive be controlled by our national parliaments but also with a debate here.  We are faced with an enemy that has a great capacity to move around, and this has nothing to do with borders as we are talking about moving within our societies and internationally. We therefore have to step up our efforts. We have to share in the trust and to make sure that the divisions we have – which are legitimate – do not simultaneously lead to a lack of effectiveness against the threat of terror.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Several proposals have been announced by the Commission. The establishment of a European border guard corps, a targeted reform of the Schengen code for systematic checks at the EU's external borders, and the extension of ECRIS to the criminal records of non-Europeans. I have been asking for these proposals for a long time now. But why so much time and lives lost before they are done? In my report on the prevention of radicalisation, voted on 25 November, I have taken many other measures. I hope that the Commission and the Member States will commit to the establishment of criminal responsibility for internet giants who do not cooperate in the face of the mass dissemination of terrorist propaganda content. Strong measures to combat the financing of terrorism must also be put in place. The focus must be on the responsibility of some Gulf countries in the financing of terrorism. We also need a European TFTS, a system for detecting terrorist financing circuits, modelled on the agreement we have with the United States. What we have so far lacked is political will! Let us not abandon European citizens to terrorists and act!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda concerns the oral question to the Commission on the opening of negotiations on the Trade Relations Agreement with Australia and New Zealand, tabled by Mr Bernd Lange and Mr Daniel Caspary, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000154/2015 - B8-0101/2016) - (2015/2932(RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have heard and read in the new trade strategy that global value chains also play a central role in Asia and the Pacific region and that these regions come into the focus of many trade contexts. This is particularly clear in view of the conclusion of the US Pacific Agreement with eleven partners, the TPP. In this respect, it is right and logical that we should also set out on our relations with Australia and New Zealand. The European Parliament has also held a workshop on this issue, and we have discussed this issue intensively of a trade agreement with New Zealand and Australia. It is clear, of course, that on the one hand we have a very close community of values with Australia and New Zealand. We are characterised by similar democratic structures and we are characterised by similar economic ideas. In this respect, there is a large basket of similarities. In terms of turnover of trade, Australia ranks 21st in trade relations between the European Union and New Zealand, not quite as at the centre of economic exchanges, but also not insignificant. On the other hand, of course, there are also sensitive sectors. Particularly in the agricultural sector – we have a heated debate on milk and sugar anyway – but also in the meat sector, as regards genetically modified organisms, and also with regard to the issue of sheep and sheepmeat. The question of geographical designations of origin is also handled differently in Europe and Australia. But, of course, we are on the way to establishing global rules, and that is right and necessary in the face of a globalised world. I and the committee firmly believe that these rules are, of course, best set with countries that are like-minded, democratically structured. In this respect, I also firmly believe that when we talk to Australia and New Zealand, we have more ambition to talk to them than we did in the Trans-Pacific Agreement, the TPP, which the United States negotiated. So far we do not have an impact assessment, nor do we yet have a scoping exercise. In this respect, we need a more detailed analysis of the consequences for such a trade agreement. And, especially before the question of the capacity of the European Commission, you should perhaps also mention, Commissioner, that this year was the first time that DG TRADE's staff had been cut. In view of this situation, the major challenges in the trade sector are, of course, difficult to achieve. I firmly believe that trade policy is a central instrument of European policy, and that is why we also need the DG TRADE to be equipped sensibly. We represent the interests of citizens and we represent the interests of the EU. That is why we need transparency and clarity, and that is why we have tabled a question for an oral answer, which will be supplemented by a motion for a resolution at the February II part-session. It is precisely the question of why the negotiations should start now, what risks we have in the face of TTP, what consequences an agreement with Australia and New Zealand will have in the Asia-Pacific region, and, of course, the question of which time component plays a role – we want to know all this from the Commission.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Australia and New Zealand are the European Union’s like-minded partners, partners with whom we share so much in terms of common values and approaches, and strengthening these relationships is a priority. That is why, in 2015, the European Union concluded negotiations for political framework agreements with both Australia and New Zealand, with the aim of further strengthening these partnerships on the basis of joint values and principles such as respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and the joint promotion of international peace and security.  The European Union has healthy and mature trade and investment relations with both Australia and New Zealand. The European Union is the biggest foreign investor, the biggest service trade partner and the third largest merchandise trade partner with Australia. The European Union is New Zealand’s largest source of merchandise imports, its second-largest source of service imports and its second-largest foreign investor. Australia and New Zealand have concluded free trade agreements with China, ASEAN, Japan, Korea, the United States and, most recently, the Trans-Pacific Partnership. This leaves European exporters of goods, services and investors in a comparatively less favourable situation than their competitors in those countries. For example, in practice, cars imported from the European Union will only pay import duties to Australia once.  The European Union is the largest investor in Australia and the second largest in New Zealand, but Chinese investors still have easier access to Australia and New Zealand under their free trade agreements. The European Union also has strong interests in government procurement, where we aim to top up New Zealand’s and Australia’s commitments in the World Trade Organisation’s Agreement on Government Procurement. For the European Union, there are a number of well-known sensitive agricultural products such as dairy, beef, sheepmeat and sugar. It is worth noting that countries with well-known agricultural sensitivities, for example Japan and Korea, have managed to conclude free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand, signalling that such sensitive issues can be managed. It is also worth noting that Australia and New Zealand already benefit from preferential access to the European Union for these sensitive products as a result of various tariff-rate quotas. As regards geographical indications, the European Union’s approach differs from New Zealand and Australia. New Zealand has announced that it will bring into force its Geographical Indications for Wine and Spirits Registration Act. In the case of Australia, we already have a wine agreement covering wine geographical indications. We want to see full protection of geographical indications beyond wines and spirits, including food products as well. The Free Trade Agreement negotiations would provide the opportunity to find solutions.  In recent meetings between the Presidents of the Commission and the Council and the Prime Minister of New Zealand in October last year, and separately with the Prime Minister of Australia in November last year, there was agreement to begin work towards the launch of negotiations on the respective free trade agreements. The Commission will carry out its impact assessment, including a public consultation. In parallel, the bilateral scoping exercise will be carried out. Both elements need to be finalised before the Commission requests authorisation from the Council to start negotiations.  The Commission will keep the European Parliament, notably through the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and INTA’s monitoring group for Australia and New Zealand, closely informed of developments as we take this important process forward.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has I am very grateful that today we have the opportunity to discuss the issue of Australia and New Zealand – the two free trade agreements. We have a situation where there are very, very few WTO Member States with which we are not yet negotiating trade agreements, or with which we have not concluded trade agreements – there are just six in number. If you look at the position of Australia and New Zealand, and bearing in mind that we share many of their values and beliefs, that is an argument why we should urgently start these negotiations.  Secondly, we have a situation where we have concluded or are in progress with many countries in the region. If we look at our trade agreement with South Korea, that is in force. If we look at our free trade agreements with Japan and other countries in the region that we are negotiating. We are negotiating an investment protection agreement with China. I therefore believe that it is urgent that we also ensure that our trade relations with Australia and New Zealand are put on a sound footing, on a new contractual basis. I would be grateful if, in the run-up to the mandate, we could ensure that we could bring in the interests of all those involved. I think we have every reason to get those who have economic interests in Australia and New Zealand on board very early to talk about our offensive interests.  However, I would also be very grateful if you would take the opportunity to speak, above all, with those who are concerned. In recent days and weeks, we have heard a lot of wishes and criticism sand concerns from the agricultural sector. We have some European regions, especially the more distant regions, of concern. I am already calling on you to do so: please take the opportunity on the part of the Commission to listen carefully here, so that you can then respond accordingly to the wishes on the one hand and to the concerns on the other side in the proposal for a mandate. I am already announcing that we in the European Parliament will do our utmost to set out our wishes and positions in more detail in a resolution, even before the Council has given her mandate.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. These agreements with Australia and New Zealand must by no means be an end in themselves, no, they must be means to an end. This means that they must have benefits for citizens.  We expect economic growth and associated job growth. It is particularly important to us that European standards are not lowered, as is the preservation and protection of public services. However, it is also the protection of intellectual property and geographical indications, and above all the agricultural sector, as one of the most sensitive areas.  Compliance with labour and social standards as well as environmental standards is our highest priority. We are not prepared to compromise on this. That is why we are calling for an ambitious sustainability chapter. As with all agreements, we are strongly committed to the transparency of negotiations and the involvement of civil society.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the EU now has the opportunity over the coming years to negotiate a modern, 21st-century trade agreement with like-minded partners: Australia and New Zealand. These are two Commonwealth countries with which we share similar values, levels of development and historical and cultural ties. They are also committed to the multilateral agenda at the WTO. At the same time, Australia and New Zealand hold equal ambitions for opening new trading markets at bilateral level, offering the EU the chance to strengthen Asia—Pacific relations. As we have heard in public meetings, they are approaching these talks with a blank canvas in areas ranging from geographical indications to investment protection. We have a real opportunity, therefore, to negotiate an ambitious new model for a trade deal that is bold enough to tackle modern day issues – issues such as the digital economy, e-commerce and rules of origin, and of course, a dedicated chapter for SMEs, for which trade agreements provide the most benefits. I would therefore be supporting these negotiations through the scoping exercises, and I hope that we can quickly conclude a successful agreement.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I am very pleased that both these oral questions to the Commission and the resolutions of the Committee on International Trade (INTA) on the opening of the free trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand are included together in this debate.  The EU has actually been negotiating free trade agreements with many third countries for many years, creating stable economic relations which make economic growth possible and leave us less vulnerable in cases of instability. But we are still lagging behind in this field. The EU is the only big trading bloc which has not negotiated an FTA with one of the most important global economies, Australia. This is all the more surprising as the EU has long traditions with both Australia and New Zealand, cooperating closely in many fields, and we share the same fundamental values. Moreover, we should not be left behind and out of the circle which is starting to build up around Australia, New Zealand, Asia and North America. By deepening and strengthening cooperation and good relations with these countries, we could set international standards and promote fair and sustainable values for trade. So I have to ask the following question: why has the EU not yet started negotiations with Australia and New Zealand? Both the EU and Australia and New Zealand have clearly stated that we are willing to start this procedure, and I am strongly convinced that all of these countries would benefit from this agreement. As has been the case with all the other FTA negotiations, we would have the power to negotiate the substance of the FTA. I strongly urge the Commission to start preparing the scoping exercise very soon and fully commit to taking the next step towards negotiating a mutually beneficial FTA with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, a dogma is a proposal which is undeniable. Since a dogma is established there is plenty of reasoning, and the more it is repeated the more obvious it seems. Today that dogma is that this crisis-scam is solved by exporting more instead of boosting domestic demand, hence this fever from free trade agreements.  The fact that there is no mutually preferential access agreement comes to light and some are throwing their hands on each other and they are saying as the only argument: "With all of us who have signed, how have Australia and New Zealand been able to escape us?" If an agreement is to be negotiated with these two states, I hope that we will not get carried away by dogmatism and that we will be able to take perspective; think, for example, to what extent the agreement will benefit workers and environmental protection, or whether the agreement will improve health in all three parties. But those aren't the questions most of you are worried about.  You continue to work for the multinationals, who will have us to the end in front of us and standing defending the rights of those below and the earth. Trade does, of course, but not at any price.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Agricultural products are important export products for Australia and especially New Zealand. That is why, with regard to the impact of a potential free trade agreement with New Zealand and Australia, agriculture should really be at the centre of the debate. Unfortunately, however, there is nothing on this issue in the proposed draft resolution.  The production costs for milk are much lower in New Zealand than in ours. In Germany, for example, they are 10 cents higher than in New Zealand. Mr Lange has already said that we will have problems with beef, sheepmeat and sugar. However, the European dairy and meat industry is already under a great deal of pressure. Our farms are already not getting enough money here – not least because of European policy in this area, which always relies on export offensives and does not think that products that we cannot sell are the cheapest if we do not produce them in the first place. If we now put European farmers in direct competition with New Zealand and Australia, we are still pouring oil on the market. That is why, in this resolution, we Greens are also calling for milk to be excluded from the negotiations and for negative effects on agriculture to be prevented. This is also in the interests of European citizens, who are also very fond of eating regionally. Incidentally, it makes no sense to ship products around the world if we can also produce them locally.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, opening negotiations for a modern, balanced and comprehensive agreement with countries such as New Zealand and Australia is undoubtedly one of the steps that the Union will have to take to bring European markets closer to those of the countries that have concluded the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement. These are certainly attractive markets for our investments and exports, but they also conceal possible threats. I am referring to the agricultural sector, like my colleague, which, unfortunately, once again risks being a commodity in our geopolitical choices. We cannot have an agreement without also taking due account of the peculiarities and problems of the dairy sector, which is already heavily affected by the Russian embargo and mistreated in discussions on geographical indications in agreements such as TTIP. We will therefore need clarity in this area, an exclusion of the most sensitive sectors from the agreements and maximum transparency in the negotiations. The lesson of TTIP has taught us that trade policy choices must take account of citizens' demands and we will ensure that the voice of citizens is heard in this process.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for These free trade negotiations are both urgent and urgent. They are concerned that New Zealand and Australia are two out of six countries with which we have no preferential trade agreement or are negotiating preferential trade agreements. The only other four are north Korea, Russia, China and Taiwan. And Australia and New Zealand deserve to be in better company in EU trade policy than that. It is urgent too because the new major free trade agreement with the Pacific Ocean is changing trade patterns, and the patterns of trade are changing so that It is Europe that is the biggest loser. We need our own trade agreements with these countries to give our companies the means to export. Moreover, this is in a position to become one of the best free trade agreements we can have, and I expect the Commission to be very ambitious in terms of both regulatory harmonisation and, not least, data flows. These are probably two of the countries in the world closest to us and if we are to start working on building global standards, Europe will lead that process together with them closest to us. There are some accident ravens, I heard some here today, warning of agricultural products. Australia and New Zealand are major agricultural exporters, but I would remind you that they have a gigantic and growing regional market. And we're on the other side of the world. I don't think we need to think we're going to be the big market for Australia and New Zealand, no matter what the trade agreement delivers. I have two expectations of the Commission. The first is that these agreements are being used to make a new gold standard for European free trade agreements, that this will be the most ambitious that we have. The second expectation I have for the Commission is that it will not get bogged down in endless negotiations. This can be delivered quickly if you lie on it, and I expect the Commission to do so.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, I also warmly welcome the Commission’s intention to open negotiations on these two free trade agreements. The Asia-Pacific region where, bear in mind, 90% of world growth is estimated to happen over the next decade, is vital for us and with their European heritage, their relative proximity to the Asian market and their membership of the TPP, Australia and New Zealand can be very important partners for us.  Given their experience in trade negotiations, these agreements have the potential to be exemplary. They can, for example, be very speedy and efficient, which is not something we can say about other trade negotiations. They have the potential to be of a very high quality with a strong, sustainable development chapter providing a template for the wider Asia-Pacific region and, given Australia’s experience in particular with investment, I think they should prove very sympathetic to tackling the flaws in the existing investor-state dispute system and that gives us an opportunity to have a high-quality investment chapter in this agreement. So for all these reasons, it is good that we are making progress with these two countries.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: blue-card question. – In July 2013, the Australian Government formally responded to the UK Government’s balance of competence review, stating Australia’s wish for the UK to remain inside the EU. As we now debate the prospects of an EU trade deal with Australia and New Zealand, do you think that a UK exit from the EU could harm our vital economic relations with these two old friends and allies?

name: David MARTIN
text: blue-card answer. – Well, absolutely. There are some in this House who have argued that we should create an alternative free trade zone with our former empire and current Commonwealth partners. What this these negotiations prove, and what the agreements with Singapore and Canada and most of our African agreements demonstrate, is that the Commonwealth values our links with the European Union and wants to trade with a wider European Union, benefiting them, benefiting the UK, and benefiting the European Union. So far from deserting the European Union, it helps our Commonwealth cousins that we remain in.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, the European Union is lagging behind in concluding free trade agreements, especially as regards the Asia-Pacific region. The United States is ahead of us, it has a great framework agreement of the TPP with a whole range of countries. We basically have a bilateral agreement with Vietnam today, which is before ratification and will take several years, two or three years; we have an agreement with Singapore that is frozen and awaiting the decision of the European Court of Justice. Otherwise, we don't have anything in our hands.  So it is in our entirely life interest to open up the possibility of entering new markets. Australia and New Zealand have long been interested and have made this clear, and I think it is high time to start such negotiations, that this barrier of silence must be broken. I therefore welcome this activity and hope that it will lead to a swift and mutually acceptable outcome.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I recently had the opportunity to exchange with Commissioner Malmstrom on the protection of sensitive products from the outermost regions in the various trade agreements. I would like to remind the European Parliament of the Commissioner's commitment to MEPs to ensure this protection. At the opening of this negotiation with Australia and New Zealand, we are therefore relatively confident that the Commission will take into account the implementation of the protection of special sugars in the outermost regions, which, as you know, could be weakened. We expect the Commissioner to take personal care of it, in accordance with the assurances that have been given to us.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Australia and New Zealand are only geographically distant from the European Union. A closeness of values, therefore, which over the years has led to close partnership and bilateral agreements. In February, the European Parliament's Australia and New Zealand delegation, in which I am honoured to participate, will travel to Australia. We will meet not only the highest institutional offices, but also representatives of the economic world. It is therefore good to learn that the Commission intends to open free trade agreements, then open negotiations, with these two countries. The launch of modern – quality and at the same time balanced – agreements that take into account the sensitivity of certain sectors, starting with the agricultural sector, including geographical indications, could be an opportunity to resolve unresolved issues, strengthen Europe's geopolitical role in the Asia-Pacific region but, above all, offer important opportunities to European companies, with positive repercussions for the citizens of the Union, including in terms of growth and employment , as has rightly been pointed out.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: – Madam President, as Vice-Chair of the Delegation for relations with Australia and New Zealand, I welcome the opportunity to have this debate and the positive news that talks are now under way with a view to concluding these trade agreements with both Australia and New Zealand. These discussions are long overdue and too often spurious, and protectionist reasons are used by some Member States and parliamentarians in this House to prevent progress, as we have heard today. At one stage these countries were even challenged on their human rights record, which is quite disgraceful. It should be remembered that thousands of members of the armed forces of these countries lost their lives during the 20th century liberating this continent and therefore, Commissioner, I now expect these talks to move forward quickly and these FTAs to be concluded as quickly as possible. This is a win-win situation and there will be benefits on both sides.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, dear Sylvie Guillaume, I hear colleagues tell us that we must not waste time and that we are lagging behind the United States, which has recently strengthened its position in the Pacific. However, I still believe that we should proceed, as we do every time, with a little caution, because, of course, we have common values with Australia and New Zealand, especially on fundamental rights and democracy, but we also have real differences in commercial cultures. Australia and New Zealand completely ignore the concept of "geographic indication". When it comes to services, they are adept at negative lists, even though we are more attached to positive lists. So why should we be careful? My previous colleague says that this is a win-win agreement, but when we look at the agricultural issue in practice, Europe has everything to fear from this openness. We really have to be vigilant, because agriculture in these two countries is intensive and industrial, the standards are less restrictive, and we should not end up with European agriculture at risk, especially in the dairy sector. So, as we say in France, "we must, of course, hasten, but hurry slowly".

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I thank the Commissioner for his opening remarks. Many colleagues in the House have mentioned the agriculture sector as being a particularly sensitive area. I would like more elaboration on how that will be handled in terms of these negotiations. Clearly we want more trade, that is good for everybody, but we do need to take into account these particular sensitivities. But there is a bigger question. Europe is engaged in many different trade negotiations, some have been completed and some are still ongoing. And my question to the Commission is: who is watching the overall impact of these agreements that are being negotiated in parallel, particularly their impact on the agriculture sector? Because – as colleagues have pointed out – we do have a common agriculture policy. We have a very different farm structure; we want to keep farming in the peripheral regions. So could you address that particular issue about the cumulative impact of different sets of trade negotiations on the specific agricultural sector?

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union, Australia and New Zealand share democratic values and interests and have the same point of view on extremely important global issues, such as human rights, security, development and environmental protection. It is therefore incomprehensible why Australia and New Zealand remain two of the few members of the World Trade Organisation with whom the European Union has no agreement on reciprocal preferential access to the market or even negotiations under way. I believe that the conclusion of ambitious agreements with countries such as Australia and New Zealand is essential, as they can allow the European Union and its Member States to further integrate into the value chain of the Asia-Pacific region. I therefore believe that the Commission must commit itself to starting negotiations as soon as possible and to encouraging the conclusion of modern, innovative and transparent free trade and preferential access agreements with neighbouring partners such as Australia and New Zealand, two modern, advanced countries with some of the most advanced democratic systems in the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union's free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand will lead to the elimination of customs duties, resulting in the Union being flooded with imported agricultural livestock and dairy products, at a time when Greek farmers, French and other farmers in the European Union are literally fighting for survival. In addition, the agreement will further strengthen the interests of multinationals at the expense of the Union's small and medium-sized enterprises, at a time when small and medium-sized enterprises are in winter, due to the same economic crisis and the mercelian austerity that has riveted demand and consumption. The agreement also entitles multinationals to seek compensation from the Member States of the Union in which they operate in the event of an alleged violation of their rights. I therefore believe that as long as the European Union has huge armies of unemployed people, opening up markets and deepening globalisation will rather increase poverty and unemployment in the Union than help growth.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the European Union is Australia's second trading partner and New Zealand's third. On the other hand, Australia is the Union's 16th trading partner and New Zealand is only 51. Bilateral trade with Australia is around 40 billion euros and shows a growth trend with a very positive balance. These figures show that there is great potential for further development of trade relations with these two markets. A free trade agreement is a logical step, but also something more than that.  Following the signing of the Trans-Pacific Agreement between the US and Pacific Rim countries and china's growing trade presence in that part of the world, the Union is forced to strengthen its partnership with these countries if it wishes to remain a global player.  If negotiations are opened, I hope they will be much more transparent than those on TTIP so that citizens get a real insight into all the positive but potentially negative effects of the agreement in time.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for opening trade negotiations. I would like to make two points: first, I acknowledge the concerns of some sectors of the agricultural industry and, while it is clear they must be accommodated sensitively, there is a danger that these are being largely overstated. I want to stress that this is a win-win deal, bringing equal benefit to both sides. Secondly, this deal is about much more than trade: it is about shared values, about strong emotional ties, and about strong historic ties – ties which should have been recognised long ago. I urge the Commissioner, therefore, to press ahead as quickly as possible with this FTA.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me reiterate the Commission’s intention to take the next steps towards launching negotiations for the free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. In doing so, the Commission will follow the relevant rules and practices, prepare the appropriate impact assessment and take the other preparatory steps, such as scoping exercises, so as to be in a position to request authorisation from the Council to formally launch these free trade agreement negotiations.  The Commission has set out its new approach to trade policy issues in the Trade for All communication of last October. The communication sets out our commitment to, and the approach we will propose for, key issues such as trade and sustainable development, including labour and environmental issues, for public services and for investment dispute resolution. So the approach we will take to the prospective free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand has been clearly set out and this is what we will seek to put in place through these negotiations. As in other negotiations, the Commission is strongly committed to ensuring the transparency of the negotiations, and in particular information, analysis and dialogue with the European Parliament will underpin and steer our work.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place in February. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – I would like to thank the Commissioner for providing us with some elements concerning the preparation of a free-trade agreement between the EU and Australia and New Zealand. Since the publication of the Commission’s new trade and investment strategy in which the strengthening of these relationships is considered a priority, there has been a positive drive towards the real start of the negotiations.  Having said that, one must wonder why it took us so long to engage in this direction. The EU has negotiated or started to negotiate agreements with all key trade partners but these two and this despite the fact that Australia and New Zealand are, except for geographically, our very close allies not only in bilateral trade, but also in multilateral trade agenda. The EU is Australia’s number one trade partner and key source of foreign investments too. However, the Australian Government managed to forge deals with the US and Canada under the TPP arrangement and with China much earlier than with us. I believe that, reflecting this context, it should be a priority for this year to initiate the scoping exercise with these two countries and show we mean it seriously.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. A pre-opening process with New Zealand and Australia is underway, which could lead to free trade agreements. While it is essential to help strengthen the links between the Union and these two partner countries, the agricultural aspect of such agreements is very sensitive, and the European Union must not sell its agriculture on the altar of diplomacy. At a time when our livestock sectors, which produce meat and dairy products, are going through an unprecedented crisis, opening up the European market to such direct competitors would be dangerous.  Let me give you a few figures: New Zealand is the world's largest exporter of dairy products and the second largest exporter of milk powder. It is the world's fifth largest exporter of beef. Australia is the world's second largest exporter of milk and the third largest exporter of beef. Other sectors are also affected, such as large crops and sugar. I therefore call on the European Commission to focus on the agreements being negotiated and not only to limit agricultural concessions as much as possible but to promote the exclusion of our sensitive products.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. We welcome the opening of negotiations with Australia and New Zealand on the establishment of a trade agreement for the creation of a free trade area. The two countries are, in fact, close allies of the European Union and share with it the same approach to the major global issues. The aim, in line with European trade policy, is to promote economic growth and, at the same time, to help define the rules of the great playing field of globalisation. The proximity of values, for example in the field of data exchange, complementarity, which is particularly strong in the agricultural field due to the different seasons, and the low volume of trade guarantee a low level of risk for the European production sector. In order to ensure the highest level of certainty, it will, in any case, be important for the Commission to draw up an impact study, with particular reference to the dairy and meat markets, and to include safeguard clauses. In addition, the negotiations are consistently part of the strategy of renewed focus on asia-pacific trading partners. The two countries have very close links with the region's emerging economies, such as China and ASEAN, and could therefore represent a potential gateway to these dynamic markets.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. A pre-discussion process is underway, and the launch of negotiations for free trade agreements between the European Union and Australia and New Zealand will provide new opportunities and opportunities for our businesses. In order to prepare for these future negotiations, it is essential that the European Commission carry out comprehensive and precise impact analyses as soon as possible in order to be able to anticipate the effects of such agreements on our market. The aim will be to negotiate ambitious and balanced free trade agreements in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit.  With a view to opening these negotiations, I would like to stress now that agricultural products will be an extremely sensitive point in these future discussions. Exclusion from the negotiations of the most sensitive products will be necessary or at least, if necessary, the establishment of specific quotas or appropriate transitional periods. It will also be essential to obtain the recognition and protection of our protected geographical indications. Finally, I would like to make it clear that Australia and New Zealand each have their own specificities and that, in that sense, separate agreements will have to be negotiated.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report of Lidia Joanna Geringer of Oedenberg, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2014 (2014/2218(INI)) (A8-0361/2015).

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We will vote today on the final shape of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. I have been involved in the work of the Committee on Petitions since 2004, so I have been following its activities for more than a decade and watching how the results of this committee's work directly or indirectly affect EU legislation. At the legal level, citizens' complaints to the Committee on Petitions are a test of the implementation of Community law in the Member States. The number of petitions is still high, indicating that there is still a lack of proper compliance with the law or poor implementation of the law. The number of petitions, on the other hand, also shows the growing awareness of the citizens of the European Union and that they know that they can effectively assert their rights in the European Parliament.  In 2013, after an earlier annual steady increase in the number of petitions, we recorded a peak level of complaints received. In the 2014 report, there was a slight decrease. Statistics show that 2714 petitions were received by the European Parliament during the period in question, 6% less than in 2013. In addition, 1,877 petitions were closed in 2014, a nearly 10% increase over 2013 figures.  However, the duration of the petition is still not satisfactory. We must strive to ensure that each petition is able to be identified as soon as possible and, at the same time, that it is dealt with in an effective and effective manner.  I hope that with the use of advanced information technologies, our contacts with citizens will be more efficient and problems will be solved more quickly. A new web portal launched in November 2014 has already streamlined an earlier website-based system. Citizens submit petitions electronically through the new portal, have all the necessary information on Parliament's powers, can register, submit a petition, download supporting documents, get information on the stage of processing their petitions, and receive notifications in the form of automatically generated emails about changes in the status of petitions. Complainants are increasingly using the internet. 80% of petitions received in 2014 were emailed. In 2013, this percentage was 5% lower.  At the end of my speech, I would like to thank all the Members involved in the work on the report. Thanks to your commitment, we have been able to produce a report that better reflects the specificity of the work of the Committee on Petitions, and now I will be happy to hear your views.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission generally welcomes Ms Geringer de Oedenberg’s report, which recognises the Commission’s role in assisting the Committee on Petitions with cases raised by petitioners. In 2014, of the 790 admissible and followed—up petitions, 688 were forwarded to the Commission.  The Commission shares the report’s opinion that there is a good working relationship between the Committee on Petitions and the Commission. It welcomes the more careful screening that has been put in place by the committee on which institution or body is the best place to respond to a given petition. The Commission does not, however, agree with the report’s observations that the Commission imposed restrictions on procedural grounds to inhibit inquiries into the substance of petitions or suggested closing files without waiting for the outcome of the examination of the issues they raise.  Indeed, the Commission would like to assure the honourable Members that it responds to all the requests of the Committee on Petitions which fall within its competence and endeavours to assist the committee as best it can. No procedural restrictions have ever been imposed concerning the handling of petitions. However, there may well be cases where the Commission cannot provide any detailed response to the committee as it has no competence in the matter. In such cases, the Commission informs the committee of the matter accordingly. Any decision to close a petition rests with the committee itself.  The report calls on the Commission to be represented in committee debates by an official with the highest possible rank. On this point, the Commission would like to reassure the committee that it always sends its most competent officials for the issues concerned to the PETI meetings, and has indeed not received any indications to date from PETI members or from the PETI secretariat that it was represented at an inappropriate level. Regarding the report’s call for the transposition of EU law, the Commission would like to recall that it actively remedies instances of incorrect transposition of EU law through the EU Pilot and infringement procedures. As part of the Better Regulation Agenda, the Commission has reinforced its preventive action to support Member States in the implementation process of Union legislation.  Turning to the issue of making information on the developments in infringement proceedings directly linked to petitions available to the committee, I would like to clarify that such information is already available. The Commission reports on its work in the annual report on monitoring the application of EU law, where it explains how it exercises its powers as guardian of the Treaties, including a follow-up to petitions received from Parliament.  The Commission also shares infringement-related information with Parliament, in line with the current framework agreement, and discloses information on infringement procedures in the form of press releases, in particular at the stages of reasoned opinion and referral to the court. In addition, the decisions on infringement proceedings can be consulted on the Commission’s searchable database available on europarl.eu. Moreover, the Commission is currently examining ways to improve the traceability of files on which petitions from Parliament are sent to the Commission. Turning to the Commission’s interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, it would like to recall that it is in line with the standing jurisprudence of the Court of Justice.  Regarding the report’s remarks on the European Citizens’ Initiative, the Commission remains fully committed to assisting the European Citizens’ Initiative’s work, so that it reaches its full potential. The Commission has already implemented – and will continue to implement – important measures to improve the functioning of the instrument under the current framework, in close cooperation with Parliament, the Member States and other EU bodies and stakeholders. The Commission provided Parliament with more detailed information in relation to these aspects in the plenary debate of 26 October 2015.  The Commission is considering further new actions to be implemented in several of the key areas highlighted in the Parliament Resolution on the European Citizens’ Initiative. However, as only three years have passed since the regulation’s effective entry into application, it is still too early to launch a legislative revision. The Commission will, however, continue to work in 2016 to further assess the possible need for such a revision at a later stage.  Turning to the calls on the Commission to implement the Ombudsman’s recommendations and to take into account the PETI Committee opinion on the TTIP negotiations, the Commission is committed to maximising transparency wherever this can be done without undermining their core elements of confidentiality, considered essential for the negotiations. Many of the Ombudsman’s recommendations have already been implemented or are in the process of being implemented. The Commission examined the citizens’ initiative on TTIP in the context of Article 11 of the Treaty of European Union, but it did not register it because the conditions laid down in Regulation No 211 of 2011 were not met.  The Commission welcomes the report’s observations on the importance of the European Year of Citizens and it will continue to provide information and sustained participation in European democracy in the future, including by means of citizens’ dialogue in the Member States. To this end, the Commission consistently deploys the Europe for Citizens’ programme, in the application of which projects strengthening and facilitating the participation and involvement of European citizens in the European decision-making process are being funded. Finally the Commission thanks the committee for its support for SOLVIT. The Commission agrees that SOLVIT should be further developed, and is currently working together with the Member States to develop SOLVIT to its full potential. In conclusion, I would like to reassure Parliament of the Commission’s continued and strong commitment to cooperating closely with it on petitions, which are a cornerstone of EU citizenship and a fundamental right under the Treaty.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The annual report of the Committee on Petitions is very pleased with the successful work of Members of the committee. I would like to ask a few questions about this report. Should the so-called wave reform for thousands of petitions, in the interests of the citizens, guarantee a rapid response and transparent processing of thousands of petitions associated with the General Secretariat of the European Parliament? Is the function of internal committee rapporteurs intended to ensure the greater efficiency of committee work? Should the importance and essential role of the European Court of Justice be explicitly emphasised? Should the Commission's role as guardian of the Treaties and the correct management of the EU institutions be highlighted? And is it to prevent fact-finding missions for political propaganda from being misused, especially before elections? I think you are more likely to say 'yes' to this spontaneously. It is therefore completely incomprehensible to me that the rapporteur has not shown cooperation, has not even sought to talk to me as the PPE's shadow rapporteur. I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur for not preventing the coordinators of the political groups from making very pleasing progress recently, so that we can have a meaningful vote today. I believe that we must safeguard the interests of the citizens; that is our task. I appeal to everyone in plenary to do justice to this mandate by voting in the house on the amendments that are being voted on today, especially those I said earlier. The rapporteur also approved the report by a majority last year.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the greatest expression of democracy, which gives meaning to politics, is nothing more than the participation of citizens in it. The Committee on Petitions must therefore be a basic tool for ensuring such participation or right. As has been said here, there are numerous requests that have been received throughout 2014 in the committee, either by announcing the violation of fundamental rights, the poor transposition of directives or the important concerns of citizens in the different Member States. It is an obligation, for our part, to give an adequate answer. Of course, also in time and fit. And that is why I appeal today, here, to the involvement of the whole European Parliament, of course the Commission, here, and the Member States in order to give an unequivocal signal that the European institutions are at the service of European citizenship. And that is why I would once again ask the Commission to develop a communication clearly establishing the obligations of each of these parties, in order to give an adequate response to the petitioners.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the Committee on Petitions is the institution to which the citizens of the Union can resort to defending their rights and monitoring the proper application of UNION law. The Committee on Petitions has now developed into a forum for dialogue between the various levels of power of the Union and its Member States and the citizens themselves. One of the most important decisions of the Committee on Petitions is that of October 2015, which accepted my recommendation that the petition of the fighters of the National Resistance of THEAE-DSE on the issue of Germany's debts to Greece should be admissible. Thus, for the first time, Germany is called upon to place itself in public, in a European semi-judicial body such as the Committee on Petitions, on the issues of war reparations, forced occupation, compensation for the relatives of the thousands of Greek citizens executed by German occupying troops and those murdered in Nazi concentration camps.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin my speech by highlighting the special value and significance of the Committee on Petitions for Participatory Democracy and for this Parliament. It's the real window open to citizens. That more than 500 million Europeans, like those who accompany us here today, can directly move their demands to the House and set the political agenda, has a unique value. The figures reveal that the main concerns and complaints concern justice, the environment, the internal market and fundamental rights. As legislators, we have to take good note of that. It is striking and we should be concerned that countries like mine, Spain, are always at the forefront of the number of petitions , especially infringements – sharing a podium with Greece and Italy. I would like to ask your governments to implement these countries. I would like to stress the need for greater coordination and cooperation between the Commission and other institutions and bodies of the European Union, as well as with the national parliaments and with The Committees of this Parliament themselves.  The main challenge is to live up to citizens' expectations and be effective tools for asserting and defending their rights. Paragraph 21 is of particular significance to me, where we regret that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has not yet been adopted by all Member States and that its implementation is confusing.  Finally, I would like to stress that the strict interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter, under which the European Commission repeatedly declares it incapable of acting in the field of fundamental rights, is a challenge and a joint commitment which we must and will address immediately in this committee to adopt a new approach.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, that the European Union was built with its backs on citizens and thinking only of the interests of financial capital is a reality. That this Parliament is a long way from the people and that the European institutions are unre democratic and do not meet the real needs of Europeans and Europeans is evident when we see that the policies that are imposed are clearly in favour of economic elites. In fact, the only real contact of this institution with citizens is the Committee on Petitions and it is through the petitions that are presented that we best observe the distance between the European Parliament and reality. You are light years away from the people you want to represent. Dozens of petitions arrive rejecting TTE and, essentially, ISDS, those arbitration courts that allow multinationals to go over laws, governments and state parliaments. But here in the European Parliament, the majority turn a deaf ear and vote in favour of continuing negotiations on this Treaty, tailored to large corporations. Dozens are also petitions that come in demanding an end to a migration policy that clashes head-on with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. But in this Parliament they continue to be committed to CIDs, repression, border violence and deportations. It is clear that this Parliament has its doors closed to the real needs of Europeans and their allies. The only allies are the lobbies, which represent ... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and my colleagues for the great work done on this report, with shadow meetings where all the Groups had the possibility to have their voices heard.  In times where many are calling the European project into question, the work of the Petitions Committee is more important than ever. The treatment that petitioners receive may shape their attitude towards the European Union for ever. Responsiveness to citizens is important, but not at the expense of the quality of our work. We need to finally address the ever-larger backlog of petitions by increasing the resources available to the committee. We must design the petition process with the petitioner in mind. That means simple, clear and transparent rules on admissibility of petitions. We have made some progress towards usability by introducing the petitions portal, but it still has fundamental flaws that need to be fixed for this portal to really provide an added value to people.  The most important task is to strengthen the quality of our follow-up. We need greater involvement of the other committees in the House in petitions that fall into their area of expertise. We need the Commission to step up its game and to take the inquiries more seriously. As the guardian of the Treaty, it is not the Commission’s role to repeat whatever Member State authorities say. After all, the right to petition is a fundamental right and it must be treated as such.  Unfortunately, the lack of commitment from the Commission is also apparent in its treatment of European Citizens’ Initiatives. The best way to frustrate people and to put them off civic engagement is introducing new participation instruments with huge entry barriers and then ignoring even those initiatives that have passed the hurdles. This treatment of ECIs has been repeatedly criticised by the European Ombudsman, whom I would like to thank on this occasion for her outstanding work in making the European Union more accountable and working with the Petitions Committee. It is this spirit – of service to the citizens – that must guide the Petitions Committee, Parliament and all the EU institutions in their work.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start from another fact, the fact of inadmissible petitions: they represent 39% of the petitions we receive and, of course, this fact underlines how there is a lack of understanding, confusion about the areas of activity of the European Union and therefore a complete and full awareness of the right to petition that all European citizens should be aware of and be able to use. Clearly, the aim is to be able to solve the problems that are highlighted and expressed by the territories, and so we, from the point of view of the Community institutions, should be able to give effective answers. I too would like to point out that the portal unfortunately still does not work and, like the other important instrument that has been introduced, the ECI, the initiative of European citizens, has unfortunately been nothing more than a great deception for European citizens.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the activity of the Committee on Petitions slowed down in 2014, with 2,714 petitions received, a decrease of 6% compared to 2013. Despite this, the Oedenberg report proposes to give additional resources to the Committee on Petitions. More means, but for what?  In 2014, 1,070 petitions received were declared inadmissible, 760 admissible and 817 closed. Many petitions are inadmissible, because the scope of the European Union's competences is not well known to citizens. Similarly, the criteria for processing petitions are not always legal or technical, but are also political; it can also discourage citizens.  But the main substantive issue in the report is participatory democracy, with European citizens' initiatives. It is clear that on this subject it is a failure. On the one hand, because these initiatives do not repeal legislation or stop preparatory work, but, on the other hand, because these initiatives are trampled on by the European Commission when they do not go its way. We saw this with the rejection of the European Citizens' Initiative against the transatlantic treaty: despite more than 3 million signatures collected, the European Commission refused to register it. To justify itself, it claimed that the negotiation of the treaty was not only its responsibility, but also that of the European Council. However, a precedent exists: in 2013, the "Swiss-out" initiative on the free trade agreement between Switzerland and the European Union was registered by the Commission. It is clear that the Commission's technical arguments conceal political biases. Similarly, when the Commission registers initiatives, nothing happens. We have seen this with vivisection and the right to water. So, for lack of results, Europeans are becoming discouraged and increasingly turning away from citizen initiatives, as they are turning away from petitions. The Oedenberg report seems to deplore it, but it does not really address the cause of the problem.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – The report on the work of the Committee on Petitions is not in any way in the same way as my personal experience and I appeal to the Representative of the European Commission here. I ask him or her for an explanation, I don't see him wearing the earphones, but he certainly speaks our language, Hungarian. So you're obviously following what I'm saying, because that's why you're here. I will show you and I will give you half a page of documents after my speech. This is a decision recently taken by the Committee on Petitions, after nearly a year, on the hungarian foreign currency loan victims. Thus, in cases involving nearly 1 million Hungarians and millions of Europeans who, as a result of the conduct of fraudulent banks and bankers, have been ind debt in foreign currency, Swiss francs and other currencies. They filed a 15-page, very detailed petition written by lawyers, to which they received this half-page response. I ask you, Commissioner– in our common language, Hungarian – that point (o) that all petitions must be examined carefully, seriously, effectively, quickly, transparently and individually, how is it compatible that, after a year, the Committee on Petitions has given a semi-page, primitive response to this important issue?

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Overall, the Committee on Petitions has presented a successful balance sheet. But, of course, there are still reserves. I would like to emphasise three, in addition to the things that Mr Becker has already mentioned.  Firstly, it is important that we distinguish more clearly and more quickly between admissible and inadmissible petitions and petitions where we do not have competence. This simply saves time to deal more intensively with the petitions for which we are quite simply responsible. Secondly, we should pay more attention to compliance with the time regime, which means the so-called wave reform or the life circle of petitions. For me, this means that nine months after the petition has been submitted, the petition must be submitted to the committee for an initial consultation or a first decision.  Thirdly, there are petitions in which the members of the committee believe that existing laws need to be amended or improved. We need to improve cooperation with the specialist committees more clearly here. This also applies to cooperation with the petitions committees of the national parliaments, because I think we still have the greatest reserves here. I also want to do not forget to get rid of a thank you to the staff of the Committee on Petitions, who do not always have it easy with us as members of the Committee on Petitions. But we always argue and fight for the cause or in the matter. I think that the Committee on Petitions is, for me, a democracy in the European Union. Citizens can contact the European Union directly, which means that the Committee on Petitions is, for me, the seismographer. We, the members of the Committee on Petitions, feel directly, we know exactly what is going on in Europe. That is why I would like to tip to the Commissioners and to the Members of the European Parliament: if you want to hear people's voices – unvarnished and direct – then you come to the Committee on Petitions more often. If you don't have time to do so, read our logs.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, it is a wonderful thing that our constituents have the right to petition this House for non-judicial support in cases in which they feel that they have been wronged or powerful interests need checking. In my first year as a Member of the Committee on Petitions, the voice of people from across Europe has clearly been heard, raising concrete concerns about the TTIP negotiations, violations of EU workers’ rights and historic miscarriages of justice such as the petition brought by the 1984 Cammell Laird strikers. I have been struck that many of the petitioners who come to our committee are desperate, as all other avenues have been blocked or cut off. In hearing, debating and advocating on behalf of our constituents, the committee has an essential role to play in European democracy. That is why we should promote the role of petitions in the work of the European Parliament. We should demonstrate as MEPs in this House that we are here by the people and for the people.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and all the colleagues for the good work and for the compromise spirit shown this week and in this report.  The Petitions Committee, of which I am chair, is a bridge between the EU’s citizens and its institutions. The committee should be the door for the citizens of Europe to bring their concerns and their ideas to the attention of their elected representatives. It is important today to underline that this report focuses on the work in the committee in 2014 – a special year since it was an election year to the European Parliament, reflected in the work of the committee.
