It is a pleasure to call attention to the fact that we, together with the secretariat and the Head of Unit of the Petitions Committee, have managed to increase the efficiency of the work in the committee since 2014. Our internal modernisation of working methods, which we started late in 2014, bears fruit today. I find it positive that we managed to persuade the Commission to appoint its First Vice-President as our Commissioner and I look forward to working with all of you to ensure even better service for petitioners and all the citizens of the EU.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! Thank you for a good report. I will not repeat all the things that have already been said. I have too little time. I would just like to stress that I think we have had better cooperation, especially with the specialist committees. However, it can still be improved. I would also like to thank you for your cooperation with the Ombudsman. Secondly, I would like to point out two things where there is still room for improvement: firstly, we simply have too few resources to fulfil our task as the citizens' committee. It should be improved. Secondly, we do not have good enough fact-finding missions either. It is one of the best places to meet citizens, and we must strengthen and improve that instrument.  And let me just make a small lament: in the Nordic countries, Denmark, Finland and Sweden, we have no petitions. This is because they have no idea that the committee exists and they do not understand what it is called. I usually say, in my campaigns at home, that the work I do homeadd is "striptease in the dark"! Could we not improve it so that we also got Nordic citizens to participate in this work? We have active Nordic members on the committee.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, it is interesting to see opposition to TTIP, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, in this document and it is also encouraging. Thousands of my constituents wrote to me expressing serious concern that TTIP will open up our NHS to private competition and creeping privatisation, but also concern about the inter-state dispute settlement which will allow private companies to sue national governments for changes in policy that result in loss of profits. This is simply outrageous and I hope that the committee and the Members of this House see sense and that this deal is dropped.  But there is also a fail-safe for my constituents who do not want TTIP. We have our referendum coming up, so anyone watching this will know that if you want to dump TTIP, dump the EU when we have our referendum.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress the significance of the annual report on the activities of our committee. It does not only give the full view of what has been done in 2014, but it also represents a possible change for the future in the way we handle the petitions in our committee. The proper treatment of EU citizens who exercise their right to petition is very important: it influences trust in the Petitions Committee, and it also gives a certain credibility to EU institutions. I support the idea that petitions are the major instrument for our citizens to be more effectively involved in the democratic process of the EU and at EU level.  In this regard, I believe that the EPP plenary amendments are crucial to this report, because they clearly indicate the obligation to comply with the administrative procedure. This is very important, because we tend to fail to realise that the administrative procedure is very important in our work. These rules are guiding principles in the whole lifecycle of the petition, and this makes the whole mechanism more focused on real results. Whatever we do, we have to make sure that we don’t give false hopes to the petitioners. We have to handle the petitions in a more transparent way, we have to make sure that citizens are properly addressed and that their issues are properly addressed in our committee, and we have to reduce the likelihood of politicisation of our agenda.  There is still a lot to be done in in our committee, but I am certain that we can win this battle to find a proper definition of the admissibility of petitions. We have to find a good way to explain to petitioners why their petition is inadmissible, and also why their petition needs to be closed at times.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Petitions plays the fundamental role of bringing citizens closer to the European institutions. It is Parliament's front office, it is the PETI Committee which is helping to make Parliament a truly democratic institution. We are well aware of the fact that the European Union is perceived as cold and distant and that all too often citizens only have the impression that they have a voice during elections, but its activity is not only of use to the citizens, it is also fundamental for us.  It is by looking at the issues often raised by petitions that we understand where and in what the European Union needs to change. Their demands, their petitions, must become our priorities. For the same reason, however, it is unacceptable for them to be examined very late, sometimes even one year after they have been sent. A way can be found to solve a problem which is likely to frustrate their own meaning and which is certainly not dependent on the will of officials and members of the committee, who work tirelessly.

name: Julia PITERA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Committee on Petitions implements the rights of citizens of the European Union guaranteed by the Treaties to address the European Parliament on their difficult, everyday matters, provided that they fall within the scope of the European Union's activities. Thanks to the work of the Committee on Petitions, problems can be removed in the process of implementing EU law. These tasks and objectives make the process of improving the functioning of the Committee on Petitions ongoing. Members of the EPP Group committees are actively involved in this process.  One of the amendments proposed by our group, which the rapporteur does not take into account, is to motivate Member States to regulate by law the obligation to set up a committee on petitions in national parliaments. This issue was discussed in 2015 with members of the Committee on Petitions. Not all parliaments of the Member States have such committees in their structures, and such a solution would significantly affect the effectiveness of the Committee on Petitions' cooperation with national parliaments. This would allow national parliaments to be transferred to matters which are not part of the Union's activities.  Another amendment not included also concerns childcare. After all, children are cared for not only by parents who are formally married, but also by couples living in free relationships. Not taking this into account can have serious consequences in childcare disputes.  An important amendment concerns the length of the work on petitions. As a member of the working group on petitions on children, I am opposed to artificially keeping open petitions on which we lack competence. Such a state only increases the bad hopes for a positive outcome. I therefore call for its adoption. By omitting these important amendments, the 2014 report on the work of the Committee on Petitions is not exhaustive.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: – It is very important to guarantee the right to petition, as we are talking about a means of communication for EU citizens. The petition is a gateway to the European Union in the eyes of citizens, and it is helping us members and the other EU institutions to do our job. However, the report states that the number of petitions received is modest in relation to the total population of the Union. I can confirm that from my own experience. As a Hungarian-spoke citizen and representative in southern Slovakia, I have received numerous requests. I am not saying that every single problem can be the subject of a petition, but I am saying that a lot of it would probably be in line with a petition. In the areas of fundamental rights, discrimination, free movement and environmental protection referred to in the 2014 Activity Report, there are problems and legitimate grievances in the EU civil law that would indeed be investigated by the Committee on Petitions. I would therefore like to continue to draw particular attention to information. The vast majority of citizens either do not know or know little about the right to petition. In the statistics of the previous year, the number of petitions in Hungarian or even Slovak is very high. I therefore see my role as Vice-President of PETI primarily in bringing our work and the right to petition closer to central Europeans. And through petitions, EU citizens can have control over the design and application of EU legislation. However, I am missing from the report the guarantees laid down in the previous report which could bring the work of the Committee on Petitions to the fore. I regret that the parts of the Administrative Reform Commission introduced by the Secretary-General of Parliament in 2014 were not published in the report. This would serve the interests of EU citizens with the right to petition and increase confidence in our institution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, can I just compliment the work of the Petitions Committee, not only as a former member but now as a Member who deals with the issue of international parental child abduction, and I very much welcome the cooperative spirit with which we work in in this area. It is really important that we do that.  A previous speaker mentioned petitions concerning children or difficulties where there are cross-border relationships. I think we’re going to get more and more of these coming to us. We don’t always have a good solution for those who are impacted, but we give – and are charged with giving – some guidance to those who are suffering. They are the most emotional and difficult petitions and queries that we deal with, and I would ask, as we are continuing to operate in this area – so that the work of my office can complement the work that the Petitions Committee is doing – that we work collectively for the review of the Brussels II Regulation. I think that will be crucial for us.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Madam President, according to the Eurobarometer in May 2015, the confidence of citizens in the European Union is only 40% and is due to many reasons: the refugee crisis, the Austerity policies of the Troika, the abandonment of rural areas, the defence of 'fracking' and above all the lack of support in matters as serious as tydomidomid or hepatitis C. Those of us working in the Committee on Petitions know these problems very closely and that is why we are demanding that the European Commission be more involved, give appropriate answers and stop throwing balls out, to be more agile. Remember that our role is to listen and give political solutions to real problems and stop being simple technocrats.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to Ms Geringer de Oedenberg for her very interesting report. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank those Members who have intervened in this morning’s debate for their comments, which I have very carefully noted. The right to petition is a cornerstone of EU citizenship and a fundamental right under the Treaty. Demonstrating to Europe’s citizens that we take their concerns seriously into consideration will serve to strengthen their trust in the European institutions. The Commission repeats its commitment to work in close cooperation with the Parliament and Committee on Petitions to ensure the effective and efficient handling of petitions.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As the main rapporteur, I am delighted to have had the opportunity to report to a group of highly engaged and creative people. This was a fruitful work that not only shows the current state of the committee's work, but above all gives guidance on how to guide its activities in the future. The report aims to further improve the work on petitions. If some of us are critical of some of the proposals identified in the report, this is only good news. This is a signal of what areas we still need to work on. There is undoubtedly still a long way to go, but every step brings us closer to better results and thus more efficient action for our citizens.  Thank you very much to Commissioner Avramopoulos for his detailed explanations of my report. The work on the report required the combined efforts of many people. I would like to sincerely thank all the shadow rapporteurs whose proposals, comments and suggestions have been very valuable to me, including Members: Marina Albiol, Heinz Becker, Beatriz Becerra, Eleonora Evi, Professor Notis Marias, Julia Reda. I would also like to thank all the coordinators and advisers, the committee secretariat staff involved in the work on the report, including Soledad Cabezón, Vivienne Byrne, Nicolaid Khier-Koskin, Karolina Lecocq Perez and my personal assistant Karolina Kocberska. I think that, despite many initial differences, we have managed to produce a fair report together, together with guidance on the future work of the Committee on Petitions.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. (The meeting is suspended for a few moments while waiting for the time of the votes) Written statements (Article 162)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon on 1 December 2009, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union has been a legally binding instrument. It allows citizens to present their concerns to the European Parliament about the impact of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives. The main policies addressed by petitioners are justice and fundamental rights, the environment and the internal market. The Commission's initiative to group the formal and informal mechanisms of the complaint into a 'Your Rights' page represents an important step forward. However, the distinction between formal mechanisms (complaints to the Commission, requests to the European Parliament and complaints to the European Ombudsman) and informal mechanisms (Solvit, CEC Network, FIN-Net) should be better clarified to citizens. On the other hand, an analysis of the statistics shows that the main reasons why petitions are declared inadmissible are that petitioners continue to confuse the European Union's competences with national competences, and that they confuse the institutions of the European Union with those of the Council of Europe, in particular the European Court of Human Rights.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: –  Herr Präsident! Nachdem endlich eine neue Regierung in Moldawien ins Amt gekommen ist, mussten wir den Text aktualisieren. Das habe ich in Abstimmung mit dem Kollegen Fleckenstein in der sozialistischen Fraktion getan. Wenn Sie auf Ihre Abstimmliste schauen, sehen Sie den Text. Er beginnt mit:  ‘Welcomes the creation of a new government after a long period of stalemate and unsuccessful attempts to form a government’ und endet:  ‘reminds the Moldovan parties of the need to enhance political stability in order to guarantee a sustainable success of the reforms and hopes that the new government will be able to deliver substantial results’.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: –  Herr Präsident! Wir schlagen vor, folgende Änderung vorzunehmen: „takes note of the upcoming Dutch ...“ und nicht „... expresses deep concern about the context surrounding ...“. Also: „Takes note of ...“. ‘ Takes note of the upcoming Dutch consultative referendum on the EU-Ukraine AA/DCFTA’ [und nicht]‘Expresses deep concern about the context surrounding the upcoming Dutch consultative referendum on the EU-Ukraine AA/DCFTA’. [Also:] ‘Takes note of’.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: –  Absolutely Mr President, there were 40 – more than 40 – people standing up and you did not count correctly. So we want it to be checked.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: It was so clear. The vote is closed.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the explanations of vote.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I voted in favour of the Kosovo Association Agreement for the following reasons. The fact that the international community has achieved full autonomy for Serbs in Kosovo would have been in favour of a 'yes' vote. And I have logically concluded that if this is the case, hungarians will be able to achieve full autonomy and national self-determination in the territory of the present Serbia, in the Southland. The reason I could not vote yes, however, is that I witnessed the flow of Kosovan refugees to southern Hungary, complaining of poverty, complaining of corruption, of total chaos in their country. Now, it would be miraculous if, six months ago or a short time ago, this were the case, and now there would be paradise conditions that this report described and on the basis of which an association agreement would take place.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: – Mr President, this issue of stabilisation of Kosovo is a very important element in the progress of the European Union’s arrangements for peace and stability in the Mediterranean region. Kosovo has gone through an extraordinary amount of turmoil and there have been instances where we have looked at Kosovo as an example of a country that can go from a position of conflict to a position of peace. Given that we have ignored and forgotten some of the issues that have been relating to Kosovo for some time because we have been preoccupied with other matters in other directions, it is salutary for us to remember that today we have brought back to the forefront of our minds a country which has suffered an incredible amount and that we have to extend the hand of friendship wherever possible in that regard.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted in favour of the report. Of course, not everything is good in Kosovo, there is a great deal to criticise. This applies to political matters, including cases of corruption and an incomplete constitutional legal system. On the other hand, we must cooperate with Kosovo. There has to be something between full membership and non-membership. We need to be more concerned with our neighbours. Because we see that if the people who live there have no hope of economic stabilisation, have no hope of political stabilisation, then they set out and try to be established in the European Union. We know the conflicts that arise as a result. That is why cooperation, stabilisation in the sense of economic and political improvement, is extremely important. The attempt alone is worth it. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The conclusion of a Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is an important step in stabilising the regional situation of the Western Balkans and is a fundamental contribution to Kosovo's further integration with our Union. I would very much like to hope that this will contribute to the improvement of the internal situation, democracy, the promotion of human rights values, positive economic and social development, and change. But, in addition to what has been said above, I would like to state that it was important to further develop today's vote, because in no way should the rather weak social, economic, political situation of the Serb minority be disregarded in the north of Kosovo, and although this agreement is not directly covered by this agreement, the agreement must be a signal that Kosovars and Serbs, as well as Kosovo and Serbia, must strive to live in mutual peace and to cultily cooperate effectively. I'm in for this. Thank you!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the High Representative Federica Mogherini has said, the signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is beginning a new phase in relations between the 28 Member States and kosovo. The agreement is an important contribution to stability and prosperity in the region and will help to undertake the necessary reforms that allow the conditions to grow in a stable and sustainable way, to implement the necessary reforms and to create trade and investment opportunities. The Kosovo Government is now continuing to work in the process of reforms that will enable the country to modernise, to grow economically and competitively and, consequently, to give its citizens a better future. Kosovo still faces many challenges, so I hope that the government will commit itself to making the necessary and courageous choices in order to successfully continue negotiations with the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I also voted in favour of the draft agreement. Although the five countries of the European Union still do not recognise Kosovo as an independent state, I believe that it is in our interest what my colleagues have already said. It is in our interest to stabilise the situation in the Balkans and to offer countries in our immediate neighbourhood relations that will help them in their economic development and give them a chance to join the European Union in the long term. The fact that Kosovo's path to the European Union is probably not entirely clear is not short, it will take a longer time for the necessary and necessary reforms of the state and society as a whole to take place in Kosovo, that is obvious. But today we are giving Kosovo a clear chance, a clear opportunity to cooperate more with us, with the European Union, and thus start to strive for membership of the European Union in the long term. And I think that is extremely important for the Balkans and therefore for the whole of Europe. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – I am pleased that today's vote is expected to bring into force the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between Kosovo and the European Union and I join those who encourage the recognition of Kosovo by the five Member States, including my own country, Romania, which have not done so so far. At the same time, I would like to underline that the successful European integration of the countries of the Western Balkans is inconceivable without settling the coexistence of indigenous ethnic groups without setting clear and accountable rules. Although the agreement does not waste much time in this area, it only speaks in general terms about the protection of persons belonging to minorities, unfortunately experience shows that this is not enough: in the countries that have already joined, there is a step backwards in the application of minority rights, general commitments are not respected by the Member States, and the EU is not paying enough attention to this area, even though it affects 40 million EU citizens. I think the Albanians in Kosovo know exactly what it means to be a minority, now it is their turn to make a fair offer of coexistence to the Serbian minority in Kosovo.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, the right to self-determination of nations is one of the fundamental rights embodied in the UN Charter and other UN General Assembly resolutions. By the way, at the instigation of the Soviet Union at that time, that is, the state that now denies the right to self-determination and the freedom of new nations. I supported this association agreement because I think Kosovo is a state, it fulfills all the characteristics of the state, although, of course, the exercise of that state power raises some doubts on some issues, I will not deny that. However, I do not want to argue with my colleague from Hungary, Mrs Morvai, but I think that Hungary and the other states should be interested in stabilising and associating Kosovo with Europe, in finding its stable future. That's what I think is security for us and our entire continent. In this sense, I fully support the position expressed by the previous speaker, Mr Sogor.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Since 2000, Kosovo has benefited from preferential trade arrangements with the EU, providing for duty-free and quota-free access to the European market, except for certain agricultural and fisheries products. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo establishes new contractual relations capable of strengthening political dialogue between the institutions and improving integration and trade cooperation.  The agreement represents a first step towards the formal and progressive accession process of the Republic of Kosovo, ensuring, among other things, new opportunities for investment, growth and business development. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The EU-Self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement establishes contractual relations between the parties on political dialogue and trade relations. Although five EU Member States have not recognised Kosovo, kosovo is officially regarded as a potential candidate to join the European Union since the European Council attributed a 'European perspective' to it in 2003. This EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which would enter into force at the conclusion of the ratification procedure, is seen as a significant formal step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, I voted against the proposal for the adoption of this Agreement, since with this agreement the EU implicitly recognises Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1244/1999. It is intolerable that the European Parliament intends to put pressure on the Member States, including Spain, which do not recognise Kosovo, which constitutes political interference in the competences of the States. Moreover, this Agreement entails the creation of a free trade area which I also reject.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. This report aims to bring into force the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and Kosovo.  It proposes, among other things, to strengthen political dialogue and promote trade integration. It also provides for the establishment of new forms of cooperation. This agreement is therefore fully within the framework of European integration and the process of Kosovo's accession into the European Union.   Opposed to the policy of enlargement of the European Union, I voted against this report. Moreover, this report undermines the sovereignty of States that have not yet recognised the Republic of Kosovo, since the EU encourages them to do so. Finally, it must be remembered that the ruling parties in Pristina are responsible for the eradication of all non-Albanians.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – On the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) we supported an abstention. We obviously support enhanced political dialogue and cooperation, especially strengthening of democratic principles and human rights.  The SAA also includes provisions aiming to promote European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, but it is vague as to what it means and to what extent when it states that it aims to establish a free trade area, or closer trade integration. However while the report was ratified in the Kosovo Parliament, it was boycotted and not supported by all the opposition parties, and the main opposition leader and MP, Albin Kurti, was arrested illegally for his parliamentary stances.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I chose to abstain in the vote on the resolution ratifying the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo because, although we support the European perspective of this region (which explains why I did not vote against), we do not recognise its status as a country.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. By associating Kosovo with the EU, a decisive step towards the Balkan country's accession to the European Union has been taken. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we are strongly opposed to any enlargement of this European Union. Moreover, this would be tantamount to endorsing the very dubious government practices of this country unfortunately nucleated by the Albanian mafia. That is why I have chosen to vote against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should be a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted against.  This legislative resolution obliges the Republic of Kosovo and its people to meet EU—imposed obstacles before being allowed to trade with the EU. I believe that the deepening of economic and trade relations between Kosovo and the United Kingdom is a matter for Her Majesty’s Government.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 On the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAS) on 27 October Commission Vice-President Federica Mogherini and Prime Minister Isa Mustafa signed in Strasbourg. The National Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo has immediately ratified the Agreement on 2 November 2015. It covers a wide range of sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, and establishing a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. In addition, the SAS includes provisions to promote the application of European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property, consumer protection and aims to create a free trade area.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Stabilization and Association Agreement provides for enhanced political dialogue and closer economic integration. It involves strengthening democratic principles and human rights and creates a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice or home affairs. The agreement, which I have approved, is an important step towards bringing the European Union and Kosovo closer together.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Balkan region is a key part of European history, culture and civilisation. After the terrible season of war and violence, many countries in this part of Europe have been welcomed into the great political and economic project represented by the European Union. Kosovo, which declared itself independent in 2008, has embarked on a path of openness, consolidation of democratic institutions and civil rights claims that has yet to be fully fulfilled.  I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo because I believe that this is an important step towards strengthening political dialogue and establishing closer trade relations. The economic and social development of the country can only be achieved through a complete stabilisation of the entire region, which can also be achieved through forms of cooperation with the Union in the field of justice and home affairs. Europe has already shown great attention to the countries on its borders, and with this text it is committed to continuing important work in this direction. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the agreement.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244/1999 and that the Kosovo state-of-stateization process is irreversible, the opinion also does not imply that the former province has a good right to be recognized by third parties. The situation in Kosovo has a complex political substrate and therefore has to be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms, poses a permanent internal threat to peace, safeguards the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and ensures in the medium term the departure of foreign military powers from the area. Therefore, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement proposed by the Council, which focuses mainly on the 'deepening of economic and trade relations' is premature and weeds in prioritizing actions leading to a real and lasting stabilisation of the area.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I very much welcome the outcome of the vote on the EU Association Agreement with Kosovo. It is an important step for the recognition of the country. I hope that today's vote will help the six EU Member States that have not yet recognised Kosovo to do so.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I formally objected to Mrs Lunacek's report on the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. This type of agreement, as we know, is the unavoidable step before a country is integrated into the European Union. In the midst of a crisis of legitimacy, and even as EU-pillar states such as the UNITED Kingdom are increasingly considering leaving the EU, Brussels is stubborn and prefers to head first into the precipice rather than consider taking a step back and making a point of observing its past mistakes. On the other hand, to consider the integration of an entity that is still not recognised as a state by all countries on the international stage or by some EU Member States is a cover-up reserved for the principle of state sovereignty, especially since the EU dares to make a big eye for those sovereign nations that do not want to recognise this narco-territory as a state. It should be remembered that Kosovo, in addition to being a revolving platform for trafficking of all kinds, including drug trafficking, was born in the blood of the massacre of the Serb minority. In these circumstances, I think it is irresponsible to consider its accession to the EU.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Lunacek report is unbalanced and I cannot support it, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo is the last Stabilisation and Association Agreement concluded with western Balkan countries. The Association Agreement includes various policies which could have major consequences for the economy, the environment and social conditions in Kosovo.  I believe that the people of Kosovo should have the decisive decision on this important issue. The best form of a populardecision on crucial issues is a referendum. A wide-ranging democratic debate on the advantages and disadvantages of the Association Agreement should be conducted in Kosovo before decisions are taken in the best democratic way. That's why I'm abstaining.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (AEA) was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and was signed in July 2014. In October 2015 the Council agreed to sign it by 27 October 2015. The Kosovar Assembly ratified it on 2 November 2015. Since Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence in 2008, Spain has maintained the same position, defending the principles of territorial integrity of States and respect for the rule of law, principles on which the European Union is also based. Exercising the discretion allowed by international law, the Government of Spain did not recognise the unilateral declaration of independence, deeming it contrary to international law, by infringing the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity recognized to Serbia and guaranteed by the Helsinki Final Act. In line with the position of the Spanish State and for the sake of a constructive attitude not to block an agreement which will introduce measures that will benefit the Kosovar population, I have decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation because the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAS) is a very important first formal step towards the integration of the Republic of Kosovo in Europe. The European Parliament hopes that relations between the Republic of Kosovo and the EU will continue to be strengthened, including through the swift introduction of visa-free travel for Kosovo citizens. Parliament also calls on the Council to adopt a decision to sign and conclude a framework agreement on Kosovo's participation in EU programmes, which will strengthen cooperation between Kosovo and the EU in various sectors. These programmes should focus on specific areas consistent with the commitments made by Kosovo on the European road and should be implemented in a transparent and immediate manner. This Agreement is an essential instrument in the stabilisation and association process. It establishes rights and obligations and provides a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. This agreement will pave the way for investment, growth, business development, strengthening, and at the same time good governance, through European standards and alignment with EU legislation, including through the creation of a free trade area. It also enables people-to-people contacts in sectors such as education, the environment, the fight against crime and trafficking, culture and provides for further strengthening of relations and cooperation with neighbouring countries, thereby contributing to stability in the region.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement (STM) with Kosovo would be the last of the stabilisation and association agreements with the western Balkan countries. Since 2000, kosovo has been subject to a preferential trading system under which it has free access to the Union market free of customs and quotas, with the exception of certain agricultural and fishery products. The proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement sets out essentially the same set of rules: it provides unrestricted access to most industrial products and agricultural products (excluding live cattle and their meat, sugar products, certain wine products). With regard to EU exports, I believe that, in the case of Kosovo, transitional periods for the gradual reduction of customs duties on industrial, agricultural, processed agricultural and fishery products, as well as for wine and spirits, will be essential for the smooth establishment of the FTA for 10 years as planned, given that the EU's external trade surplus with Kosovo is significant and has increased slightly over the last few years.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ u2012 I am pleased to have cast my vote in support of the decision to conclude the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. The agreement thus establishes better political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers several sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, and establishes a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, environment, justice and home affairs. The adoption of European standards in the areas of competition, public procurement, intellectual property, etc. is also encouraged. It is now in Kosovo to begin radical reforms. The kosovo region is in an extremely difficult situation. Unemployment is high, the population is moving away en masse, and the level of corruption is also among the highest in Europe.  I hope that the agreement adopted will really create opportunities for investment and growth, business development, which is crucial for the future of Kosovo. I also welcome the enhanced cooperation between Belgrade and Prishina, which paves the way for a conflict-free future that has been going on for decades between them. I am sure that the opening of pre-accession negotiations between the EU and Serbia will also help. The city of the Balkan countries is in the EU!

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Stabilisation and Association Agreement Report between the EU and Kosovo.  I believe that this Agreement is a very important first formal step in the EU accession process, and will create opportunities for investment, growth, business development, good governance through the application of European standards and a rapprochement with EU laws.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement represents an important step towards Kosovo's entry into the European Union and an important instrument of economic growth and stability for a young nation such as Kosovo.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Strengthening relations with Kosovo and the privileged trade relationship aimed at the inclusion of the region in the European free trade area is functional to the inclusion of the region in the European system. Only a fully European Kosovo can develop economically and strengthen itself culturally, strengthening its democratic institutions and civil rights practices. The European Union must take responsibility for protecting and directing its neighbourhood towards the road to development and democracy, particularly in those territories that have lived through a troubled, painful and complex history such as Kosovo over the last thirty years. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) is a key point in the process of normalising relations in the area and overcoming the regional isolation of the territories of the former Yugoslavia to which we must all contribute, both in European for a and in those of the states of origin.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Mrs Lunacek's report proposes to adopt an EU-Kosovo stabilisation and association agreement. This type of agreement is a prerequisite for the integration of this province, which is still not recognized as a state under international law.  At a time when the European Union is facing many U-turns from its Member States, notably Hungary, Poland and now Denmark and Italy, the European Parliament and the European Commission are insisting on pursuing their policy of enlargement. In addition to its economic consequences, it should be stressed that in a regional context undermined by inter-religious and inter-ethnic tensions, the adoption of such an agreement will aggravate the destabilization of the Balkans. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo (SAA) aims to establish contractual relations and strengthen a political dialogue so as to create new forms of cooperation and trade integration. Furthermore, a number of democratic principles are promoted through this agreement, transposed into cooperation policies in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. There are also provisions for the promotion of European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, with the agreement also aimed at establishing a free trade area. Through this act, the premises for economic growth and the development of investment opportunities will be created, while also providing a remarkable incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. I was in favour of this report because I believe it is essential for the Process of European integration of the Republic of Kosovo and for strengthening good governance by promoting democratic principles and European standards.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. The Asa (Stabilisation and Association Agreement) is a first step towards the formal process of EU membership and kosovo's path to European integration. The European Parliament looks forward to further strengthening relations between the Republic of Kosovo and the European Union, including through the rapid introduction of the visa waiver regime for the citizens of Kosovo. Parliament also called on the Council to take the decision to sign and conclude the framework agreement on Kosovo's participation in EU programmes, which will strengthen cooperation between Kosovo and the EU in a number of areas. These programmes should focus on specific areas corresponding to kosovo's commitments on its European path and should be implemented transparently and without delay.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as I support the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between EU and the European Atomic Energy Community and Kosovo, which seeks to establish an even firmer relationship between the parties. The provisions outlined in the agreement provide good groundwork for the establishment of a free trade area between the EU and Kosovo. This further cooperation aims to encourage good practices and promotion of European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement and human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a single vote to approve the STABILISATION and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo.  The agreement, which helps improve political dialogue and open trade between the EU and Kosovo, was signed in October 2015 by the Head of European Foreign Policy, Federica Mogherini, and ratified by kosovo's national parliament last November. All the issues addressed in this agreement fall within the competence of the EU. This makes it an 'EU-only' agreement: it does not need to be ratified by individual Member States. The European Parliament cannot intervene in the text of the agreement but can only give a positive or negative opinion. I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We vote against the report and recall that the Republic of Cyprus does not recognise Kosovo's unilaterally declared independence and remains fully committed to respecting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all states, including Serbia.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The issue of Kosovo recognition remains a point of friction for a long time. The procedures for upgrading and improving conditions in the region are in the interests of the citizens of these regions. Although there are positive elements in the recommendation on the draft Council decision, the conclusion of agreements with Kosovo provokes discussions at both legal and political level, given the known problems that existed and probably continue to exist in the region. Therefore, we should be particularly careful when our decisions and resolutions can influence and, above all, shape a given situation. That being said, I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and Kosovo, of the other part. This agreement establishes contractual relations involving enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation in the areas of human rights, education, the environment, energy, justice and home affairs, and aims to create a free trade area. The ASA is a very important first step towards the formal process of EU membership and the European integration path of the Republic of Kosovo, which is therefore expected to be strengthened through the introduction of the visa waiver regime for Kosovar citizens.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft decision because I believe that a good neighbourhood policy is essential to prevent many major problems. It is no coincidence that the migratory flows we are witnessing now are the result of a neighbourhood policy, and a broader foreign policy, which have made water on all sides.  This agreement with Kosovo is a major push towards modernisation and greater interoperability of infrastructure, particularly legal infrastructure, which can enable our businesses to do business there. Furthermore, the ultimate aim of these steps is to reduce poverty in Kosovo, with the result that we import less crime from there and create an additional outlet market for our products. It is a convenient situation for everyone.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is only through close cooperation with the EU that we will ensure that Kosovo finds its role as a partner of the EU. In order to participate in our internal market, European standards such as competition rules or the protection of intellectual property must be guaranteed. I hope that, with this agreement, we will achieve greater stability in the Balkans and strengthen the political dialogue that must be conducted across borders, particularly on energy supply and environmental issues.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a free trade area between the EU and Kosovo is important because since 2014 trade relations with kosovo, thanks to the concessions encouraged by the reduction of duties, have generated a considerable surplus in favour of the Union.  I am therefore in favour of concluding the stabilisation agreement with Kosovo, as this would only further improve relations between the two trading partners. There will be positive effects on cooperation, and a solid basis for the definition of reforms in that country with a view to bringing legislation closer together, not only for economic trade but also for social and human rights.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative resolution represents an association agreement strengthening EU relations with Kosovo on sectors that are of fundamental importance to the rule of law, commercial as well as social development. It provides a framework of assistance and cooperation which can lead to sustained and stable reforms. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The EU-Self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement establishes contractual relations between the parties on political dialogue and trade relations. Although five EU Member States have not recognised Kosovo, kosovo is officially regarded as a potential candidate to join the European Union since the European Council attributed a 'European perspective' to it in 2003. This EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which would enter into force at the conclusion of the ratification procedure, is seen as a significant formal step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, I voted against the proposal for the adoption of this Agreement, since with this agreement the EU implicitly recognises Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1244/1999. It is intolerable that the European Parliament intends to put pressure on the Member States, including Spain, which do not recognise Kosovo, which constitutes political interference in the competences of the States. Moreover, this Agreement entails the creation of a free trade area, which I also reject.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014. The agreement was signed in July 2014. It was ratified by the Parliament of the Republic of Kosovo on 2 November 2015. At the conclusion of the current Memorandum of Understanding before the European Parliament, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement may enter into force. Under the agreement, a contractual relationship will be established, ensuring enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It will cover a number of areas, including respect for democratic principles and human rights, and the establishment of various sectoral cooperation frameworks, such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement also contains provisions aimed at promoting European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. It will create opportunities for investment, growth and business development, while at the same time strengthening good governance by proximity to European standards and EU legislation. In today's vote, Parliament agreed that the Council would adopt the decision to sign and conclude the Framework Agreement on Kosovo's participation in EU programmes.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Stabilisation and Association Agreements are part of the stabilisation and association process with the EU, which is centred on the Western Balkan countries. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement was signed on 27 October. This is one of the key documents in the stabilisation and association process. It sets out rights and obligations and provides a strong incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement will create opportunities for investment, growth and business development, while strengthening good governance through the application of European standards and harmonisation with EU law, including in the framework of the creation of a free trade area.  I welcomed the recent signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo. The agreement is the country's first step towards European integration. I hope that this agreement with the EU will stabilise the situation in Kosovo and help bring peace between different ethnic groups and ensure prosperity in the country.  With this in mind, I voted in favour of the document.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will allow the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo (SAA). This is the first formal step towards the EU accession process and European integration path of Kosovo. The SAA establishes contractual relations which provides for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It will create opportunities for investment, growth, business development and good governance through the application of European standards and approximation to EU laws.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement as an important step, helping to stabilise the Western Balkans and enhance economic development, the rule of law and democracy in Kosovo. It is vital that we continue to work on reducing the potential for further conflict in this part of Europe, and improving the long-term prosperity and stability of Kosovo is central to that aim.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) between the European Union and Kosovo is part of the wider framework of the close relations between the European Union and the Western Balkans. It is the last to be concluded with the countries of the Western Balkans and the first between the European Union and Kosovo, and it will certainly have the merit of opening a new phase in relations between the two parties. I think it is very positive that the agreement contains, among others, provisions on the promotion of European standards in the fields of competition, procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, which are essential elements of the model of our internal market, with a view to a broader path of European integration. Above all, I hope that the cooperation policies included in the agreement, relating to various policy areas, and within the framework of the progressive establishment of a free trade area, will be able to stimulate and facilitate the socio-economic development of the region, promoting its stability. The aim is to strengthen and further extend relations between the European Union and Kosovo, while not prejudicing, and indeed respecting, the position of the Member States on the status of kosovo. That is why I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report presents Parliament's decision, which is necessary in the context of the approval (ratification) procedure for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) between the European Union and Kosovo. The agreement aims to promote diplomatic relations and trade in a wide range of sectors between the countries of the European Union and Kosovo. The agreement will also contribute to the implementation of many reforms in education, employment, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: in writing. In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary-General, we would like to state, in relation to Parliament's approval of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, that we abstained in the final vote, since the Agreement concerns only the exclusive competences of the EU and not those of the Member States , and does not affect in any way the position of the Member States which, like Spain, have not recognised Kosovo's unilateral declaration as an independent State. We also note that we do not share the content of the 'short justification' with which the rapporteur accompanies the Resolution. This text has not been submitted at any time to amendments and subsequent votes, eer in the Committee on Foreign Affairs or in the plenary. Finally, we regret that, in the Resolution, the mention of Kosovo is not accompanied by its corresponding asterisk and footnote.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo will intensify our ties with the neighbouring country in many areas such as governance, judicial cooperation, consumer protection, intellectual property, energy cooperation and environmental protection.  The agreement will also provide support to the Balkan country in its process of political and economic reforms. Seven years after declaring independence, Kosovo remains marked by severe economic difficulties, widespread corruption and a significant movement of its population to neighbouring countries.  It should be noted, however, that this tool for cooperation between the European Union and Kosovo is not linked to the prospect of Kosovo joining the European Union. In fact, in 2014, the European Commission wisely committed itself to taking a break from enlargement to consolidate what was achieved between the 28.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report aims to normalise relations between the European Union and a "state" that is not recognized by the United Nations or two permanent members of its Security Council, namely China and Russia, or by four Member States of the European Union or by India. Moreover, to recognize this entity would be to divert attention from one of the real issues that is the considerable influence of the Albanian mafia on the ground.  Finally, after the corruption scandal denounced within the Eulex mission, the European Union would benefit from limiting its interference in the subjects concerning the Balkans, especially since it has been shown by its inability to act against the ethnic cleansing of non-Albanians. Opposed to the Union's interference in the internal affairs of States, I naturally voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the Kosovo reports, I welcome and support the conclusion of a Stabilisation and Association Agreement between Kosovo and the European Union. This agreement is a first step towards the country's European integration and sets out the conditions for participation in European policies and financial instruments. But the right to use European funds is granted provided that the country implements key reforms in the areas of statehood, justice, the fight against corruption and organised crime. The country is in a difficult institutional situation and that is why it needs guidance and assistance in building its statehood, and kosoors need jobs and rising living standards to stop them leaving their country. In addition to access to European funds, the agreement also provides for further visa liberalisation, which will happen when Kosovo has fulfilled all the conditions set by the European Commission.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Kosovo in the spiritual and moral sense is the heart of Serbia and the soul of the Serbian people. Kosovo's accession will be an acceptance of the change of borders of a state by force, just as was the case with the Turkish invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus and the unilateral secession of Serbian territory stemming from ethnic albanian motives. Kosovo is not a state, nor is there a Kosovar nation. We must not forget the illegalities of Tito's Yugoslav communists, who transformed states and literally raped the historical truth, creating Macedonian dreams and Kosovar abortions.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo (EEA) was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and was initialled in July 2014. The EEA establishes contractual relations that provide for enhanced political dialogue, greater trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers a number of sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, the definition of a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. It also includes provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, and aims at creating a free trade area. I agree that the SAA is a formal first step of great importance for the EU membership process, and the Council should adopt the decision to sign and conclude the framework agreement on Kosovo's participation in EU programmes, which will strengthen cooperation between Kosovo and the EU in different sectors.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I do not recognize kosovo's legality or legitimacy in terms of international law.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation contains, in itself, two aspects that portray well the imperialist posture of this process of European capitalist integration. On the one hand, the consecration of a so-called Stabilisation and Association Agreement which, without being ratified by means of free popular expression, confirms a process of membership which imposes on a people the loss of sovereignty and subjugation to the neoliberal macroeconomic policies of the European Union, the creation of a free trade area, which culminates in the process of balkan integration and the fragmentation of yugoslavia's territory. On the other hand, and worse than the first, the continuation of the formalisation of the establishment of relations with a territory, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that has opened up in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo, and which the EU has sought to legitimise. An illegal decision, which we do not recognize, which created a protectorate through aggression and military occupation by the US, NATO and the EU. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is a key document of Kosovo's stabilisation and association process with the European Union. In addition to clearly demarcating rights and obligations, we are also providing Kosovo with a significant incentive to implement and institutionalise the necessary reforms. With this agreement, we are creating opportunities to intensify contacts not only between professionals in the fields of education, the fight against crime and smuggling or culture, but also between people. We also provide for further strengthening relations and cooperation with neighbouring countries, which can contribute to stability in the region. Last but not least, I would like to point out that Kosovo has not yet been recognised by some Member States of the European Union.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Kosovo in the spiritual and moral sense is the heart of Serbia and the soul of the Serbian people. Kosovo's accession will be an acceptance of the change of borders of a state by force, just as was the case with the Turkish invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus and the unilateral secession of Serbian territory stemming from ethnic albanian motives. Kosovo is not a state, nor is there a Kosovar nation. We must not forget the illegalities of Tito's Yugoslav communists, who transformed states and literally raped the historical truth, creating Macedonian dreams and Kosovar abortions. For all the above reasons I am voting against the conclusion of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement (STM) with Kosovo would be the last of the stabilisation and association agreements with the western Balkan countries. Since 2000, kosovo has been subject to a preferential trading system under which it has free of duty and quota access to the Union market, with the exception of certain agricultural and fishery products. The proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement sets out essentially the same set of rules: unrestricted access to most industrial products and agricultural products (excluding live cattle and their meat, sugar products, certain wine products, baby-beef products and certain fishery products). With regard to EU exports, I believe, in agreement with the rapporteur, that transitional periods for the gradual reduction of customs duties on industrial, agricultural, processed agricultural and fishery products and wine and spirits for Kosovo will be essential for the smooth establishment of the FTA for the planned 10 years, given that the EU's external trade surplus with Kosovo is significant and has increased slightly over the last few years.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (AEA) so that, once the european Parliament has been approved, it will allow the entry into force of the AEA, which establishes contractual relations that allow for strengthened political dialogue, greater trade integration and new forms of cooperation and includes multiple issues, such as respect and consolidation of democratic principles and human rights.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Stabilisation Agreement (ASA) between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and Kosovo, of the other part. I believe, in fact, that this agreement represents a key step in the stabilisation process of the country, which is fundamental for the full recognition of the sovereignty of the young Republic and for its full integration into the European system and lays an important foundation for formal accession to the European Union. I also believe that the ASA places important preconditions for closer cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Kosovo on education, the environment, culture and the fight against organised crime, and I hope, finally, that this cooperation will develop, mature over time and embrace more and more different areas of action.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, as I consider it geopolitically important to support the balkan countries in their democratic and economic development in such a way that they have a real prospect of EU membership in the medium term. In this respect, however, I would also like to see rapid progress in the development of a genuine blue card initiative for these countries.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Both sides will benefit from the development of economic and trade relations. In doing so, we are creating incentives for companies to make further investments while enabling closer political dialogue.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, an important first formal step in Kosovo’s integration into Europe – a key contribution to the development of a safe and prosperous neighbourhood for the EU. The agreement will form the backbone of strengthened political association and economic integration between the EU and Kosovo. The agreement enhances EU-Kosovo political dialogue and trade relations, and fosters closer cooperation in many sectors, including energy, the environment, and justice and home affairs.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This is about ratifying an agreement that everyone knows is a first step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. It organises cooperation with the country, and liberalizes trade as well as the granting of visas to Kosovar citizens. As usual, the European Union is doing things backwards. It is supposedly doing this to improve a situation it cannot ignore: a disastrous economic situation, corruption, the role of the mafias, the involvement of the ruling parties in the ethnic cleansing of non-Albanians. However, it offers Kosovo what should only be the reward for an internal process of reforms, particularly in the areas of democracy and the rule of law, which are theoretically sacrosanct for the European Union... This is not the only nonsense. The Commission, by negotiating and signing alone, and Parliament, have their share of responsibility. But the Council has also given the go-ahead. Unanimously, if I believe the legal basis, therefore without opposition, the five Member States of the European Union which persist in not recognising Kosovo's independence. It's already a scandal. Another is that it was an Agriculture and Fisheries Council that did it! We're really walking on our heads!

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244/1999 and that the Kosovo state-of-stateization process is irreversible, the opinion also does not imply that the former province has a good right to be recognized by third parties. The situation in Kosovo has a complex political substrate and therefore has to be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms, poses a permanent internal threat to peace, safeguards the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and ensures in the medium term the departure of foreign military powers from the area. Therefore, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement proposed by the Council, which focuses mainly on the 'deepening of economic and trade relations' is premature and weeds in prioritizing actions leading to a real and lasting stabilisation of the area.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, I voted in favour of this report. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo is a very important first formal step towards the EU accession process and the European integration path of Kosovo. The SAA provides a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. The SAA will create opportunities for investment, growth, business development, good governance through the application of European standards and approximation to EU laws.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We cannot consent to the adoption of this agreement for two main reasons. The first and most important reason is because the signing of this agreement presupposes the recognition of Kosovo as a state, a position with which the Republic of Cyprus disagrees, as do other States of the European Union. Secondly, the agreement not only has a political dimension but is a free trade agreement and we have often expressed our opposition to such policies promoted by the EU. For these reasons, we consider voting against as an appropriate attitude

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report due to the fact that the SAA establishes contractual relations which provide for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers numerous sectors, including the respect for and strengthening of democratic principles and human rights, establishing a framework for cooperation on sectors such as education, energy, environment, justice and home affairs. The SAA also includes provisions aiming to promote European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, and it aims to establish a free trade area. The SAA is a very important first formal step towards the EU accession process and the European integration path on the Republic of Kosovo. The European Parliament looks forward to a further strengthening of relations between the Republic of Kosovo and the EU.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The Association Agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We therefore welcome the EU-Kosovo Association Agreement, but we reject Full Kosovo's membership within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and Kosovo, on the other, giving consent for the conclusion of the Agreement.  I support the integration of all southeast European countries into the European Union and the SAA is an important first formal step in the process of eu accession and European integration of the Republic of Kosovo. The agreement is a key document in the Stabilisation and Association Process, sets rights and obligations, and provides incentives for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. The SSP establishes a contractual relationship that ensures political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation in a number of sectors, including respecting and strengthening democratic principles and human rights.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The combination of Kosovo with the EU is a decisive step towards the Balkan country's accession to the European Union. However, together with my colleagues on the National Front, we are opposed to any further enlargement of this already sprawling Europe. Moreover, to associate with Kosovo would be to endorse the murky governance of that country, which is the core of the Albanian mafia. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I do not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo. Parliament's approval is necessary to ratify this stabilization and association agreement, which insists on respect for democratic principles. After it enters into force, the agreement should promote the implementation of reforms in Kosovo and strengthen cooperation with Kosovo. This will lead to the establishment of a free trade area and the application of European standards in areas such as competition, state aid and intellectual property.   That recommendation has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to sign a stabilisation and association agreement with Kosovo. This agreement will enable a number of objectives to be put in place, including trade cooperation, the engagement of a regional political dialogue and the harmonisation of many rules on the internal market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
