text: Writing. We Liberals have always spoken out against Kosovo's independence, as it is not possible to gain far-reaching autonomy under the dominant Serbian minority in the north of the country. An unstable foreign body has arisen in a tense region. I am therefore equally opposed to the further integration of Kosovo.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the agreement, as it will bring new possibilities for Kosovo to strengthen relations with the EU and thus contribute to the stabilisation of the whole region. The agreement enhances EU-Kosovo political dialogue and trade relations, and fosters closer cooperation in many sectors, including energy, the environment, and justice and home affairs. It also has provisions aiming to promote EU standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property, consumer protection and good governance.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Association Agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We therefore welcome the EU-Kosovo Association Agreement, but we reject Full Kosovo's membership within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) with Kosovo is the last SAA to be concluded with Western Balkan countries. Therefore, it could be scrutinised as an important step towards the Europeanisation of the whole Western Balkans. In Kosovo’s case, the SAA with the EU will facilitate economic growth and investment promotion. This economic development will be more than welcomed since the country of 1.8 million suffers from an unemployment rate of 40 % and Kosovo’s youth flee in search of jobs and opportunities (just bear in mind that Kosovo is the fourth biggest source of asylum seekers in the world). Last but not least, the SAA with the EU will promote political stability which is very much needed in terms of finding a solution to Kosovo’s status. A solution that will guarantee peace and long-term stability in Europe.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. This agreement is a very important first step on the road to the European integration of Kosovo and that of its accession process to the European Union. One element is the rapid release of the visa regime in favour of Kosovar citizens. Parliament also encourages the five Member States that have not yet recognised the Republic of Kosovo to do so. The policy of enlargement of the European Union is catastrophic. Its Balkan policy has resulted in crimes against the Serbian people. Facilitating Kosovo's accession would be politically tantamount to giving a premium to the Albanian mafia, which is the most stable institution in the "country". Moreover, interfering in the internal affairs of sovereign states that do not intend to recognize the creation of Kosovo is an attack on the sovereignty of states by this Parliament. It should be grounds for refusal on its own.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because by associating Kosovo with the EU, it is a decisive step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, as a principle, I am opposed to any new membership. Moreover, facilitating Kosovo's accession is tantamount to bowing to the Albanian mafia that has taken over this fragile little country.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This report aims to bring into force the stabilisation and association agreement between the EU, the European Atomic Energy Community and Kosovo. Advocating for closer political dialogue, closer trade relations and increased cooperation, it further endorses kosovo's path to European integration and even its EU accession process. For example, it advocates the liberalisation of the visa regime in favour of Kosovar citizens. Moreover, such a text seriously undermines the sovereignty of the Member States of the Union, which for some have not yet recognised the Republic of Kosovo, a state creation much discussed from an international law point of view. Finally, this accession process would implicitly give a white-seing to the many segregationist abuses committed by the ruling parties in Pristina against non-Albanians. In view of these important elements and my overall opposition to the policy of enlargement of the European Union, I voted against this text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The EU-Self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement establishes contractual relations between the parties on political dialogue and trade relations. Although five EU Member States have not recognised Kosovo, kosovo is officially regarded as a potential candidate to join the European Union since the European Council attributed a 'European perspective' to it in 2003. This EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which would enter into force at the conclusion of the ratification procedure, is seen as a significant formal step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, I voted against the proposal for the adoption of this Agreement, since with this agreement the EU implicitly recognises Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1244/1999. It is intolerable that the European Parliament intends to put pressure on the Member States, including Spain, which do not recognise Kosovo, which constitutes political interference in the competences of the States. Moreover, this Agreement entails the creation of a free trade area, which I also reject.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Association Agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We therefore welcome the EU-Kosovo Association Agreement, but we reject Full Kosovo's membership within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. There is already virtually tariff-free trade with Kosovo. However, an association agreement should not be concluded when not all EU countries recognise Kosovo as a state.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo forms a framework for a free market and deals with issues related to common policy, economic objectives and regional cooperation. Furthermore, the Agreement provides Kosovo with one of the vital steps forward towards joining the European Union.  The agreement covers a wide range from democratic principles and human rights to cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment and legal issues. The SAA also promotes the legal state and democratic values of the European Union. Furthermore, the SAA is an essential step towards a formal accession process as well as a key document in Kosovo's stabilisation and association process. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is the basis of rights and obligations to implement and institutionalise the necessary reforms.  I supported the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo, as the Agreement provides room for the development of democratic principles and key elements of the European Single Market. The agreement is an opportunity to further foster the necessary reforms in Kosovo to ensure democratic institutions and values, and to become a competitive market both in the region and in the EU. In conclusion, the Agreement is an essential step by Kosovo towards EU accession and better regional cooperation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I strongly disagree with Kosovo's independence because it will lead to the destabilisation of the Balkans. I therefore choose to vote against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and Kosovo, on the other, because it promotes the recognition of Kosovo as an independent state.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. This agreement establishes contractual relations for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation with Kosovo. It is important to mention that this agreement includes the rapid release of the visa regime in favour of Kosovar citizens and the obligation for Member States that have not yet done so to recognise the Republic of Kosovo as an independent state. This is in fact an official first step towards Kosovo's integration into the EU. We strongly oppose this opening of the EU to the East, especially to a country that some Member States do not even recognise!

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement: it is a key document in the stabilisation and association process. It sets out rights and obligations and provides a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. The SAA will create opportunities for investment, growth and business development while strengthening, at the same time, good governance through the application of European standards and approximation to EU laws, including in the framework of the establishment of the free trade area. Furthermore, it creates opportunities for enhancing contacts between people and experts in sectors such as education, environment, culture and the combatting of crime and trafficking, and it foresees a further strengthening of relations and cooperation with neighbouring countries, thus contributing to stability in the region.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and Kosovo, of the other part. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) is a key document in the stabilisation and association process. This is an important first step towards the formal process of EU membership and the European integration path of the Republic of Kosovo. It establishes closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo is an important step towards bringing Kosovo closer to the EU. I hope that this agreement will not only bring greater stability to our Balkan neighbour, but also closer trade relations.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is a backlash to Kosovo's integration process in Europe, as it will be the axis on which the political partnership and economic integration between the EU and Kosovo will be strengthened. My support, therefore, for the proposal, which will help institutionalise the reform process and also offers new possibilities for Kosovo to strengthen relations with the EU, contributing to the stabilisation of the whole region.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Kosovo became Albanian through an artificial settlement. As long as the Serbian minority in the north of the country is not granted broad autonomy, Kosovo's integration cannot be supported. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report endorses the conclusion of the "stabilization and association" agreement with Kosovo, the final step in creating a free trade area across all the Western Balkans. These agreements are economic annexations that put all the neighboury countries under the shock of structural adjustments and at the same time amplify the social and fiscal dumping movement in the Union. For these reasons, I am opposed to any further enlargement of the EU, the final objective, displayed or dreamed of, of these agreements. And finally, this is an agreement with a territory that is not internationally recognised as a state, including by five Member States of the Union. For all these reasons, I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The combination of Kosovo with the EU is a decisive step towards the Balkan country's accession to the European Union. However, together with my colleagues on the National Front, we are opposed to any further enlargement of this already sprawling Europe. Moreover, to join Kosovo would be to endorse the murky governance of that country, which is the core of the Albanian community. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Atomic Energy Union, on the one hand, and Kosovo on the other. Kosovo has benefited from a system of trade preferences with the EU since 2000. Eu-Kosovo cooperation policies, especially economic and trade policies, must continue so that kosovo can continue its reforms.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which promotes more political dialogue, as well as a deeper trade relationship, and more generally, closer cooperation between Kosovo and the European Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. We welcome the Approval of the European Parliament at the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilization and Association Agreement, marking the strengthening of relations between the EU and Kosovo. With the establishment of the space for enhanced political dialogue and closer trade integration, the agreement is a cornerstone of Kosovo's reconstruction. This agreement not only aims to encourage the implementation of the reforms necessary for stability in the country but is also a crucial step towards effective cooperation between Brussels and Pristina.  The key function of the agreement with regard to the strengthening of EU-Kosovo relations is to be underlined. Indeed, the cooperation framework provides for a range of measures leading to the legislative rapprochement between the EU and Kosovo by putting in place provisions to promote the application of European standards in certain areas, and with a view to the establishment of a free trade area. Finally, we support this agreement which encourages the country's growth prospects but also economic exchanges between MS and Kosovo, thus sending a positive signal to the Kosovar citizens.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – One of the fundamental principles of Roman law, which we still consider to be almost perfect today, is the principle: 'pacta sunt servanda' - 'agreements must be respected'. This principle applies without exception in both private and international law and, if it is not respected, stable relations cannot be achieved. In 1975, a declaration was adopted in Helsinki at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which includes the principle of border invincibility. The invincibility of borders means that borders cannot be changed even as a result of the emergence of a new state. Kosovo declared independence in 2008 by unilateral act, thereby violating international law and serbia's territorial integrity. For these legal reasons, Slovakia and four other Member States of the European Union have not recognised Kosovo's independence, and I wholeheartedly support this position. For this reason, I also do not agree with the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision to ratify the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo signed on 27 October 2015. The adoption of this decision requires parliament's consent. The Agreement sets out rights and obligations and provides strong incentives for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. It ensures enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights and the establishment of different sectoral cooperation frameworks. It also contains provisions aimed at promoting European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, as well as the creation of a free trade area. It will create opportunities for investment, growth and business development, while at the same time strengthening good governance by proximity to European standards and EU legislation. In its report, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to ratify the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Lunacek report on the EU-Kosovo Association Stabilization Agreement was negotiated from October 2013 to May 2014, and was signed on 27 October 2015. This agreement establishes contractual relations that provide for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. The agreement is a very important first official step on Kosovo's EU accession process. One of the key points of this agreement is the rapid release of the visa regime for Kosovar citizens and the recognition of Kosovo by all Member States. With the EU's Balkan policy resulting in crimes against the Serb people, allowing Kosovo to join would give even more power to the Albanian mafia, which is the only organised structure in the territory. Moreover, forcing Member States to recognize Kosovo as a sovereign state is an infringement of sovereign rights. We therefore strongly oppose this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo provides for a strengthening of political dialogue, greater trade integration and new methods of cooperation in various sectors, including respect for democratic principles and human rights, education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. Provisions for the promotion of European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection are also covered, and aim at creating a free trade area. I believe that deepening relations between the Republic of Kosovo and the European Union and concluding the Stabilisation and Association Agreement are the first formal step of great importance for the process of EU membership and the european integration path of the Republic of Kosovo. As i am in favour of the celebration of the EEA, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The eu's enlargement policy has already been a serious political mistake. Its Balkan policy has resulted in crimes against the Serbian people. Facilitating Kosovo's accession would be politically tantamount to giving a premium to the Albanian mafia, which is the most reliable institution in the "country". Moreover, interfering in the internal affairs of sovereign states that do not intend to acknowledge the affront that the creation of Kosovo was in the eyes of international law or which do not intend to see this dangerous precedent backfire (as in Spain in particular) is an attack on the sovereignty of states by the European Parliament. It should be grounds for refusal on its own.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on EU-Kosovo relations. The aim was to approve the Council's proposal on the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community on the one hand and Kosovo on the other.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. The recommendation contains the decision of the European Parliament, necessary as part of the approval (ratification) procedure of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) between the European Union and Kosovo. After receiving approval from the European Parliament, the ASA is expected to enter into force in the first half of next year. Once in force, the ASA will establish a contractual relationship that involves mutual rights and obligations and covers a wide range of sectors.  The ASA emphasizes respect for the essential democratic principles and fundamental elements that are at the heart of the EU's single market. It will establish a space for free trade and the application of European standards in other areas, such as competition, state aid and intellectual property. It will also contribute to the implementation of reforms through which Kosovo can adopt European standards. Other provisions cover political dialogue, cooperation in a wide range of sectors, from education and employment to energy and the environment, justice and home affairs.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Unable to attend the votes on Thursday 21 January, I would like to express my support for the report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community on the one hand, and Kosovo, on the other, which will enable better cooperation in the areas of justice, home affairs and environment, jobs and energy.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 To have good relations with the countries around us, which in some cases may mean new allies, the agreements with them are an excellent opportunity. I believe that such deals will benefit the European Union and create the right foundations for cooperation in different areas. For this reason, I also support the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Republic of Kosovo. This Treaty will help to promote enhanced political dialogue, trade integration and democratic principles and provide opportunities for cooperation in areas such as education, energy and the environment.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement was instated in July 2014. I voted for this report that will provide enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this recommendation of the European Parliament because I believe that it does not express the reality within the EU, as some Member States are still waiting for a solution and an official and definitive position from Serbia. In this context, I cannot consider the position expressed in this recommendation to be unanimous and expresses the position of the whole European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report. As long as the Serbian minority in the north of the country is not granted broad autonomy, I do not believe that Kosovo's integration can be supported.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement aims to deepen economic and trade relations between the EU and Kosovo.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement can, in my view, generate a wide range of trade and investment opportunities. In addition, it will be able to create cooperation in a wide range of areas, ranging from education to employment and energy, from the environment to justice and home affairs. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I believe that co-operation between the European Union and Kosovo is of utmost importance, not only for the countries mentioned, but also for those surrounding countries that have not yet joined the negotiations for entry into the European Union. I support this proposal because it encourages the creation of new markets, and thus provides numerous opportunities in creating much needed jobs, and contributes to the realization or improvement of already existing good-budgetary relations. Likewise, this agreement can help stabilise relations between Kosovo and Serbia, which could be an important step in further development. I believe that the aim of this proposal is to have a positive impact, i.e. to make a positive impact. positive change in the daily lives of Kosovo citizens, thereby opening them up to opportunities to use the European Union programme. Also one of the important changes that will make it easier for Kosovo citizens to move through the European Union is the abolition of visas. Accepting this proposal would take a very important step in achieving the integration of the Republic of Kosovo into the European Union, which would open co-operation in many areas and integrate the Republic of Kosovo into various European Union programmes, in order to help it economically.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I am extremely pleased that Kosovo signed a Stabilisation and Association Agreement last November after less than a year of negotiations. I hope that the European Parliament will give its consent to the conclusion of this agreement by tomorrow's vote, allowing its implementation to begin formally. It is a kind of reward for Kosovo's commitment to full membership and a European future. At the same time, this completes the process of establishing contractual relations with the Western Balkan countries. This agreement is an important step for the EU accession process and Kosovo's European integration path. It can create opportunities for investment, growth and financial development through the application of European standards and a rapprochement with EU laws. But further progress will depend on the commitment and constructive cooperation of all political stakeholders, which is not the case now. Once again, unfortunately, the "regional" problem of opposition participation in Parliament is being realised. Measures to combat terrorism and radicalise the reduction of illegal migrants and asylum seekers in the EU are needed, as well as work to reduce the high unemployment rate as a key precondition for the success of these measures. I hope that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, as the first treaty between Kosovo and the EU, will serve as a boost to the many institutional and legislative reforms that Kosovo must adopt and implement and that on this path the youngest European state will receive unified European support.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The bond between the European Union and Kosovo is strong and the two sides share equal values and are equally eager to strengthen their relationship even more by establishing a close and lasting relationship based on common interests and reciprocity. Such co-operation further enables Kosovo to strengthen and expand its relations with the European Union. The STABILISATION and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo establishes a relationship that ensures increased political dialogue, stronger trade integration and new forms of co-operation. It is important to point out that the Agreement also creates a large number of opportunities for investment, growth and business development, while establishing good rule by applying European standards and moving closer to European laws, including the framework for establishing a free trade zone. Furthermore, it is important to highlight the fact that the Agreement creates opportunities to increase contacts between people and experts in sectors such as education, culture, the environment and combating crime and smuggling. For all these reasons, I support REPRESENTATIVE Ulrike Lunacek and his proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and Kosovo on the other.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that strengthening political dialogue as well as closer trade integration will help Kosovo to implement and implement the necessary reforms and create a more favourable environment for business development and governance. The Stabilisation and Development of Kosovo will then also benefit the European Union. The consent of the European Parliament will allow the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which has already been signed by both parties, i.e. representatives of both the European Union and Kosovo. This may lead to the development of contractual relations and the application of the measures contained in this Agreement. These include, above all, respect for and strengthening the principles of democracy and human rights, cooperation in the fight against crime, professional cooperation in areas such as energy, the environment, education or culture. I think that the recognition of the Republic of Kosovo and the other five Member States would be very helping to normalise relations between Prištěna and Belgrade. It should be in our interest to stabilise the whole region as much as possible.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) establishes contractual relations providing for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers many areas, such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs.  The National Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo ratified the Stabilisation and Association Agreement as soon as possible, on 2 November 2015. The conclusion of the ongoing approval procedure in the European Parliament will allow the entry into force of the ASA.  The European Parliament encourages the remaining five Member States to proceed with the recognition of the Republic of Kosovo, believing that this would further facilitate the normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Pristina.  I voted in favour of this recommendation, which represents a very important first step for the Republic of Kosovo towards the formal process of EU membership and the path of European integration.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2000, the European Union (EU) launched a policy on the countries of the Western Balkans which, through Stabilisation and Association Agreements (SAA), sets in motion free trade incentives. The obligations undertaken by the parties are, on the one hand, a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms in line with EU values and, on the other hand, a step in the European integration of the Republic of Kosovo, which strengthens the prospects for peace and prosperity in the Balkans and its neighbourhood. The proposed EEA establishes the same trade preference regime which has been in place since 2000 and provides for duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market (except for some agricultural and fish products). It should be noted that the Committee on International Trade of the European Parliament has given its assent to the proposal for a Council decision covering the provisions on such economic and trade matters and that, finally, the Committee on Foreign Affairs approves it in this Recommendation. Taking into account the opinion of the rapporteur and sensitive to the spirit of this contractual relationship which, through trade integration, favours political dialogue and strengthens cooperation, I supported the above-mentioned report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the further expansion of the EU, or the development of EU foreign relations or a foreign policy. The signing of this agreement represents developments in all these areas. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo, signed on 27 October 2015, establishes contractual relations that provide for enhanced political dialogue, greater trade integration and new forms of cooperation. This report, which I approved favourably, aims to create a free trade area, defines rights and obligations, is a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms and creates opportunities for investment, growth and business development. It covers a number of sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, the definition of a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs and includes provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted for the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, which is a major step in relations between that country and the EU. This contractual agreement, which entails mutual rights and obligations in a wide range of sectors, should encourage Kosovo to make the necessary reforms, should promote trade relations and political dialogue with the EU and allow for closer cooperation in many areas such as energy, the environment, justice and home affairs.  The agreement also emphasizes respect for the essential democratic principles and fundamental principles of the EU single market.  Finally, I believe that this agreement will help put Kosovo on the path to stability, sustainable economic growth and the job creation needed for the country.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement provides for enhanced political dialogue, greater trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers a number of sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, the definition of a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. It also includes provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. This stabilisation and association agreement is a formal first step of great importance for the process of EU membership and the european integration path of the Republic of Kosovo.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (AEA) was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and was signed in July 2014. In October 2015 the Council agreed to sign it by 27 October 2015. The Kosovar Assembly ratified it on 2 November 2015. Since Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence in 2008, Spain has maintained the same position, defending the principles of territorial integrity of States and respect for the rule of law, principles on which the European Union is also based. Exercising the discretion allowed by international law, the Government of Spain did not recognise the unilateral declaration of independence, deeming it contrary to international law, since it violates the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity recognized to Serbia and guaranteed by the Helsinki Final Act. In line with the position of the Spanish State and for the sake of a constructive attitude not to block an agreement which will introduce measures that will benefit the Kosovar population, I have decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This recommendation includes the European Parliament's decision, which is necessary as part of the ratification process for the Stabilization and Association Agreement (ASA) between the European Union and Kosovo. After receiving the approval of the European Parliament, the procedure is for the ASA to enter into force in the first half of next year. Once in force, the ASA will establish a contractual relationship that involves mutual rights and obligations and covers a wide range of sectors. The ASA emphasizes respect for the essential democratic principles and fundamental elements that are at the heart of the EU's single market. It will establish a space for free trade and the application of European standards in other areas, such as competition, state aid and intellectual property. It will also contribute to the implementation of reforms through which Kosovo can adopt European standards. Other provisions, of course, also deal with political dialogue, cooperation in a wide range of sectors, from education and employment to energy and the environment, justice and home affairs.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 As we know, the enlargement of the EU and its imitation process – The Association and Stabilisation Agreements are one of the main and undoubtedly the most successful instruments of the European Union's external policy. The Association Agreement with Kosovo was also designed for a similar purpose, in exchange for stability and the commitment of all Kosovo's political forces to peace, the EU proposed a package of aid measures that could eventually lead to membership. The EU has achieved its objective in part by being democratic and stable, even not recognised by some Member States. There is still a guarantee that he becomes rich. However, the main task is for the Kosovans themselves: they control their own land. The EU can only provide the necessary expertise. I am voting in favour of this proposal, and at the same time I call on the Commission to closely monitor the implementation of this agreement. The EU's primary objective is kosovo stability has already been achieved. However, we still need to help the Kosovans themselves to make Kosovo rich and well-managed. And we cannot compromise on this path.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo (EEA) was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and signed on 27 October in Strasbourg. This agreement provides for enhanced contractual relations and political dialogue between the European Union and Kosovo, greater trade integration and new forms of cooperation, covering various sectors, from education, energy, to preserving the environment, justice and home affairs. The proposal also includes the introduction of provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, with the aim of creating a free trade area. I support this Agreement, which I consider to be a key step towards Kosovo's eu membership process within a broader framework of the other Balkan countries. In view of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the approval of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. This vote paves the way for the deepening of relations between the EU and Kosovo. It is about building a genuine political dialogue and committing to greater economic integration. The agreement includes provisions to promote European standards in key areas such as public procurement, consumer protection and competition. The ultimate goal is therefore the establishment of a free trade area. More than the commercial and economic aspects, the signing of such an agreement allows the areas of cooperation between the EU and Kosovo to be extended to justice, energy or the environment.  Parliament's approval of the signing of the agreement sends a strong message to Kosovo of EU support on the path to reforms, which are essential to stabilizing the country. The agreement must now enter into force in order to implement all of these provisions.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has been called upon to ratify the agreement with Kosovo establishing contractual relations providing for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. In particular, the agreement promotes respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights and also includes provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection and aims to create a free trade area. It is important to establish, maintain and improve relations between the European Union and the neighbouring countries, both because of the economic opportunity they represent and because of their contribution to the stabilisation and control of such strategic areas.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244/1999 and that the Kosovo state-of-stateization process is irreversible, the opinion also does not imply that the former province has a good right to be recognized by third parties. The situation in Kosovo has a complex political substrate and therefore has to be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms, poses a permanent internal threat to peace, safeguards the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and ensures in the medium term the departure of foreign military powers from the area. Therefore, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement proposed by the Council, which focuses mainly on the 'deepening of economic and trade relations' is premature and weeds in prioritizing actions leading to a real and lasting stabilisation of the area.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement establishes contractual relations between the parties on political dialogue and trade relations. Kosovo has been officially regarded as a potential candidate for accession to the European Union since the European Council attributed a 'European perspective' to it in 2003. This EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which would enter into force at the conclusion of the ratification procedure, is seen as a significant formal step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, I voted against it since I systematically oppose such agreements which do not benefit the populations of the countries involved and only reproduce a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery. Thus, among the main objectives of this Agreement is the creation of a free trade area as well as increasing the EU's 'interference' policy through the euphemism of 'stabilisation', issues which I reject head-on.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the recommendation voted on today, the European Parliament gives its approval to the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) between the EU and Kosovo. Kosovo, following the Declaration of Independence from Serbia in February 2008, implemented a series of economic and political reforms in order to meet the criteria for accession to the European Union. Thanks to this agreement, which aims to strengthen political dialogue and to forge new forms of cooperation and trade, Kosovo will enjoy numerous economic and social benefits, while strengthening good governance through the application of European standards and the approximation of EU legislation. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation, as I believe that the European integration of this country will make a significant contribution to the stability of the Balkan region, to the benefit of Europe's security and prosperity.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this agreement today because I believe that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is an incredibly important first formal step towards the accession process and integration path for the Republic of Kosovo. This agreement creates a lot of conditionality pressures for the Republic and gives the institutional structures an incentive to implement and institutionalise these reforms.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo is the last of the agreements to be concluded with the countries of the Western Balkans. Kosovo has benefited from a preferential trade regime with the EU since 2000, with tariff-free and quota-free access to the European market, with the exception of certain agricultural and fishery products. These measures are currently laid down in a Council Regulation which expired on 31 December 2015. In essence, the proposed agreement provides for the same regime – guaranteeing unrestricted access for industrial products and most agricultural products (with the exception of live bovine animals and meat thereof, sugar products, certain wine products, young cattle meat products and certain fishery products). The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement is the first formal step towards the process of accession of the Republic of Kosovo to the EU and its European integration. Given that Slovakia is one of five EU states that have not recognised the Republic of Kosovo, I did not vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Negotiations on the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement concluded in July 2014. The Agreement was subsequently ratified by the National Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo on 2 December 2014.  This agreement establishes contractual relations that ensure better political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation between the EU and Kosovo. It covers several sectors, including respect for and strengthening of democratic principles and human rights. It also contains provisions promoting European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. The agreement sets out rights and obligations and provides a strong incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms.  The recommendation calls for the conclusion of the agreement, which is a central document in the process of stabilisation and association of Kosovo. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement will create opportunities for investment, growth, business development and strengthening, while also ensuring good governance through the application of European standards and approximation to EU law.  The agreement should also open up opportunities to strengthen contacts with experts in important sectors (environment, fight against crime and illegal trade, culture, etc.) and further strengthen relations and cooperation with neighbouring countries, thereby contributing to the stability of the region.  As this is an important step in the process of accession and convergence of the Republic of Kosovo to the EU, I voted in plenary.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The Association Agreement primarily includes the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU and Kosovo. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We therefore welcome the EU-Kosovo Association Agreement, but we reject Full Kosovo's membership within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing ‒ the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is a very important first formal step towards the process of accession of the Republic of Kosovo to the EU and its European integration. Relations between the Republic of Kosovo and the EU are expected to be further strengthened. In order to normalise relations between Belgrade and Pristina, recognition is needed by all (including the remaining five EU Member States). All EU Member States should make every effort to promote economic and people-to-people contacts and social and political relations between their citizens and those of the Republic of Kosovo.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo was signed in Strasbourg on 27 October, and the National Assembly of the Republic of Kosovo ratified the agreement on 2 November 2015. The agreement establishes a relationship that ensures political dialogue, better trade integration and new forms of co-operation. It covers a number of sectors, including respecting and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, establishing a framework for cooperation for sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. The SSP also contains provisions aimed at promoting European standards in areas such as competition, procurement, intellectual property, consumer protection, all with a view to establishing a free trade area. The agreement provides rights, but also obligations, and provides a strong impetus for the implementation of reforms. The SSP will create opportunities for investment, growth, business development, strengthening, at the same time, good governance of the application of European standards and approximation of EU laws. The SSP is a very important step in the EU accession process and European integration for the Republic of Kosovo, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and Kosovo, of the other part.  This is a historic event – the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo is now becoming a reality. The deal is a milestone for Kosovo and brings new opportunities for the country's economy. Kosovo's future lies in the European Union.  However, European integration is not taken for granted. This requires enormous political will and the implementation of much-needed reforms. In the case of Kosovo, it is precisely the fight against corruption that is the key issue where Kosovo must show a great deal of will to move forward.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The situation in Kosovo is a continuation and consequence of invasive policies. This is a clear violation of international law which is a bad precedent because it increases the risk of being used as a model in other cases. Of particular concern is the fact that various circles link the case of the 'TDBK' with Kosovo. Unfortunately, the report makes a direct call for Kosovo to be recognised as an independent state, which would be a violation of international law. In addition, the proposed Association Agreement itself aims at closer political association, in particular gradual economic integration with the EU. The ultimate aim is to lead this agreement to an in-depth and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA). The Free Trade Agreements fully serve the EU's intended benefits as they create interdependence - both economic and political - with partners and promote extreme competition for the benefit of large capital. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Kosovo in the spiritual and moral sense is the heart of Serbia and the soul of the Serbian people. Kosovo's accession will be an acceptance of the change of borders of a state by force, just as was the case with the Turkish invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus, and the unilateral secession of a Serbian province in order to satisfy the ethnic aspirations of albanians. Neither Kosovo is a state, nor is there a Kosovar nation. We must not forget the illegalities of Tito's Yugoslav communists who transformed states and literally raped the historical truth, creating Macedonian dreams and Kosovar abortions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the entry into force of the STM between the EU and the Republic of Kosovo. The Stabilisation and Association Agreements have now proved to be a proven and effective instrument of the EU's enlargement policy in the Western Balkans. I believe that, in the interests of stability and democratic development in the region, it is high time that Kosovo could also benefit from the opportunities for closer cooperation with the Union, including the perspective of visa-free travel. I regret that, as the proposal for a decision points out, the completeness of this process continues to be hampered by the fact that five EU Member States still do not recognise kosovo's independent statehood. I hope that the entry into force of the agreement may be an appropriate opportunity for these Member States to correct this legally and politically advanced situation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade for the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, I am very pleased that the European Parliament has agreed to this agreement, which aims to significantly deepen economic and trade relations between partners.  The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is an opportunity for Kosovo, the poorest country in Europe, for economic development. The agreement includes both incentives and commitments to carry out the necessary reforms, create the conditions for creating new investment and jobs.  I hope that the authorities in Pristina will seize this opportunity to improve the situation of the people of Kosovo, where around 40% of the population lives in extreme poverty and unemployment reaches 30%. Only in this way can we try to stop the mass exodus of people from the country that we have seen in the last dozen months.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Stabilisation and development of the Western Balkans region has been a policy consistently carried out by the European Union over the past two decades. Through existing instruments or through the creation of others specifically designed to do so, the EU has come to the aid of the citizens of the region, with a view to normalising their lives and the possibility of aspiring to the status of European citizens in the future. The main instrument that can strengthen the evolution of the countries in the region towards the status of EU Member States is the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. It creates the prerequisites for attracting more foreign investment, developing business environments, economic growth and good governance, through the application of European standards and Community legislation. For this reason, the conclusion of the agreement is an important motivating factor in implementing and institutionalising the necessary reforms. Such documents were concluded with most states in the region. With regard to Kosovo, uncertainty about its international status has so far not allowed a similar agreement to be concluded. Citizens living there should not, however, be deprived of the benefits enjoyed by other citizens in the region. Before signing this agreement, however, it may be useful to regulate the issue of Kosovo's status, in order to avoid the equivocal issues that may give rise to implementation problems.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. This agreement establishes contractual relations that provide for enhanced political dialogue, closer trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It applies to many sectors, including respect and strengthening of democratic principles and human rights, and creates a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. It also includes provisions to promote the application of European standards in the areas of competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection, among others, and to establish a free trade area.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo. By voting this text Parliament welcomes the deepening of relations between Kosovo and the EU. Indeed, this agreement is a very important first formal step towards the EU accession process and the European integration path for the Republic of Kosovo.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the signing of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement is a very positive fact and an important step towards bringing Kosovo closer to the European Union. Kosovo must continue to pursue the reform process, and the European institutions must support this process. The political and economic stabilisation of the Balkans is extremely important for the EU. We must ensure that this is done correctly.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, as I believe that the agreement will bring closer trade integration, create opportunities for investment, capital building and growth and development in all areas of the country's functioning. It will bring new opportunities and progress for both the EU and Kosovo, while also helping to bring stability of Kosovo's relations with neighbouring countries and the region itself.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote because, although the International Court of Justice concluded that Kosovo's unilateral declaration of independence did not violate international law or United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244/1999 and that the Kosovo state-of-stateization process is irreversible, the opinion also does not imply that the former province has a good right to be recognized by third parties. The situation in Kosovo has a complex political substrate and therefore has to be addressed and resolved politically, through an agreement that in any case integrates Serbia, neutralizes Serbian and Kosovar nationalisms, poses a permanent internal threat to peace, safeguards the rights of ethnic minorities in the area and ensures in the medium term the departure of foreign military powers from the area. Therefore, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement proposed by the Council, which focuses mainly on the 'deepening of economic and trade relations' is premature and weeds in prioritizing actions leading to a real and lasting stabilisation of the area.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome very much this agreement, which will enable Kosovo to keep progressing along its European path. I would also like to call on MS that have not recognized Kosovo to do so as soon as possible.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The eu's enlargement policy has already been a serious political mistake. Its Balkan policy has resulted in crimes against the Serbian people. Facilitating Kosovo's accession would be politically tantamount to giving a premium to the Albanian mafia, which is the most reliable institution in the "country".  Moreover, interfering in the internal affairs of Member States which do not intend to acknowledge the affront that the creation of Kosovo was in the eyes of international law or do not intend to see this dangerous precedent backfire on them is an attack on the sovereignty of States. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (STM) was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and was corked in July 2014. The Council contributed to its signature on 22 October 2015. For the EU, it was signed by Vice-President/High Representative Federica Mogherini and Commissioner Johannes Hahn, Prime Minister Isa Mustafa of the Republic of Kosovo and European Integration Minister Bekim Çollaku in Strasbourg on 27 October. It was quickly confirmed by the Parliament of the Republic of Kosovo on 2 November 2015. Following the completion of the current Memorandum of Understanding before the European Parliament, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement may enter into force. I supported the report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the SAA is a very important first formal step towards the EU accession process and the European integration path for the Republic of Kosovo. It is the last in line of such agreements for the Western Balkan countries but contrary to the others the Commission decided this time to use a different juridical basis in order to overcome the vote of ratification of the national parliaments of the five countries that do not recognise Kosovo (Cyprus, Greece, Romania, Slovakia and Spain). Another step forward should be the introduction of the visa-free regime for Kosovo citizens that was put on hold for the moment by the Council in December and the framework agreement on Kosovo’s participation in EU programmes, which will strengthen cooperation between Kosovo and the EU in a variety of sectors. These programmes should be focused on specific areas that correspond to the obligations taken up by Kosovo on its European path and should be implemented with transparency and without delay.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The EU-Self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement establishes contractual relations between the parties on political dialogue and trade relations. Although five EU Member States have not recognised Kosovo, kosovo is officially regarded as a potential candidate to join the European Union since the European Council attributed a 'European perspective' to it in 2003. This EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which would enter into force at the conclusion of the ratification procedure, is seen as a significant formal step towards Kosovo's accession to the EU. However, I voted against the proposal for the adoption of this Agreement, since with this agreement the EU implicitly recognises Kosovo as a State, as well as its unilateral declaration of independence, in violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1244/1999. It is intolerable that the European Parliament intends to put pressure on the Member States, including Spain, which do not recognise Kosovo, which constitutes political interference in the competences of the States. Moreover, this Agreement entails the creation of a free trade area, which I also reject.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is a crucial first formal step towards the EU accession process path for the Republic of Kosovo and I was proud to vote in favour of it. This agreement creates the groundwork for extended cooperation between the EU and Kosovo in a variety of sectors including education, energy, the environment and justice, while also providing assistance in the critical area of human rights development. This will build on the long-standing relationship between the Republic of Kosovo and the EU, as will the quick introduction of the visa-free regime for Kosovo citizens. It is vital that we buttress security in the western Balkans at this time of international instability. No one wishes to see a return to the situation of the instability of late 1990s. It is vital that the EU continues to help Kosovars build internal stability and promote external harmony with their Balkan neighbours.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo. By agreeing to this agreement, the European Parliament is emphasising the strengthening of the link between the European Union and Kosovo. In fact, this agreement is an important first step towards the European accession process and integration into Europe for the Republic of Kosovo.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The consecration of an SAA without being ratified by popular expression confirms a process of integration that imposes on a people the loss of sovereignty, subjugation to the macroeconomic policies of the European Union and the creation of a free trade area, culminating in the process of integration of the Balkans and the fragmentation of the territory of Yugoslavia. On the other hand, and worse than the first, the continuation of the formalisation of the establishment of relations with a territory, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that has opened up in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo, and which the EU has sought to legitimize. An illegal decision, which we do not recognise and which has created a protectorate through aggression and occupation by the US, NATO and the EU.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Kosovo became Albanian through an artificial settlement. As long as the Serbian minority in the north of the country is not granted broad autonomy, Kosovo's integration cannot be supported. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo because I firmly believe in the European Union's pull force as a driving force for stimulating internal change. The Agreement is the first formal step in the accession process, but its impact will be limited if it is not accompanied by tangible benefits for Kosovars, in particular visa liberalisation to the EU.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. Rejection, because the establishment of an art state "Kosovo" ultimately stems from the geostrategic calculus of NATO and is part of the disintegration policy of the West in the European southeast.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and Kosovo, on the other, on behalf of the Union. Association agreements, even if otherwise desirable, are the first step on a one-way street towards membership. At this stage, the EU should not accept any more members. First, the EU treaties should be amended and the existing problems – the euro, the refugee crisis, over-regulation, centralisation, bureaucratisation – should be brought to a solution.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the European Parliament's recommendation on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU and Kosovo whereby this agreement will be able to enter into force. The SAA was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014 and was initialled in July 2014, and the representatives of the European Council signed it in October 2015. Contractual relations are established in the SAA and more intensive political dialogue, stronger trade integration and new forms of cooperation between the EU and Kosovo are foreseen. The agreement covers many sectors, including respect for and strengthening democratic principles and human rights, establishing a framework for cooperation in sectors such as education, energy, the environment, justice and home affairs. The SAA also contains provisions aimed at promoting European standards in areas such as competition, public procurement, intellectual property and consumer protection. The agreement also aims to establish a free trade area. I welcome the fact that the EP encourages the five Member States that have not yet done so to recognise the Republic of Kosovo, believing that this will make it even easier to normalise relations between Belgrade and Pristina.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing – Parliament's approval of the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) will allow the Council of Ministers to formally complete the procedure and enter into force. The agreement introduces a strengthening of the political dialogue between the EU and Kosovo, closer integration of trade and new forms of cooperation through contractual relations. The agreement covers many different areas, including strengthening democratic principles and respect for human rights, combating crime and trafficking in human beings, establishing a framework for cooperation in the fields of justice, education and home affairs and contributing to stability in the region. There is broad agreement that the agreement will be determinative in kosovo's stabilisation and association process by requiring the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms. The SSP also includes provisions to promote European standards in areas such as competition, markets, intellectual property, consumer protection, energy and the environment. It also establishes a free trade area, creating opportunities for investment, growth and business development through the application of European standards and the approximation of EU legislation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo. This type of agreement had already been concluded with all the Balkan countries apart, in fact, Kosovo because of problems mostly related to its status and what follows for international recognition. This agreement is seen as the first step in the process of European integration of the Balkan countries as it provides for reinforced political dialogue, the start of Kosovo's trade integration, but this does not establish a free trade area and cooperation at different levels and in different EU programmes. The procedure could not be concluded without parliament's official approval, but it could not intervene in the text of the agreement, but merely expressed its opinion.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the recommendation on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo. These agreements are part of the stabilisation and association process with the western Balkan countries, and Kosovo is the last country in this geographical area with which the agreement has not yet been signed, and it is also the first ever agreement concluded between the European Union and Kosovo. Among other things, the agreement calls for Kosovo to be recognised by the remaining five Member States that have not yet recognised Kosovo. Although the Slovak Republic is one of these five countries and does not yet intend to recognise Kosovo, it is not opposed to maintaining relations and cooperation with Kosovo and therefore supports this agreement. I hope that the agreement will greatly help to consolidate democracy and act as a new stimulus for reforms and an opportunity for new investment, growth and prosperity. At the same time, I consider it an important step in Kosovo's integration into the European Union.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation contains, in itself, two aspects that portray well the imperialist stance of this process of European integration. On the one hand, the consecration of an SAA which, without being ratified by popular expression, confirms a process of integration which imposes on a people the loss of sovereignty and subjugation to the macroeconomic policies of the European Union, the creation of a free trade area, culminating in the process of integration of the Balkans and the fragmentation of the territory of Yugoslavia. On the other hand, and worse than the first, it means the continuation of the formalisation of the establishment of relations with a territory, as if it were a legitimate country, after the very serious precedent that has opened up in international law with the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo, and which the EU has sought to legitimise. An illegal decision, which we do not recognize, which created a protectorate through the aggression and occupation of the US, NATO and the EU. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which establishes contractual relations between Kosovo and the EU and will make an important contribution to the development and stability of the situation in the Balkans. I am convinced that the Republic of Kosovo will try to successfully comply with provisions that promote European standards and work towards the creation of a free trade area and respect for democratic principles and fundamental human rights.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, as leaks to the press have shown that they were aware of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-gislate on emission limits and to reformulate (down and with the participation of multinationals themselves) transatlantic car regulation through TTIP. I believe that this issue is fundamental, not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas) but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy. This is a technical vote that completes appointments to the Committee of Inquiry, whose mandate was formally approved at the previous session.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The decision to set up the Committee of Inquiry and the immediate start of its work is a strong signal that the rules must be applied and applied by even the most powerful. We do not negotiate the health of European citizens and we do not sacrifice our environmental morality on the altar of profit and distorted competition from multinationals.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I will be an alternate member of this committee with the incumbent MPs Jalkh and Mayer. This commission must not lead to harm to the European automotive industry for the benefit of the American or Japanese automotive industries.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should have been a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that this appointment was brought before the Parliament and passed without a vote. Had I been given a vote on this matter, I would have voted against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the composition of the EP Committee investigating counterfeiting of car pollution. This temporary committee will examine whether the Manipulation of pollution measuring equipment by car manufacturers did not violate EU law by the European Commission and the states. It was prompted by the us revelations that the Volkswagen Group manipulated pollution measuring equipment. The final report will be submitted within this year.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved the proposed designations in order to be able to set up as soon as possible the Commission of Inquiry which will hopefully shed light on the "dieselgate".

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to appoint the members of the Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. Following the emissions scandals involving some European car manufacturers, the European Parliament decided to carry out an investigation to identify shortcomings and omissions in the application of EU emission legislation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector shall be approved 'AUTOMATICLY'.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported the appointments of the committee of inquiry to be launched in Parliament. I hope the work starts as soon as possible and that we can know what actually happened.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I approved the appointment of the members of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector as voted at the last plenary session in December. I reaffirm my full confidence in Jean-François Jalkh and Georg Mayer, members of the ENF Group who will sit on this committee, which will be responsible for examining allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in the application of EU law with regard to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, without prejudice to the competences of national courts or the Union.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of the proposed members of the Committee of Inquiry into Emissions Measurement in the Automotive Sector set up by the European Parliament at the plenary session last December.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this list of 45 Members of this House to be part of the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector following the scandalous discovery of fraud committed by Volkswagen. The composition of this commission reflects the correlation of forces and balances present in this House. Personally, it is an honour to be part of this committee of inquiry to elucide the actions of the Barroso Commission and the Authorities of the Member States with regard to the scandal of measuring polluting emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - Despite the fact that I objected to the proposed decision to set up a committee of inquiry to measure emissions in the automotive sector, as I believe that it is the task of the competent naive authorities as well as the authors of the legislation to remove the unlawful consequences of the Volkswagen affair, I expect the committee to carry out its task responsibly and objectively.  Decisions must not be to the detriment of the European car industry, but must focus on finding offenders, penalising them accordingly and proposing solutions to prevent such abuses in the future, which will restore consumer confidence in the automotive sector. The European car industry accounts for around a quarter of global motor vehicle production, it is one of the pillars of the European economy with exceptional multiplier effects, and its protection is of paramount importance to the EU. It is important that the committee will work on solutions, not as a kind of inquisitive court, which would cause even more damage. I repeat once again that the Committee must define responsibility for the fraudsters of the Volkswagen affair and ensure that such matters do not happen again.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the recent scandals in the car industry, I welcome the establishment of a committee of inquiry to clarify infringements of EU rules on the measurement of car emissions. The investigation to be carried out over the next twelve months by the committee composed of colleagues will aim to identify the responsibilities at stake and any omissions that have allowed the non-implementation of existing legislation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The exhaust scandal is actually an attack on the health and consumer rights of citizens and the economy of the European Union and the Member States. The release of nitric oxides, which are particularly harmful to the liver, lungs and blood count of citizens, was set up.
