They were cheated into selling more expensive cars that were supposedly less harmful to the environment. Someone has to answer for this, and the EU must contribute to finding a way to restore trust in the European automotive industry. This committee is necessary and that is why I support the decision.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Jean François Jalkh and Georg Mayer, two members of the ENL group, have been appointed to sit on the commission of inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. Because I have every confidence in my two colleagues to participate effectively in the work of this committee charged with examining violations of EU law, without undermining the competences of national courts. I voted for the report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the appointment of members of the Commission of Inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the motor vehicle sector is the result of joint efforts by representatives of the main bodies of the European Union calling for the examination of alleged allegations of irregularities and maladministration with regard to the application of Union legislation on the measurement of emissions in the motor vehicle sector. The main objectives of this committee will be to monitor the test cycles carried out to measure emissions and to adapt them when they are no longer in accordance with the provisions, so as to adequately reflect emissions from actual traffic on the road.  In addition, within the framework of its mandate, the Commission of Inquiry will carry out various investigations into the implementation of the explicit prohibition on defeat devices, on compliance with the provisions on effective, proportionate penalties applicable to manufacturers in the event of infringement of the rules for the use of defeat devices, refusal to grant access to information and falsification of the results of the type-approval or in-service conformity tests. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to monitor compliance with the legal provisions on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector in order to ensure a legitimate framework for the operation of this sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. This is the composition of the EMIS Committee of Inquiry set up at the December I meeting.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a simple approval vote on members of the Committee of Inquiry on emissions in the automotive industry, arising out of the Volkswagen emissions scandal late last year.  Three MEPs from my own political grouping GUE/NGL, whose candidacy I supported, will sit on this Committee.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the discovery in the United States that the Volkswagen Group used software to reduce NOx emissions during testing, we voted on a resolution last October calling for a thorough investigation into the role and responsibilities of the European Commission and member states, asking them to disclose what they knew about these breaches and what actions were taken later. Together with the entire M5S Europe delegation, I therefore voted in favour of appointing the members of the Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of voting on the report on the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurements in the automotive industry. The Committee will investigate infringements of European regulations by car manufacturers with regard to pollutant emission measurements, as well as any infringements by Member States and the European Commission in the implementation of European standards. The Committee shall submit an interim report within 6 months and a final report within 12 months of the start of its work.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of emissions in the automotive sector leaves me, as a politician, a great doubt: is it fraud, how will the courts have to ascertain, or were the rules too permissive? It is therefore right that a committee of inquiry should be set up to make the names of those responsible clear. I have serious doubts about the responsibilities of the European political level, because the then Commissioner for Industry, Antonio Tajani, asked for independent studies and, given the discrepancy with what the car manufacturers said, he put in place a legislative reform of the sector with the aim of reviewing the role and responsibilities of the national agencies, but the EU could not do more. The composition of this committee, which is the subject of my vote, faithfully reflects the composition of Parliament and is therefore approved. Good work to the colleagues who will be part of it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of appointing the members of the Committee of Inquiry into the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, which will present a first report within 6 months and the final report within 12 months of the start of work.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ While we often speak of climate change, environmental pollution and its effects on human life, we rarely find concrete instances where action is speedily taken to investigate specific cases of gross negligence or incorrectness with the aim of ensuring that these actions are not repeated. This inquiry is expected to, at least in part, find ways of ensuring that the automotive sector does not fail to fulfil its legal obligations as well as its social corporate responsibility. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, as leaks to the press have shown that they were aware of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-gislate on emission limits and to reformulate (down and with the participation of multinationals themselves) transatlantic car regulation through TTIP. I believe that this issue is fundamental, not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas) but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Members of the European Parliament requested that a Committee of Inquiry be set up to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. The aim of the inquiry would be to investigate alleged contraventions of Union law and alleged instances of maladministration in the application of Union law which appear to be the act of an institution or body of the European Union and public administrative bodies of Member States. I supported the setting up this committee, of which I will be a member.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Following the revelations about the cheating of carmaker Volkswagen, Parliament has decided to set up a temporary commission to investigate violations of EU rules, as well as alleged failures by national authorities and the European Commission to enforce EU standards. The purpose of this vote is to approve the list of 45 members of this committee to which I myself have been appointed as an alternate member.  In this 12-month commission, we will be responsible for submitting an interim report within six months and then a final report at the end of the mandate. It is crucial that we shed light on this unacceptable case of fraud and ensure that this does not happen again in the future. However, I will be engaged alongside my colleagues in the EPP Group and the French EPP delegation to ensure that the mandate of this committee is respected. It is not a question of tried diesel, nor of making an amalgamation between the fault of a company and the entire European automotive sector which employs millions of people. I supported that list.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Emissions of microparticles and nitrogen oxides from diesel vehicles affect and burden air quality with tragic effects on public health and mortality of European citizens. We are in favour of setting up a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry because in this way car manufacturers will be screened for concealment of data, infringements and there will be no room for deception as was the case with Volkswagen.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Developments in the Volkswagen scandal on the manipulation of data on emissions from light vehicles once again highlight the fact that we are facing a European Commission handled by lobbyists, in this case the car industry lobby, one of the most powerful with the EU institutions, influencing and leaving their indelible proposals. After the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Council of Atmospheric Resources (CARB) issued a notice of violation of pollution standards applicable to the Volkswagen group and recent data pointed to a large discrepancy between nitrogen oxide emissions measured under laboratory conditions and under normal conditions of circulation, the European Parliament has approved the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in this regard, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national courts. This committee will aim to investigate and collect data on the alleged failures of the European Commission and the Member States to comply with the obligations imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. We will carefully follow your work, not failing to intervene so that light on this case can be shed.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the european institutions' review of the emissions counterfeiting scandal by a company as important as Volkswagen is a necessary step to restore consumer confidence. The European Union has decided to set up a commission for measuring emissions in the automotive industry, the results of which will be very important for our citizens who are interested in protecting the environment. I therefore also consider it important to select the persons who will operate on this commission, because their credibility will play an important role.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Emissions of microparticles and nitrogen oxides from diesel vehicles affect and burden air quality with tragic effects on public health and mortality of European citizens. I am voting in favour of the proposal to set up a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the car industry because in this way car manufacturers will be screened for concealment of data, infringements and there will be no room for deception, as was the case with Volkswagen.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector, in order to restore trust amongst consumers after the outbreak of the emissions scandal.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the decision to set up a committee of inquiry into allegations of breaches of EU law and abuses in the application of EU law in relation to emissions measurement in the automotive industry, without prejudice to the judicial powers of national and EU courts. I welcome the fact that it will be up to the Committee of Inquiry to oblige the Commission to supervise the measurement cycles used to measure emissions and, if the tests no longer prove to be adequate or reflect real emissions, to adjust them in such a way as to credibly reflect the emissions generated by real road driving.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of appointments, among which I have the honour to meet, convinced that this committee of inquiry can and should shed light on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector and help a scandal like the one experienced never to occur again in the EU.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of appointing the members of the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry because I believe that good, evidence-based work in this Committee of Inquiry is crucial. At the same time, the committee must not be misused to convey one-sided, market-distorting messages against individual companies.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have applied to the Committee of Inquiry to promote a fair investigation. The Committee must not develop into a tribunal which is only aimed at presenting an individual company. The stakes are also too high for our region with several automotive locations. In principle, I consider the Committee of Inquiry to be the wrong instrument. The Social Democrats and Greens from Lower Saxony in particular had called for the committee. If such a body becomes a political means of struggle, it has little to do with education and puts jobs in our region at risk. However, since it was not possible to prevent the committee, I now want to limit damage. I am a member of the Committee of Inquiry to work for a fair investigation. The Committee must not develop into a tribunal, either against different companies or against individuals. For Lower Saxony in particular, the stakes are too high.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the set-up of the committee that will investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration of EU law, following the scandal which revealed that devices were installed in cars to distort emission measurements. It is crucial we now collect and analyse information to identify where authorities failed on this file. Citizens deserve to know and we expect full transparency.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector shall be approved 'AUTOMATICLY'.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, I voted for the proposed appointments of members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the list of members who will make up the commission of inquiry into emissions from the automotive sector.  The creation of this committee was approved in December 2015, so I felt it was essential to weigh in on the activities that will be carried out and to make this committee useful.  It is important to renew the confidence of our citizens in the European automotive industry. I will be particularly vigilant to ensure that the mandate is respected and that this commission conducts a serious investigation. It will have to identify the responsibilities following Volkswagen's scandalous cheating but also highlight the solutions so that such a case does not happen again.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The scandal of data tampering in gas emissions measurements in the automotive industry is a top issue. This huge fraud has been uncovered in the US, which shows that the EU's control system is lax and incomplete. The committee of inquiry voted on and the members appointed have a duty to fully solve the scandal as soon as possible and to conduct an investigation into the role and responsibility of the European Commission and the Member States, asking them to disclose what they knew about these violations and the measures they had taken.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I approve of the appointed member of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to appoint members of the Commission of Inquiry on Emission Measurements in the automotive sector, as I believe that the Committee should start work as soon as possible in order for the collection and analysis of information and research to yield concrete and effective results.  I believe that the proposal for a decision on the appointment of members to the Committee concerned is balanced and consistent with the political forces within Parliament, and I therefore support it.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I will be a full member of this commission. This must not lead to harm to the European automotive industry for the benefit of the American or Japanese automotive industries.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ By endorsing this text, Parliament appointed the 45 members of the special Committee of Inquiry into car makers’ breaches of EU rules on car emissions. The decision to set up this committee was taken after the Volkswagen scandal. It is clear that something went wrong and we need to find out why. We also need to investigate alleged failures by EU Member States as well as the Commission to enforce EU standards. I hope this committee will be able to give us some answers.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I approved the establishment of the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector, decided by the European Parliament in the wake of the Volkswagen cheating scandal. I believe that this opportunity must be seized to improve air quality, in particular through the introduction of real-world driving tests. I also hope that all the light will be shed on Volkswagen's fraud and that the Committee of Inquiry will make concrete proposals to ensure that such a case does not happen again. At the same time, the French EPP delegation will ensure that the commission's mandate is respected and that it is not used to make the diesel trial. Indeed, the fraud of a few, however scandalous, must not jeopardize whole sections of our industrial fabric.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although I am not convinced of the purpose of setting up a committee of inquiry into emission measurements, I agree with the nominees.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the appointment of the members of a Committee of Inquiry into car makers’ breaches of EU rules on car emission tests. The committee will investigate alleged failures by EU Member States and the Commission to enforce EU standards.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. Like the other members of the EPP Group, I voted against the creation of a temporary commission to investigate violations of EU rules on car emissions. However, since the creation of the latter was voted on by a majority of Parliament, we decided to send several of our members to sit there, in order to try to influence its work. The commission will present its first interim report within six months.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal sheds light on the fraudulent practices of some car manufacturers to distort the results of emissions tests. It also demonstrates the industry's collusion with regulators and legislators. The parliamentary committee of inquiry into the Volkswagen scandal will have to investigate the rigging of carbon emissions tests in the car industry, and the failures of the Commission and regulators to enforce emissions rules. In the weeks following the scandal we and my group called for the creation of this commission of inquiry, but the main groups opposed it, first trying to replace it with a Commission investigation that would have had the responsibility to shed light... on his own failings. I therefore supported the creation of an independent parliamentary commission of inquiry. However, I am concerned about the European Commission's attempt to accommodate car manufacturers by giving them flexibility on emissions thresholds of 110%: after having tolerated the cheating of car manufacturers, the Commission is changing the rules in their favour. This parliamentary committee of inquiry must therefore tackle these relations between manufacturers and political institutions that are at the expense of consumers.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms group has appointed Jean-François Jalkh and Georg Mayer as full members of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector. These MEPs will refuse to put European industry at odds. Air quality is a matter of great importance, but we must ensure that the French and European automotive industry can combine competitiveness with the environmentalist doxa in Brussels.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, as leaks to the press have shown that they were aware of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-gislate on emission limits and to reformulate (down and with the participation of multinationals themselves) transatlantic car regulation through TTIP. I believe that this issue is fundamental, not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas) but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy. This is a technical vote that completes appointments to the Committee of Inquiry, whose mandate was formally approved at the previous session.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This proposal was adopted in light of last year's disclosure of the emissions data falsifier scandal. Market surveillance needs to be improved and European car certification supervision monitored to ensure compliance with European rules for safety, environmental protection and manufacturing. I supported the appointment of members of the Automotive Emissions Measurement Commission as it is necessary to address any weaknesses of the current car certification system. I believe it is necessary to ensure the independence of emission tests as well as the greater involvement of the European Parliament in order to achieve better exchange of information between national authorities.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. On 17 December 2012, the European Parliament voted in the committee of inquiry into the establishment, competence, numerical composition and term of office of the Committee of Inquiry into emission measurements in the automotive sector. This was the basis for a recent scandal discovered by the US Environmental Protection Bureau, in which the German car maker VW admitted that for years it had actually ordered its cars, both diesel and petrol engine, to "lie" during the CO2 measurement tests (t.sk. The indicators in these tests were several times smaller than "on the road", because specially installed hardware "felt" the test, leading to automatically edited emission measurement results. One of the main objectives of the committee set up will be to understand why it was the US authority that discovered this breach and the long-term lying of millions of consumers, not an institution in the European Union. It is hoped that the appointed members of the committee of inquiry will not only be able to analyse the existing facts and evidence quickly enough and scrimisingly, but will also be as effective as possible from any external influence. Any fact-finding must be fully objective, rational and fair, at least because it is about ecology, consumer rights and their health.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I agree and support the proposal for a decision on the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry into Emissions Measurements in the automotive industry.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The European Parliament must work effectively to ensure that Community emissions regulations are complied with. That is why it is great news that a commission is being set up so that we can know everything that has happened in relation to the infringements of vehicle manufacturers and the role of the institutions in this whole case. I support the list of Members who will form this body and I want their work to clarify everything that has happened.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. There are no concerns about the proposed members. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate alleged breaches of EU law and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to emission measurements in the automotive sector. The Committee of Inquiry has been tasked with investigating allegations of exceeding the emission limit value for vehicles used and to collect and analyse all information on the sanctions member states have taken to prevent alleged infringements. I believe that the study carried out will help prevent unfair actions by the automotive industry in the future.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. 283 MEPs have called for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the Volkswagen scandal. The commission will investigate violations of EU law in the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. It will consist of 45 members, three of whom come from my GUE/NGL group. I vote for the appointment of these members so that it can begin its work as soon as possible

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The ENL Group has appointed MPs Jalkh and Mayer as full members of the committee. This commission must not lead to harm to the European automotive industry for the benefit of the American or Japanese automotive industries.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I approved in favour of the composition of members to the Committee of Inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. The Committee of Inquiry will be tasked with analysing alleged bouts of European rules on emissions measurement in the automotive sector.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the creation of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector as it is a positive step towards increasing transparency.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – In September last year, information about violations of emission limits by Volkswagen, the largest car manufacturer in Europe, came to light. Breaching emission limits means that cars produce more nitrogen oxide or carbon dioxide than permitted by standards, which can cause various health problems for the population. Such action must be firmly described as unacceptable. Given that the serious infringement comes from the largest automotive manufacturer in Europe, and it is likely that the Volkswagen group was not the only one, and other car manufacturers have also committed such activities, it is necessary to make the measurement of emissions in the automotive industry more difficult. For this reason, I welcome the creation of an investigation committee on emissions measurement, which will contribute to better control of compliance and thus to the protection of the health of the general public.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. After the revelation of the fraud on certain engines of the manufacturer Volkswagen, a commission of inquiry was set up in the European Parliament to study for a year the issues relating to emissions of polluting gases in the automotive sector. Its composition, not subject to a formal vote, was announced by the President of the Parliament: 45 MEPs were appointed, including 14 members of the EPP, 12 of the S and D, 5 CRE, 4 ALDE, 3 Greens, 3 GUE/GVN, 2 EFDD and 2 ENF.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the appointment of the members of the committee of inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. This newly formed committee has 45 members in its composition to investigate breaches of EU rules on car emissions tests and allegations that Member States and the European Commission have not applied EU standards. The Committee of Inquiry shall submit an interim report within 6 months and a final report within 12 months of the start of the activity. This committee will investigate the following issues related to the automotive sector: the European Commission's possible failure to check test cycles; the possible failure of the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to take appropriate and effective measures to supervise law enforcement; the Commission's possible failure to introduce tests reflecting actual driving conditions; the possible failure of the Member States to take measures on effective, proportionate and dissuasive penalties applicable to manufacturers in breach of the law; whether the Commission and the Member States had evidence of the use of 'protective equipment' before the scandal broke in September 2015.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Commission was set up to investigate the recent manipulation of car emissions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Air pollution, as we know, is now a worldwide problem and is a growing phenomenon, especially in large urban areas. As a member of the ENVI parliamentary committee and sensitive to environmental issues, I wish all the members of this committee good work so that you can make continuous improvements in this area. I would vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I see the inquiry committee as a useful tool to restore the confidence of citizens in the European automotive sector and evaluate possible solutions not only to amend mistakes, but also to bring higher and better standards. In this way, both the industry and consumers will benefit in the long run, by having an eye on a framework to avoid similar mistakes and on the other hand preserving the European automotive industry leadership as well as capacity for innovation and job creation. Let’s use the inquiry committee as a booster for the industry in terms of innovation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the appointment of 45 colleagues as members of the Eu Commission of Inquiry into infringements of EU emissions measurement rules in the automotive sector. In addition, the committee's main objective will be to investigate alleged failings by Member States and the Commission in the implementation of EU standards. It will present its interim report within 6 months and the final report within 12 months of its start. This is a continuation of the parliamentary initiative following the adopted resolution in October, which called for a thorough investigation into the role and accountability of the Commission and the Member States, and encouraged them to reveal everything they know about the breaches that have taken place and the actions taken. I hope that the Committee will justify the trust shown with a view to maintaining transparency and consumer information, but also trusting the institutions representing them.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The ongoing infringement proceedings of Directive 2008/50/EC, Directive 2007/46/EC and Regulation (EC) No 125/2007 of the European Parliament (EP) and the Council have prompted a request for a temporary committee of inquiry to examine allegations of infringement of EU law and maladministration in the application of Community provisions. Whereas Rule 2 of the EP Rules of Procedure stipulates a minimum of signatories (one quarter of MEPs) and taking into account that 283 Members supported the request under the stipulated conditions, Parliament hereby proposes a decision to lay down the composition and rules of operation of the committee investigating the measurement of car emissions. In accordance herein, it is for the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the commission's alleged failure to comply with the obligation to review the test cycles used to measure emissions and alleged omissions by the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to provide for measures to control and prohibit defeat devices, introduce tests reflecting actual driving conditions and lay down provisions on applicable sanctions, ensuring that applicable sanctions are enforced. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. Having given my support from the outset to this commission of inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector (EMIS), I welcome its implementation and look forward to being a part of it.  In accordance with the mandate given to us, we will now be able to investigate allegations of breaches of EU law and misapsed it, and make any recommendations that we deem necessary to ensure that such a situation does not happen again. The responsibilities of each individual should be established after the revelations that took place in the automotive sector. As I have already pointed out, this is necessary in order to restore and consolidate consumer confidence in this vital sector of European industry, and to move forward on reducing the polluting emissions in which we have collectively committed.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this list of 45 Members of this House to be part of the Committee of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector. The composition of this commission reflects the correlation of forces and balances present in this House. I would also like to congratulate my colleague José Blanco as part of this committee of inquiry to elucide the actions of the Barroso Commission and the authorities of the Member States with regard to the scandal of measuring polluting emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. We voted today in favour of the list of 45 MEPs and substitutes who will take part in the committee of inquiry into the Volkswagen car group scandal. I recall that I was one of those who voted in favour of setting up a commission of inquiry; I am therefore particularly pleased that she can start her work and I am counting on the quality of the work of my Belgian colleague Ivo Belet to help restore the image of the quality of European industrial production.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal presented by the Conference of Presidents on the appointment of the members of the committee of inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, as leaks to the press have shown that they were aware of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-gislate on emission limits and to reformulate (down and with the participation of multinationals themselves) transatlantic car regulation through TTIP. I believe that this issue is fundamental, not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas) but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy. This is a technical vote that completes appointments to the Committee of Inquiry, whose mandate was formally approved at the previous session.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Part of the European automotive sector has given a bad example of what the role of companies should be in combating climate change and pollution in general. A modern society needs responsible companies that go far beyond the simple generation of wealth. Whether in environmental or social and economic terms, it is essential that it goes beyond the law. Unfortunately, some European companies have not even been able to resist the temptation to break the law. It is now crucial that we identify all the frauds, confirm the scale of the fraud and create rules so that this phenomenon does not happen again. I also congratulate my colleagues Carlos Zorrinho and Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar for being the Portuguese to be part of this Committee of Inquiry. I wish you happiness in the truth and in pointing out new solutions.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ in the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal to appoint members of the Committee of Inquiry on Emission Measurement in the Automotive Sector, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. I welcome the appointment of independent members of the Committee of Inquiry. I believe that they will contribute to clarifying laws and standards in such a way that they are based on the latest technological research and ecology. The final price for consumers must also be taken into account so that the price of cars is not unnecessarily overcharged.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ In accordance with Rule 198 of the Rules of Procedure, the EP has submitted a draft decision on the establishment, scope, number of members and duration of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive industry. I support this proposal, and I have also signed a motion in support of the submission to plenary of the EP. It is important that we properly investigate the CO2 emissions scandal and, above all, that measures are taken in the future to prevent carmakers from cheating. Just a few days ago, very difficult negotiations on climate change in Paris ended and a climate agreement was born, which has yet to be ratified by individual states. The EU 2020 strategy has also set itself the objective of reducing CO2 emissions, which is why I welcomed the European Parliament's interest in large companies in the automotive industry complying with the declared emission values, so that the consumer is not misled when buying a car and, ultimately, that we protect the environment.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament has today appointed me as the only Slovak to the committee of inquiry into measuring emissions in the automotive industry. My aim is not to impose disproportionate fines and introduce new regulations. Automakers and their subcontractors also give jobs to thousands of people in the Slovak Republic. However, the rules must apply to everyone and we cannot tolerate consumer deception. Even large companies have to abide by the agreed rules. Environmental standards are some of the highest in the European Union and the world. If there is a demand for change, the European Union is open to negotiations. Together, we will look for solutions that will prevent such action in the future.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒The role of the Automotive Emissions Measurement Commission of Inquiry consisting of 45 members will be to control the effectiveness of emissions tests in the automotive sector and to verify that Member States have imposed effective and proportionate penalties in the event of infringements of Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 715/2007, which include the use of prohibited devices, refusal to provide access to information and falsification of test results. The Commission also aims to verify that Member States are taking proper and effective action to strengthen the explicit prohibition of devices that have not been approved. It will investigate whether the Commission has introduced tests reflecting actual driving conditions in a timely way and adopted measures relating to the use of defence mechanisms. The Council should collect and analyse information to determine whether the Commission and the Member States have proof of the use of defence mechanisms issued by the Environmental Protection Agency and whether they have evidence of the use of prohibited devices for CO2 emission tests. The commission will submit its final report within 12 months of starting work. As a result, I supported the report.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive sector. Despite my opposition to the committee of inquiry, as I do not believe that there is any need to set up a special committee of inquiry to investigate the conduct of the European Commission and the Member States, I supported the appointment of members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive sector.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament decided, after the information on the Volkswagen scandal came to light on 17 December 2015, to set up a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements. We supported the establishment of this committee because it will investigate complaints about the commission's and the Member States' authorities' failures to monitor the application of Union law and will consider penalising manufacturers for breaches of the provisions. However, we consider it a serious omission that this committee was not authorised to deal with matters relating to the responsibilities of companies but also with the rights of employees in the companies affected. The Group of the European United Left has set up a working group to examine these issues.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Emissions of microparticles and nitrogen oxides from diesel vehicles affect and burden air quality, have tragic effects on public health and increase the mortality rates of European citizens. We are in favour of setting up a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry as, in this way, car manufacturers will be screened for concealment of data, infringements and frauds as was done in the past with Volkswagen.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to set up a committee of inquiry into the so-called Volkswagen scandal. The Committee shall present an interim report in six months' time and the final report shall be prepared within one year. I will participate in the work myself, I will help the process as the only Hungarian leftist. Alleged infringements and maladministration in relation to emission measurement tests should be investigated. The production, repair and maintenance phases of euro 5 and 6 engines need to be analysed and a complete picture of whether transparency and necessary correction of test processes can be ensured? Effective and dissuasive EU sanctions against manufacturers that break regulations may be necessary at Member State level. Personally, I think it is important to clarify the matter from a climate and health point of view, and on the other hand, I believe that we should not forget the protection of workers. Such a perceived or real scandal threatens hundreds of thousands of jobs, in this case directly in our country! The process can therefore also affect Hungary and affect jobs in Hungary, since these measurement protocols and procedures are carried out according to the same principles in all production units! Some technical solutions are no longer secret devices, and some innovations quickly spread to other brands. However, I believe that the scandal could also provide a basis for companies to invest more resources, for example, in the development of electric cars.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of appointing the members of the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the Automotive Sector and wish them good luck. Europe must be fair and not treat big business and citizens differently.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry. The Committee will last 12 months, to investigate alleged contraventions of European Union law and alleged maladministration in the application of European Union law that led to the recent ‘diesel gate’ scandal. In particular, the inquiry will investigate why so called ‘defeat devices'’ were permitted to be installed in millions of cars, why the Commission and Member States failed to comply with the obligation to enforce EU emissions legislation and why tests reflecting real-world driving conditions were not introduced in a timely manner.  The ALDE Group pushed for the setting up of this committee and will have four full members: Dita Charanzova MEP (ANO CZ), Fredrick Federley MEP (Centre party, SE), Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (D66, NL) and Dominique Riquet (Parti Radical -UDI, FR); and four substitute members: Philippe De Backer MEP (Open VLD, BE), Robert Rochefort MEP (MoDem, FR), Nils Torvalds (Svenska folkpartiet, FI) and Gesine Meissner (FDP,DE).

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the appointment of members of the Automotive Emissions Measurement Commission for alleged violations and irregularities in the application of Union legislation in the measurement of emissions of harmful gases. Given the manipulation of emissions data and recent developments that have rocked the major German carmaker (VW), the European Union must restore citizens' trust and establish more effective control and control over the implementation of remedies in preventing fraud. In my view, the Committee of Inquiry needs to gather and analyse information to determine whether the Commission and the Member States possessed evidence of the use of jamming devices before the United States Environmental Protection Agency issued a breach notice on 18 September 2015. Ultimately, the European Union must also protect the consumer as the end-user.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision appointing the members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive sector, as I believe that the appointed members will do their job professionally and contribute to progress in this area.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – The appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurements in the automotive sector (EMIS) was ‘Approval without a vote’.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 283 Members have previously submitted an application calling for the establishment of a committee of inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive industry in order to investigate alleged violations of EU law and alleged maladministration. I supported the process and the proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Approval without a vote.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Volkswagen emissions scandal has once again demonstrated the complicity of the Commission and the Member States with large multinational groups, as leaks to the press have shown that they were aware of the manipulation of emission limits long before the American environmental agency uncovers the scandal. These political responsibilities and connections must be urgently clarified, since the Commission intends to re-gislate on emission limits and to reformulate (down and with the participation of multinationals themselves) transatlantic car regulation through TTIP. I believe that this issue is fundamental, not only because of the serious impact of emissions on the quality of life of Europeans (especially in urban areas) but because the scale of the scandal is such that the future of the car industry and its workers in Europe comes into play. The establishment of a commission of inquiry should clarify responsibilities and lay the groundwork for an environmentally and socially sustainable industrial policy. This is a technical vote that completes appointments to the Committee of Inquiry, whose mandate was formally approved at the previous session.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the Committee of Inquiry into emissions measurements in the automotive sector. In the coming year, this committee will continue to investigate the alleged breaches of European law which led to the so-called 'dieselgate scandal'.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The interests and lobbials of the automotive industry are powerful, as confirmed by the developments surrounding the Volkswagen scandal. A European Commission technical committee proposes authorising Euro 6 diesel cars to issue more than twice the limits previously set between 2017 and 2019, allowing for a 110% discrepancy between laboratory tests (which the industry handles more or less in general issuing) and testing in real-world conditions. From 2020, this discrepancy could be up to 50%, i.e. emissions 50% above the previously set limits. It is essential that measurements in real conditions move forward as soon as possible. But it is essential that they move forward in a way that ensures adequate protection of the environment and public health and not the protection of the interests of multinationals – against populations and the environment.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no concerns about the proposed members. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The developments surrounding the Volkswagen scandal on the manipulation of data on light vehicle emissions are a clear example of a European Commission handled by lobbyists, in this case the car industry lobby, one of the most powerful with the EU institutions, influencing legislative proposals and leaving their indelible trace. After the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Council of Atmospheric Resources (CARB) issued a notice of violation of pollution standards applicable to the Volkswagen group and recent data pointed to a large discrepancy between nitrogen oxide emissions measured under laboratory conditions and under normal conditions of circulation, the European Parliament has approved the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in this regard, without prejudice to the jurisdiction of national courts. This committee will aim to investigate and collect data on the alleged failures of the European Commission and the Member States to comply with the obligations imposed by Regulation (EC) No 715/2007. We will follow the work of this committee of inquiry carefully, intervening so that the fault does not die unmarried.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. At the strong push of the M5S, the European Parliament has set up an extraordinary committee to investigate the responsibilities of the Volkswagen scandal. As a substitute member of this committee, my commitment will be to bring to light information and contradictions that will emerge in the coming months during the work.  It will be essential to have access to all the necessary documentation to understand how much both the European Commission and the Member States were aware of the manipulations carried out on vehicles by the car manufacturer, in order to circumvent the rules on limiting emissions. The creation of this committee is a battle won against the staunch opposition of the People's Party, which would have preferred to have lowered the veil of oblivion over the scandal that has hit the German carmaker.  The scandal is that Member States, without opposition from the Commission, have introduced correction factors that make double emissions legal until 2018 and 1.5 times the limits for subsequent years. The Italian Government has even proposed legalising emissions at least 300% higher than the limits. The omen is therefore not the best. We in the M5S in this committee want to clarify the real responsibility for this fraud.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision appointing members of the Committee of Inquiry on emission measurement in the automotive sector. I agree that a thorough investigation should be carried out into the role and responsibility of the Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States in the case of alleged infringements and irregularities in the application of EU law relating to the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector.  I would like to see consumer confidence in the car industry restored and that effective measures be taken to prevent a repeat of emissions measurement infringements.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I voted against this resolution. When speaking on this issue yesterday, I supposed the approach of its authors was based either on blind eyes or lies or double standards, but all three approaches come together in the characteristics of the events in Donbas and Luhansk described in paragraph 34, which was approved today. Which ‘temporarily occupied territories’ of Luhansk and Donetsk are you speaking about? Who are the occupiers? The local people are these ‘occupiers’, people in Donetsk whom the Kiev army is bombing. The journalist Ruslan Kotsaba who opposed mobilisation into this army is now in a Ukrainian prison. Do you think that the occupier is an 18-year-old girl called Julia from Donetsk who lost both feet and a hand when an artillery shell hit a trolley bus standing at a stop? I speak about one person because I personally watched her destiny and helped to get artificial limbs for her, but there are thousands of injured people like this and tens of thousands have lost their lives.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: I am a Hungarian man, a Hungarian MEP. So, when I have to vote on the Ukrainian Association Treaty, I would like to assess first and fore most the human rights of the Hungarian people living in the territory of the present Ukraine. With regard to Hungarians in Transcarpathia, it is not even possible to say the word national self-determination, that it is autonomy. Contrary to what we have said about Kosovo and the Serbs who live there. In fact, the European Union points out in all its relevant human rights documents that the right to national self-determination is a fundamental collective human right. If someone in the current Ukraine says that, or if the Hungarians have the right to self-determination, the right to autonomy, Ruthenian or... Otherwise, it's going to trigger some kind of shock reaction, punish the person. There have also been cases where MPs and others have been banned from Ukraine as a result. Therefore, freedom of expression is neither respected nor the right to national self-determination. In these circumstances, I voted against the Association Agreement.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Of course, there are also reasons not to vote in favour of this report on this economic agreement. It is, of course, a balancing process, what will be done? I am one of the optimists and I always say that economic cooperation is better than embargo policy. Economic cooperation also creates contacts and can also be a means of improving political and economic development. It is also essentially a question of creating hope in the countries concerned. And here I repeat myself, because I said earlier on Kosovo: that alone is worth agreeing to this matter. Economic cooperation promotes trust, promotes economic stability, and demarcation triggers the opposite. The question now is: are we now an optimist or a pessimist? I am rather optimistic. Nevertheless, we will of course have to follow the path and see what comes out of it at the end. I am also at the side of my colleagues, who always criticise this.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. As rapporteur for Georgia here in the European Parliament, and in general as someone following the activities of the Eastern Partnership in the European Parliament, I always look with great delight and joy at those activities that could bring Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia closer to the European Union. It is to be welcomed that there is free trade, that Moldovan citizens, very soon Georgian citizens and, I hope, Ukrainian citizens could travel visa-free to the European Union. But I voted with shared feelings today and voted against, because I want to understand why we only use such words, for example, against Russia. Do we really believe, colleagues, that Russia will give in and, having read another resolution, will go back to the European Union, apologise or do something else? We cannot build a constructive relationship with Russia if we use such words in our resolutions. That is why I voted against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the association and free trade agreement signed between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine is a recognition of the considerable progress made by these countries and is the logical and natural result of a path that began more than twenty years ago. These agreements are in everyone's interest and must also be a point of reference in our Eastern Partnership policy. Our partners must therefore continue along the path of reform in order to consolidate the rule of law and good governance and to boost the economic growth of the region. The European Union must work to maintain the political will within these countries and to promote effective coordination within each of the partner governments, in order to build a national consensus in favour of the measures necessary to ensure real and sustainable transformation. However, the Association Agreement cannot replace the momentum and political leadership within these countries. Key issues to be addressed to make the reform process an irreversible success include reforming judicial systems and improving efficiency and transparency in public administration.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I come from the Czech Republic, representing the Czech Republic, a country that has great experience, unfortunately tragic, from the period of communist totalitarianism. That is why I will always support Eastern Partnership projects and support any economic cooperation between the European Union and the countries of the former Soviet Union. For me, the reason is mainly geopolitical.  Russia never sleeps, and it is clear that it is very interested in strengthening its influence in the former countries of the Soviet Union, after all, we can see this today and on a daily basis, see the current problems that are now occur in Moldova. So it is necessary to offer an open hand to the countries of the former Soviet Union, to see them as partners, to want to cooperate with them and, despite the agreements that are on the table here, to improve their economic situation. But as I said, for me personally, the main reason is geopolitical, to be a partner with the former countries of the Soviet Union and not to put them on the defensive so that Russia is the only country that wants to communicate with them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution on the progress of the implementation of the Association Agreement with Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine. I did not support the proposals of the Communist Parties, which call into question the democratically elected government of Ukraine and ukraine's direction towards the European Union.  Unfortunately, I was unable to speak in the debate yesterday and thank the European Commission. This is not often, but this time the European Commission and Commissioner Hahn in particular have pleased me very much with their active approach to visa liberalisation, especially in the direction of Ukraine. I know that in Ukraine there is a great expectation, support and such impetus for greater energy for the reforms that Ukraine is implementing with this promise of visa liberalisation. I would like to thank the Commission and, in person, the Commissioner.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: I want to make it clear why I voted against it. This association agreement with Ukraine is not about free trade, but purely about geopolitical power. The European Union is playing a particularly dangerous game by interfering in this conflict and further turning countries against each other. If the European Union is so keen on free trade, let it remove barriers to trade against Russia. After all, the consequences for many European farmers are enormous. By supporting a contestable insurgency in Ukraine, people like Guy Verhofstadt have only exacerbated the problems and certainly did not serve occupied democracy.  Conclusion: free trade, yes, condemning violations of sovereignty, yes. But a hypocritical association agreement to prepare countries like Ukraine for EU membership and the introduction of a new cold war, no.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, on the sidelines, I note that I also voted in favour of this economic agreement, and these are indeed economic and economic issues that are linked to these association agreements. I do not want to question the right of national minorities, I think we should continue to monitor them, but these agreements are much more. On the other hand, in order for us here to properly lecture on how another state should be organised in terms of autonomy, I do not think that it belongs in this chamber.  But with regard to Kosovo and Moldova, I have my doubts about Moldova, because even in the light of the latest events – I will pick up on my colleague Pospisil – the question is whether we will become victims or spectators of developments, where Russian oligarchs are having sex in both Kosovo and Moldova and control both part of the governing coalition and undoubtedly part of the opposition. I think this is a very dangerous development, we should pay due attention to this.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the Resolution in favour of the Association Agreements and the broad and deep free trade agreements between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the conviction that the EU is following a policy of broad and profound enlargement of its geopolitical interests and the sphere of influence of the EU and NATO in the area with a desire for confrontation with Russia. These types of trade agreements already pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. In the case of Ukraine, much further afield, the eu's desire for expansion of the sphere of control has been the key factor in triggering the coup d'coup in Ukraine and the civil war in the country. Since my deep condemnation of escalating tensions with Russia and NATO's presence in the area, with my no vote I wanted to show my rejection of these agreements, which harm the local population and, even more, endanger peace in the region.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – On the motion for a resolution on the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) with Georgia-Ukraine-Moldova I voted against the joint motion for a resolution and in favour of the GUE resolution and all of the GUE amendments.  The GUE amendments and resolution focus on two things - the fact that the EU should not have such an agreement with Ukraine on the basis of anti-democratic government actions and abuses of human rights (such as child labour) and the negative impact of the agreement on working people and the poor in these countries. The role pushing this agreement plays in feeding conflict in the neighbourhood was another good reason to reject the Joint Motion for a Resolution.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I chose to abstain on this resolution because I believe that the final version of the resolution suffers from basic shortcomings. I agree that we need to support the Association Agreements and the positive effects they may have on both the three countries and the European Union, but I do not believe that we should limit ourselves to the trade part. On the contrary, I believe that these countries must also take many steps in the field of combating corruption, protecting freedom of expression and protecting human rights. Actions such as banning the Communist Party of Ukraine are unacceptable and must be condemned.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution announces the future accession of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to the EU. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we categorically oppose any further enlargement of this moribund Union. I therefore voted against it, especially since, as the report itself points out, these three countries are plagued by corruption!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in democracy and transparency, and therefore I believe that my vote on this matter should have been a matter of public record. In that spirit, I wish to confirm that I voted against this resolution.  The United Kingdom should be able to sign trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine without the interference of the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Association and free trade agreements with Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine provide a real opportunity for greater political and economic integration with the European Union and long-term stability, economic growth and the well-being of their populations. It is therefore essential that the proper implementation of these agreements is one of the main priorities of the European Union and the partner countries. Today, we can already welcome the Commission's conclusion that Georgia and Ukraine have already fulfilled all the objectives set out in the visa liberalisation plans, which demonstrates their determination to choose the path of European integration. In the light of this progress, the Council and the Member States must immediately fulfil the commitments made by the EU and grant them visa-free travel. Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine are critical eastern partnership countries and in the context of regional security, and we therefore look forward to closer cooperation in the field of conflict prevention and general security challenges, which is a key priority for the renewed Eastern Partnership.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine is in fact a free trade agreement, which lists on hundreds of pages how much of each country's products can be imported duty-free into the UNION. However, this is not the point, but the geopolitical importance of the Treaty, i.e. the break-up of these countries from the Eurasian Economic Area initiated by Russia. Moreover, the EU is well acquiesced to the fact that the preconditions for the agreement (including the rule of law) are not ensured in these countries. This agreement will result in an even greater economic crisis for the countries in question, because they will be cut off from the region where their industry is competitive (from the Russian market). As has been said, the proposal for a decision calling for the conclusion of the treaties was rejected for two reasons. On the one hand, I do not agree with the aggressive expansion of NATO and the EU in the east, because it is not good for us or for the countries on the eastern side of Europe. Moreover, the situation with the treaty and the Russian response to this will cause an economic catastrophe in Ukraine, if the current chaos can be exacerbated at all.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved the proposal to finalize association agreements with these three countries. This is a necessary step to stabilize these countries by strengthening their democratic system and developing their economic growth through deep economic exchanges. Particular attention will also be paid to combating social and environmental dumping practices.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme of the Eastern Partnership is undoubtedly one of the most important challenges for the future of Europe. Since the collapse of the USSR, there has been a constant commitment on the part of the Union to ensure that the countries of Eastern Europe are firmly in the group of democratic countries.  This continuous path today sees, with the association and free trade agreements between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, a further moment of development. I support this resolution because I am convinced that it is essential to continue along the path of a European Neighbourhood Policy based on the promotion of good governance, the consolidation of the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights.  Europe's commitment must be directed in particular towards developing the social dimension of the partnership, while promoting compliance with the commitments made by these countries in the field of work and the environment. The pro-European aspiration of states must be protected, which is why russia's operations to prevent closer relations between the EU, Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia must be countered. Finally, the agreements also represent a great opportunity in terms of improving judicial systems, combating corruption and organised crime; For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report by the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade on the Association Agreement for the Establishment of Free Trade Zones between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on the view that the report points to an asymmetric agreement that strengthens the perverse logics of neoliberal trade treaties, which seek liberalization as a single unrecovered end in human rights and social rights.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I have supported the Partnership Agreements/Free Trade Zones of broad and deep scope with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. However, In Amendment No 14, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to stop imports of goods in which children have participated or other human and social rights violations have been committed, I did not vote for the same as my group. I voted in favour of the amendment.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I opposed this resolution on association agreements and the comprehensive and comprehensive free trade area with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. These agreements arise with a view to the imminent accession of these three countries to the European Union. Apart from the fact that, in general, the principle of further enlargement of the Union does not seem to me to be relevant - given the multiple crises it is currently going through and the impossibility of carrying out a common policy efficiently effective at 28 - the three countries covered by this resolution pose additional problems: Ukraine is still experiencing a constitutional crisis and the text clearly shows the will to bring it into the Brussels fold to counter the influence of Russia; this is not only risky from a diplomatic point of view, but also dangerous for the country's prospects for stability. Finally, these agreements are established by the will of a single market, to which I am strongly opposed, since it would be established within the framework of global governance, to the detriment of the peoples and the freedom of sovereign nations.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Geringer De Oedenberg's report is balanced and contains ideas that I fully support, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution agreed with the various political groups on the basis of the Partnership Agreements and wide and deep free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which have been in place provisionally for months. The ratification process is nearing completion and this Resolution assesses the progress made to date and highlights the importance of finally implementing these agreements. With this Resolution, Parliament shows its support for the implementation of these Association Agreements and puts the focus both on the progress these agreements make in terms of their social dimension and their usefulness as instruments to demand greater efforts on legal certainty, the fight against corruption and the consolidation of democracy.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, the eastern partnership countries, have chosen the path of close political association and economic integration into the European Union through the state-of-the-art Association Agreement, which provides for the creation of comprehensive and comprehensive free trade spaces. In line with the association agreements, all three partners have committed themselves to promoting and implementing reforms based on the common values of democracy, good governance, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the rights of persons belonging to national minorities. The European Parliament stresses the importance of developing the social dimension of the Partnership, in line with the association's agendas and the relevant provisions of the International Labour Organisation conventions. Parliament also calls on all parties to honour their commitments on core labour standards, to exchange best practices and to continue their efforts to promote decent work and the transformation of the informal sector into formal work, to improve labour security standards, and to promote social dialogue and to make full use of trade union rights. Finally, Parliament stresses the importance of raising public awareness and visibility of the benefits of the Association Agreement, including through regular contacts with civil society organisations, and to simplify and promote objective, independent and impartial information on this issue.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have come a long way to engage in Democratic Reforms with a European spirit, breaking with the post-Russian operating system. This process has not yet been completed and new opportunities have been created for development and european progress through the Association Treaty with the European Union and the Free Trade Treaty. These three countries have declared a desire for closer political and economic integration with the European Union by starting to implement the reforms provided for by the EU and the Treaties, despite russia's constant political and economic pressures, but still have many tasks to do to become a democratic welfare state that respects human rights and international law. I welcome the progress made so far and voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the association agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine and the DEEP and comprehensive free trade treaty.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the global and in-depth association agreements/free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine represent important steps towards the economic integration of these three countries with the European market and that their ratification can create important opportunities for economic growth both for the countries in question and for the Union.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Freedom of trade and economic investment is important for the civil, economic and technological progress of individual States and for the well-being of their citizens, but this progress cannot be real and lasting unless it is accompanied by the strengthening of democracy, the protection of freedom of speech, participation in political and social life and respect for civil and human rights. The association and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are to be supported as they are essential for the contracting countries to continue their path of political independence, civil and democratic progress and their economic development.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Association Agreements and the creation of a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade area with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine constitute a real economic and geopolitical crime. These agreements are a prerequisite for these countries to join the European Union in the near future. The free trade area is already generating real economic and social dramas in Europe.  It should also be pointed out that in Moldova, for example, the monthly minimum wage is 43 euros. Moldova is 30% of the population living below the poverty line, but it is also an underground economy that accounts for 40% of GDP. Therefore, in the context of the Russian embargo, Georgia and Ukraine are real weapons of massive unfair competition for our farmers, who are struggling and facing difficulties in exporting their agricultural products. Of course, I voted against this outrageous report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union pursued a policy of expanding the sphere of economic and political influence in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine by signing association agreements, including deep and comprehensive free trade agreements.
