The three countries therefore opted for a policy of rapprochement with the Union, elaborating various ambitious reform programmes in many areas, such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine's approach to closer economic integration and policies with the European Union strengthens the three countries' efforts to approximate national laws to Union standards. Such an agreement therefore generates added value for the reform processes in these countries. I was in favour of this motion for a resolution, given that the Association and Deep-Fashion Agreements are a priority in the European Neighbourhood Policy, also having a fundamental role in ensuring good governance, democracy, the rule of law and the promotion of human rights.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. It is not surprising that there are many positive points on the GUE Group's amendments. The text of the joint resolution by the other groups is, in fact, highly open to criticism. It is a document that praises the EU's political activity in the Ukrainian scenario and the amendments tabled would tend to introduce a better balance. The association agreement with these areas will not only not bring economic and political results, but will also help to make even more unstable a geographical area of historical Russian influence, where the European institutions are making very serious mistakes. It is to be hoped that the consequences will not be irreversible. Respect for political, social and human rights, however, as a prerequisite for any agreement, is not respected in the countries with which the EU has established this type of political and trade relations.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution for this trade agreement as I disagree with the policy the EU has taken in extending its political and economic sphere to these countries without properly considering conflicts in the region, including the ramifications such a deal would have on other neighbouring countries and their relations with one another. On 1 January 2016 and in anticipation of this agreement, Russia cut the participation of Ukraine to the CIS free trade zone.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as I fully support Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in implementation of the trade agreements with the European Union. These agreements will integrate the three countries closer with the European Union and further help them with their economic reforms.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the joint resolution on global and in-depth association and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The text over-praises both the Commission's work and the efforts made by these countries in the context of their constitutional and democratic reforms. Ukraine still lacks a credible conflict of interest law, and the constitutional reforms that have been undertaken are also completely unsatisfactory. Furthermore, I believe that free trade agreements with these areas will not only not lead to the desired economic and political results, but will also contribute to fuelling even more a confrontation with Russia that is extremely harmful to our businesses. It is unthinkable to conclude agreements with former Soviet countries while continuing to exclude cooperation with Russia.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the motions for resolutions on association and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine because we know that these countries as a whole have ratified the association agreements with all their provisions for global and in-depth free trade areas. In this way they have chosen a path of deeper political and economic integration in the European Union, which goes through ambitious reforms in numerous areas, including democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights, and which is worth supporting.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote negatively on the motions for resolutions on association and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. I believe, in fact, that the implementation of the agendas for these agreements should not be considered a top priority for the Union. Such agreements could have a negative impact from the point of view of the Union's economy, but also with regard to social issues such as unemployment and immigration.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 As chairman of the Committee on Economic Integration of the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, I could not but vote in favour of these agreements, which are one of the steps on a long road to bringing these countries closer politically to Europe.  It is essential to have reliable and stable neighbours who do not export crime and political tensions but who can import our goods. I was in Moldova monitoring the 2014 general election, and I found a country that really needs us. There is still a long way to go, but I am pleased that this Parliament can confirm its willingness to move forward.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements, which include Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Areas, thus opting for further political and economic integration with the European Union and for carrying out ambitious reforms in many areas such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights. I support the intention of these countries and the technical and financial assistance that the Union has provided to these countries, and we must condemn the pressures of third states, such as Russia, to undermine the pro-European trajectory. I believe it is vital that the ongoing reform programme, in particular the judicial system, the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organised crime, should be pursued with determination, which should not be dissociated from civil society. To praise the participation of these countries in European programmes such as COSME, Erasmus +, Marie Sklodowska-Curie and Creative Europe, thus providing the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the Union's policies and working methods.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are countries that are at the earlye stage of a possible future association with the European Union, although unfortunately the very precarious situation, the political struggle and the lack of reforms are holding the whole region to a standstill.  I felt I had to vote in favour because I believe it is necessary to continue to strongly encourage the reform programme, particularly in the areas of justice, the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organised crime, as an important essential requirement for the socio-economic development of the three association countries.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The conclusion of the association agreement is part of the broader process of seeking closer cooperation with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. While democratic institutions in these countries may still be weak, the EU needs to play a role in facilitating the strengthening of these structures, even through trade agreements.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the Resolution in favour of the Association Agreements and the wide and deep free trade areas between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the conviction that the EU is following a policy of broad and profound enlargement of its geopolitical interests and the sphere of influence of the EU and NATO in the area with a willingness to confront Russia. These types of trade agreements already pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. In the case of Ukraine, much further afield, the eu's desire for expansion of the sphere of control has been the key factor in triggering the coup d'coup in Ukraine and the civil war in the country. Since my deep condemnation of escalating tensions with Russia and NATO's presence in the area, with my no vote I wanted to show my rejection of these agreements, which harm the local population and, even more, endanger peace in the region.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are the three Eastern Partnership (CI) countries that have signed and ratified association agreements and deep and comprehensive free trade agreements with the EU. All three countries are currently implementing their reform plans with varying degrees of success and depending on the circumstances. Unfortunately, they are also dealing with the occupation of parts of their territories in conflicts in which Russia plays a key role. In Georgia, you can have reservations about the independence of the judiciary, the repression of the political opposition and media freedom (the government's attempt to take over a television station). Moldova is facing a deep political crisis that has almost led to the blocking of reforms and could threaten the European direction taken by the country. Ukraine is embroiled in an armed conflict in the East with separatists actively supported by Russia.  I have always tried to support the European aspirations of the Eastern Partnership countries, and I welcome the progress made by these countries since the signing of the AA and the DCFTA. I also fully support the territorial integrity of all three countries. However, there remain some problems in the above-mentioned areas, which have not yet allowed me to vote in favour of the document. I hope that in the future (forthcoming) all three countries will be free from these ills for the benefit of their people.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I welcome the ratification of the various EU association agreements established with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The agreements encompass the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTA) and are an invaluable sign that different countries are willing to work towards their European Aspirations by ensuring that their national legislations reach the standards expected by the European Union within the commitments of the established agreement.  However, these agreements must come hand in hand with stronger rule of law, human rights safeguards, the possibility for parliamentary scrutiny to ensure the highest standard of democracy and greater efforts to seek peace in the region, especially in light of various internal and external conflicts with Russia, for the benefit of the countries’ own people and their safety.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the aspirations of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to continue their economic and political development and reform and their desire to create stronger ties with the rest of Europe. All sides can benefit from this positive progress in relations, and many businesses in the UK are already operating in or seeking to expand into these growing markets.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint resolution on global and in-depth association and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The positive response to european programmes and the considerable intensification of trade so far confirm that, despite recent developments in the three countries, we must continue to give firm support to the path they have taken towards ever closer rapprochement with the European Union, both from a commercial and political point of view. The main objective of these agreements is to help the reform process in various areas and to further facilitate its stabilisation. The resolution stresses the need to push for the strengthening of the rule of law and the fight against corruption, but above all to take action to ensure that the partners strengthen their will to bring about real structural changes, which primarily benefit the living conditions of citizens. That is why it will be important to continue to monitor the progress of reforms and the full implementation of association and free trade agreements.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution looks at the progress made by Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the signing of association and free trade agreements with the EU. Taking stock of the political and judicial improvements in the three countries since 2014, the European Parliament considers that Russia must stop getting directly or indirectly involved in the conflicts in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, and interfere with their European aspirations. It welcomes the increase in trade but calls for more effort with regard to reforms related to the independence of the media and the judicial system in particular. Considering that this resolution is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. One year after the ratification of the association and free trade agreements between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, there has been a tightening of economic and trade ties with these countries in the eastern neighbourhood. While progress in terms of economic development and stability can be welcomed, reforms remain to be made in the area of individual freedoms and human rights and within certain state institutions. In Ukraine, corruption remains endemic. In Georgia, the judicial system is not sufficiently independent, as evidenced by the lack of transparency in the appointment of prosecutors and investigators. In Moldova, it is the financial sector that needs to be completely overhauled. Naturally, the European Union will continue to provide assistance to these countries as progress is made in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and the fight against corruption. At the same time, there is an urgent need to convince Russia not to interfere in the conflicts in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, and to interfere with their European aspirations. Finally, it must be remembered that this rapprochement and closer cooperation with these countries does not presage systematic accession to the European Union.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. These agreements are in line with a further enlargement of the European Union, in this case to the three countries concerned, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. In addition, they condemn Russia for destabilizing these countries and, on the other hand, refer to an attack on the sovereignty of these three countries. Being opposed to further enlargements of the European Union, which already has 28 members, and not associating me with the double discourse of the European Union on the sovereignty of States, which is invoked only when it concerns external countries, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreement/Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine requires the Parties to implement comprehensive political and economic reforms, providing preferential access to the Union internal market and better conditions for cooperation in return. The resolution in question looks at the progress of these three countries over the past year. The undisputed champion between them is Georgia, which will soon receive visa liberalization. But many more democratic problems remain unresolved, such as the independence of the courts, media freedom and the repression of the opposition. Moldova is in a severe political crisis that threatens the process of European integration and the implementation of reforms. Ukraine is also trying to reform its system and tackle organised crime, corruption and a difficult economic environment. I supported the European Parliament resolution because I believe that it comprehensively presents the problems of these countries and provides key recommendations for the process of their reform and Europeanintegration.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Racism and anti-Russianism in the European Union are reflected in the lines of this text. In an effort to raise an "anti-missile shield" policy around Russia, the European Union is funding and concluding agreements with ukraine's coup d'government. Completely ignoring the consequences that such methods may have on the economies of its southern Member States, the European Union is strengthening and trying to integrate some of Europe's most corrupt and economically weak countries into its ranks.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. I welcome the European Parliament resolution on the Association Agreements and The Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which I voted in favour of. I believe that these Agreements can contribute to strengthening these countries' commitment to good governance, democracy, the rule of law and human rights, representing greater political and economic rapprochement with the European Union. I abstained, however, in the share vote on paragraph 31, part 2. I support Ukraine's position in the present trade disputes with Russia, which result from the unilateral suspension by Ukraine of the Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine and the impediment to the transit of goods from third countries in breach of WTO agreements. Nevertheless, I believe that future disputes between those two countries should be examined on a case-by-case basis before the European Union has taken a decision to support the WTO.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements (AA), which include Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Areas (FTAA), thus opting for further political and economic integration with the European Union and for carrying out ambitious reforms in many areas such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights. The three countries have been making efforts to ensure that national legislation approaches EU standards on the basis of commitments under the agreements. I agree that the success of these efforts depends on many factors, such as a stable political environment, strategic reflection, concrete reform plans and a good use of international financial and technical support.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The dramatic development swellof the situation in Ukraine, resulting from the destabilisation and escalation of violence triggered following the announcement of the suspension of the signing of the association agreement with the EU in November 2013. A coup d'état has been carried out, promoted by the most retrograde sectors of the Ukrainian oligarchy with the support of the US and the EU, which want to secure Ukraine's political, economic and military dominance by continuing NATO's expansion along the border of the Russian Federation. This represents an increased threat to security and peace in Europe and the world. The advance and consolidation of xenophobic, fascist and neo-Nazi forces in Ukraine, which disrespect and trample on rights and freedoms, is extremely serious. All this is omitted by the resolution. As the recent decision of the Kiev Administrative Court to illegalise the Communist Party of Ukraine is omitted. This motion for a resolution extending to Georgia and Moldova is another step in the EU's imperial-area strategy, with the use of Association Agreements and Free Trade Areas which, under the pretext of so-called "European integration", effectively seek to impose harmful and serious economic and political conditions on these countries. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ we have established the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership to ensure peace, stability and prosperity in Europe. Instruments promoting democracy, the rule of law or sustainable economic development are intended to do so. The Association Agreements have been in force for a year now and the creation of a deep and comprehensive free trade area between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine represents a significant advantage emerging from the association agreements, as they have a significant impact on the growth of economies or job creation. Associated countries are making considerable progress in a number of areas, but in all three countries democratic institutions are still weak. The conclusion of association agreements should not be the ultimate objective, but rather part of the process to achieve deeper cooperation between the European Union and the countries concerned.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports in their entirety because racism and anti-Russianism in the EU are pervasive in the lines of this text. In an effort to raise an "anti-missile shield" policy around Russia, the EU funds and concludes agreements with ukraine's coup government. Completely ignoring the consequences that such actions may have on the economies of its southern Member States, the Union is strengthening and trying to integrate into its ranks some of the most corrupt and economically weak countries in Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of association agreements and I would like more attention to be paid to the social dimension of the partnership. I believe that more efforts are needed in the area of the rule of law, in the fight against corruption, and in strengthening democracy. It is the right of these countries and their citizens to choose their own path, as long as it is to European values, to democracy and the market economy, to respect human rights and freedom, to the rule of law and the independence of justice, and not to an authoritarian-dictatorial, Asian-style regime. The Republic of Moldova is an entity belonging to European culture, South-Eastern European space. This policy of confrontation promoted from eastern Europe is neither in the interest of Europe nor in that country.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it emphasises the importance of the Union's commitment to the countries of the Eastern Partnership. In the resolution, we welcome the progress made by Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, and we recall that the implementation of the association and comprehensive free trade agreements must remain a priority for the Union and these three countries.  We welcome the financial and technical assistance provided by the Union, while stressing that the Union's financial support must be contingent on concrete reforms, particularly in the areas of justice and the rule of law.  Finally, it is important to include these agreements within the broader framework of strengthening our partnership, which must address both political dialogue and priority areas, ranging from employment to energy, security, conflict prevention and the fight against terrorism.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The eu's priority is the security, stability and economic prosperity of the countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus and the consolidation of democracy and the rule of law. In June 2008, the European Council invited the Commission to draw up a proposal for an Eastern Partnership with a view to supporting regional cooperation and improving relations between the EU and its eastern neighbours. I welcome the EU's commitment to develop close, differentiated and mutually beneficial cooperation with all six countries within the framework of the Eastern Partnership, regardless of what motivates each country in their relations with the EU.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements, which include wide and deep free trade areas, thus opting for greater political and economic integration with the EU and undergoing ambitious reforms in many areas, such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights , of which we must be very pleased, as the progress of our neighbours has a favourable impact on the well-being and prosperity of the EU.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I shared the structure of the joint motion for a resolution tabled pursuant to Article 123 of the Regulation on Global and In-Depth Association and Free Trade Agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.  I believe, in fact, that in recent years these countries have made important efforts towards building a path of political and economic integration with the European Union, demonstrating their willingness to implement ambitious reforms in the field of democracy, the rule of law and human rights.  I agree with the reference to the need to ensure their full territorial integrity and national sovereignty, especially in view of the fact that the states in question have democratically chosen to establish closer relations with the EU and that this free choice cannot be pressured by third countries.   Finally, I welcome the participation of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in EU programmes, such as COSME, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus Plus, which will give many young people, entrepreneurs and researchers the opportunity to get to know the EU more closely and learn about European best practices.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Association Agreement and deep and comprehensive free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. It is precisely the unrest in Moldova that shows us how important it is for these countries to be closely linked to the EU. A link that is not necessarily directed against Russia – but that builds bridges to strengthen democracy, a market economy, and the rule of law in Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report by the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade on the Association Agreement for the Establishment of Free Trade Zones between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on the view that the report points to an asymmetric agreement that strengthens the perverse logics of neoliberal trade treaties, which seek liberalization as a single unrecovered end in human rights and social rights.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of this report. The S&D Group fully supports the implementation of the association agreements. We call for greater attention to be paid to the social dimension of the partnership. We insist on the need for more efforts in the field of the rule of law, the fight against corruption, and the consolidation of democracy.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The EU has pursued a policy of expanding its economic and political sphere of influence in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine through the signing of association agreements, including comprehensive and in-depth free trade agreements, without ever taking into account trade relations and the historical interdependence of these countries' economies with the economies of other countries in the region, including Russia. Our group calls for the annulment of the three agreements, which we have also opposed in the past and which have proved negative for the well-being of the people and for peace in the region. We call for new forms of cooperation between the EU and the Eurasian Economic Union. We strongly condemn NATO's role and expansion in the region. With respect to Ukraine, we call for the implementation of the Minsk agreements and oppose the EU's trade policy. With a connection with Moldova, we call for the release of political prisoners and an end to austerity. With a connection with Georgia, we call for the normalisation of the country's relations with Russia. For all these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it welcomes the efforts made by Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in ensuring that national legislation approximates EU standards based on AA/DCFTA commitments. It additionally points out that success in doing this depends on many factors, including a stable political environment, strategic thinking, concrete plans for reforms, and good use of financial and technical international support. Funds which are made available must be spent well, and by themselves they are not enough to stabilise the economy, nor can any sustainable success be achieved without the continued commitment of the partners to bringing forward and implementing structural reforms, ensuring a rise in domestic demand, and achieving social cohesion. The association countries have freely chosen to establish a deeper relationship with the EU and that choice must be fully respected and be free from pressure by any third party. The actions taken by Russia to undermine or derail the pro-European course taken by the three association countries should be condemned.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This Resolution of the European Parliament advocates the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU on the one hand and Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia on the other. This creates new business opportunities for German companies in these countries. I am also convinced that free trade with the EU will generate a positive impetus for development in these countries. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We welcome the expansion of this market, but we are opposed to full membership of these countries within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the efforts made by Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in taking the necessary measures towards meeting EU standards for association agreements/deep and comprehensive free trade agreements (AA/DCFTA). I also believe that the AA/DCFTA provisions regarding energy cooperation are of great importance in order to ensure the development of competitive, transparent and non-discriminatory energy markets in line with EU rules and standards.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a resolution of association agreements/Agreements on deepened and comprehensive free trade with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which represent for these countries a turning point in their path towards European integration. This is particularly important due to the fact that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have been affected by protracted conflicts aimed at undermining sovereignty and territorial integrity. This supports the objective of the Agreement to significantly deepen political, social and economic relations between Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and the EU and contribute to improving the lives of citizens in areas such as education, employment, justice and increasing living standards and the safety of citizens through the implementation of these treaties. They welcome the efforts of these countries in their efforts to bring national legislation closer to EU standards and to emphasise the role civil society can play in raising public awareness and adopting the necessary reforms. In the case of Ukraine, the vote is welcomed in the first reading of constitutional amendments related to decentralisation, and expresses concern about deep-rooted corruption. Georgia's case recalls the need to strengthen the rule of law and separate state institutions from the influence of the current ruling political forces, and Moldova expresses concern over the political crisis engulfing the country following the fall of the government formed in July 2015, which is damaging the European perspective.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This resolution announces the future accession of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to the EU. However, together with my colleagues on the National Front, we are opposed to any further enlargement of this moribund Union. Moreover, these new accessions are all the more unwelcome since the resolution itself recognises that these three countries are plagued by corruption. Finally, this resolution is a new affront to Russia, or even yet another provocation by the EU. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such my fellow colleagues and I voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine I voted in favour of the resolution on the deep and comprehensive Association and Free Trade Area agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. One year after the ratification of the three comprehensive and comprehensive association and free trade agreements with the EU, the resolution specifies the reforms that still need to be adopted in those countries that wish to move closer to the European Union. It also takes note of the Dutch referendum on the EU-Ukraine agreement on 6 April. This resolution has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which notes and validates the fact that the Union, Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova have signed association and free trade agreements that deepen relations between the European Union and those countries that have made the most efforts in the areas of human law, good governance, the rule of law and democracy within the Eastern Partnership. The report also calls on Russia to stop being directly or indirectly involved in the conflicts of these three countries.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova today face the same challenges that Estonia faced in the 1990s. We, too, had to build a modern rule of law, eradicate corruption and build an open society, without prior experience.  Estonia was successful for two reasons. Firstly, we had the courage and willingness to take radical decisions. Secondly, we had enough supporters outside Estonia who helped us with advice and strength.  Political will or popular support is needed to make change. Without it, the aid on the show will not be of much use. When concluding association agreements, we recognise the efforts of Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova. More importantly, we are showing that we are ready to support them in carrying out reforms. Believe me, it's important to work hard.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this resolution. A forced approach to the EU has triggered the chaos in Ukraine, which ended with the secession of Crimea. Now, other countries with similar territorial problems, such as Moldova with Transnistria and Georgia with Abkhazia, are to follow a similar path, at a time when European-Russian relations are at a new low. In my opinion, such an approach is far from responsible and effective.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it recommends that the reforms related to the association agreements and deep and comprehensive free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are continued and enhanced. The report underlines that political stability und concrete reform programmes are necessary if the EU’s eastern neighbours want to benefit fully from their association agreements.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. This Resolution of the European Parliament advocates the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU on the one hand and Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia on the other. This creates new business opportunities for German companies in these countries. I am also convinced that free trade with the EU will provide a positive impetus for development in these countries. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We welcome the expansion of this market, but we are opposed to full membership of these countries within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support the resolution on association agreements and deep and comprehensive free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The efforts made in recent years by association countries to adapt their rules and procedures are of great importance for the future of these countries, as they deepen the process of integration into the EU in economic, legal, social and political terms. However, in view of the geopolitical situation, maintaining a pro-European course is becoming an increasing challenge; in Moldova in particular, the political and economic crisis has deepened and the country has been on the brink of bankruptcy.  In this context, visa liberalisation between the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries is one of those concrete benefits that helps to convince citizens of a good balance of pro-European choice. Visa-free travel facilitates contacts and helps to gain experience and develop infrastructure, communication and business – crucial for the proper implementation of association agreements.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the resolution on the association agreements/deep and comprehensive free trade agreements (AA/DFCTA) with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. These are crucial times for the Eastern Partnership (EaP) countries facing huge internal and external challenges and pressures. They chose the path of European reforms and Parliament with this resolution reaffirms its continuous and unwavering support. Corruption remains the main challenge to reforms, development and societal change; efforts in this regard must be significantly stepped up. The Minsk Agreements must be implemented without any further delay, Crimea occupied by Russia must be returned, the Russian military must leave Ukrainian territory at once – this is the prerequisite for easing the sanctions. However, the most recent Russian full-scale trade retaliatory measures against Ukraine only prove that Moscow still has not changed its habits of pressurising and destabilising its neighbours.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The resolution on free trade agreements with Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia takes a far too positive view of these agreements. The one signed with Ukraine has set fire to the powder in this country and destroyed a Ukrainian economy that will be unable to cope with European competition. The economic and social situation in that country is catastrophic, as Ukraine cannot compensate for the loss of the Russian market for its companies; and yet this text calls for further integration of Ukraine into the European market. In these circumstances, I refuse to be part of the complacency of this text on agreements which have led to a merciless struggle for influence between the European Union and Russia, and which calls for further sanctions against Russia. I therefore voted against this text and preferred the resolution of my group which denounces the EU's eagerness to sign these agreements, without measuring the catastrophic consequences of the struggle for influence they would trigger with a revanchist Russia. Ukraine is now economically on its knees and needs help first rather than subjecting it to competition from the European market or to the remedies advocated by the IMF.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on association agreements and the deep and comprehensive free trade area with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. These association agreements are a turning point towards the European integration of these countries. The text stresses that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine can apply for EU membership, and also welcomes the visa-free policy for nationals of Georgia and Ukraine. It calls for an "information" campaign aimed at the public to show all the benefits of these agreements and neighbourhood policy, and to respond to "propaganda" and "denigration". You think you're dreaming. This resolution goes in a way that is contrary to our interests and even to the interests of these countries.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it announces the future accession of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to the EU. However, I am against any new membership on principle. These are all the more unwelcome because the resolution recognises that these three countries are plagued by corruption. But is this really a flaw for the EU? Finally, this resolution is unnecessarily insolent towards Russia and will be felt by this great country as a new provocation from the EU.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the favourable resolution of the Association Agreements and the wide-ranging and deep free trade areas between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the conviction that the EU is following a policy of broad and profound enlargement of its geopolitical interests and the sphere of influence of the EU and NATO in the area with a desire for confrontation with Russia. These types of trade agreements already pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. In the case of Ukraine, much further afield, the eu's desire for expansion of the sphere of control has been the key factor in triggering the coup d'coup in Ukraine and the civil war in the country. Since my deep condemnation of the escalation of tensions with Russia and NATO's presence in the area, with my no vote I wanted to show my rejection of these agreements, which harm the local population and, even more, endanger peace in the region.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. This Resolution of the European Parliament advocates the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU on the one hand and Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia on the other. This creates new business opportunities for German companies in these countries. I am also convinced that free trade with the EU will provide a positive impetus for development in these countries. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We welcome the expansion of this market, but we are opposed to full membership of these countries within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The resolution calls on countries to ratify, thereby interfering in the internal affairs of states. The agreement with Ukraine itself is poorly written and subverts Ukrainian society. If the agreement is rejected by a referendum in the Netherlands, a better agreement should be negotiated, which would really only be free trade.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Association Agreement as well as on deepened and comprehensive free trade with these states supports territorial integrity and democratic institutions. Also, the agreements call on the Russian Federation to abandon its occupation of Crimea, and to halt direct or indirect participation in the conflict in Ukraine, as well as in the currently frozen conflicts in Moldova and Georgia. I supported the motion for a resolution since it is necessary to ensure freedom of the media, speech, free elections and democratic institutions in these countries, which these agreements allow.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on association agreements and areas of global and in-depth free trade with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 20 January 2016 but also for the shortcomings of this text, which cannot be considered complete either , nor documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against these motions for a resolution. The important point to remember is that these three countries, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, can apply for EU membership. The rapporteur calls for an information campaign aimed at the public to demonstrate the benefits of these agreements and neighbourhood policy, and to respond to "propaganda" and "denigration". We strongly oppose the opening up of the EU to the east, especially to countries as fragile and divided as these three.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 I support the motion for a resolution in which we urged Russia from the European Parliament to stop intervening in the affairs of Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine and their relations with the EU. We also call on these three countries to persist in their agenda of political and economic reforms.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on association agreements and comprehensive and comprehensive free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The resolution reiterates, among other things, that the EU strongly supports the territorial integrity of all these countries, respects their choice to take a democratic path and reiterates its commitment to providing them with diverse financial and technical support for political, economic and institutional reforms. The resolution also sets out the main lines of reform that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine should pursue in order to strengthen their democratic political system and ensure the rule of law.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Through these association agreements, the EU offers its eastern neighbours comprehensive political co-operation and economic integration without EU membership. The EU’s eastern neighbours need to implement far-reaching reforms in the economic and trade sector, as well as in legal approximation in order to benefit fully from this offer of co-operation. The more reforms take place, the more benefits will be generated by the association agreements and the deep and comprehensive free trade agreements. This means that these agreements constitute an ambitious programme for modernisation, which is why the EU also offers financial and technical support to help implement them. In its resolution, the European Parliament underlines that political stability and concrete reform programmes are necessary if Georgia, Moldova und Ukraine want to benefit fully from their association agreements.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This resolution takes a position on the free trade agreements being finalised with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, following the provisional implementation of the agreement with The Latter since 1 January 2016. Yes, the EU applies agreements before ratification of all the states, including the Netherlands, which will hold a referendum on 6 April on this subject, and before the approval of this House.  The preparatory "structural" reforms demanded of Ukraine have had their effect: inflation at 43.3%, a quarter of the population has fallen below the poverty line and external debt has doubled in 2 years. In Moldova, the IMF and this Parliament are calling for a new government to carry out these same reforms. It does not matter that these countries do not respect the basics of the rule of law and that the oligarchy feeds endemic corruption. The EU is not so much driven here by a desire for economic annexation as by purely geopolitical and offensive motives of war on Russia and its Eurasian Union. I vote against this bellicose policy which has already shown that it is even accommodating neo-Nazis in power.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This resolution announces the future accession of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to the EU. However, together with my colleagues on the National Front, we are opposed to any further enlargement of this moribund Union. Moreover, these new accessions are all the more unwelcome since the resolution itself recognises that these three countries are plagued by corruption. Finally, this resolution is a new affront to Russia, or even yet another provocation by the EU. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in agreement with the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on association agreements and comprehensive and deep free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Association agreements are essential for consolidating reforms, respecting the rule of law and strengthening economic growth.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution regarding the Association Agreements and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements with Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine. The resolution acknowledges the strides forward the Georgian, Moldovan and Ukrainian Governments have made in ensuring that national legislation approximates EU standards.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The association agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are, in my view, essential because they provide a clear framework for our relations with these three countries. The EU's support for them in the implementation of these agreements is essential for their stability. Moreover, these agreements also demonstrate a long-term policy for stability, prosperity and democracy on the European continent. In particular, the agreement between the EU and Ukraine, while representing a whole series of stumbling blocks with Russia, is a fundamental mechanism to encourage the promotion of human rights in Ukraine and a solid basis for strengthening our trade relations.  In general, these agreements create a framework for cooperation whose usefulness is no longer to be defended. These stimulate the strengthening of the rule of law and give impetus to the fight against corruption, two essential parameters in the context of the reforms undertaken by these countries for their stability. Efforts are still to be made, and we welcome the european Parliament's general willingness to encourage these three countries to go further in these reforms.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The Eastern Partnership was established in 2009 as a joint effort by the European Union and its Eastern European partners to link political and economic integration on the basis of common interests. The Eastern Partnership states are committed to upholding the rule of law and democracy and upholding both fundamental human rights and market economy principles. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have concluded association agreements with the European Union, including a deep and comprehensive free trade area. I am of the opinion that these agreements, which can help these countries achieve their stated objectives, must be respected and do not create further unnecessary conflicts by denying them.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ As Rapporteur for Moldova and Shadow Rapporteur for Georgia in the INTA Committee, I welcome this resolution and its emphasis on our trade relations with those countries and, of course, also with Ukraine. The EU is a key trading and economic partner for them, and it therefore plays an important role in their development. The DCFTAs, if properly implemented, will generate jobs and will bring significant improvements to the living conditions of their people. The resolution highlights the positive results in terms of exports to the EU during the first 12 months of the DCFTAs’ implementation for Georgia and Moldova. I expect the DCFTA with Ukraine to achieve similar results. However, the three countries must continue to pursue their reform agenda in the areas of judiciary, the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organised crime, to which I personally attach absolute priority in the institutional arena. These reforms will allow the countries to maximize and consolidate the economic benefits deriving from the full implementation of the DCFTAs. Their economic integration through trade and investment with the EU is the only real mid-to-long—term source of social, economic, political and institutional dynamism and structural change for – hopefully – the better.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Six political groups on the subject indicated: Verts/ALE, PPE, ALDE, ECR, S&D and GUE/NGL submitted motions for resolutions. With the exception of the GUE/NGL, the other five political groups have reached an agreement on the content of the resolution. I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The EU Association Agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are another step towards the integration of these countries which will be able to apply for membership. In addition, the report condemns Russia's so-called policy of destabilizing these countries. At the same time, it is concerned in Ukraine about corruption, expectations of freedom of expression, and the non-application of the Minsk II agreements; in Georgia, the bias of the judiciary, the lack of independence of the judiciary and the pressure on the Constitutional Court; and in Moldova, the absence of a stable government, corruption, the state of the financial system, and the behaviour of some Moldovan politicians.  We therefore oppose this resolution, which is contrary to the interests of this country as well as our own.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements, which include Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Zones, demonstrating their intention to deepen political and economic integration with the European Union and to carry out reforms in various areas such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights. It is important to highlight the efforts of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to ensure that their national legal systems are closer to European Union rules. However, I argue that it is essential to continue with the reform programme, in particular in the areas of the judicial system, the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organised crime, which are elementary contexts for the socio-economic development of the countries concerned. This proposal reflects in detail the political, economic and social landscape of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine and, for the above, i have my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution is contrary to our interests and the interests of the countries concerned. Indeed, it proposes applications for membership of these three countries, welcomes their gradual integration into the EU.  The application of these association agreements risks mechanically provoking territorial partitions in fragile and divided states. The natural bedrock of these states is the immediate Russian neighbourhood, like it or not.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, which once again contributes to the sterile escalation of tensions with Russia. In particular, the text calls on the EU to assist Ukraine in its current and future disputes with Russia at the WTO.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Unable to attend the votes held on Thursday 21 January, I would like to express my support for the resolution on the Association and Free Trade Area Agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which guarantee greater European aid to these countries, including part of the territories of South Ossetia and Abkhazia respectively. , Transdrestria, Crimea and eastern Ukraine, remains de facto autonomous and fuels political and economic destabilization.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will bring Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine onto the path of closer political and economic integration with the European Union, undergoing reforms in numerous areas such as human rights, good governance, and the rule of law and democracy.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Association Agreements/Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements with Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. As S&D ITRE coordinator, I stress the importance of energy cooperation, security of supply and the development of competitive, transparent and non-discriminatory energy markets, in line with EU rules and standards, as well as renewable energy and energy efficiency. The EU wants to strengthen the full integration of Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia into the energy market through the Energy Community. The EU's active support and solidarity in the field of energy has enabled Russia to resume gas supplies to Ukraine in the winter of 2015-16. Thus, Member States should make full use of Ukraine's transit potential, strengthen their cooperation to ensure the energy supply of both the EU and Ukraine, and avoid the construction of new gas pipelines from Russia to Europe that bypass Ukraine, which could have a negative impact on the EU's energy diversification strategy and EU legislation. I support the EU's intention to promote Ukraine's full integration into the energy market through the Energy Community and to reduce energy dependency without overburdening private households.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Association Agreement with Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine because I believe it is very important for the European Union to continue cooperation with these Eastern Partnership states, despite pressure from the Russian Federation.  In the context of events and progress in the three countries, I support efforts to increase collaboration with them, to encourage and support their development and stability, both economically and democratically and socially.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a resolution evaluating the last first year of the association agreements. On the one hand, the progress made by all three states in the field of reform must be highlighted, but, on the other hand, the shortcomings and ailments that remain cannot be left out. While Ukraine continues to face growing corruption, the problem in Georgia is the tendency to slide into russia's sphere of influence, and Moldova is not doing very well to break out of political instability. However, I believe that, despite the continuing difficulties, all three partner states are well on their way to the EU and, with our strong help, can persevere on this path.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given the pressure on the EU's cooperation with the Eastern Partnership countries, it is essential that EU countries that have not yet ratified the Association Agreements do so as soon as possible. As regards Georgia and Ukraine, the introduction of visa liberalisation should be moved quickly. Moldova's political crisis is worrying, hopefully finding a way to resolve the situation without jeopardising the country's economy and progress in terms of reforms.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I begin by expressing my support for the efforts already made by the institutions of these countries. Considering that the opening up of new markets makes our economies grow and bearing in mind that the European Union is one of the most open economies in the world. It is in our interest to lead Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on a path towards European integration. For these reasons, and in the hope that progress towards globalisation will continue, I would vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are part of a strategic block from a political, geographic and economic point of view. The EU, now more than ever, should continue investing in giving this region the benefits of the fundamental values of the EU and helping in achieving structural reforms. The steps towards the implementation of association and deep and comprehensive free trade agreements are key building blocks in the comprehensive approach strategy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on association agreements/areas of deepened and comprehensive free trade with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, as I believe that the European Union needs to work actively towards political and economic rapprochement with all Eastern Partnership countries, especially these three countries with which we have already made significant progress. While these countries need to make further efforts to implement agreed reforms, it is important that we send them a clear and unequivocal message that their path to European integration is open. I also believe that the European Union must take additional measures to ensure the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which has been severely undermined. Without a solution to these problems, it will be impossible to create a stable region in the long term that could actively cooperate with the European Union.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In the first 12 months of applying the agreement on deepened comprehensive free trade, Georgia's exports to the EU increased by 15% and Moldova by as much as 62%. Favourable results are also expected for Ukraine. But as for other trade agreements, I think free trade must be monitored by the free movement of people. The conditions have been met and there is no reason why visas for citizens of Ukraine and Georgia should not be revoked. In addition to declaratively political, the European Union should also economically assist eastern partnership countries, with strict supervised implementation. But the key to the relationship to the Eastern Partnership countries is the European Union's relationship to Russia. With all three countries, Russia is conflicted, whether it's the annexation of Crimea, the occupation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, or the issue of Trans-Ingentria. Following european union sanctions on Russia and Russian sanctions on Ukraine following the implementation of this agreement, the EU-Ukraine-Russia trilateral dialogue is extremely necessary and necessary. In addition to relations with Russia, particular attention should be paid to the situation in Moldova where the upcoming elections could have significant implications for foreign policy orientation. In conclusion, I hope that the upcoming referendum in the Netherlands will not further impede Ukraine's already difficult enough European path.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on association agreements and agreements on a deep and comprehensive free trade area with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which is necessary for their full implementation. Through these agreements, there will be political and economic convergence with financial and technical support from the European Union for the implementation of far-reaching reforms. The governments of Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine have been criticised for their lack of accountability to certain elements of democracy, such as freedom of expression, good governance and overall political stability, thereby jeering the democratisation of their countries. However, this is no reason to hinder their integration. On the contrary, we should open the door for them to take advantage of the offer of constructive cooperation with the European Union, which will help to socialise and modernise them. We must realise that association agreements and free trade area agreements do not serve political elites, but have a deep social dimension, as they will serve the needs of the citizens here by help to increase their standard of living. It is not only in our interest, but also in our responsibility to strive for stability and peace in the Eastern Neighbourhood. That is why I have also supported macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in the past with the decision to confer implementing powers on the Commission. These are the first steps by which the Union shows that it is aware of the problems of neighbouring countries and is willing to provide them with assistance to overcome them.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider this resolution to be extremely important. I am very happy for the efforts of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to ensure the convergence of national legislation with EU standards based on commitments under the AA/DCFTA. I believe that parliamentary oversight is an essential condition for democratic support for EU policy and it is necessary to enable the European Parliament to monitor the application of the AA/DCFTA regularly and in detail. I express my unequivocal support for the territorial integrity of all three countries and stress the fact that the associated countries have freely decided to establish deeper relations with the EU and that their choice must be fully respected, moreover, it is important to recall that Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union states that any European state can apply for EU membership if it is guided by the principles of democracy, respects fundamental freedoms and human rights and minority rights, and ensures the rule of law. I am pleased that dcfta between the EU and Ukraine entered into force on 1 January 2016, and I also welcome the progress made in Georgia, where progress has been made over the last three years in all areas covered by the four blocs of the Visa Liberalisation Action Plan. At the same time, however, I cannot express serious concern about the de facto systemic political instability in Moldova, when the country's institutions are at risk of being destabilised and when the economy is at risk, which has a major impact on the inflow of foreign direct investment.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Association Agreements (AA) / Free and Comprehensive and Deep Trade Zones concluded with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine (FTAA) institutionalised the European aspirations of the signatories, establishing a new framework for contractual relations between the parties. This new generation of agreements includes provisions on future trade relations, but is not limited to economic designs. In the light of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), the European Commission has negotiated comprehensive agreements to ensure that legal systems other than associates are gradually approaching EU standards. Thus, through concrete reforms introduced in exchange for Community financial support, national legislation is guaranteed to bring national legislation closer to the values (good governance, democracy, rule of law and human rights) enshrined in the Treaties. In this scenario of cooperation, support for Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine is also the defence of the Union's values. This resolution reiterates the economic and social aid already contemplated by the AA/CLAFT AFTA and also confirms support for the territorial integrity of the three countries of the association harmed by russia's continued direct or indirect interference. In view of the above, I supported with my vote the resolution of the European Parliament here.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP did not support the ratification of Association Agreements with Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova. The signing of these agreements contributed to increased tensions between the EU and Russia and contributed to the increased insecurity in eastern Europe and the Caucasus. They are also seen as a step towards future EU membership. As such we voted against. UKIP were however pleased to note that Amendment 17 called for the EU to ensure that the upcoming vote in the Netherlands on the EU-Ukraine Agreement is respected.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements (AA), which include Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Areas (FTAA), thus opting for further political and economic integration with the European Union and for carrying out ambitious reforms in many areas such as democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights.  I welcome the presentation of this report which stresses the importance of the Association Agreements as well as the progress made to date and insists that AA/LAFTA and its association programmes should be at the top of the priorities of the EU and the three partners. Furthermore, the report strongly underlines support for the territorial integrity of the three countries, calling on the Russian Federation to end the occupation of Crimea and immediately suspend any participation in the current conflict in Ukraine, as well as in the latent conflicts in Georgia and Moldova. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The efforts of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to ensure that national legislation approaches EU standards on the basis of commitments under the Association and Free Trade Agreements are clear. The success of these efforts depends on many factors, such as a stable political environment, strategic reflection, concrete reform plans and a good use of international financial and technical support. I would like to remind you that EU financial support to all its partners is conditional on concrete reform measures. These countries have freely chosen to establish a deeper relationship with the EU and their choice must be fully respected and not subject to pressure from third parties.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution agreed with the various political groups on the broad and deep-reaching Association Agreements/Free Trade Areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which have been in place provisionally for months. The ratification process is nearing completion and this Resolution assesses the progress made to date and highlights the importance of implementing these agreements definitively. With this Resolution, Parliament shows its support for the implementation of these Association Agreements and focuses both on the progress these agreements make in terms of their social dimension and their usefulness as instruments to demand greater efforts in the area of legal certainty, the fight against corruption and the consolidation of democracy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. "Russia must stop getting directly or indirectly involved in the conflicts in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, and interfere with their European aspirations," says a resolution on the progress of reforms that we voted on today. The text of the resolution welcomes the progress of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which have chosen the path of closer political and economic integration with the European Union.  We have asked Russia to put an end to its direct or indirect intervention in the conflicts in these territories, including its occupation in Crimea.  Finally, one year after the ratification of the three comprehensive and comprehensive association and free trade agreements with the Union, we also mentioned the reforms that still need to be adopted and we took note of the Dutch referendum on 6 April on the EU-Ukraine agreement.  It is pointed out that in the first 12 months Georgia's exports to the EU increased by 15% and Moldova's by 62%. Similar growth is expected for Ukrainian exports. While recalling that these countries can apply for EU membership if they meet the necessary criteria, Parliament also points out that the Financial Support of the European Union is conditional on concrete reform progress.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified the Association Agreements, which include Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Zones with the Union, thereby opting for greater political and economic integration with the European Union and for carrying out ambitious reforms in many areas, such as ensuring democratic scrutiny of government action, on the road to good governance , the existence of an effective rule of law and the protection of human rights. It should also be noted that these three countries already participate in European programmes such as COSME, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus programmes, which gives them a very wide range of benefits and facilitates their process of familiarisation with EU policies and working methods. I therefore welcome the efforts made by these countries towards European integration and have therefore given my vote in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which provides an initial assessment of the implementation of association agreements and comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreements between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Reforms have taken place in these countries, including deepening political and economic integration. Nevertheless, progress still needs to be made in some areas, including the independence of the judiciary and possible threats to media pluralism in Georgia. In Moldova, it will be important to follow the new government that has just been elected after more than a year of political instability. Finally, on Ukraine, reforms still need to be made, in particular to strengthen the fight against corruption.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Sudden changes of government, cases of selective justice, restrictions on freedom of expression are some of the problems that these countries still face. There is a long way to go, and in order not to disappoint either the expectations of the citizens of these countries or those of Europe, the European Commission must continue to support the implementation of the reforms provided for in the association and free trade agreements voted on today.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report by the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade on the Association Agreement for the Establishment of Free Trade Zones between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on the view that it points to an asymmetric agreement that strengthens the perverse logics of neoliberal trade treaties, which seek liberalization as a single unredressed end in human rights and social rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the Resolution in favour of the Association Agreements and the wide and deep free trade areas between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the conviction that the EU is following a policy of broad and profound enlargement of its geopolitical interests and the sphere of influence of the EU and NATO in the area with a willingness to confront Russia.  These types of trade agreements already pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. In the case of Ukraine, much further afield, the eu's desire for expansion of the sphere of control has been the key factor in triggering the coup d'coup in Ukraine and the civil war in the country. Since my deep condemnation of the escalation of tensions with Russia and NATO's presence in the area, with my no vote I wanted to show my rejection of these agreements, which harm the local population and, even more, endanger peace in the region.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as a whole. I, like my colleagues in the Socialist Group, fully support the implementation of these association agreements. We are calling for much greater attention to be given to the social dimension of the partnership and we insist on the need for greater efforts in topics concerning the fight against corruption, respect of the rule of law and the consolidation of democracy.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ in the event of a vote on association agreements and comprehensive free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. Despite the visible problems we have in the EU, it is clear that slovakia's accession process and slovakia's membership of the EU itself have given us the possibility of greater economic growth. I am therefore happy to support this process also in countries that are struggling not only with economic uncertainty, but also with Russia's efforts for greater influence.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
