text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the joint motion for a resolution on association agreements/deep and comprehensive free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The EU recognises the European aspirations of the three countries and stresses the added value of association agreements in their reform processes. The latest political unrest and expressions of dissatisfaction in Moldova are worrying because the impasse has reached a critical point, which risks destabilising the country and threatening the economy, which has a significant impact on the inflow of foreign direct investment. Therefore, even in the resolution, we called on the political forces in Moldova to stabilise the political situation in the country and to move forward with reforms for the benefit of all Moldovan citizens. We also called on the Georgian Government to continue to reform the judiciary, including strengthening its independence and depoliticising the prosecution service. With Ukraine, we have put emphasis on greater efforts for the peace process in eastern Ukraine and on the fight against corruption and reforms in the areas of decentralisation of state power and the judiciary.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the Association Agreement between Moldova and the EU is very important, as it announces an important step forward towards European integration for Moldova. This agreement further deepens and strengthens political, economic and social relations between the two partners.  And that is precisely why the EU cannot stand idly by and watch once moldova is facing a deep and difficult political crisis in a country that has paralysed important progress towards a European perspective. At this point, I can therefore express my concern at many of the important areas facing Moldova, but I nevertheless find moldova's most problematic financial and banking sector, which poses an immense threat to the country's economic progress.  It is therefore crucial that the problems are rehabilitated in a completely transparent manner, that all stolen funds are returned and the culprits are put in to justice so that they are held accountable for their actions. There is an urgent need to strengthen the fight against corruption and to implement reforms in the area of the judiciary. The Moldovan Government will have to make improvements in this area if it is to achieve European integration in the true sense of the word, and the EU must actively and unconditionally help it.  For this purpose, I voted in favour of the resolution in plenary.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This Resolution of the European Parliament advocates the establishment of a free trade agreement between the EU on the one hand and Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia on the other. This creates new business opportunities for German companies in these countries. I am also convinced that free trade with the EU will provide a positive impetus for development in these countries. ALFA stands for an EU of sovereign states with an integrated internal market. We welcome the expansion of this market, but we are opposed to full membership of these countries within the current EU. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the Association Agreement and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas with Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova bring economic growth and political stability to these countries. Relations with the EU are based on the development of democratic legislation, the development of the free movement of goods and entrepreneurship as a whole. These countries need to be supported economically as well as politically in order to develop their relations with the EU.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution concerns the implementation of association agreements in Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova. The three countries have one more common denominator. Parts of the territories of all these countries are occupied by the Russian Federation. As shadow rapporteur for the Association Agreement with Georgia, I was also involved in the creation of this resolution and I am very happy that the resolution calls things by their real names. The EP expresses its unequivocal support for the territorial integrity of all three countries and calls on the Russian Federation to end the occupation of Crimea and to immediately cease to engage directly and indirectly in the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and in the frozen conflicts in Georgia and Moldova. The resolution also welcomes, among other things, the Council's decision to extend economic sanctions against the Russian Federation, calls for greater efforts to combat disinformation, and also mentions the East Strat Com Working Group. I voted against the 17 amendments tabled by the European United Left Faction, under which the Member of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, Mr Jiří Maštálka, is also signed. For example, the proposals critically refer to the ban on the Communist Party of Ukraine or condemn nato enlargement. The Communists' amendments also called on the EU to end its sanctions policy towards Russia. Since I take the opposite view, I am grateful that all these amendments have been rejected.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine have ratified association agreements covering areas of deepened and comprehensive free trade, thereby opting for closer political and economic integration with the European Union and the implementation of ambitious reforms in a number of areas, including democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights. The EU recognises the European aspirations of these three countries and underlines the added value of association agreements in their reform processes. I welcome the efforts of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to bring national legislation closer to EU standards on the basis of obligations under the association agreement and the agreement on deepened and comprehensive free trade. In this context, I support the multi-layered financial and technical assistance provided by the European Union and other financial institutions to Ukraine and Georgia, but I also want to stress that the EU should provide financial support to all its partners provided that they implement concrete reforms.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on association agreements/deep and comprehensive free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. I welcome the creation of a new government in Moldova. I expect her to roll up her sleeves right now and start work that's not a little bit.  Modernisation and urgent reforms are mandatory if Moldova wishes to continue to move closer to the EU. The fight against corruption needs to be stepped up, particularly as far as the banking sector is concerned. Stabilisation of the country and the economy is essential.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against the report because we believe that these free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine fully serve the desired benefits of the EU's dominant circles, because they create interdependence - economic and political - with partners and because they promote extreme competition for the benefit of large capital and at the expense of the interests of society and peoples.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Eu racism and anti-Russianism are reflected in the lines of this text. In an effort to raise an "anti-missile shield" policy around Russia, the EU funds and concludes agreements with ukraine's coup government.  Without regard to the consequences for the economies of the southern Member States, the Union is strengthening and trying to integrate into it some of the most corrupt and economically weak countries in Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision, taking into account experience that association agreements are a proven tool of eu neighbourhood and enlargement policy, which are an important motivation and guide for the partner countries concerned in building a democratic European rule of law. All three partner countries have made significant progress in meeting the expectations and measures set out in the Agreement. Personally, as First Vice-President of the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee, I have given special attention to Ukraine when considering the decision. In the case of our largest eastern neighbour, ties with the EU are also an important handrail against violent Russian expansion efforts. I agree with the concerns raised in the resolution in the context of the referendum in the Netherlands that threatens the entry into force of the Ukrainian Association Agreement, which in itself could demotivat the Ukrainians, damage the credibility of our common foreign and security policy and eastern partnership policy, and its possible negative outcome could have serious consequences for the interests of both Ukraine, the Netherlands and the European Union as a whole. I trust that this EP resolution will also help dutch citizens to understand that the Association Agreement does not mean Ukraine's membership of the EU and cannot prevent the democratic development and European catch-up of another people in the exercise of their democratic rights.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Association agreements and deep trade agreements are important instruments to support the comprehensive development of European countries outside the European Union. Political and economic agreements are also a strong impees for the necessary reforms to become full members of the Community in the long term. In its resolution on the evaluation of the implementation of trade and association agreements with Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, the European Parliament called on the European Commission to continue to support countries in the implementation of the agreements, both in technical and financial form. He also called for the results of structural and social reforms carried out in the above-mentioned countries to be presented. However, it is also important to pay attention to the external aspect of these agreements and, in particular, to Russia's actions towards the countries of the former Eastern Bloc, which have undertaken closer cooperation with the European Union. An example would be Ukraine, which has been benefiting from a trade agreement with the Community since the beginning of the year. Russia, convinced that the agreement would hit its interests, decided to introduce tariffs and an embargo on Ukrainian products, which will have a very negative impact on the weakened Ukrainian economy. The other two countries, Georgia and Moldova, may also face a similar situation. It is therefore important for the EU to focus on a holised approach to trade and association agreements in its activities, without ignoring the geopolitical consequences.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution. I believe that, in addition to deliberately falsifying reality, it goes against EU interests. The three association agreements have undermined the historical ties of the economies of Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia with the Russian economy. Who benefits from Russia's economic strangulation? Certainly not to the EU, for which it would be more advantageous to have peaceful relations with everyone. I also find it simply scandalous that this House rejected Amendment No 14, which at least called for goods produced in Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia not to enter the EU by exploiting child labour or trampling on human rights. This Parliament, which on so many occasions is so ready to be indignant at human rights violations, is therefore prepared to make respect for human rights conditional on an association agreement that supports the EU's expansive bulimia towards the East. This means that for the majority of the European Parliament respect for human rights, rather than value, is a mere instrument of political rhetoric. This is a deeply sad observation, but unfortunately it is inevitable and indeed necessary.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union pays particular attention to the stabilisation and development of the regions in its immediate neighbourhood and encourages the strengthening of relations with the States that so wish. The conclusion of Association Agreements, also known as Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements, represents a new step in strengthening cooperation with countries in the region that have demonstrated that their relationship with the EU is one of their strategic objectives. Since the ratification process of the agreements is almost completed and after a period of provisional application of their provisions, it is time for these documents to enter into full force. They will act as further confirmation and motivation for those countries to keep the path of the reforms they have seen in recent years. This is all the more so since there is currently political instability in the Republic of Moldova that must not be accentuated, and the EU must support the pro-European forces in all three countries. The EU's partnership with these states should also focus on progress in the area of the rule of law, the fight against corruption and the strengthening of democracy, and should take into account the evolution of the social dimension in each state.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text to stress the importance of association agreements and their components relating to a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade area.  We can welcome the progress made to date and insist that the implementation of the association and comprehensive free trade agreements and the association programmes associated with them must be a top priority for the Union and the three partners.  It should be remembered that the Council of the European Union signed the association agreements unanimously.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which highlights the progress made by Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia in implementing their association agreements and their chapters on a deep and comprehensive free-trade area with the EU. With this text we also remind Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine of the need for them to be determined in their pursuit of their respective reform programmes, in particular in the areas of justice and the rule of law, and in tackling corruption and organised crime. The socioeconomic development of the three countries is heavily dependent on the progress made in these areas. Finally we called on Russia to end its direct or indirect involvement in conflicts in the three countries and its interference with their EU aspirations.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Creating a transparent business and investment environment and appropriate regulatory reform to enable companies and investors meeting EU standards to trade freely within the EU market, as well as providing trade access for EU companies to the Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine markets is desirable and necessary. These three Eastern Partnership countries have already signed and ratified the DCFTA agreement, which committed to implementing thorough political and economic reforms in their countries in exchange for free trade with the European Union.  Each of these three countries faces difficult problems, be it a political crisis, a struggle for the independence of the judiciary, the media or the occupation of its territory. This is particularly concerning Ukraine, whose authorities, since the signing of the DCFTA, have made great efforts and respected the signed agreement with the European Union, focusing on constitutional changes, judicial reform and the fight against corruption and organised crime.   This agreement will further deepen free trade between the European Union and these three countries, and stronger political and economic ties will contribute to greater stability and prosperity across the European continent.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the joint motion for a resolution replacing the motions for a resolution on association agreements/deep and comprehensive free trade zones with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, as I believe that closer political and economic integration benefits both the countries involved and the European Union. The European Union will be able to further support Ukraine's priority efforts to remedy the adverse economic measures that have affected it. These countries will be able to take a step forward towards a democratic system where human rights and fair justice are brought to the fore.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report by the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade on the Association Agreement for the Establishment of Free Trade Zones between the European Union and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine on the view that it points to an asymmetric agreement that strengthens the perverse logics of neoliberal trade treaties, which seek liberalization as a single unredressed end in human rights and social rights.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report as I think that free trade agreements are one of the best existing tools for the promotion of economic advancement and democracy.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. We are opposed to these resolutions, which are contrary to our interests and the interests of these countries.  Indeed, they propose applications for membership of these three countries, and welcome their gradual integration into the European Union. The application of these association agreements risks mechanically provoking territorial partitions in fragile and divided states. The natural bedrock of these states is the immediate Russian neighbourhood, like it or not. I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are eastern partnership countries that have chosen close political cooperation and economic integration with the European Union. I voted in favour of the S&D group's proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the association agreements need to proceed.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a motion for a Resolution which highlights the necessary improvements that these countries must continue to make to their institutional systems as well as the importance of the Association Agreements with the European Union in order to contribute to this. The EU's neighbourhood policy with our eastern neighbours needs to help them consolidate their political systems, especially given the current situation with Russia.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against the Resolution in favour of the Association Agreements and the wide and deep free trade areas between the EU and Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine since the conviction that the EU is following a policy of broad and profound enlargement of its geopolitical interests and the sphere of influence of the EU and NATO in the area with a willingness to confront Russia. These types of trade agreements already pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. In the case of Ukraine, much further afield, the eu's desire for expansion of the sphere of control has been the key factor in triggering the coup d'coup in Ukraine and the civil war in the country. Since my deep condemnation of the escalation of tensions with Russia and NATO's presence in the area, with my no vote I wanted to show my rejection of these agreements, which harm the local population and, even more, endanger peace in the region.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that free trade agreements are one of the best instruments in the European Union for achieving economic and democratic progress.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The COMPREHENSIVE and Deep Free Trade Agreements (ACLAA) signed by the EU have conducted a policy aimed at extending their sphere of economic and political influence to Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, without taking due account of the intensity of trade relations and the historical interdependence of the economies of these countries with the economies of other countries in the region, such as Russia. This imperial policy, coupled with internal problems, has increased political instability and contributed to violence and war in Ukraine, with devastating effects in Moldova and Georgia in terms of the well-being of the local population and peace in the region. It is therefore justified to suspend it so that work is to be started on defining new forms of cooperation and relations between the EU and each of its members and the Eurasian economic zone. We reject the EU's current Eastern Neighbourhood Policy, as it is based on a political and economic strategy, putting the interests of the EU and those countries in the background.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the full implementation of the association agreements, which emphasise a stronger social dimension in the partnership. The EU must promote greater efforts on the part of the three governments concerned, within the framework of the rule of law, the fight against corruption and the consolidation of democracy.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. All the draft resolutions put to the vote here are directed against Russia. All three countries mentioned – Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine – are part or object of NATO and EU eastward enlargement policy, which cannot be in the interests of Europeans in the sense of trusting and peaceful cooperation with Russia.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I was among the initiators of the EPP resolution on association and/or free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The resolution adopted by the EP reiterates the EU's support for the three countries to maintain their pro-European course and maintain their territorial integrity.  In the chapter dedicated to the Republic of Moldova, the EP expresses its concern about the political instability in Chisinau, drawing attention to the fact that recent developments can lead to the destabilization of the whole country, endangering the economy and thus foreign investment flows. The EP urges the political forces of the Republic of Moldova to speed up negotiations to form a government to continue the reform processes in favour of the citizens of that country.  The resolution also calls on the Moldovan authorities to continue their investigations and bring to justice those who are guilty of stealing one million euros from the Moldovan banking system.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing – This resolution on the reform process in Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, adopted one year after the ratification of the three Association and Free Trade Agreements with the EU, draws attention to the reserves of democracy and reforms still to be adopted in these three countries. The resolution stresses the need for Russia to put an end to its direct or indirect participation in conflicts in these territories, in particular the occupation of Crimea. As far as Georgia is being as far as Georgia is being, the threat to the independence of the judiciary and media pluralism must be eliminated. As far as Moldova is concerned, Parliament welcomes the creation of a new government approved after more than a year of unsuccessful negotiations and awaits its reform plan. With regard to Ukraine, it insists on fulfilling its commitments in the fight against wild corruption. At the same time, Parliament condemned Russia for suspending the free trade agreement with Ukraine at a time when the EU-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement entered into force. It deplores the "severe trade restrictions" on Ukrainian exports to Russia and concerns about ukraine's economic and financial paralysing. It also recalls the need for further Union financial assistance to that country and the possibility of adopting a legislative proposal to include Ukraine in the list of visa-exempt countries.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament adopted a resolution recommending that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine continue and, where possible, step up reforms and efforts related to the association and free trade agreements that these countries have signed with the Union. I believe that the role of the European Commission, which must monitor implementation in the associated countries and, at the same time, provide adequate financial and technical assistance, is fundamental.  I fully agree with the resolution adopted today. I fully agree with its content, particularly where it is emphasised that, if Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine want to benefit fully from their association agreements, they must present concrete reform programmes in the name of combating corruption, consolidating the rule of law and social rights for their citizens.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this agreement because it is necessary to continue to support the approximation of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to the European Union. All three countries face similar challenges, such as territorial integrity, pressure to implement political, social and administrative reforms. I agree that a successful implementation of the Association Agreement can only occur if there is a stable political environment in the countries, there will be clear plans for trade policy reform, institutional settings with a clear division of powers and other elements of course for stable democratic states.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the association agreements with these three Eastern Partnership countries. This type of agreement between the European Union and third countries foresees significant political and economic reforms in exchange for very good trade relations and cooperation. Although all three countries have encountered problems relating to either the shortcomings of the judiciary, media freedom or, in the case of Ukraine, the loss of Crimea, I believe that it is the conclusion of such agreements that motivates and stimulates the country to continue the reforms that have already begun in all three cases, and it is precisely the better conditions for trade relations with the European Union that will help them to stabilise the situation and achieve growth and prosperity.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the association agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine because I believe they will help to stabilise the political situation, economic development and the enforcement of European legal standards.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Very interesting reports and motions have been made from different parties on the mutual protection clause. I really liked the fact that a number of people have finally made the point about counter-terrorism. For example, the EFDD writes that, as recent terrorist attacks in the EU have made clear the lack of exchange of information and the serious shortcomings in the coordination of cooperation and activities between European secret services. For example, the Greens have pointed to problems related to the arms trade and the financing of terrorism. At last, these draft reports, or draft resolutions, have finally started to talk about the substance. And they are not trying to force large, large groups of secret services, citizens who have nothing to do with terrorism to observe, interrogate, etc. That's not the answer to the terror threat.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Our common defence policy should be expressed above all by a common, solidarity-based position in the Atlantic Alliance, to which three quarters of our countries belong. Of course, it should also manifest itself in mobilising the Atlantic alliance to be more concerned about our security. What prevents us, as three-quarters of NATO members, from caring more about protecting the security of Estonia or Latvia? If we are really thinking about common security, it is time to guarantee it by mobilising the covenant to which we belong, and not through paper declarations or by falling into a kind of defensive schizophrenia, where within the European Union we behave as if we were outside the European Union – and even earlier than we joined it or than it was created – belonged to an alliance that effectively guaranteed our freedom and security.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Following the horrific terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November last year, France in fact became the first country in the history of the European Union to invoc invoize Article 42(7) of the TEU Treaty, a mutual protection clause, rather than Article 222, namely the solidarity clause. It can be welcomed that, in principle, all the other Member States responded in one way or another and provided France with various forms of support. Otherwise, there could not be a fight against terrorism in just one country, and solidarity must be shown not only in the form of solidarity, but also in the form of concrete assistance. Since no country called this clause before France, it will actually be necessary in the near future to pay attention to its invosing system and possible improvement, because if something like that, God guards, happens, then this mechanism must work quickly and legally correctly. So I support it. Thank you!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, solidarity, aid and mutual assistance between the Member States are among the founding values of the European Union. It is therefore to be welcomed that all Member States have expressed their full and unanimous support for France and that they are prepared to provide all the necessary aid and assistance following France's invocation of the mutual defence clause following the Paris attacks. However, as indicated in the report, practical arrangements are currently lacking to ensure an effective response in the event that a Member State invoi people invoitive to the mutual defence clause. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, is therefore working to better define the guidelines and practical arrangements for the future activation of the mutual defence clause, in order to ensure a rapid decision in the Council in support of the Member State under attack. I very much hope that the current activation of the clause will act as a catalyst to exploit the potential of all the Treaty provisions on security and defence and, above all, that it will prepare the ground for a common EU foreign policy in Syria and the Middle East, where there is currently no integrated European approach.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I, of course, also voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, as did the pre-presidents. I see that we are at war with terrorism and that it is not only France where the tragic attacks took place in November last year that is at war with terrorism, but that our entire European civilisation and therefore the entire European Union are at war with terrorism. It must be said, as the previous words have already said, that, on the one hand, this is essentially the first use of this instrument under Article 42 of the Treaty of Lisbon, and it will now be necessary to talk about how to implement practically the resolution adopted today, so that it does not stick to words and only to general declared solidarity and to general declared support. As the Czech Republic, we are trying to help France, for example, we are involved in operations in Mali. But, of course, this runs outside this European mechanism and therefore needs to be given concrete form.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, in 1975 the people of Britain voted to join the European Community as a free-trade organisation. This year we will have a referendum to decide whether we stay in the European Union. The motion before us today to have a mutual defence clause, or otherwise a European army, will help. We joined a free-trade union; we did not want to join an empire. We did not want to join an organisation that wanted to expand its borders. We did not want to join an organisation that slaps the face of America and NATO, two entities that kept Europe safe. The European Union did not. This motion creates a permanent military headquarters. It creates a military alliance, it creates a European army. I voted against the option of allowing the European Union to be an empire with its own army. I believe in freedom and democracy and the nation-state. I believe the people of Britain will vote to leave the European Union because they want that too.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon Treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament in favour of activating the mutual defence clause requested by France under the pretext of the latest attacks in Paris since this manoeuvre, if carried out, will strengthen the process of converting the European Union into a military alliance. This is a misguided response to the Paris attacks. France's interpretation is sesatic and intentional since a terrorist attack is not an act of war no long as they are committed. Its interpretation is a fraud of international law and the return to the logic of the war on terror. In the face of terrorism, only civilian responses, police action, intelligence, cutting off the funding of terrorist groups and cutting off international support. In any event, the answer must always be within the rule of law and these acts cannot be used as a pretext for a collective cut in individual freedoms.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution requested by France for a mutual defence clause. This proposal includes an expansion of the European Union's powers in the areas of criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. If the tragic events of 13 November have motivated this request, I believe that the Union does not have to interfere more in the internal affairs of the Member States. They must be able to maintain their exclusive jurisdiction over criminal law and diplomatic and military strategy. This proposal represents yet another offensive by Europe against the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the GUE/NGL resolution and against the Joint Motion for Resolution on this file. Our reasons for voting for the GUE/NGL Resolution were because of its strong opposition to the creation of an EU military alliance and its absolute rejection of the activation of Article 42(7) TEU on the Mutual Defence Clause. Rejecting both of these aspects is crucial to safeguarding Irish neutrality.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The Europeanists here use the pretext of recent attacks to further expand the European Union's powers over criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. This further decline in the sovereignty of the Member States is unacceptable, which is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this report because it calls for the establishment of practical arrangements and guidelines for the mutual defence clause to remain an urgent priority.  I am completely opposed to the EU wanting an army at its disposal or acquiring a permanent civil-military headquarters. I do not believe this resolution is in the best interests of the defence capabilities or security of the United Kingdom.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because the mutual assistance clause invoked by France after the terrorist attacks in Paris gives us a unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a strong and sustainable European Defence Union in order to be able to face security threats and challenges. It is important to enable the Union to act autonomously in operations abroad, especially when it comes to stabilizing our neighbourhood.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is going through a particularly difficult period. The uncontrolled flow of immigrants, the radicalisation of EU citizens, terrorist attacks and the constant threat of terrorist attacks require a new and decisive approach to European security. For the first time in the history of the EU, Article 42 of the EU Treaty has been used to ask for military assistance, but as we can see, there is no clear procedure in the European Union on how to apply the provisions of this article. The European Union must take action as soon as possible in the area of the common security and defence policy. We need a very clear military structure at EU level that has clear strategic tasks and the right capacity to ensure collective defence.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November, France invoked the mutual defence clause in Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on european Union, a first in the EU. In this resolution, Parliament underlines the unanimous support given to France by the Member States and the provision of additional resources in the fight against terrorism. He believes that this first is an opportunity to relaunch the debate on the organisation of an effective, rapid and coordinated response when a Member State invokes this clause and asks the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to propose the modalities and guidelines. I supported that resolution.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. The European Parliament wants Member States that want to move forward towards closer defence cooperation to be supported by the EU. This 'coalition of the willing' is the perfect stepping stone towards further Europeanisation of defence through far-reaching, structured cooperation. We therefore want the EU to work on a permanent military headquarters. Such an operational headquarters is a must to be able to respond effectively to threats - as is now requested by France - and to implement collective defences more quickly and effectively, in close cooperation with NATO.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The serious terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015 prompted the French government to invoke the defence clause in Article 42(7) TEU. For the first time in the history of the Union, one Member State has called for the activation of this mechanism, requesting the help and assistance of other States following an attack. The unanimous acceptance of the position expressed by The President of the Republic, Mr French, represented a turning point in the Union's defence policy.  I voted in favour of the resolution on the mutual defence clause because I am convinced that this is a starting point for pushing the Council and the Member States to start fully implementing the security and defence architecture provided for in the Treaties. Since the failure of the EMCA in 1954, European countries have not made sufficient efforts to develop a defence system capable of achieving ambitious objectives but, with the Treaty of Lisbon, the possibility of permanent structured cooperation in the field of defence has opened up. The great challenges of our time can only be met by an EU united in foreign policy and equipped with the appropriate tools to intervene in different contexts.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We reject the activation of paragraph 7 of Article 42 OFC because it represents an ineffective and high-risk military response to cause even more innocent victims, greater population displacement and further destruction of territories. We advocate diplomatic structural solutions, development cooperation and peaceful conflict resolution under international law outside the EU; within the EU, we advocate actions that prioritize police research and action with full respect for human rights and individual freedoms, as well as appropriate and sufficient public integration and interculturality policies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution on the mutual defence clause condemning in the strongest terms the execrable terrorist attacks perpetrated by the Dáesh and the transfer of our deep sympathy and solidarity as well as our condolences to all the victims of terrorist attacks and their families.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution providing for a "mutual defence clause". It is once again scandalous that the European Union is using the consequences of its incompetence to try to expand its prerogatives to the detriment of those of Member States. Here, insecurity and the terrorist threat, largely fuelled by the irresponsible actions of the EU, are used as a pretext for a new Brussels offensive on the freedom of states and peoples. Proposals such as the request for a European civilian and military headquarters are an unacceptable attack on our sovereignty, whether in the field of defence or diplomacy. If cooperation between sovereign nations is more necessary than ever to combat Islamist terrorism, it is out of the question to acquiesce to a European defence policy - which would be merely a vassal of NATO, and therefore at the behest of American interests - which would only make France more dependent and fragile at a time when the threats to it are most serious.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The time has come for the EU to set clear and firm guidelines on the 'mutual defence clause', to ensure an effective response in the event that a Member State calls for its application, as President Hollande did after the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November. All European countries must commit themselves to the mass in the fight against terrorism and a more rigorous approach must be adopted at both national and EU level. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. After the Paris attacks of 13 November 2015, the French Government activated the mutual defence clause in Article 42(7) OFC, where by which the Member States of the Union must provide assistance and assistance in the case of armed aggression to one of them. This is the first time this mutual aid clause has been used and it is very well unknown what development and consequences it will entail. In the absence of protocols developing what to do, Member States' support is in most cases to be realized and has not resulted in concrete operational measures except for some exception. This joint resolution proposal aims to strengthen the mechanism and request the establishment of a protocol and practical measures for more effective implementation in the future; it also recalls, as the Treaty itself does, that any armed action must in any event respect the Charter of the United Nations, and also respect human rights and international provisions on humanitarian law. That is why I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because solidarity, support and mutual assistance between Member States, ensured and used at EU level, are fundamental values of the European Union. The security of the Member States is indivisible and all citizens of the European Union should have equal security guarantees and equal level protection against traditional and non-traditional threats, including terrorism and attacks by actors at both state and non-state level. The Institutions of the European Union should be more active in the area of security and defence policy and promote the implementation of all the provisions of the security and defence policy enshrined in the Treaties, including those on nato's special role in European and transatlantic security and defence matters. The EU-NATO strategic partnership should be strengthened. The European Parliament recalls the request made in its previous resolutions to the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to propose practical arrangements and guidelines for ensuring an effective response when a Member State makes use of the mutual defence clause and to provide an analysis of the role of the EU institutions in the event that this condition is applied. Parliament also calls for better coordination between border management, police and other law enforcement and intelligence agencies, and calls for a more efficient and structured exchange of information between them.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The terrorist attacks in Paris last November have greatly reversed the flow of events in France and Europe. France declared war on Islamic State and, immediately after the attacks, made a request to activate Article 7 of Article 42 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, which stipules that a military attack on one EU Member State is an EU-specific attack. EU defence ministers later confirmed the activation of this article, but I agree with the report that the Paris attacks should not be seen as military attacks falling within the scope of the article. A more solidarity clause in Article 222 TEU would be considered, which would strengthen the exchange of information and coordination at EU level.  Terrorism has no borders, so there must be full exchange of information, full cooperation between the security services and a common fight against terrorism; the causes of terrorism must be eliminated. The causes of terrorism on European soil are mainly related to the removal of dictatorial regimes in Libya and Iraq and the events in Syria and Afghanistan. This results in the emergence of a terrorist Islamic State and the largest flow of migrants and refugees since World War II, which is increasingly destabilising Europe. It will be possible to start resolving the situation by resolving the crisis in Syria, stopping the migrant flow and actively integrating Muslims into European society.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon Treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, following the activation of the mutual defence clause in Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union, it is important that the Member States provide all the necessary assistance to France and that, at the same time, efforts are being made to put in place instruments to make the effective application of the measures provided for in the clause more effective and efficient.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This resolution provides for the implementation of a mutual defence clause. The threat posed by Islamist terrorism to the security of Europeans should not be used as a pretext for the creation of a civil and military European headquarters, which would constitute an unacceptable violation of the sovereignty of the Member States. If the strengthening of cooperation between sovereign states is more than necessary to combat Islamist terrorism effectively, it must be based on an intergovernmental and non-federalist vision.  I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Against the backdrop of the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, which resulted in the loss of at least 130 people from more than 26 countries, immediate measures should be taken to combat international terrorism. Over the past decade, EU Member States have been the target of several terrorist attacks, resulting in hundreds of deaths and several thousand injuries. The Paris attacks led to France invoking the mutual defence clause, with Member States obliged to provide France with aid and assistance by all means at their disposal. Such tragic events underline the importance of conflict prevention and the need for the more active involvement of the Union institutions in security and defence policy and in promoting the implementation of all the provisions in the field of security and defence policy enshrined in the Treaties.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that solidarity, aid and mutual assistance between Member States are urgently necessary in such situations. At the same time, combating terrorism must continue to be a priority for the European Union, and concrete measures are needed to strengthen security policy and crime prevention.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The mutual defense clause was invoked by Hollande (and for the first time in Europe) on November 13, 2015 following the attacks in Paris. The resolution condemns in the strongest possible terms the terrorist attacks carried out by ISIS and expresses its concern that the management of aid and assistance under the mutual defence clause on a bilateral basis – as in this case – will not be possible for all Member States; calls, therefore, on the European Council to give impetus to the development of this clause and urges it to develop the facilitating role of the relevant EU institutions. It therefore calls on all European countries to engage in the fight against terrorism and to adopt a rigorous approach at both national and non-national level. It calls for appropriate measures to control the movement of weapons, explosives and suspects. It urges the Member States to create a structured system for information sharing and operational cooperation for border management, police and other law enforcement agencies, as well as the sharing of national databases.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. In the wake of the terrorist attacks on 13 November 2015 on French soil, France appealed to the solidarity of other European states by using the mutual defence clause in Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty. This clause specifies that in the event of an armed attack on the soil of a Member State, the other States must assist and assist it by all means in their power. The Member States, in accepting this request, have shown their solidarity with France in the fight against terrorism outside the Union's borders. The resolution welcomes France's request and the willingness of Member States to cooperate on defence. The text also stresses the progress of EU cooperation in the fight against terrorism. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the GUE/NGL resolution and against the Joint Motion for Resolution on this file. My reasons for voting for the GUE/NGL Resolution were because of its strong opposition to the creation of an EU military alliance and its absolute rejection of the activation of Article 42(7) TEU on the Mutual Defence Clause. Rejecting both of these aspects is crucial to safeguarding Irish neutrality.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I condemn the recent attacks in France and regret that we have found ourselves in a situation where the Mutual Defence Clause needs to be invoked. I fully support the people of France and I hope that all Member States, in one way or another, will be able to contribute to the fight against terrorism as it is a problem that concerns us all. I therefore voted in favour of this motion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution expresses its opinion on France's decision to activate the mutual defence clause referred to in Article 42(7) TEU following the tragic events in Paris on 13 November.  Although the text makes some positive comments, I believe that there is too lenient an approach to the missed opportunity to use a clause that was much more suited to this situation. It seemed more correct to invoke Article 222 TFEI, which governs the case where a Member State is the victim of a terrorist attack. The use of Article 42(7) TEU, which is applied in cases where a Member State is the victim of an armed attack, not only risks representing an implicit recognition of Daesh as a State but also establishes the predominance of the intergovernmental method over the Community method. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the mutual defence clause, which was formally invoked after the terrorist attacks of 13 November in Paris by the French Government. I believe that invoking the clauses of mutual defence and solidarity under the Treaties is primarily a political issue and I believe that when these clauses are invoked, both the European Council and the European Parliament are the appropriate venues for political dialogue.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that the fight against international terrorism is one of the Union's priorities and that only with an autonomous security and defence capability will the EU be able to address the enormous threats and challenges to internal and external security. Following the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, the French government officially invoked the mutual defence clause referred to in Article 42(7) TEU. EU Member States are required to provide aid and assistance to France by all means in their power, in accordance with Article 51 of the UN Charter. Parliament considers that the current case should act as a catalyst for in-depth political discussions on the multidimensional nature of European security and defence; it also calls on all Member States to maintain their unconditional and lasting support and to continue to contribute for as long as necessary. The legislative body insists on an overall approach to deradicalisation, including national efforts aimed at young people, the prevention of violent extremism and the fight against terrorism, which aims to strengthen social cohesion and crime prevention.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This clause is a very important instrument of international law, and at this specific time it is quite relevant that France has requested that it be applied. However, there are aspects that should not be underestimated, which emerged strongly during the negotiations for the preparation of these reports. I am therefore very pleased with the final text, the approval of which I voted for, because it represents a balanced and effective synthesis of the pros and cons of the decision to rely on this particular institution of international law now, and of the reasons that should guide these choices.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 For the first time in the history of the Union, a Member State has activated the mutual defence clause provided for by the Treaties and which provides for all Members of the Union to cooperate in the defence of one that has been attacked. Essentially, a mechanism at all similar to that underplying NATO, but only for the members of the Union.  The French Republic has unfortunately been attacked twice this year on its territory by terrorism, thereby activating this clause. The motion rightly points out that this is an opportunity not only to develop the basis for a defence union, but also for European foreign policy to be more than the sum of national policies. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this very important parliament resolution, which is adopted on the occasion of the first time that the mutual defence clause has been invoked. I believe it is necessary to promote the development of this clause, as well as to identify practical arrangements and guidelines to ensure an effective response in the event that a Member State activates it in order to defend itself against an attack such as the one that took place in Paris on 13 November. I do not believe, in fact, that the bilateral management of these situations is the right reaction, since a European response is needed.  This opportunity can really be an opportunity to establish new, stronger foundations for achieving a strong and effective European Defence Union, improving the Union's autonomous security and defence capacity from external attacks that so severely undermine its stability.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The use and application of the mutual defence clause has come to the fore with its first use by France following the terrorist attacks of 2015. Yet the use of this clause alone will not be sufficient to protect citizens from terrorist attacks, especially when these attacks are being committed by European citizens with strong ties to third countries. I have thus voted in favour of the mutual defence clause report, but only as an element of broader action that addresses security.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament in favour of activating the mutual defence clause requested by France under the pretext of the latest attacks in Paris since this manoeuvre, if carried out, will strengthen the process of converting the European Union into a military alliance. This is a misguided response to the Paris attacks. France's interpretation is sesatic and intentional since a terrorist attack is not an act of war no long as they are committed. Its interpretation is a fraud of international law and the return to the logic of the war on terror. In the face of terrorism, only civilian responses, police action, intelligence, cutting off the funding of terrorist groups and cutting off international support. In any event, the answer must always be within the rule of law and these acts cannot be used as a pretext for a collective cut in individual freedoms.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At the Meeting of Defence Ministers in the Council of Foreign Ministers on 17 November 2015 France invoked the mutual defence clause for the first time in history to ask other countries for support against the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq and other missions following the November terrorist attacks in Paris. The French President pointed out that France refers to Article 42(7) and not to the so-called solidarity clause, article 222 of the Treaty on European Union. While the latter paves the way for greater EU involvement, the former operates in an intergovernmental formula, allowing Paris to play a greater role. France could also refer to Article 42(7) in order to obtain derogations from the EU Treaty requirements both on specific matters and, in general, on the budgetary savings imposed by the EU.  In view of the lack of coherence between actions and the law, in the light of the foregoing and the discussion of two points related to Article 42(7) at the SEDE meeting of 1 December 2015, it seemed that there was no reason to use the reference to this article to promote a greater EU role in the field of security and defence.  With this in mind, I abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Member States agreed on 17 November 2015 to grant military assistance to France following the terror attacks in Paris. For the first time in EU history, defence ministers unanimously decided to activate the ‘mutual defence clause’ of the EU treaty. Bilateral talks have begun between France and other Member States to clarify French needs and other countries’ capabilities. The Treaty of Lisbon provides the possibilities for enhanced cooperation in common security and defence policy, including the consignment of specific tasks and missions to clusters of states. I supported this resolution as it serves as a first, general parliamentary position, setting as its objective to stimulate the Council and the Member States to draft and adopt practical arrangements and guidelines for ensuring an effective response in the event that a Member State invokes the mutual defence clause. I abstained on the provisions that can shed doubt on the provisions of the neutrality clause established in the Constitution of Malta.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I wholeheartedly support cooperation between France, the United Kingdom and other Member States in joint efforts on tackling terrorism. The terrorist attacks in Paris last year were a strong wake—up call for every country in Europe that the fight against terrorism is far from won. However, this should not be at the expense of surrendering our individual countries’ right to take our own action in these areas to defend our borders and our citizens. So, unfortunately, I cannot support this motion for resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows France's decision to invoke the mutual defence clause of the EU Treaty (Article 42, paragraph 7) to seek the assistance of Member States in the face of the threat of the Islamic State. Invoked for the first time since it came into force in 2009, the article states that "if a Member State is subjected to armed aggression on its territory, the other Member States have an obligation to it to help and assist by all means". Following France's request, all the countries of the European Union showed their support, symbolising Europe's union against terrorism. This resolution looks at the scope of this article, how it is implemented and the role of the Union's institutions. In support of this approach, I supported the resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon Treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This resolution is of great importance as it calls on the Council and the Member States to draw up the guidelines for a political framework for the effective implementation of the mutual defence clause. This clause of solidarity in case of aggression against a country was requested for the very first time by a country, in this case France, in the wake of the Paris attacks. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In the wake of the tragic attacks of 13 November, the President of the French Republic chose to use the mutual defence clause, citing Article 42, paragraph 7 of the EU Treaty, which states that "if a Member State is the object of armed aggression on its territory, the other Member States have an obligation to help and assist by all means".  The Union will therefore have to live up to its duty of solidarity. The activation of the mutual defence clause should be an opportunity to finally lay the foundations for a Europe of defence that we have long called for. Member States must also find ways to build more effective cooperation between their police services and improve the exchange of information on the movement of weapons, explosives and terrorist suspects.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. On 13 November 2015, France invoked the mutual assistance clause in Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on the European Union, on 13 November 2015, struck by a series of attacks orchestrated from Syria by the armed terrorist group Daesh. In general, all Member States have expressed their political will to respond to the French call and significant contributions have been or will be made in the near future. That is why I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the mutual defence clause. In particular, this resolution supports France in its request for the application of Article 42, paragraph 7. In addition, Parliament calls for the establishment of an activation guide for Member States wishing to activate the mutual assistance clause.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. On 17 November 2015, four days after the terrorist attacks in Paris, France invoked, for the first time in the union's history, the mutual defence clause before the Foreign Affairs Council (Article 42, paragraph 7, of the EU Treaty). By this appeal, France intends to satisfy an old request: the support of its defence efforts. All European states have responded favourably. Bilateral consultations have already enabled the mobilization of new resources. I support this text, which, beyond this substantive objective, gives leads and clarifies the limits thanks to the elements provided by the group, in particular concerning respect for human rights and international humanitarian law. It affirms the primary role of the European Parliament and the European Council as places of political debate. The context of a global terrorist threat requires the European Union to support a renewed and more appropriate interpretation of international humanitarian law. I would add that the defence efforts carried out by France (or other Member States, if any) should also be removed from the convergence criteria, as I have repeatedly requested, notably in the Committee on Budgets.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text is tantamount to using the attacks to better accept a further expansion of the European Union's powers at the expense of states and their regal powers. This relates to the areas of criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. It also calls for the establishment of a civil and military headquarters of the European Union, as well as a kind of co-management of defence and strategy issues with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). I believe that the Union's inability to ensure the security of the nationals of its Member States will not be resolved by further dispossessing states of their sovereignty. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on the common defence clause (Article 42(7) TEU), as I believe that security and defence must remain fully within the competence of the Member States and no more powers should be conferred in this area at EU level. Separately, France has no reason to use this article and to demand greater Union engagement in the war in Syria, as the EU is not a security and defence organisation, but a political and economic union. Cooperation in the fight against IS and terrorism must be done through NATO, which is the most appropriate organisation and of which all Member States are members. Last but not least, it should also be mentioned that the use of Article 42(7) by France may be intended to justify the many breaches of European legislation in areas such as public security contracts, freedom of movement of goods and persons, public debt, etc.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Effective counter-terrorism presupposes first of all the admission by the victims that their wrong policies were the cause of the emergence of terrorism in their country. When you start wars in third countries to strengthen your geopolitical position, when, under the pretext of freedom of speech, you insult the intelligence and religion of your fellow human beings, and when you sacrifice human souls on the altar of power and economic interests, then you cannot ask for the help of others to protect you without changing your attitude and policy. Terrorism must be tackled, but above all its causes must be neutralised. The application of this clause will involve other countries in the dance of terrorism rather than solve the problem.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mutual defence clause (Article 42(7) TUE), first invoked by France following the recent and deplorable Paris terrorist attacks, welcoming the mobilisation of efforts and the aid made available by all Member States. I abstained, however, in the vote on Amendment No 1 to paragraph 3 of the text, since the invocation of this clause should not be a pretext for the legitimisation of military operations which in the past have brought nothing positive to the stabilisation and promotion of peace and democracy in the neighbouring regions of Europe.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. Since I believe that the EU should focus on civilian security work and NATO should be the arena of military cooperation, I have chosen to vote against parts of the report. This applies to paragraphs 11 and 18, which call for progress towards a common defence union. I have voted in favour of the whole report because I think it is important to highlight the need for the EU countries to stand in solidarity in the event of an acute crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. In November 2015, Paris was the scene of several terrorist attacks, resulting in at least 130 fatalities from more than 26 nations, and since 2004 the EU and Member States have been the target of several terrorist attacks, which have left hundreds dead and several thousand injured. As a result, the French Government has officially invoked the mutual defence clause for the first time, which obliges Member States to provide aid and assistance to France by all means at its service. I believe that combating international terrorism is an EU priority and pursuing the principle of solidarity requires measures both internally and externally. I would like to strongly condemn the abominable terrorist attacks perpetrated by Daexe and i welcome the strengthening of the capabilities made available in the fight against terrorism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is no surprise. You could almost say you follow a pre-written script. Right and social democracy challenge the rhetoric of the fight against terrorism, defending supranational responses, the federalist way. A path that seeks to accelerate the creation of a political and institutional framework that guides and streamlines the application of this clause, signaling the "unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a European Defence Union", resuming the idea of the need for European military forces, "in close cooperation with the relevant structures" of NATO. From the reasons, origins and sponsorship of terrorism and its organizations, from the actions of aggression and attentive interference of sovereign countries promoted by the EU, USA and NATO, not a word. This proclaimed fight against terrorism and the posture of aggression and interference have fueled the growth of racist, xenophobic and fascist forces and their action of terror. We affirm the imperative need to combat terrorism by developing a genuine peace policy, based on the end of the escalation of aggression, particularly in the Middle East, and on the effective defence and affirmation of the values of freedom, democracy, respect for the sovereignty and independence of states and peoples. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The European Union's interior ministers agreed almost a year ago to strengthen cooperation between police and security services, which should have included improving the exchange of information on dangerous persons, or taking joint measures against the proliferation of illicit firearms and terrorist financing. The European Union has adopted a counter-terrorism strategy in which it proposes that measures should be targeted at four fundamental objectives: prevention, protection, prosecution and response. It is therefore essential that the Council and the Member States swiftly adopt a policy framework that will help the implementation of Article 42(7) ZEU and include a timetable and review clause and monitoring mechanisms.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Effective counter-terrorism presupposes first of all the admission by the victims that their wrong policies were also the cause of the outbreak of terrorism in their country. When you set off wars in third countries to strengthen your geopolitical position, when, under the pretext of freedom of speech, you insult the intelligence and religion of other fellow human beings and when you sacrifice human souls on the altar of power and economic interests, then you cannot ask for the help of others to protect you without changing your attitude and policy. Terrorism must be tackled, but above all its causes must be neutralised. The application of this clause will involve other countries in the dance of terrorism rather than solve the problem. That is why my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This was the first time the mutual defence clause was invoked. The current case will serve as a precedent for the future use of the mutual defence clause and is therefore extremely relevant. Unfortunately, the security and defence architecture foreseen by the Treaties is not yet fully implemented. The Treaty of Lisbon provides the possibilities for enhanced cooperation in CSDP, including the consignment of specific tasks and missions to clusters of states, as well as the concept of permanent structured cooperation in military matter, while the Member States are responsible for achieving progress in the area of security and defence of the Union.  I strongly believe that the Council and the Member States should draft and adopt practical arrangements and guidelines for ensuring an effective response in the event that a Member State invokes the mutual defence clause, as well as an analysis of the role of the EU institutions should that clause be invoked.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it stresses that the use of the mutual defence clause is a sign of the unanimous support given by all Member States to France and is, in this sense, a sign of European solidarity, the foundation of the Union. In the resolution, we deplore the intergovernmental nature of this clause and recall the 'facilitator' role of the European institutions, which can ensure a collective and effective response when this clause is invoked.
