We call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to propose guidelines on the practical modalities of this clause, in order to avoid ad hoc management and cooperation in the future. Finally, we underline the catalytic role of this first activation, which can be used to lay the foundations for a genuine European defence union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU should strengthen its cooperation with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) in order to make security and defence policies developed within the framework of the two systems increasingly compatible, especially in the event of an armed attack on its territory, including terrorist attacks; Furthermore, I am convinced that the EU institutions should play a more active role in security and defence policy and promote the implementation of the provisions of the Treaties on security and defence policy, including on NATO's specific role in the field of European and transatlantic security and defence; whereas the EU institutions should support The Member States in their efforts to fully implement these provisions.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this, since the 13 November terrorist attacks in Paris are not an attack on France, they are an attack on the whole European Union, and as such we must respond. Further than that, following the terrorist attacks, the French Government officially invoked the mutual defence clause in Article 42(7) OFA, and the other Member States are therefore obliged to provide it with assistance and assistance with all means at their disposal. The eradication of international terrorism must be a priority for the European Union. We must move forward to establish greater collaboration and coordination in this area that allows us to have a permanent operation in order to react quickly in emergencies.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the resolution on the assistance clause (Article 42(7) TEU). This does not change my full solidarity with our French neighbours and friends. However, the resolution,' in its overly broad approach, deals with an extremely sensitive issue with a rough, political hand. For example, the call for a common European army is unacceptable in this flat-rate and without an in-depth, detailed and factual debate.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In the event of an attack on a Member State of the European Union, it is necessary to oppose it in a united way.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause, which was invoked by France following the November terrorist attacks in Paris. Given this is the first time the mutual defence clause is being invoked, how we deal with it will serve as precedent. We therefore need to take a long-term view and develop concrete guidelines that will allow us to respond fast and effectively in the future. Let this also be the opportunity to strengthen cooperation on defence and intelligence sharing. This does not mean taking sovereignty away from national governments nor side stepping NATO – a point made very clear in Article 42(7). It means being smart: supporting clusters, role specialisation, joint research and procurement, increasing market integration.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We reject the activation of paragraph 7 of Article 42 OFC because it represents an ineffective and high-risk military response to cause even more innocent victims, greater population displacement and further destruction of territories. We advocate diplomatic structural solutions, development cooperation and peaceful conflict resolution under international law outside the EU; within the EU, we advocate actions that prioritize police research and action with full respect for human rights and individual freedoms, as well as appropriate and sufficient public integration and interculturality policies.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I and my fellow Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report. This was the first time the mutual defence clause was invoked. The current case will serve as a precedent for the future use of the mutual defence clause. However, Labour MEPs however did vote against measures in the resolution which called for the creation of an EU defence headquarters. Labour MEPs do not believe in the need for the creation of another international defence mechanism, in essence duplicating NATO. We also do not support EU institutions having a greater role in security and defence matters. The S&D group believes that the Council and the Member States should draft and adopt practical arrangements and guidelines for ensuring an effective response in the event that a Member State invokes the mutual defence clause, as well as an analysis of the role of the EU institutions should that clause be invoked.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. – The possibility for a Member State to invoke Article 42(7) is enshrined in the Eu Treaty. We Swedish Social Democrats support a review of the mutual defence clause because we believe that the EU needs to learn the lessons from the management after the first application of Article 42(7) and establish how a similar situation should best be dealt with in the future. On the other hand, we do not believe that a permanent civil-military headquarters is needed or that the activation of the mutual assistance clause should in any way lead to a European Defence Union. We therefore chose not to support these wordings.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We disagree with the activation of this article of the Treaty of Lisbon, as we disagreed in the debate on the Treaty itself, when we criticised the introduction of this article. We do not believe that the militarisation of the EU's foreign policy can achieve the desired peace in our wider region. Unfortunately, instead of acting as an auxiliary to the practical expression of solidarity in the Member States under attack, the article is only triggered when it is to be used to justify imperialist interventions by EU Member States.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this resolution due to the many contentious issues within the report regarding the promotion of NATO and the fact that it calls for a civil military headquarters and calls to establish a strong European Defence Union, as Ireland is a neutral country.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. On 17 November, following the devastating terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France called for the so-called mutual assistance clause with Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Accordingly, in the event of an armed attack on the territory of a Member State, the other Member States owe it all the support in their power. This must be consistent with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the right of self-defense of a State, and also in accordance with the commitments made under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for NATO members. Irrespective of existing legal provisions, there is no question that France must be given the full estout of support from the EU and all Member States. Our European values, our freedom and our principles of the rule of law must be defended unreservedly. With regard to the legal aspects, it is necessary to clarify in the longer term where an EU Member State is exposed to a threat, Article 42(7) (TEU) and when Article 222 is to be insofared under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). For NATO members, the relationship of these provisions must also be determined with Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, which governs the case for the alliance. However, I reject a permanent European army called for in the European Parliament resolution without a previous, comprehensive debate followed by direct democratic legitimacy.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the activation of the mutual defence clause requested by the French authorities following the attacks of 13 November 2015. This clause stipulates that "in the event that a Member State is subject to armed aggression on its territory, the other Member States owe it assistance and assistance by all means in their power, in accordance with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations". In this way, France will be able to receive material assistance to support its actions in Iraq and Syria as well as in other theatres of operations, such as the Sahel, the Central African Republic and Lebanon. The fight against terrorism and against the Islamic State, which has renewed its threats against France and the coalition states, is an ongoing struggle that requires mobilizing resources and capabilities that France should not have to endure alone. Europe, by the values and principles it defends, and each of the Member States that are part of it are threatened by this new form of terrorism which is free of national borders and which recruits its agents within our nations. France must not take on the heavy responsibility of defending the continent alone.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint resolution of the European Parliament on the mutual defence clause (Article 42(7) of the UEU) because I believe that following the terrorist attacks carried out in Paris on 13 November 2015, a great deal of solidarity is needed from all Member States with France to support and assist it. EU foreign policy-making in specific areas and global regions should become part of the EU's global strategy and information sharing needs to be strengthened and relevant EU instruments strengthened.  One of the Union's priorities is to fight international terrorism to strengthen European security and defence, and therefore I certainly support this clause.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. Indeed, it is yet another attempt to further expand the Union's powers in criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. This further decline in the sovereignty of the Member States is unacceptable.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I and my fellow UKIP MEP’s voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). My colleagues and I supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The mutual defence clause was invoked for the first time by France in November after the Paris attacks, in order to formally ask its European partners’ support in its war against ISIS. I highly welcome the unanimous support given to France, but I believe that more must be done. We have reached the moment when the Member States can no longer count solely on bilateral support and must now reinforce their capabilities and effectively protect Europe from the increased terrorism threat. We need more cooperation between Member States’ police and intelligence services on the movement of weapons and terrorist suspects in order not to repeat the mistakes of the past.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mutual defence clause (Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty). This clause stipulates that in the event of an armed attack on the soil of a Member State, the other States must assist and assist it by all means in their power. It was first activated by France in the wake of the tragic attacks in Paris in November. In accepting this request, European states have shown their solidarity with France in the fight against terrorism. The resolution voted welcomes France's approach and the solidarity of the Member States. It was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sought to examine the use of the mutual defence clause activated by France in the wake of the November 13, 2015 attacks in Paris. The use of this clause makes it possible to ask member States for help and assistance in cooperating, as France cannot do everything on its own. Moreover, the activation of this measure will lay the foundations for a strong and sustainable European Defence Union to deal with internal and external security threats.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this resolution. It opposes the Austrian requirement of neutrality, such as the call for greater involvement of the EU and the troops of its Member States in military operations. Moreover, a European defence union is, as requested, a short-sighted and questionable undertaking.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Following the terrorist attacks of 13 November 2015 in Paris, the ‘mutual assistance clause’ of the Treaty of Lisbon was invoked for the first time by an EU Member State. We welcome the unanimous and full support extended to France by all Member States and their readiness to provide all necessary aid and assistance. The EU has never before faced such a convergence of security crises on its doorstep. Although defence policy remains a matter of national sovereignty, we can make European Defence more effective and efficient through European Solidarity.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. On 17 November, following the devastating terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France invoked the so-called mutual assistance clause on Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Accordingly, in the event of an armed attack on the territory of a Member State, the other Member States owe it all the support in their power. This must be consistent with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the right of self-defense of a State, and also in accordance with the commitments made under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for NATO members. Irrespective of existing legal provisions, there is no question that France must be given the full estout of support from the EU and all Member States. Our European values, our freedom and our principles of the rule of law must be defended unreservedly. With regard to the legal aspects, it is necessary to clarify in the longer term where an EU Member State is exposed to a threat, Article 47(7) (TEU) and when Article 222 is to be insofared under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). For NATO members, the relationship of these provisions to Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, which governs the case for the alliance, must also be determined. However, I reject a permanent European army called for in the European Parliament resolution without a previous, comprehensive debate followed by direct democratic legitimacy.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ After the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015, France asked for mutual aid and assistance from the other Member States, legally based on Article 42 of the TEU. The EU ministers expressed their will to support this request. This mutual aid was used for the first time (since the Lisbon Treaty). I voted against this resolution, since I do not agree when the EU is used for military intervention. Another reason is also because none of the European institutions were involved in the process. The decision was taken only from the Council, without seeking the agreement of the Commission or the Parliament.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ By invoking article 42(7) TEU instead of article 222 TFEU (the so-called ‘solidarity clause’), France chose an intra—government approach rather than an institutional one. In this regard, we can conclude that the activation of Article 42(7) represents an important test for Member States since they are obliged to provide ‘aid and assistance by all means in their power’ to support France. There is no doubt that the best way to pass this test for Member States is to take their commitments under Article 42(7) TEU seriously. This refers to the point that Member States should be well prepared not only to provide immediate support (whether it is political, military of financial) but also to bear the cost of such support. Moreover, to achieve better application in future applications of Article 42(7), Member States should use the full potential of the European institutions, especially the EEAS and the Commission. Moreover, this will facilitate cohesion between the EU institutions and Member States, which will hopefully result in further integration.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the mutual defence clause. This report aims to use terrorist attacks to justify a further expansion of the European Union's powers in the areas of criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. Paragraph 17 calls for a European foreign policy; paragraph 18 calls for a European defence policy. European states must be able to cooperate in these areas, but on a voluntary and intergovernmental basis.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it intends to use the attacks to justify a further expansion of the Union's powers in the areas of criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out against this text requested by France.  Once again, we are facing a European Union that wants to expand its powers and encroach on the sovereignty of States, which is also in matters as important as criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. If the initiative, motivated by the dramatic attacks of November 13 in Paris, is obviously commendable, the realization is unfortunately not. The Union does not have to interfere further in the internal affairs of the Member States. The fight against terrorism, through diplomatic, military and criminal policies, is the sole responsibility of the States and must remain so.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament in favour of activating the mutual defence clause requested by France under the pretext of the latest attacks in Paris since this manoeuvre, if carried out, will strengthen the process of converting the European Union into a military alliance. This is a misguided response to the Paris attacks. France's interpretation is sesatic and intentional since a terrorist attack is not an act of war no long as they are committed. Its interpretation is a fraud of international law and the return to the logic of the war on terror. In the face of terrorism, only civilian responses, police action, intelligence, cutting off the funding of terrorist groups and cutting off international support. In any event, the answer must always be within the rule of law and these acts cannot be used as a pretext for a collective cut in individual freedoms.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. On 17 November, following the devastating terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France called for the so-called mutual assistance clause with Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Accordingly, in the event of an armed attack on the territory of a Member State, the other Member States owe it all the support in their power. This must be consistent with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the right of self-defense of a State, and also in accordance with the commitments made under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for NATO members. Irrespective of existing legal provisions, there is no question that France must be given the full estout of support from the EU and all Member States. Our European values, our freedom and our principles of the rule of law must be defended unreservedly. With regard to the legal aspects, it is necessary to clarify in the longer term where an EU Member State is exposed to a threat, Article 42(7) (TEU) and when Article 222 is to be insofared under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). For NATO members, the relationship of these provisions must also be determined with Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, which governs the case for the alliance. However, I reject a permanent European army called for in the European Parliament resolution without a previous, comprehensive debate followed by direct democratic legitimacy.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is a move towards a European army. The EU points to the example of migration quotas as a risk to the Czech Republic.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Following last year's terrorist attack in Paris, after which France formally invoked Art. 42(7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament considers it necessary to further ensure safeguards in the EU. In particular, measures should be taken to control the movement of cold weapons and explosive devices. Structural sharing of information as well as operational support in particular on borders between Member States should be ensured to implement these measures. Furthermore, the motion for a resolution underlines the need to further strengthen rules and regulations when it comes to acquiring cold weapons and explosive devices. I supported the proposal for a resolution, in order to reduce the possibility of terrorist attacks, and to strengthen security in the EU. More intensive cooperation between Member States on security can only enhance the overall security situation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – For a mutual defence clause to be meaningful, its content must be carried out in a sufficiently timely and flexible manner. Member States' authorities must report on the undercapacity of their own forces in good time. The refugee crisis, coupled with terrorist attacks, clearly demonstrates that there is no time for statements and policies. The security of Europe and its people requires decisive and fundamental action. Indecision and ignorance of the integrated evaluation reports have already taken their toll in the form of terrorist attacks in Paris and other violence in several parts of Europe. The mutual defence clause guarantees mutual assistance between Member States in the event of terrorist attacks, but at the same time urgent measures must be taken that have preventive effects as a matter of priority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on the mutual defence clause for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 20/1/2016 but also because I do not believe that this report is complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution but voted against Paragraph 11 because I do not believe that the EU needs ‘permanent civil—military headquarters’.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mutual defence clause. According to this clause, contained in Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), where an EU country suffers armed aggression on its territory, the other EU countries are obliged to provide it with aid and assistance by all means at its possession, in accordance with Article 51 of the United Nations Charter. Solidarity, aid and mutual assistance between the Member States, including through the use of Union resources, are among the foundations of the European Union. A common European strategy is essential if the principle of mutual defence is to be implemented and so that the fight against international terrorism, which is one of the Union's priorities, can be guaranteed and the principle of solidarity is applied, which requires action both inside and outside its territory.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The proposal for a Joint Resolution of Parliament on the mutual defence clause shows our satisfaction with the full and unanimous support given to France by all Member States, and welcomes, in particular, the willingness of all Member States to provide all the necessary assistance and assistance. However, in view of the doubts that have existed about this clause after this case, in Parliament we consider that adjustments need to be made and procedures for their implementation better defined. That is why my support for this proposal, which is also committed to giving the European Union a more important coordinating role in this process.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This resolution is not compatible with the Austrian requirement of neutrality. I am therefore voting against this motion for a resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, following the terrorist attacks in Paris, the application of the mutual assistance provision is a unique opportunity to create the basis for a strong and sustainable European Defence Union. The report provides for key policies and measures that enable Member States to prepare themselves to deal with the growing internal and external security threats and challenges.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The French government invoked Article 42, paragraph 7, of the EU Treaty in the wake of the 13 November 2015 attacks in Paris. As a result, the Member States of the European Union owe it "help and assistance by all means in their power. France's demands focus on supporting France's operations in Iraq and Syria through the pooling of resources, as well as support on other areas of intervention (Mali, Sahel, CAR and Lebanon) in order to redeploy its troops. In fact, the mobilization of other Member States remains limited. The resolution proposes, to counteract this, "to cooperate more with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in order to increase the compatibility of the security and defence policies established by these two entities." Finally, the resolution calls for the establishment, at European level, of a "permanent civilian and military headquarters at the strategic and operational levels, (...) responsible for planning strategic and operational emergency measures." I am voting against this text, which takes the pretext of the fight against terrorism to further defend France and Europe in the United States.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Europeanists here use the pretext of recent attacks to further expand the European Union's powers over criminal law, military cooperation and intelligence. This further decline in the sovereignty of the Member States is unacceptable, which is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The mutual defence clause represents solidarity between Member States in the face of an external threat, the fundamental principle of the Union.  In the context of cross-border crime that goes beyond the borders of sovereignty, I share the position that the European Union can only be prepared to meet internal and external security challenges if there is genuine solidarity between Member States in this area.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this cross-party resolution regarding the Union’s mutual defence clause because I believe that Member States should support each other in this time of heightened uncertainty and insecurity.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. As Daesh's terrorist attacks on Member States and our nationals increase, and in the spirit of a willingness to respond effectively to the crises facing the Union, we welcome the adoption of this resolution on the mutual defence clause covered in Article 42, paragraph 7 of the EU Treaty. The invocation of this clause for the first time by France in November 2015, following the terrorist attacks on its territory, calls us to consider the possibilities of responding to the crises they face and thus directs us towards the revision of this clause. Despite the general commitment of the twenty-eight following France's appeal, the modalities for the implementation and implementation of this clause remain undefined to this day and we are deeply concerned about this. We call on the HR/VP to address this lack of clarity and to set guidelines for this clause so that it can respond effectively when it is invoked. With the adoption of this resolution, we call on the HR/VP, the Commission and the Council to revise the basis of this clause, as clarification of its application is, in our view, essential.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The attacks that occurred in Paris last November have shaken the world. The situation has escalated dramatically, which has been felt in several major cities in Europe, so we have started to ask ourselves questions about common security. Through the media, we have seen reports surfaced of reports of a lack of exchange of information on criminals between the secret services of the various Member States of the European Union. This area deserves increased attention, as the exchange of correct information can greatly help reduce crime. I also consider it essential for Europe's security that the details of the mutual defence clause be precisely defined. I welcome point 6 of the motion for a resolution, which prioritises a political solution to the crisis in the Middle East and North Africa. Armed conflict always has two sides of the coin: it rarely produces satisfactory results, but unnecessary loss of life is an integral part of it. For these reasons, I agree with the content of the motion for a resolution.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the recent Paris attacks, the French Government has decided to invoke the mutual defence clause stipulated in the Treaty of the European Union. This means that Member States now have an obligation to aid and assist France by all means in their power in its actions against terrorism, in this particular context. Given that this is the first time that the clause has been invoked, the Parliament’s resolution primarily calls for establishing a clear implementation and monitoring procedure for the clause. It is a sensible approach that can potentially lay the groundwork for an effective EU security and defence mechanism and I therefore support it.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven groups on the mutual protection clause: PPE, Verts/ALE, S&D, GUE/NGL, ALDE, ECR and EFDD, tabled a motion for a resolution. Among them, PPE, S&D and ALDE agreed on the content of the resolution. I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence clause, corresponding to Article 42(7) OF the TUE, is invoked for the first time in the Union after the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015. Solidarity, aid and mutual assistance between Member States are basic principles of the European project, which should not be forgotten, as the fight against terrorism must have a comprehensive response. I therefore believe that it is necessary to clarify the practices and guidelines that ensure an effective and clear response whenever any Member State invokes the mutual defence clause and the very role of the European institutions in this process.  I am in favour of this proposal, stressing that the Union needs a common security and defence policy that responds to global challenges. Bilateral cooperation between Member States and international organisations should also be strengthened by taking advantage of existing instruments.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the urgent adoption of a political framework for the implementation of Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on European Union (mutual defence clause) in order to combat terrorist attacks that have caused hundreds of deaths and thousands of injuries in the Union since 2004. This text calls for a more active role of the Union's institutions in security and defence policy and the implementation of all the provisions in the treaty. It is a question of joining together to fight the barbarism that hit France in particular hard in November 2015.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Unable to attend the votes held on Thursday 21 January, I would like to express my support for the resolution on the mutual defence clause, which supports France's approach in its request for the application of Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty on european Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty of Lisbon strengthens the solidarity between EU countries in dealing with external threats by introducing a mutual defence clause (Article  42(7) of the Treaty on European Union). This mutual defence clause provides that if an EU country is the victim of armed aggression on its territory, the other EU countries have an obligation to aid and assist it by all means. I have voted for this resolution on the mutual defence clause.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the position expressed by the European Parliament in this document. France's first-time invocation of the mutual defence clause highlighted the lack of mechanisms necessary to manage and coordinate such a situation.  Thus, I join those who support the establishment of a permanent civilian-military command with the aim of planning and coordinating the emergency response system at EU level. In the context of growing terrorist threats across the EU, it is essential that Member States understand that only through better cooperation and coordination can these attacks be prevented and responded effectively to emergencies.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The unprecedented terrorist attacks in Paris have challenged the EU to find new ways to ensure the safety of its citizens. A basic precondition is a willingness to cooperate even where Member States have traditionally not been in a position to share information and take joint action, such as military action or intelligence activities. In this sense, I also welcomed the position of France, which was the first Member State in history to initiate the activation of the mutual defence clause, the thus creating an opportunity for closer and more coordinated action by The Member States in areas key to the effective fight against terrorism. It will be up to them whether they take advantage of this opportunity for the benefit of EU citizens.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The resolution contradicts the Austrian requirement of neutrality, as it calls, for example, for greater involvement of the EU and its troops in military operations. Consequently, I voted against.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The implementation of the mutual protection clause in practice must be swift and effective in order for the requesting State to also be able to benefit from it. In order to combat terrorism, it is necessary to enhance europol's work and exchange of information, and a European Intelligence Agency must also be established if necessary. The Schengen system must be enhanced, but it must not be forgotten that the free movement of people within the European Union is one of the fundamental freedoms of the EU. There is a need to strengthen controls at the external borders, to establish a proper legal framework for arms trafficking, to work more hard to integrate people into society and to contribute to education.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As Europe is a possible battleground, given the latest terrorist attacks, it is our duty to show solidarity, help and assistance. Mutual defence, in my opinion, is a right that must be pursued. I would give you all my full support by voting in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Europe needs a deep discussion on foreign security and defence policy to enter into a structured exchange and operational cooperation between military, border control agencies, the police and the secret services. The activation of the mutual defence clause means a first step in this direction, which I fully support.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015, as well as the threat posed by Daesh to the security of EU citizens, I wholeheartedly welcome the Resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause. I believe that the EU must demonstrate the unity of all Member States in its fight against terrorism. In this regard, I support the development of a policy framework that should enable the creation of effective instruments necessary in the face of terrorist and other security threats. Preventing any form of violent extremism at source should be a priority in our fight against terrorism. We must recognise to ourselves that EU nationals are also among the terrorists, which is why it is very important to take appropriate measures to control the movement of arms and persons as soon as possible. We must encourage, establish and effectively implement structured and continuous exchange of information between Member States. At the same time, the EU must also be more actively involved in finding a peaceful solution to the conflicts in the Middle East, which, as we could see, have major consequences not only for local people but also for EU citizens.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorism is a reality that undermines the stability of our societies. In recent months we have witnessed violent escalations that, in Europe, culminated in the bloody attacks in Paris, on 13 November 2015. The fight against terrorism is certainly a priority for the Union, and the mutual defence clause is evidence of this, but it must be remembered that preventive efforts need to be stepped up.  Following the atrocious events in France, france invoked Article 42(7) for the first time in the history of the Union, triggering this clause. This is a very important mechanism for establishing effective cooperation between Member States, as well as a single European defence that would make the Union's external action coherent and autonomous.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is necessary to bring this issue into the political debate, particularly in the Council and the European Parliament, in order to achieve integration between the EU's security and defence instruments and the resources of the Member States, enhancing their effectiveness. The priority, given the events, is to ensure greater and more careful sharing of information by the intelligence agencies of each Member State.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Following the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November last year, the French Defence Minister invoked Article 42 for the first time in the HISTORY of the EU. agreement on the functioning of the European Union and, due to an "armed attack on the territory of France", asked all Member States for "all assistance and support, as far as possible". Many interpret this part of the Lisbon Treaty as a kind of counterpart to Article 5 of the Lisbon Treaty. The North Atlantic Treaty Agreement, which, in the event of an attack on a member of the Alliance, obliges all Member States to come to its aid. The European partners are virtually unusable to reject the French application, as this would not stand in solidarity. And they all answered yes. The truth is that France can be helped in different ways and it is not necessary for this support to be military. But again many questions are being asked even more sharply about the internal security of the European Union that exceeds the protection of national states. The best answer would be if the ZSOP ceased to be the weakest link of European integration.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 A series of terrorist attacks in France in 2015 culminated in Paris in November of that year. Following these attacks, France officially invoked the principle of mutual defence enshsed in Article 42(1) of the Treaty. In this article, it is not the first time that the European Union has been in a state of In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution confirming the European Union's willingness to fulfil its mutual defence commitments and proposing several instruments to strengthen mutual defence at European level. I have long joined the voices of those calling for the strengthening of European mutual defence instruments. Unfortunately, the situation around the EU's borders has deteriorated, and therefore it is necessary to strengthen its so-called hard power. We cannot pretend that NATO will provide our security exclusively. I therefore agree with the need for a greater and really effective exchange of information between European secret services and with the creation of European command structures. This would not be a substitution or de-nato de-establishment, on the contrary, all these defence initiatives should be closely coordinated with NATO. The Czech Republic is undoubtedly ready to meet its obligations under the common European defence. It is also one of the few Member States to provide specialists and material during the current migration crisis in order to contribute to a common European defence.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Following last November's terrorist attacks in Paris, France asked for the support of other EU countries using the 'mutual defence' clause in Article 42(7) TEU, which had never been used before.  The clause, having been used for the first time, has given rise to the need to implement ad hoc measures and to provide for completely new management and cooperation. For this reason, the definition of practical arrangements and guidelines for the future activation of the mutual defence clause should be a priority for the Union.  I welcomed the unanimous support given to France by all Member States and the willingness to provide all the necessary help and assistance. I hope that the Member States will continue to maintain their unconditional and lasting support for as long as is necessary to ensure the maximum safety of citizens across the Alps. I see the activation of the mutual assistance clause as a unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a genuine common defence and security policy of the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 The entire European Union is facing an unprecedented threat of violence and terrorism and it is the duty of all Member States to address this threat. France has been the victim of a reprehensable attack on an unprecedented scale, and under the Treaty of Lisbon Article 42 TEU containing assistance to the affected Member State has been activated. Member States must cooperate with each other on countering and preventing terrorist threats and seek to apply practical solutions to their legal frameworks. The EU is facing major challenges this year, and this clause contains many steps that we should take to prevent any further threats.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Poland is in solidarity with France and, at a meeting of defence ministers, declared all assistance to France after the terrorist attacks in Paris in accordance with Article 42(7) OF the EU HERE. However, this article only speaks of bilateral cooperation and calls on member states to coordinate their security policy "within NATO, which for those countries that belong to it, continues to be the foundation of their common defence". I therefore believe that the use of Article 42(7) to strengthen the EU's role in the field of security and defence is contrary to the spirit and letter of this article.  However, due to the need to show solidarity with France after the terrorist attacks, I abstained.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the terrorist attacks in Paris, the President of the French Republic has declared that France is at war. This speech of 16 November 2015 was followed by the invocation of the mutual defence clause provided for in Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union, through which aid and assistance to the requesting country is triggered by all means available to the Member States. This unprecedented request was accepted with ad hoc measures, ad hoc management and ad hoc cooperation, which left the bare the absence of practical modalities and guidelines indispensable for effectively responding to the invocation of the clause. The rapporteur considers that, in the solidarity effort to help France, basic and fundamental structures are lacking. Without them it will not be possible to arbitrate cooperation and coordination between Member States. In this regard, the report recommends the establishment of a permanent civilian-military headquarters, which is responsible for strategic and operational planning in the field of collective defence. Having said the above, I supported with my vote this resolution, which calls on the Council and the Member States to move forward in creating a policy framework to guide the implementation of the above-mentioned article.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because we do not support the further militarisation of the EU. We are also specifically concerned about discussion of the development of a European Defence Union or further activation of other defence provisions contained within the Lisbon treaty. UKIP is in complete support of the French people in their fight against terrorism and offers its condolences for the tragic attacks in Paris last year. However, we do not support the activation of Article 42(7). The UK has strong defence ties with France, through NATO and bilateral agreements between the two countries, such as the Lancaster House Treaties (2010). UKIP supported Amendment 1 to the resolution on the Mutual Defence Clause because it rejects the activation of Article 42(7) TEU. This should, however, not be interpreted as offering support for any other statements contained within this amendment.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. Since 2004, the EU and the Member States have been the target of several terrorist attacks, which have left hundreds dead and several thousand injured. On 13 November 2015, Paris was the scene of several attacks, resulting in at least 130 fatalities from more than 26 nations, which led the French government to officially invoke the mutual defence clause. I voted in favour of this report which strongly condemns the abominable terrorist attacks perpetrated by Daexe. Member States have an obligation to provide assistance and assistance to France by all means at their fingertips in accordance with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations. The EU institutions need to be more active in security and defence policy and need to promote the implementation of all the provisions of security and defence policy enshrined in the Treaties. The report adds that the invocation of the mutual defence clause and the solidarity clause under the Treaties is, first of all, a political issue, pointing out that the European Council and the European Parliament are the bodies indicated for the debate whenever such clauses are invoked.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution.  The mutual defence clause under the EU Treaty was invoked by France, for the first time in the union's history, following the terrorist and obscurantist aggression that our country suffered last November.  The means of a strong and sustainable European Defence Union must be strengthened to better address internal and external security issues. We have been saying that for a long time. It is a pity to have to wait for the events of the fatal content of Paris for a decisive step to be taken in this direction.   In this regard, I would remind you that any action taken in the permanent and multidimensional fight against terrorism and violent extremism cannot be detached from respect for democratic provisions as well as intangible European and universal values, otherwise this fight will already be lost. In addition, the use of this clause must be the subject of political debate at the level of the European Parliament and the European Council, while practical modalities and guidelines can be formulated by the High Representative to frame its operation. This is essential.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 I cannot fail to feel satisfaction with the unanimous support expressed to France by all Member States, noting that any use of force must be in line with the Charter of the United Nations, international human rights law and international humanitarian law. This mutual defence clause was invoked for the first time and the present case will serve as a precedent for its future uses and should also promote the strengthening of security and defence at European level. The invocation of the mutual defence clause and the solidarity clause under the Treaties is first and foremost a matter of a political nature and the European Council and the European Parliament are the bodies indicated for political debate where these clauses are invoked.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. After the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France called on EU member states to provide assistance and assistance, including the exchange of intelligence, to fight the Islamic State. It invoked Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on the European Union, which states that "if a Member State is the object of armed aggression on its territory, the other Member States have an obligation to it to help and assist by all means". Today, with the vote on this resolution, we gave our unanimous support to France. "The activation of the mutual defence clause is indeed a unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a strong and sustainable European Defence Union [...] ready to face overwhelming internal and external security threats," the adopted text stresses. We called on EU Member States to look for ways to build more effective cooperation between border management agencies, police and other law enforcement agencies and to improve the exchange of information on the movement of weapons, explosives and suspected terrorists. We have also suggested the establishment of EU civil-military headquarters to prepare contingency plans, particularly for collective defence.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the November terrorist attacks in Paris, France requested assistance from the other EU Member States by invoking the mutual defence clause, which was included in the Treaty on European Union, but which had never been used before. The report therefore considers that this request should serve as a catalyst for an in-depth debate on the multidimensional nature of security and defence at European level, as the invocation of the mutual defence clause and the solidarity clause under the Treaties is, first of all, a political issue, with the Council and the European Parliament being the ones indicated for the political debate , where they are invoked. I therefore support the concerns contained in the resolution as to the urgent need to establish practical arrangements and guidelines for the future implementation of the mutual defence clause, bearing in view of the view that terrorism is increasingly a latent threat that does not give a respite and deserves a full response. I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on European actors, and in particular the Member States, to clarify the implementation of the mutual defence clause, which was activated by France last November.  In the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France invoked the provisions of Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty on european Union, which calls for European solidarity in defence. All Member States are indeed affected by the terrorist threat. That is why the activation of this mutual defence clause must be an opportunity for the concrete expression of the solidarity of European states.  We welcome the unanimous responses of support from the other 27 Member States. However, the terms of the application of this clause remain indefinite to this day and more concrete actions must be taken to support France in the various theatres of war on which it operates.  I am therefore committed to this text, which calls for the definition of guidelines for the implementation of the activation of this clause.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The problems posed today by terrorism within Europe's borders, the political instability of many countries bordering the Mediterranean and the control of the flow of migrants make it necessary to speed up the project, which is increasingly being talked about, of a common European defence policy. The Member States must stop 'chatting' on this issue, but open up to a structured dialogue with well-defined deadlines, starting with improving cooperation between (external) border control agents, police and secret services.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We reject the activation of paragraph 7 of Article 42 OFC because it represents an ineffective and high-risk military response to cause even more innocent victims, greater population displacement and further destruction of territories. We advocate diplomatic structural solutions, development cooperation and peaceful conflict resolution under international law outside the EU; within the EU, we advocate actions that prioritize police research and action with full respect for human rights and individual freedoms, as well as appropriate and sufficient public integration and interculturality policies.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament in favour of activating the mutual defence clause requested by France under the pretext of the latest attacks in Paris since this manoeuvre, if carried out, will strengthen the process of converting the European Union into a military alliance. This is a misguided response to the Paris attacks. France's interpretation is sesatic and intentional since a terrorist attack is not an act of war no long as they are committed. Its interpretation is a fraud of international law and the return to the logic of the war on terror. In the face of terrorism, only civilian responses, police action, intelligence, cutting off the funding of terrorist groups and cutting off international support. In any event, the answer must always be within the rule of law and these acts cannot be used as a pretext for a collective cut in individual freedoms.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first time that the mutual defence clause has been invoked, which means that the case will serve as a precedent for the future of this clause and will give an insight into where else the clause can and will be applied in the future. As with a number of things in the Treaties, the architecture for security and defence has not yet been fully implemented and provides only for ‘enhanced cooperation’ within the scope of the CSDP. I am joining many of my colleagues in the chamber today in calling on yhe Council and the Member States to draft and adopt practical arrangements and guidelines for ensuring an effective response in the event that a Member State invokes the mutual defence clause again in the future, as well as an analysis of the role of the EU’s institutions.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ last year's November attacks in Paris were a terrifying crime carried out on European citizens. The way defenceless people have lost their lives is extremely cowardly and condemnable. I therefore believe that declaring war on the terrorist organisation Daesh was a legitimate response from the French Government. In addition, however, it must be acknowledged that these events have exposed the weaknesses of European security in full nathote. Mutual assistance is also part of the EU's founding principles. After these attacks, it was the first time that one Member State would ask for assistance by referring to the mutual defence clause. According to this Article, other Member States are obliged to provide the means and assistance that are in their capabilities if one State is the target of an armed attack. All countries have shown readiness to support France where possible. On the other hand, these are still only bilateral agreements between France and other countries. Since this clause was used for the first time, there are still no precise procedures for applying it. The lack of common rules stemming from mutual defence has thus led to dedicated measures and uncoordinated cooperation. The Council must be informed of the activities carried out by the countries in cooperation with France in order to reflect in the future on the preconditions for a common European defence. At a time of ongoing conflicts in the surrounding area, the European defence system is also in our interest, which is why I supported the resolution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution in the first place expresses deep shock at the brutality and inhumanity of the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015. It strongly condemns terrorist attacks and calls on all Europeans to respond to them with more democracy, openness, freedom and respect for human rights.  I agree that more European cooperation is needed in the fight against terrorism and that this requires a number of new strategies, guidelines, instruments, funds and procedures. I also believe that efforts need to be stepped up in the area of deradicalisation, preventing violent extremism and combating terrorism. In doing so, the focus should be on strengthening social cohesion, crime prevention, targeted police action and security measures based on individual suspicions or concrete threats.  I support the EU's proposed response to terrorism, which promotes democracy, dialogue and good governance. All of the above includes a motion for a resolution, which is why I supported it in plenary.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. On 17 November, following the devastating terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France called for the so-called mutual assistance clause with Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Accordingly, in the event of an armed attack on the territory of a Member State, the other Member States owe it all the support in their power. This must be consistent with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the right of self-defense of a State, and also in accordance with the commitments made under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for NATO members. Irrespective of existing legal provisions, there is no question that France must be given the full estout of support from the EU and all Member States. Our European values, our freedom and our principles of the rule of law must be defended unreservedly. With regard to the legal aspects, it is necessary to clarify in the longer term where an EU Member State is exposed to a threat, Article 42(7) (TEU) and when Article 222 is to be insofared under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). For NATO members, the relationship of these provisions must also be determined with Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, which governs the case for the alliance. However, I reject a permanent European army called for in the European Parliament resolution without a previous, comprehensive debate followed by direct democratic legitimacy.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the motion for a resolution on Article 42(2) of the Ec Treaty. 7 in response to the Terrorist Attacks in Paris. The implementation of Article 42(7) guaranteeing assistance and cooperation to our French allies who rightly feel threatened is our moral duty. However, it is important to remember that these terrorist attacks were not only an attack on France or Parisians, but rather were intended as aggression against the entire European Union and the ideals of liberal democracy; so all those who identify with European culture and civilization were the indirect targets of terrorists. It is therefore absolutely essential to respond with a single European voice. This proposal is also important because it will set a precedent for the EU's future common foreign and security policy. One of the reasons for the success of these terrorist attacks was that European intelligence and security services were unable to cooperate and coordinate effectively. At the same time, the common security policy will not compete or replace NATO structures; it is only an improvement and deepening of cooperation between the defence forces of the Member States. Eu-wide cooperation will better counter such a bloodthirsty enemy as the Islamic State, and we will be able to confront Russian aggression or solve the complicated problems associated with the refugee crisis.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. \u2012 N-VA voted in favour of this joint resolution because it believes in the added value that a European army can offer. Nevertheless, pooling military resources at European level is a long-term project. In the meantime, it is to build on ad hoc bilateral and multilateral cooperation, including on the basis of Article 42(7) of THE VEU. There is no need to revise this article in the meantime, because the EU institutions are more involved or subject to more rules. What works doesn't have to be entertained.  At the military level, ging ties with like-minded states is the best guarantee to build trust and move towards more structural mechanisms. What defence policy should be linked to this and how that should relate to the NATO framework is a complex question. This question is currently the subject of discussions in the context of the development of a new foreign security and defence strategy, which is being developed by Federica Mogherini as High Representative in charge of that policy branch.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒If one of the Member States is attacked in its territorial territory, the Mutual Defence Clause obliges other countries to assist it with all available means in accordance with Article 51 of the Regulation. Charters of the United Nations. The Union and its Member States shall act together in a spirit of solidarity if a Member State is the target of a terrorist attack, a victim of a natural or man-made accident. The Union aims to prevent a terrorist threat addressed to Member States, protect democratic institutions and civilian populations from possible attacks and assist Member States. The European Council regularly assesses the threats faced by the Union to enable the Union and its Member States to act effectively. This is due to the terrorist attacks that took place in November 2015 in Paris and therefore the European Union has become more involved in counter-terrorism cooperation. In this case, France invoked mutual defence and solidarity clauses. This is the first time a Member State has invoked these clauses, and that is why I support it.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the motion for a joint resolution on the mutual defence clause. We have seen terrorist attacks and threats of terrorist attacks in the last year, and we must respond accordingly.  I welcome the common understanding and solidarity of the European defence ministers, who met a few days after the attacks. Coordination and cooperation between Member States and other international partners, including the Arab world, is crucial. I believe that the priority is resolving the conflict in Syria and formulating a common foreign policy on the future of Syria and the wider Middle East.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's resolution on the mutual defence clause (Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union), as it is right to respond to the impulse that has come from the French Government, which invoked this clause following the terrorist attacks of November last year. The French Government was the first government to do so, and it turned out that there was no basic procedure for responding to the application of this clause and that follow-up measures were taken on an ad hoc basis. According to the European Parliament, the French call is intended to provide an impetus for the development of the potential of all the provisions of the Treaties relating to security and defence, which may gradually create a more uniform UNION procedure in these areas. In the meantime, however, intelligence sharing and operational cooperation between national security forces responsible for progress in the field of Union security and defence need to be strengthened.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution concerns the mutual defence clause of the EU Treaty of Operation, under which EU countries must provide "assistance and assistance" to their counterpart a Member State under armed attack, either in the form of an exchange of information or even by air strikes. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the EU's dominant forces, with France prominent and through regulations such as Article 42 of the Treaty of Lisbon, have tried to give their expansionary policies legislative "approval" while also involving other countries in their methodologies in order to achieve their objectives in the Middle East and Africa more easily. The term Mutual Defence Clause is by no means accidental, as this term is also used in Article 5 of nato's Founding Treaty. We voted against the report because we disagree both with the policy of intervention in the internal states and with the objective of creating a European alliance to promote the imperialist policies of the dominant circles of the Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The effective response to terrorism requires, in principle, the admission by the victims that their wrong policies were also the cause of its development in their country. When you create wars in third countries to strengthen your geopolitical position, when under the pretext of freedom of speech you insult the intelligence and religion of other fellow human beings and when you sacrifice human souls on the altar of power and economic interests you cannot ask for the help of others to protect you without changing your attitude and policy.  Terrorism must be tackled, but above all its causes must be neutralised. The application of this clause will involve other countries in the dance of terrorism rather than solve the problem.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of the decision, essentially agreeing with the positive but critical approach of the report. Following the application, for the first time, of the mutual protection clause under Article 42(7) TSI following terrorist acts there, a number of valuable practical experiences and lessons learned from this important instrument of EU solidarity have emerged. On this basis, I agree that, in addition to the fundamentally encouraging experience, the legal framework for mutual assistance between Member States in a defence situation needs to be further clarified and clarified in order to avoid the ad hoc solutions that have now occurred. I think it is important that the report emphasises in particular that this work must be in line with the renewal of the TSG and that the political debates on this should be conducted as soon as possible in the for a of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Following the November attacks in Paris, France decided to invoke, on the basis of Article 42 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a mutual defence clause in order to obtain assistance from other EU Member States in the fight against the perpetrators of this tragedy. The unanimous support given to Paris by the Member States of the European Union, particularly as regards the exchange of intelligence on the movement of arms, explosives and movements of suspected terrorists, is extremely important for the effectiveness of these efforts. This exceptional situation can undoubtedly serve as a pretext for creating also a more effective platform for cooperation on border management or police and other law enforcement activities. The French request for assistance in the fight against the so-called Islamic State should give impetus to closer cooperation on European security and defence and to the development of practical solutions by the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy in order to ensure an effective collective response to similar situations in the future.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because I consider it a mistake - a serious mistake - to call for the establishment of permanent headquarters to plan the EU's defence and to manage it in cooperation with NATO. The idea of an EU moving under NATO will certainly not help to give rise to benecious feelings towards nato. The EU cannot be perceived as a peaceful mediator who stands above the parties.  I hope that, instead of thinking about developing and coordinating its military defence potential, the EU will return rather to its peaceful vocation at birth, which took place under the banner of a commitment not to repeat the horrors and mistakes of the two world wars.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks that have taken place in France over the past year have demonstrated the need for the EU to strengthen its security and defence policy. The activation of the mutual defence clause, in accordance with Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union, was the automatic reaction of the Member States to defend democratic institutions and the civilian population. However, at present, Member States' capabilities to send troops for external intervention in Syria and Iraq, as requested by France, are being reduced. This requires, in the future, to accelerate the implementation of the security and defence architecture set out in the EU Treaties by strengthening cooperation within the framework of the common security and defence policy.  Cooperation may also be carried out through groups of Member States for specific missions, but also through permanent structured cooperation in the military field. The Council and the Member States are at the main responsible at this time for the adoption of practical arrangements to ensure a consistent response when invoking the mutual defence clause. The role of the European institutions in this case should also be clarified. The current resolution is more than necessary, supporting the improvement of the coordination of the various existing structures at national and European level.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I share the ideas of this text. I condemn in the strongest terms the terrible terrorist attacks perpetrated by the Islamic State group.  The European Parliament expresses its deepest sympathy and solidarity and expresses its condolences to all the victims of the terrorist attacks and their families.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it draws attention to the fact that for the first time the Mutual Defence Clause (Article 42(7) of the Treaty of the European Union) was invoked but regrets that the application of Article 42(7) TEU has not been efficiently managed so far. It calls on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the European Council and the European Commission to clarify the relevant Union means and procedures within the scope of the Mutual Defence Clause (Article 42(7)). I also believe that the activation of the Mutual Defence Clause is a singular opportunity to establish the grounds for a strong and sustainable European Security and Defence

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mutual defence clause, because in situations of crisis such as those caused by a terrorist attack, it is particularly important for the European Parliament to show support and joint assistance to its members.  The rise in threats, where civilians are mainly at risk, calls for strengthening Europe's internal and external security and defences. We will achieve this through a common European Union strategy and closer structured cooperation between Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We reject the activation of paragraph 7 of Article 42 OFC because it represents an ineffective and high-risk military response to cause even more innocent victims, greater population displacement and further destruction of territories. We advocate diplomatic structural solutions, development cooperation and peaceful conflict resolution under international law outside the EU; within the EU, we advocate actions that prioritize police research and action with full respect for human rights and individual freedoms, as well as appropriate and sufficient public integration and interculturality policies.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. On 17 November, following the devastating terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015, France called for the so-called mutual assistance clause with Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Accordingly, in the event of an armed attack on the territory of a Member State, the other Member States owe it all the support in their power. This must be consistent with Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, which establishes the right of self-defense of a State, and also in accordance with the commitments made under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for NATO members. Irrespective of existing legal provisions, there is no question that France must be given the full estout of support from the EU and all Member States. Our European values, our freedom and our principles of the rule of law must be defended unreservedly. With regard to the legal aspects, it is necessary to clarify in the longer term where an EU Member State is exposed to a threat, Article 42(7) (TEU) and when Article 222 is to be insofared under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). For NATO members, the relationship of these provisions must also be determined with Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, which governs the case for the alliance. However, I reject a permanent European army called for in the European Parliament resolution without a previous, comprehensive debate followed by direct democratic legitimacy.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On November 13, 2015, several terrorist attacks took place in Paris, in which at least 130 people from more than 26 different countries were killed. The fight against international terrorism is one of the Union's top objectives and the enforcement of the principle of solidarity requires both domestic and foreign action, in accordance with international law. The internal and external dimensions of EU security are necessarily and closely linked. I voted in favour of the S&D group's proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, other political groups made the same strategic mistake as France and the EU Member States: to link the terrible Paris attacks, which were mainly committed by EU citizens, to military interventions abroad. The majority in the EP went even further than France and the Member States: they presented and adopted a resolution which calls for using the terrorist attacks and the activation of Article 42(7) TEU for far—reaching institutional changes – the establishment of a permanent EU military headquarter, a Defence Union for collective defence like NATO, the activation of the structured cooperation of Article 44 TEU and further aspects of military cooperation in the field of CSDP. Greens/EFA would have preferred and supported the activation of Article 222 TFEU, which is specifically designed for responding to terrorist attacks on the territory of an EU Member State and which relies on a criminal justice approach to terrorism by making use of EU instruments, procedures and funds. The way chosen by France and the Member States weakens EU institutions, values and principles, including CFSP and CSDP.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The proposal for a Joint Resolution highlights the unanimous support for France by all Member States after relying for the first time on the mutual defence clause laid down in Article 42(7) OFA. We must vote in favour of this joint motion for a resolution since the attack on France was an attack on all the Member States of the European Union. It is therefore good that, through this response, Member States have made a common front to this threat.
