name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament in favour of activating the mutual defence clause requested by France under the pretext of the latest attacks in Paris since this manoeuvre, if carried out, will strengthen the process of converting the European Union into a military alliance. This is a misguided response to the Paris attacks. France's interpretation is sesatic and intentional since a terrorist attack is not an act of war no long as they are committed. Its interpretation is a fraud of international law and the return to the logic of the war on terror. In the face of terrorism, only civilian responses, police action, intelligence, cutting off the funding of terrorist groups and cutting off international support. In any event, the answer must always be within the rule of law and these acts cannot be used as a pretext for a collective cut in individual freedoms.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution because it draws attention to the fact that for the first time the mutual defence clause (Article 42 (7) of the Treaty of the European Union has been invoked.  At the same time, I regret that the application of Article 42 (7) VEU has still not been worked out in an efficient and concrete manner. With this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the European Council and the European Commission to clarify the means and procedures under the mutual defence clause.  I am also firmly convinced that france's invocation of this clause is a unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a strong and sustainable European defence union.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 I did not support the joint resolution on the mutual defence clause.  The name of the resolution is misleading. Article 42(7) concerns mutual assistance. By using the term mutual defence, the aim is to give the impression that there is an obligation to provide military assistance.  The text of the resolution aims to make the EU a military alliance and a European pillar of NATO. I do not accept this.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. After last November's deadly attacks in Paris, the French government asked the Council of the European Union on 17 November 2015 to activate Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on the European Union.  According to François Hollande, France is at war and the Member States of the Union must show solidarity with France's military actions in Iraq and Syria, but also in Mali, CAR and Lebanon. Article 42, paragraph 7, known as the mutual defence clause, must therefore be activated. Another article of the treaties was more appropriate to the real situation in France: Article 222 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on Solidarity between States subject to a terrorist attack or victims of a natural disaster. But it has the disadvantage of limiting mutual aid to the territory of the Member States concerned, of providing for a formal decision-making procedure, while Article 42 has the advantage of leaving The Member States free to intervene or not. And, as if by some miracle, we can break the locks of the Stability Pact.  It is not by going to war that we ensure the defence and protection of citizens. Jean Jaurès told us more than a hundred years ago. I voted against this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of Article 42(7) of the ETU represents a totally inappropriate measure in the face of recent events. It represents another manoeuvre aimed at converting the European Union into a military alliance and may set a dangerous precedent. We remind you that the application of this article constitutes an obligation to support France militarily in military operations, that is, it is a way to justify and legitimize ongoing or previously planned military interventions. We reject the timing of the Paris attacks as acts of war in order to make the military response legitimate. Military operations have never been able to contain or eliminate terrorism, causing more casualties and disturbances, and aggravating the situation of the people affected. We therefore call for a policy to combat terrorism in accordance with the rule of law through police investigation and law enforcement and we warn that the fight against terrorism serves in many cases as a pretext for limiting individual freedoms and fundamental rights.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This resolution is not compatible with the Austrian requirement of neutrality. I am therefore voting against this motion for a resolution.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. It is necessary to reject this because, from a German point of view, for example.B, it is not comprehensible why Germany should take joint responsibility for the consequences and accompanying effects of the former colonial and mandate policy of European powers in the Arab region within the framework of EU assistance commitments. Today's events in the Levant are also the results of this past. On the other hand, the joint motion for a resolution shows an attempt, through the back door, to implement NATO structures and NATO interests through European assistance commitments. That must be rejected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the application of the assistance clause (Article 42(7) TEU). The EU is neither a military alliance nor a system of collective security. Article 42(7) TEU requires members to provide each other with all assistance and assistance in the event of an armed attack. The Paris attacks are criminal acts of criminal activity, but not armed attacks by military means. The attacks are also no longer present, so they do not empower for self-defense. However, this is a condition under international law and also applies to the obligation to provide assistance under Article 42(7) TEU because of the condition that it be acted "in accordance with Article 51 of the UN Charter". The conditions for the application of the assistance clause are not met in any way. Once again, in an emergency, the EU is acting only in its own interests to acquire further power and competence. But the EU is not a military alliance, otherwise neutral Austria would not have become a member. This crisis must not be used to militarise the EU.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ this resolution follows the attacks in Paris, after which France began invoking Article 42.7 of the Treaty on European Union. This is an unprecedented use of this article instead of Article 222 of the same Treaty, which could also, and perhaps in a more appropriate way, be used for this situation. Of course, it is extremely necessary to express solidarity with France and to show that the Member States are sticking together in the threat of terrorism; In this, I am in a clear position that defence and security policy must remain a national sovereignty and, instead of greater harmonisation at European level, states should focus on NATO as a basis for collective defence. It is for these reasons that I did not support the resolution.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. It was no surprise that the right and social democracy were in the usual federalist verborrhea of consummating supranational responses in the fight against terrorism. A path that seeks to accelerate the creation of a political and institutional framework that guides and streamlines the application of this clause, signaling the "unique opportunity to lay the foundations for a European Defence Union", resuming the idea of the need for European military forces, "in close cooperation with the relevant structures" of NATO. From the reasons, origins and sponsorship of terrorism and its organizations, from the actions of aggression and attentive interference of sovereign countries promoted by the EU, USA and NATO, not a word. This proclaimed fight against terrorism and the posture of aggression and interference have fueled the growth of racist, xenophobic and fascist forces and their action of terror. We affirm the imperative need to combat terrorism by developing a genuine peace policy, based on the end of the escalation of aggression, particularly in the Middle East, and on the effective defence and affirmation of the values of freedom, democracy, respect for the sovereignty and independence of states and peoples. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the mutual defence clause, as I believe that the institutions of the European Union and the Member States need to be more active in the field of security and defence policy. It is therefore envisaged to develop guidelines to ensure an effective response in the event that one of the Member States invokes the mutual defence clause. The call for a common EU foreign policy on the future of Syria and the wider Middle East and the future of the EU's global strategy is also crucial.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I could not vote in favour of the motions for resolutions on priorities on UN human rights issues because I found it terribly disingenuous that each motion for a resolution stressed the importance of treating civil and political freedoms and social and economic rights equally and inextricably in external countries, i.e. countries outside the EU. I agree with that perfectly, of course, but I have been here for six and a half years in this regularly empty room, and I listen to how my own country, Hungary, and, more recently, Poland, is being pilloryed for alleged violations of political rights and freedoms. But no one has ever asked me how it is that in Hungary or Poland a nurse, a firefighter, an educator earns a fifth of what in Western countries. No one asked why workers' rights are so in their infancy, why there are no strong unions. When you're dealing with this here, you're going to have to hold other people to account.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, the proposal for a resolution of the European left which we voted on requires the European Union to defend the position adopted, time and time again, by this European Parliament. In other words, that human rights violations in Western Sahara be investigated, that the Kingdom of Morocco releases Saharan political prisoners and that free access to the occupied territories of Western Sahara is allowed. We cannot, we cannot, continue to close our eyes to a situation that is getting worse every day and that Morocco is committed to silencing, as has been shown by the recent expulsion of dozens of Norwegian and Swedish human rights observers. We demand, once again, the urgent release of Gdeim Izik's political prisoners, and call on Spain to grant political asylum to Hassana Aalia. Finally, I would like to express from this Parliament solidarity with the unemployed young Saharawis on hunger strike in El Aaiún and with the wounded following the Moroccan repression in the last Sahrawi demonstrations in the occupied Bojador.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – In the last two years, Slovaks, Slovenes and Croats have been performing in national referendums in defence of the natural family system, against imposing political recitations on them by the political homosexual movement. Of course, similar provisions are found in the Hungarian or Hungarian Polish or in the ordinary laws of Lithuania. Meanwhile, today, once again, the European Parliament voted in support of these recitations. Instead of representing the position of our countries in the United Nations, or even respecting the positions that some of our societies have taken in national referendums, the European Parliament wants the European Union to change us. All this shows that today the greatest threat to democracy in Europe is the policies of the current authorities of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Violation of the rights of ethnic, religious and linguistic minorities, as well as children's rights, violation of women's rights, oppression or even killing of human rights defenders , all just showing that the Role of the European Union in the UN Human Rights Council is fundamental and vital. I think we must do everything to ensure that our values, many of which can undeniably be considered universal—universal— values on a global scale, are not only gradually simply taken into account, but ideals are also truly respected. I would like to note, however, that every year the growing criticism of the UN Human Rights Council is linked to the fact that the bloc's vote is actually flourishing because of the numerical superiority of the Middle East and African countries. This bloc pays enormous attention, for example, to Israel, where the situation with human rights is far better than in any country in NATO's eastern region, and a representative from Saudi Arabia, a country where a huge number of people are being executed, may also become the chairman of the panel.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, let me briefly explain why I did not vote in support of the European Parliament's position on the priorities for the UN Human Rights Council. The motion for a resolution contains provisions that are contrary to my conscience. It is not possible to impose and recommend to all countries, to all people, an ultra-free attitude towards ethical values, such as access to sexual and reproductive health services, which makes abortion a solution to infant and maternal mortality. I therefore voted in favour of the deletion of these provisions, but unfortunately we were a minority. Like the minority, it opposed the designation of Israeli settlements as illegal and as undermining the feasibility of a two-state solution, the peace process. These are untrue and unacceptable solutions for me, which is why I did not support the resolution as a whole, because it is unacceptable to me.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the proposal for a Joint Resolution on EU priorities for un Human Rights Council sessions in 2016 (2015/3035(RSP)) because, while there are important issues mentioned in the Common Resolution on Mechanisms for the Defence of International Law and Human Rights, I do not agree that the European Union should have a growing role within the United Nations, which would lead to a diminishing national sovereignty of the Member States. On the other hand, I do not share at all the analysis of the situation or the condemnation of Venezuela, as well as the instrumentalisation of human rights by the European Union, which prevents me from supporting this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution to set the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council scheduled for 2016. This proposal, under the pretext of defending human rights, is merely an exhibition of the Union's grounds for interference in the national affairs of sovereign states. Moreover, this pro-immigration text only underlines the obligations of Member States with regard to immigration. Opposed to the mass immigration policy imposed by the Union, I cannot support this text.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Under the pretext of defending human rights, particularly with regard to minorities, the motion for a resolution aims to interfere with the policies of Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not believe that the EU, rather than individual Member States, should set out ‘priorities’ for the UNHRC.  I do not agree with the report when it suggests that ‘climate change’ is a major cause of the current refugee crisis.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to set EU priorities at the 2016 SESSIONS of the UN Human Rights Council. I agree that the members of the HRC should be elected from states that respect human rights, the rule of law and democracy. I support calls for the EU to promote the universality of human rights, including civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights. The EU must take a rights-based approach and integrate human rights compliance into trade, investment policy, public services and development cooperation, as well as its common security and defence policy. It is important that the EU is constantly actively involved in all UN human rights mechanisms and to ensure greater visibility of EU action in all multilateral for a. I support calls on all governments to promote and support media freedom, civil society organisations and human rights defenders and to allow them to act without fear, repression or intimidation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this joint resolution, which first of all reminds us that it is important that the members of the Human Rights Council be elected from among the representatives of states that ensure respect for the rule of law, human rights and democracy. It also stresses the importance of preserving the independence and integrity of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, in particular by providing this structure with sufficient resources. Parliament is also concerned about constitutional revisions that allow for changes to the maximum number of presidential terms and condemns the continued use of harassment and detention of human rights defenders and opposition figures by government forces in a number of third countries. It reaffirms the EU's zero tolerance for the death penalty and torture, recalls the fundamental right of free elections by universal suffrage and emphasizes respect for economic and social rights that have been undermined, notably by rising poverty.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU's priorities for the 2016 sessions of the UN Human Rights Council.  Seventy years after the birth of the UN system, in a world ravaged by wars, threatened by global warming, hit by the most massive migration phenomenon since the Second World War; the major issue of respect for human rights remains a priority. In too many parts of the world we continue to see constant violations of the freedom, life and security of individuals by unseen states and governments. Key principles of European law, such as zero tolerance of the death penalty, torture and inhuman and degrading treatment, are often violated by some of the same states that now sit on the Human Rights Council.  Taking note of this situation, the EU wanted to define a number of priorities in order to promote a broader affirmation of the rule of law and democratic principles. Commitment to religious freedom, commitment to the protection of migrants, refugees and LGBTI people, the defence of children and women are the pillars of the European position, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote since the analysis put forward by many of the countries did not share it. Moreover, according to this report, the idea is to go to the UNHCR conference with its own agenda, and then see how to implement it in our policies, without the capacity of European and Member States to be influenced on the agenda.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank you for the negotiating work done to reach a Joint Resolution on the United Nations Human Rights Council. I support this report, which talks about civil and political rights, human rights defenders, the death penalty, religious freedom, economic and social rights, businesses, climate change, migration and refugees and the rights of women, children and LGBTI people. A range of fundamental rights that, in our view, must be respected.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I rejected this resolution setting out the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council in 2016. Apparently, these priorities are limited to imposing an immigration policy through a mechanism of pure interference in the diplomacy of sovereign nations. Some proposals are a scandal of irresponsibility in geostrategic terms, such as the proposal to exclude countries such as Russia or China, which are members of the UN Security Council, from the UN human rights body; it has only one purpose: to please the United States by pilloriing its main competitors on the international stage. Moreover, the vision of human rights set out in this text is a communitarian analysis, in which each community becomes a victim that must be saved by affirmative action; to give Europeans the pill of uncontrolled flows of migrants, the concept of 'climate refugee' is invented. A perfectly characteristic text of imperialism under the guise of human rights led by Brussels.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on is not acceptable and presents considerable critical issues. Not only does it not propose any concrete solution to the topics covered, but it is completely unbalanced in favour of the protection of immigrants, even calling for the introduction of the 'climate migrant' among the categories to be protected.  For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. \u2012 I have abstained on this resolution. The resolution contains many good points on women's rights, on more humane asylum and refugee policies according to international standards and on ensuring lgbtq people's rights. However, the resolution is a clear example of the EU's duplicity when it comes to foreign relations and human rights. The section on human rights in Iran has been completely removed, Turkey's human rights violations and the situation of the Kurds are conspicuous by their absence, the occupation of Western Sahara is completely forgotten. I reject double standards of human rights, which is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported this joint motion for a resolution by which Parliament sets its priorities for the sessions of the UN Human Rights Council. With it, Parliament welcomes the appointment of Ambassador Choi Kyong-lim as chairman of the HRC for 2016 and insists that the recommendations of the Special Rapporteur on contemporary forms of racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and related intolerance be implemented to combat the spread of hatred and incitement to racial, ethnic and xenophobic hatred. It also condemns the permanent harassment and deprivation of liberty of human rights defenders and opponents in several third countries. It also prioritizes the fight against terrorism, social and economic rights, children's rights, women's rights, LGTBI rights, migration and refugees, the death penalty, press freedom or climate change. It also insists that Member States strengthen their coordination in the UN. As for countries under universal periodic review, Parliament focuses on Georgia, Lebanon, Mauritania, Myanmar/Burma, Nepal, Rwanda, South Sudan, Venezuela, Syria, Burundi, Saudi Arabia and Belarus, and the Middle East peace process.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, in which the European Parliament examines the Priorities of the European Union at the 2016 sessions of the UN Human Rights Council. Upholding respect for human rights, regardless of race, origin, gender or colour of skin, is an obligation for all states. Parliament regrets the fact that, more than 20 years after the adoption of the Vienna Declaration on the universality, indivisibility, interdependence and interoperability of all human rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights is not considered to be as important and does not pay the same attention as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In addition, it is deeply concerned about the extreme increase in poverty, which threatens the full enjoyment of all human rights, and it is therefore essential to give economic, social and cultural rights the same meaning and priority as civil and political rights, to recognise the right to social protection, to implement fiscal policies specifically aimed at reducing inequalities, to give new impetus and importance to the right to equality and to raise resources as a key issue in the debate on human rights. The European Parliament strongly supports the effective and full implementation of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights within and outside the EU and strongly recommends that EU Member States develop and implement national action plans.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The UN is undoubtedly the best forum for promoting the EU's values and interests by transferring them to a global level. Universal human rights, advocated by both the UN and the EU, are an important segment that needs to be paid a great deal of attention, as human rights violations are becoming more and more severe.  The EU's role in the protection of human rights within the UN is therefore of paramount importance, but there are a number of shortcomings that make it difficult to act effectively. Indeed, the EU cannot act as a single entity within the UN, as the UN's action is directed at individual countries and not so much interstate organisations such as the EU.  The EU itself also has problems with a patchy foreign policy, which is why it does not play the most important role in international relations. The interests of individual Member States play a significantly greater role here, and the interest of the EU as a whole is often sidelined, as it is often difficult to identify, let alone defend. Therefore, in tackling the current global challenges within the EU, unity, criticality and determination are needed, which must also be shown at UN level. Countries must stop egotistical thinking and defend their interests at all costs and face the challenges side by side.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The promotion of the universality and indivisibility of civil, economic, political, social and cultural rights is at the heart of the EU's ethical and legal acquis, which reaffirms the commitment of its Member States to condemn torture and inhuman and degrading punishments against any individual and in all circumstances. The priorities identified by the United Nations for 2016, which include, among others, the fight against the death penalty and the rights of migrants and women, constitute urgent needs that cannot be postponed. I strongly support the recommendations of this resolution and the renewed European commitment to ensuring the obligations under the EU Treaty and the United Nations in the internal and external policies pursued by the European Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this STATEMENT on EU priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council sessions. Civil and political rights, economic and social rights, business and human rights, LGBT rights, etc. are among the areas where the EU must persevere and amplify its influence as a global "player". Unfortunately, radical groups that incite hatred and intolerance have been strengthening in Europe for a long time, so it is the EU's duty to fight for respect for human rights at all levels.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I fully agree with its spirit and content. In particular, I believe that it is important to ensure that the election of the Member States of the HRC takes place on the basis of the achievements of the countries in the field of defence and protection of human rights, so as to make the work of this body truly effective.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe must continue to work to promote the protection and promotion of human rights. The EU must support the work of the new CHAIRMAN of the CDU, Ambassador Choi Kyong-lim, and the concrete implementation of the CDU's annual report to the UN General Assembly on its 28th, 29th and 30th sessions.  The EU must strongly reiterate the absurdity of the election of CDU members by states that do not defend or respect the most basic human rights. The rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights must become the criterion on which to assess the results in this area for any country that is likely to be elected a member of the CDU: it is unacceptable that newly elected MEMBERS of the CDU such as Saudi Arabia constantly violate human rights and freedom of thought and expression.  That is why it is necessary to reaffirm the independence of the HRC in order to ensure that it can continue to exercise its mandate effectively and impartially. We Europeans must act to ensure that all participants honour their obligations to build a freer and more humane world for all.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council in 2016. It seeks to impose an immigrationist policy through a mechanism of pure interference in the diplomacy of sovereign nations. Above all, it proposes to exclude countries such as Russia and China, which are members of the UN Security Council, from the SUBCOMMITTEE on Human Rights at the United Nations. This delusional text must be fought, and that is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for human rights regardless of race, origin, religion, class, caste, sex, sexual orientation or colour has always been a priority for the European Union, with Member States being required to ensure respect for the indivisibility of human rights. The UN Human Rights Council aims to respect, promote and guarantee the universality of human rights, which is one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity. Member States therefore have a duty to take concrete actions to facilitate respect for these rights at national level, but also to cooperate internationally with a view to removing obstacles to the exercise of human rights in all areas. The EU's priorities for the CDO sessions focus on respect for social and economic rights, freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief. The issue of migration and refugees, as well as human rights, women and children, is also a priority. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that it is necessary to continue the process of integrating the issues of respect for human rights into EU policies.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The resolution proposes nothing and is totally unbalanced in favour of protecting immigrants, LGBTI. It underlines the introduction of the so-called category of climate migrant among the categories to be protected. There are attacks on Russia, which is considered to be a country that does not respect human rights, including in the sporting sphere.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Union's priorities for the SESSIONS of the UN Human Rights Council in 2016. Respect for, promotion and safeguarding the universality of human rights are one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity and must be the cornerstones of the EU's foreign policy. In particular, as indicated in the report, it is important to focus attention on fundamental issues such as respect for civil and political rights by all nations, zero tolerance for capital punishment and torture, as well as the protection of freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief. For several months we have been witnessing the most serious humanitarian crisis since the Second World War, due to the growing number of people forced to leave their land due to persecution, armed conflict and climate change. These people are heading to Europe in search of protection and a better life, facing dangerous journeys even at the risk of their lives. Today's text also strongly highlights this element, highlighting the problems to be solved. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the joint resolution which lays out the EU’s priorities for the UN Human Rights Council’s priorities for 2016. My main reasons for abstaining were that the resolution made no specific reference to human rights abusers within the Human Rights Council, it did not take a harsh enough stance on the death penalty and it made no reference at all to the Western Sahara issue or recent events in Turkey. Furthermore, the resolution was discriminatory in the protection it was willing to offer to certain religions over others.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 All states have an obligation to defend respect for human rights, regardless of ethnicity, origin, religion, class, caste, sex, sexual orientation or skin color. Respect for, promotion and safeguarding the universality of human rights are an integral part of the European Union's ethical and legal acquis. Internal and external coherence in the field of human rights is essential for the credibility of the EU's foreign policy on human rights.  In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council sessions in 2016.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the European Parliament resolution on the European Union's priorities for human rights council meetings in 2016, because we disagree with paragraph 89 referring to the Middle East peace process.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the EU's priorities for the 2016 Human Rights Council meetings is an attempt to fully address the challenges facing us in the coming period, which we are called upon to consider in a spirit of rationality and respect for our values. This proposal does indeed contain positive elements directly linked to the human dignity, individual rights and religious freedoms of sensitive social groups that have been so brutally affected in recent years on the altar of economic or other global political crises. Although the proposals contained in this proposal are generally positive, we cannot overlook the existence of controversial points that need clarification and thorough discussion. The proposals made on terrorism leave open the possibility of taking measures contrary to the fundamental rights of citizens, because the establishment of profiling procedures and the preventive distribution of people to friends and enemies has essentially been announced. I have therefore decided to abstain. The SYRIZA MEPs have done the same because we consider it necessary to systematically review our objectives for the next period.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions that are intended to bring to light the priorities of the United Nations Human Rights Council. These documents are based on the recognition of issues, such as civil, political and economic rights, as well as women's and children's rights, capital punishment, immigration and religious freedom, as a priority on the human rights agenda in 2016.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately I had to vote against this resolution because, despite the great and meritorious work done by the PPE negotiator to have a text acceptable as a whole and in which all the issues important to us were mentioned, we have not been able to prevent Parliament from issuing a harsh judgment on the most controversial issue affecting, to date, international politics. : the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It is not for us to say who is right and who is wrong, and, however much I have a specific idea of mine, I do not think it is appropriate to have to quote it in political documents, unless it can be a contribution to achieving a stable and lasting solution. As this has not happened, I did not feel able to vote in favour, but I wanted to show my opposition.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the 2015-2017 biennium, Portugal is a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council. This resolution is therefore of particular importance to us Portuguese and presents a set of guidelines on the major challenges in 2016, as well as some paths and criticisms. I cannot fail to highlight the challenges facing the right to asylum, the fight against the death penalty and women's rights. I should also point out the recommendation that the Union itself defend and promote human rights in a coordinated and transversal way to all its policies. Finally, I recall that Portugal is among the set of countries that respects and promotes fundamental rights in its territory. Unfortunately, not all members of this UN Council do so. As the resolution rightly points out, I do not think it is reasonable for that to be the case.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of the resolution encouraging the EU to participate actively and continuously in UN human rights mechanisms, as well as to improve the preparation and coordination of EU policies for THE HRC sessions and to address the issue of coherence between the internal and external dimensions of European human rights policy. In addition, greater efforts will have to be made in adopting an approach based on human rights and their respect also in trade and investment policies.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the proposal for a Joint Resolution on EU priorities for un Human Rights Council sessions in 2016 (2015/3035(RSP)) because, while there are important issues mentioned in the Common Resolution on Mechanisms for the Defence of International Law and Human Rights, I do not agree that the European Union should have a growing role within the United Nations, which would lead to a diminishing national sovereignty of the Member States. On the other hand, I do not share at all the analysis of the situation or the condemnation of Venezuela, as well as the instrumentalisation of human rights by the European Union, which prevents me from supporting this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Legislature considers the issue of respect for human rights at global level very important, through the eu's active and constant involvement in all UN human rights mechanisms. Respect for human rights must be integrated into all policies, such as those on peace and security, development cooperation, migration, trade and investment, humanitarian action, climate change and the fight against terrorism. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights must continue to increase the effectiveness, coherence and visibility of EU human rights policy at the United Nations Human Rights Council sessions and in close cooperation with the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. The EU must follow up on the recommendations of the UN-developed Uuniversal Periodic Assessment in all EU political dialogues with the countries concerned, in order to explore ways and means of implementing the recommendations through national and regional strategies.  Priorities of the UNHRC sessions in 2016 should include respect for civil and political rights, including individual and collective freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and association, economic and social rights, the adoption of a human rights-based approach to migration, the impact of climate change on human rights, and respect for the rights of women and children.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which lists the European Parliament’s priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council sessions in 2016, because the report highlights a number of aspects which are essential to global development and stability in the world. Through this resolution, Parliament is calling for better defined legal criteria which will help address a number of issues within the field of human rights, such as the establishment of a legal definition of climate refugees and the recognition of climate change as a force behind the movement of people and migratory pressure, amongst others. The report also advocates for better LGBTIQ rights throughout the world and gives particular importance to expressing one’s gender identity in a way which they find desirable.  As I have done in the past, I have voted against any references to sexual and reproductive health rights (SRHR) in the report, as my stance against SRHR has always been clearly against abortion.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. Petitions and the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) are instruments that should increase the democratic participation, dialogue, inclusion and legitimacy of the institutions itself. But the limits and the problems are objectively enormous. The number of ECI and petitions rejected is very high, the delay in their consideration and the lack of clarity of the information provided to citizens have led to a collapse in confidence and expectations in these instruments. Not only that: many European citizens do not even know of the existence of these opportunities and even when they are known, those who are interested are faced with a range of problems ranging from bureaucracy, to the difficulty of active participation in the possible phase of discussion, from the exclusion of the possibility of institutional intervention due to lack of competence, to the absence of concrete legislative action following the action of the citizens. The criticisms and proposals set out in the report therefore have my vote in favour, but we must not forget that each of us can play a fundamental role in the European Parliament. Indeed, we can be real spokesmen, turning citizens' petitions into subjects of discussion and political initiative, which give a complete meaning to democratic participation and tend towards the creation of a genuine people's Europe.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution sets out the UNION's priorities for the 2016 Human Rights Council sessions on the defence of political, economic and civic rights, the rights of children and women, the death penalty, migration and freedom of religion. The text reiterates the importance of supporting these priorities through the Union's external policies. Country priorities will also be set as part of the UN Human Rights Council's universal periodic review. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In this joint resolution, which I supported, the European Parliament sets the Union's priorities in the framework of the sessions of the United Nations Human Rights Council. This text is very important because it calls in particular to respect human rights in the field of trade, public services or development cooperation.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Respect for and safeguarding the universality of human rights must be an unrelenting struggle for the European Union. Human rights continue to be violated around the world, as evidenced by the executions still carried out by many countries, discrimination against minorities or intimidation of human rights defenders. The Union must continue to exert its full weight in the fight against the death penalty, the defence of freedom of conscience and religion, the rights of women and children and the protection of people in humanitarian crisis. The very serious crisis faced by refugees fleeing the war in Syria reminds us of this moral need.  We urgently need to implement a common asylum policy and an effective migration policy. Similarly, it is essential that the members of the Human Rights Council be elected from among countries that respect these rights. It is unacceptable that some of the Member States of the Council are causing serious violations of civil rights and freedoms. Corrective action must be taken to remedy this situation and prevent such a situation from happening again in the future.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The resolution on the European Union's priorities for the 2016 Human Rights Council sessions is, in my view, far too asymmetrical. That's why I abstained. Indeed, two major issues are not properly stated: Daesh, which is mentioned only at the end of the text and about violence against women, and Christians, who are not mentioned in the paragraph on religious minorities, while they remain persecuted in the East. On the other hand, I did not want to vote against this resolution, which contains essential proposals, including the proposal for an international definition of 'climate refugees', because there is a real legal vacuum in this area.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text invokes human rights to justify several types of European Union interference in the affairs of sovereign states, or even international structures, such as the United Nations. It also relies on the issue of sexual minorities to justify interference and also encourages family planning, under the guise of women's and children's rights. Being opposed to any kind of intrusion into the affairs of states and institutions, and rejecting all methods of instrumentalization, I voted against this resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's joint resolution on "EU priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council sessions" sets out the EU's position at the upcoming UN Human Rights Council meeting in March in Geneva. The resolution is comprehensive and addresses thematic issues such as the death penalty, freedom of religion, social and economic rights, as well as the human rights situation in a number of countries such as Saudi Arabia, Burundi, Syria and others. The Group of European Conservatives and Reformists has always placed great importance on human rights in all EU policies and relations with third countries. However, our group did not join the joint resolution, as it pays great attention to LGBTI rights, which we cannot support, as we promote the preservation of family and Christian values. It is for this reason that I decided to abstain.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Let the EU finally stop dealing with the internal affairs of third countries, because - when influential Member States have been serially involved in unjust and illegal wars, - when they have illegally authorised their security forces to kidnap citizens and imprison them without trial in detention centres on other continents, - when, en masse and indiscriminately, most governments in the EU illegally monitor their citizens , - when governments themselves are mass importing into the territories the 'refugees' and migrants who turn Europe into a continent of rape and abuse of women, - when in Greece there is innumerable evidence of pre-trial circuits, interventions by politicians in justice but also of rigging electoral processes, how can the EU invoke the Republic or its principles and values?

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. I voted in favour of paragraph 89, as I feel it adequately describes the situation and makes it clear that all parties to the conflict must comply with international law.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of respect for human rights, regardless of race, origin, religion, class, caste, gender, sexual orientation or colour, is an obligation of all States, which have an obligation to respect the fundamental rights of their populations and the duty to take concrete measures to facilitate respect for those rights at national level, as well as to cooperate at international level, as well as to cooperate at international level, as well as to cooperate at international level, as well as to cooperate at international level , with a view to removing barriers to the achievement of human rights in all areas. I therefore argue that UNHRC members should be elected from among states that advocate respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy, based on human rights performance criteria.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Promoting respect for human rights is the responsibility of all states. Human rights are indivisible and interlinked, and the withdrawal of any such rights has a direct impact on other rights. All states are obliged to respect the fundamental rights of their citizens and to take steps and measures to facilitate respect for these rights at national level, as well as to cooperate in removing obstacles to their application at international level. Respect for and protection of the universality of human rights are part of the European Union's ethical and legal acquis and also a cornerstone of European unity. Therefore, respect for human rights must be part of all policy areas. Like 2015, 2016 is the year of significant annuiers precisely in the field of human rights, peace and security. In particular, I would like to recall the important UN Security Council Resolution 2242 on women, peace and security, which made women central to all efforts to tackle global challenges, including the growing violent extremism.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against all the reports on EU priorities ahead of the UNHRC meetings in 2016. Let the EU finally stop dealing with the internal affairs of third countries, because - when important Member States - its Member States have been serially involved in unjust and illegal wars, - when they have illegally authorised their security forces to kidnap citizens and imprison them without trial in detention centres on other continents, - when massively and indiscriminately most governments in the EU illegally monitor their citizens , - when governments themselves massively introduce to the territories the 'refugees' and migrants who turn Europe into a continent of rape and abuse of women, - when in Greece there is innumerable evidence of pre-trial circuits, interventions by politicians in justice but also of rigging electoral processes, then how can the EU invoke the Republic or its principles and values?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report that will highlight our main priorities for the UN Human Rights Council sessions in 2016. I support the call on EU Member States to reinforce the EU practice of speaking with one voice as it would raise the visibility and influence of the EU as a global actor. I believe this report will encourage the EEAS, notably delegations in Geneva and New York to increase the coherence, visibility and credibility of the EU’s action in the UNHRC by further development of cross-regional outreach and cooperation and on lobbying all moderate States in the UN. We must actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concept of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights, underline the need to keep special procedures and to preserve the independence and the adequate funding of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, as well as sufficient funding for regional UNHRC offices open.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Respecting, promoting and protecting the universality of human rights is an important part of the European Union's ethical and legal achievements and a cornerstone of European unity and integrity. The Union's actions in relation to third countries are guided by Article 21 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which strengthens the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and provides for respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law; Furthermore, respect for human rights must be enforced in all policy areas affecting peace and security, development cooperation, trade and investment, humanitarian aid, climate change and the fight against terrorism, as these problems cannot be tackled in isolation from respect for human rights.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Union's priorities in this area. Similarly, I think it is very important that the Member States of the European Union do not support the election to the Human Rights Council of countries that do not act with respect for human rights, as well as to support the independence and integrity of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the resolution on the EU's priorities for the 2016 UNHRC meetings, as this text makes the gross mistake of copying the typical European demand for more 'gender policy' with dot and comma right from the start. As a German MEP, human rights politician and refugee expert, I say – in plain language: there are many priorities that are obvious to us and the UNHCR! It must also be about, for example, openly addressing the fact that people in Jordanian UN refugee camps are suffering because EU states simply do not transfer money to the UNHCR. I know that politicians do not like to talk about this – that is gross failure. But we need to talk about it. Otherwise we can give ourselves the priorities!

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote since the analysis put forward by many of the countries did not share it. Moreover, according to this report, the idea is to go to the UNHCR conference with its own agenda, and then see how to implement it in our policies, without the capacity of European and Member States to be influenced on the agenda.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The UN Human Rights Council meets annually to ensure that UN member states follow its recommendations to strengthen the promotion and protection of human rights. The resolution voted on 21 January by the European Parliament sets out the EU's priorities for the next session of the Human Rights Council. It is therefore of crucial importance. I voted for this resolution because it stresses the importance of this annual human rights assessment and the need for the independence and vigilance of the Human Rights Council. I also supported it because it fully addresses all fundamental rights: civil and political rights, the fight against the death penalty, social and economic rights, children's rights, minority rights, women's and LGBTI rights. It also recalls the rights of migrants and refugees and calls for them to be guaranteed in the implementation of migration-related policies.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We consider the issue of human rights to be of paramount importance to the EU and the world at large. On the question of human rights, there can be no half-talk or oversight because of other interests. Unfortunately, the resolution does not live up to our expectation and we believe that the appropriate attitude is that of abstention. We had tabled as a group a resolution which we consider to be more complete, without purpose and more representative of the current human rights situation in the world but also in the Union itself.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because respect for human rights irrespective of race, origin, religion, class, caste, sex, sexual orientation or colour is an obligation on all states. This resolution reiterates its attachment to the indivisibility of human rights (whether civil, political, economic, social or cultural), which are interrelated and interdependent. The deprivation of any one of these rights has a direct and adverse impact on the others. All states have an obligation to respect the basic rights of their respective populations and a duty to take concrete action to facilitate respect for those rights at national level, and to cooperate at international level with a view to eliminating obstacles to the realisation of human rights in all areas. Having respect for, and the promotion and safeguarding of, the universality of human rights is part of the European Union’s ethical and legal acquis and one of the cornerstones of European unity and integrity. The internal and external coherence in the area of human rights is essential for the credibility of the EU’s human rights policy abroad.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I would first like to congratulate Ambassador Choi Kyong-lim as president of the UNHRC for 2016. I would also like to underline that it does not do the UNHRC justice to support the election to the Human Rights Council of countries which do not uphold respect for human rights.  The fight against racial discrimination and xenophobia is of crucial importance and must be upheld as a central goal by the UNHRC. Furthermore, the EU’s position should be backed fully with respect to a zero tolerance towards the death penalty and the countries still making use of it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on EU priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council sessions, as I agree with these priorities on the following topics: the UN Human Rights Council, which stresses that UNHCR members should be referred to among human rights-respecting states; civil and political rights, highlighting the problem of changing the constitution to extend political mandates; social and economic rights and the problem of rising poverty, as well as in the fields of business and human rights; migration and concerns about the biggest migrant crisis since 2 January 2016. World War II; climate change and human rights, and upholding the conclusions of the Paris Agreement, women's rights, children's rights, the fight against terrorism, democratisation, the integration of human rights into EU policies, and the stated country-by-country priorities subject to universal periodic review.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. Indeed, under the guise of protecting human rights, particularly with regard to minorities, it aims to interfere in the policies of the Member States.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU’s attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council in 2016. These priorities revolve around the importance of disseminating human rights through external policies. The resolution highlights fundamental issues for the European Union, such as the full enjoyment of civil, political and economic rights, the end of the use of the death penalty, freedom of religion, with particular attention to respect for women and children. This resolution has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text, which forgets to remind us that Christians are persecuted by Daesh. We are only talking about "religious minorities." Nor is there anything about the persecution of Jews, including in developed countries, such as ours in Europe.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This resolution is nothing more than a highly ideological catalogue of demands which, instead of analysing, makes values judgments. In addition, it provides for an expansion of European interference. This contradicts my views in many respects, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because in a decade the UN Human Rights Council has established itself as a platform that identifies and offers answers to today's human rights challenges. It also serves as a key starting point for research on human rights, education, public information, as well as advocacy activities in the UN system.  Looking from this perspective, it should come as no surprise that a prominent human rights champion such as the EU, which promotes and protects human rights both within and outside the Union itself, provides comprehensive political and financial support in this regard. It is from the position of a leading political and financial supporter of human rights that the EU must continue to raise and express its concern on the international stage about human rights violations. Including some members of the Council.  I believe that it is absolutely imperative to introduce basic criteria for membership of the UN Human Rights Council. Countries must be chosen among those who maintain a high level of human rights. Only then will it be possible to ensure that the Council exercises its mandate in an effective and impartial manner and will not be subjective or dependent.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council in 2016. I regret a number of asymmetries in the priorities mentioned in this report. Indeed, while the "Islamic State" organization is now the main threat to human rights in the world, it is only mentioned in paragraph 6, only with regard to violence against women. Moreover, Eastern Christians are by no means mentioned among persecuted religious minorities around the world. The extent of the abuse inflicted on them is largely underestimated by paragraph 81, which unfortunately does not mention the murders, massacres and serious abuses they suffer. Finally, I voted against paragraph 89, concerning the Middle East peace process, which I consider highly unbalanced at the expense of Israel.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council in 2016. It is a fairly comprehensive catalogue of the Union's grounds for interference under the pretext of human rights. This text is pro-immigration in the sense that it intends to underline only the obligations of the host countries. In particular, it calls for a definition of the concept of 'climate refugee'. Paragraph 31 requires EU Member States to respect the right to apply for and benefit from asylum. However, this text would have been an opportunity to denounce the fact that this is not the case for Saudi Arabia and Qatar, for example.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. Under the pretext of the defence of human rights, it is in fact merely exposing - and justifying - the reasons for the Union's interference in the national affairs of sovereign states. Moreover, it only recalls the obligations of Member States with regard to immigration. Firmly opposed to the pro-immigrationist logic constantly implemented by the European Union, I could only oppose this text.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am against the resolution because it blames the current migration wave on the earth's climate and disproportionately meddling in the Israeli-Palestinian dispute, calls for the application of the institute of registered partnership in the world, but this should be left to individual countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The motions for resolutions relate to the need to further confirm the importance of certain items related to the UN Human Rights Council. In particular, they propose that all proposals on human rights should be implemented, focusing on all forms of discrimination, xenophobia and similar intolerance. Furthermore, the resolutions stress that Member States should have zero tolerance for death sentences. The resolutions also mention the importance of freedom of expression of opinion, religion and belief, that everyone should enjoy human rights equally with a particular focus on refugees. I supported the resolutions, as I believe it is always necessary to reassess the importance of human rights, without any form of discrimination.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – Respect for human rights is a natural part of the law of both the Member States and the Union itself and must also be reflected in all EU external policies, including trade, investment, public services, development cooperation and the common security and defence policy. Respect for human rights must also be promoted in third countries through political dialogue and diplomatic channels.  In this sense, the European Union must strengthen its position and influence in international groupings (in particular the UN and the UNHCR). All forces must focus on eliminating problems in europe's non-member countries, in Africa and on resolving the causes of conflicts preventively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the joint motion for a resolution on the EU's priorities for the SADI summits in 2016 due to the many weaknesses of the proposal.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that this resolution ‘expresses deep concern about the targeted attacks on human rights defenders, journalists and their family members; strongly condemns political violence, summary executions and other human rights violations; urges the Burundian authorities to end these violations and abuses as a matter of critical and urgent priority and to conduct impartial and independent investigations with a view to bringing those responsible to justice and providing victims with redress’.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the EU's priorities for the 2016 sessions of the UN Human Rights Council, I support it. Respect for human rights and dignity, as well as the principles of freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, are among the values common to all the Member States of the European Union and which inspire the Union's action both within and outside its borders. All states have an obligation to defend respect for human rights, regardless of race, origin, sex or colour, and this respect for human rights must be integrated into all areas, such as policies on peace and security, migration, trade and investment, and the fight against terrorism.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I supported the proposal for a Joint Resolution on EU priorities for un Human Rights Council sessions in 2016. While we have made great progress in this area, we still have many challenges ahead of us to defend rights, especially the most vulnerable groups. There are countries that concern us in a special way, as this report outlines, such as Venezuela. That is why we welcome the holding of elections on 6 December. But it is necessary to stress the importance of the defence of the Constitution and respect for human rights, as well as of fulfilling the will of the Venezuelan people at the ballot box. Venezuela has the challenge of meeting a wide range of human rights issues: from impunity and accountability for extrajudicial killings committed, among others, by security forces, to arbitrary detention and deprivation of liberty, the right of political prisoners to a fair trial, and the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly and association, and freedom of the media.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The catalogue of demands contains ideological assessments that contradict my views. I reject the development of European influence in national affairs and further paternalism. I am therefore voting against this motion.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Parliament takes a position here ahead of the next meeting of the UN Human Rights Council. For once, the resolution strongly condemns Saudi Arabia and its appointment as head of the UN commission. It also calls for an internationally recognised definition of the concept of "climate refugee" and the participation of Member States in work on a binding instrument of respect for human rights by multinationals, launched by Ecuador. But through a list of general good intentions, against the death penalty, for women's rights (but without mentioning the right to abortion), the European Union claims to lecture the rest of the world. For example, it calls on "all countries to adopt a human rights strategy on migration" as EU member states build walls and strip refugees. I cannot condone so much hypocrisy, but in order not to interfere with the work of the United Nations on the issue of human rights, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Under the pretext of defending human rights, particularly with regard to minorities, the motion for a resolution aims to interfere with the policies of Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union currently faces numerous challenges, from the humanitarian crisis representing the wave of asylum applications, to climate change, to the fight against terrorism, which require the Union to take concerted action and enhanced cooperation. At the UNHRC sessions, the European Union must lead the process with one voice to address internal and external challenges.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution because despite the many positive elements it contains, the final version contained unacceptable references to sexual and reproductive health rights.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In this resolution, the European Parliament has listed its priorities for the UNHRC sessions in 2016. Respecting, promoting and safeguarding the universal nature of human rights is part of the European Union's legal and ethical acquis. Respect for and expression of respect for human rights is central to the European Union's foreign and multilateral action. Europe must continue to play its leading role in protecting human rights, both in Europe and in the world.  This resolution lists a list of issues such as migration and human rights, the pursuit of a moratorium on the death penalty and torture, freedom of religion and belief, which are being asked to be discussed by the Human Rights Council. The events of the past few months show us that respect for human rights and universal values must be absolutely safeguarded.  Although I support the commitment and purpose of this resolution, I abstained in the final vote because this resolution has been added to a list of countries that require universal periodic vetting and where Rwanda does not have to belong.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The motion for a resolution lists the various areas that will represent the European Union's priorities at the 2016 UN Human Rights Council meetings. Europe, but also the whole world, has recently faced unprecedented changes in society and, at the same time, the most serious humanitarian crisis since the Second World War. The proportions of migrants are extremely bad. This whole issue is seriously affecting the situation in Europe, so I appreciate that the refugee problem is one of the topics that has become a priority for the European Union. However, other areas where we have seen violations of fundamental rights before the refugee crisis broke out should also be forgotten. Among these areas, I include women's rights and children's rights in particular. These are two groups that always require a specific approach, at all times. At a time of ever-escalating violence in the Middle East, the situation of women and children in this area is truly frightening. The European Union must stand firm in favour of protecting human rights in the Middle East and condemn the current situation, which does not respect fundamental freedoms and rights. I welcome the provisions that deal with the situation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven political groups on the subject indicated: PPE, ALDE, GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE, EFDD, ECR and S&D submitted motions for resolutions. Among them, PPE, ALDE, Verts/ALE, EFDD and S&D reached an agreement on the content of the resolution. I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to support the respect, promotion and safeguarding of the universality of human rights are part of the legal and ethical acquis of the European Union. These are fundamental principles of European unity and integrity, as well as guarantees of internal and external coherence in the field of human rights in external relations. I would like to express my dismay at the constant violations of women's rights, the emergence of violent extremist groups such as Boko Haram in West Africa or IS in Syria and Iraq, and violence against the most vulnerable people. I also highlight the situation of refugees and migrants, one of the greatest humanitarian scourges of recent times, created by the exponential increase in people forced to leave their countries due to armed conflict and widespread violence. All countries must safeguard the rights of migrants and refugees in migration policies, with particular attention to marginalised and disadvantaged groups such as women and children.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on this resolution, which deals with the priority issues that the European Union wants to see included in the sessions of the UN Human Rights Council in 2016. In particular, this text calls for the establishment of migration corridors from the Middle East, which I strongly oppose. I consider that the serious economic difficulties in most European countries do not encourage immigration. I also opposed the migrant quota policy proposed by the European Commission in 2015.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Unable to attend the votes on Thursday 21 January, I would like to express my support for the resolution on the priorities of the European Union for the UN Human Rights Council, which reaffirms its positions in the field of law, democracy, international justice and counter-terrorism.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The important relationship of the UN Human Rights Council with the European Union is unquestionable, since the day-to-day work of the organisation is aimed at examining and protecting the human rights situation. Our job was to adopt a motion for a resolution that properly conveys the European Union's priorities to the EU. The motion tabled by the European Parliament focuses on important areas such as the effective fight against terrorism, human rights and migration, the fight against discrimination and the exercise of economic, social and cultural rights. In my opinion, we have received a well-thought-out and well-worded motion, which I voted in favour of.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The United Nations Human Rights Council has appointed Ambassador Choi Kyong-lim as President for 2016. I have voted for this resolution that should set out the priorities of the United Nations Human Rights Council for 2016.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that respecting, promoting and guaranteeing the universality of human rights is part of the ethical and legal culture of the European Union. All states have an obligation to guarantee respect for human rights regardless of race, origin, religion, class, caste, sex, sexual orientation or color. I support the report voted on today, as it presents the situation of some third countries and their problems in terms of respect for human rights, as well as the EU's priorities and actions in this area. The EU is re-establishing its zero tolerance for the death penalty, expresses its concern about the amendment of the constitution undertaken in some countries with the aim of increasing the limit set for the number of presidential mandates, and stresses that minority communities must be promoted in order to achieve their equality in all areas of life.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the content of the report has very strong ideological opinions, which are largely contrary to my views. The report calls for facilities such as humanitarian corridors and visas for all refugees.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The UN Human Rights Council has an important role to play on the world scale in protecting human rights and drawing attention to their violations. The resolution draws attention to almost all the challenges we face, such as migration, the problem of harassment of human rights defenders, the abolition of the death penalty, the protection of religious freedom, etc.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU's attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that every individual has all the rights and freedoms set out in the Declaration of Human Rights, without distinction. I personally believe that every body in society, constantly bearing this Declaration in mind, must strive to promote respect for these rights and freedoms through teaching and education. Last but not least, it will have to ensure, by means of progressive measures of a national and international nature, universal and effective recognition and respect both between the peoples of the Member States themselves and among those of the territories under their jurisdiction. I would therefore welcome and enthusiastically accept the motions for resolutions and vote in favour of them.

name: Alojz PETERLE
