text: in writing. ‒ The EU should maintain its leadership position in influencing the global human rights agenda. I am inclined towards approaching third countries from a humble position, not with a moderate scale of human rights, but by understanding the identity of third countries and finding ways of promoting human rights in a way that the right conditions for improvement are created, searching for respect and joint sharing points.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I could not support this joint proposal for a resolution on european union priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council meetings, as I believe it does not adequately present eu priorities. While I welcome most of the proposals covered by this joint resolution and are properly geared towards preserving the EU's core values, including the protection of human rights worldwide, I nevertheless consider that some parts of the resolution go beyond the actions of the UN Human Rights Council. The Council is responsible for promoting and protecting human rights and addressing situations of human rights violations. The Council's responsibility is the same when we talk about the situation in the Middle East – the Council can and must promote the protection of human rights in conflict areas by advocating an end to violence and the establishment of peace. However, resolving the Middle East conflict, while depending on respect for human rights, is not exclusive. The establishment of peace in the Middle East goes far beyond the purgage of the UN Human Rights Council. The Middle East conflict is full of specifics and as such requires a specific approach. The EU must condemn all crimes committed and act as a mediator and instigator of a dialogue that seeks to establish peace and a sustainable solution for the benefit of all people living in Israel and the Palestinian Authority.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect, promotion and defence of human rights are an integral part of the European Union's external action. However, global challenges have highlighted the need for a stronger EU commitment to the protection of human rights within its borders. This is particularly true in the area of migration and asylum where, while affirming respect for these rights as a fundamental principle, some Member States draw attention to the need to improve border control without at the same time imagining measures to facilitate legal migration or safe access to asylum in the EU. In this respect, it is essential that the European Union cooperates with the UNHCR and develops a strategy that acts at the root of the phenomenon and ensures that states respect international laws and the principle of non-refoulement and establish transnational humanitarian cooperation. The Union also needs to step up its efforts to protect LGBT rights, and to take action against acts of individual and political violence on the basis of sexual orientation. Finally, it is essential for the EU to develop a gender mainstreaming strategy, in order to reduce gender gaps and violence, and to strengthen women's participation at all levels of decision-making.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The resolution should highlight the situation in 2016 in Georgia, Israel/Palestine, Lebanon, Mauritania, Myanmar, Nepal, Oman, Rwanda, South Sudan, Venezuela as well as in countries where the situation of respect for human rights is as critical as in Syria, Burundi, Yemen and Saudi Arabia. The resolution reiterates the importance of the EU's active and consistent engagement in all UN human rights mechanisms, in particular at the session of the Third Committee of the UN General Assembly and the UN Human Rights Council, he shall see efforts by the EEAS, EU envoys in New York and Geneva and Member States to increase EU coherence on human rights issues at UN level through timely and substantive consultations and to send a 'unanimous message'. The resolution also encourages the EU to put more effort into expressing its position, including by strengthening the increasing practice of launching interregional initiatives and participating in the design of resolutions and taking a leading role in this process, and highlights the need for stronger visibility of EU action in multilateral for a. I fully agree with these calls and guidelines, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN Human Rights Committee is an organisation criticised from almost every possible angle, which is undoubtedly one indicator that it is doing its job well. One of the most important guides for the UN Human Rights Committee is also the European Parliament resolution on this matter, which represents the EP's priorities in the field of the protection of human rights in the world. I supported the resolution without much reservation. However, I abstained on the issue of creating humanitarian corridors for refugees to EU countries. At the moment, it is not clear what the much-discussed introduction of humanitarian corridors means. On the one hand, it can be an effective tool to facilitate the escape of people from areas at risk of war, on the other hand it can mean the creation of a 'motorway' to Europe and not the intended catalysis of economic migration. This would ultimately make things worse for those refugees who are actually fleeing in order to save their own lives. I certainly welcome the reference to the need to define climate refugees. There is no doubt that the ongoing climate change threatens many central Africans, who are moving towards more climate-friendly areas. In view of the potential meatiness of this movement, it is already necessary to prepare and establish an appropriate legal framework for climate migration.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The current complex international situation presents an unprecedented number of human rights challenges that require clear answers and a truly global and functional system to combat human rights violations. As a Social Democrat, I believe that unhrc members should be elected among states that respect human rights and the rule of law and democracy. At the same time, I am concerned that some countries have adopted constitutional changes aimed at changing the time limit on the office of president. Among the most important topics addressed in the resolution are: the increase in extreme poverty, the EU's zero tolerance of the death penalty, the need for access to migration on the basis of human rights, and the introduction of measures to strengthen women's leadership and participation at all levels of the decision-making process. Finally, I would like to mention that, contrary to popular belief, there are clearly positive developments in most countries subject to the general periodic review.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not fully support the Proposed Priorities of the European Union for the Human Rights Council. However, despite some reservations, I abstained. The Member States of the European Union profess the values of democracy, civil liberties and the rule of law, and we should therefore coordinate procedures on a much larger body such as the UN. I welcome the effort to promote civil and political rights, freedom of religion in those countries where these values are trampled. On the other hand, I would like to express reservations about the part concerning the Middle East peace process. I do not agree with the unilateral condemnation of Israel and the designation of Israeli settlements as illegal. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is not black and white, and the European Union should approach such complex points with caution with regard to both sides and not condemn the actions of only one of them. The main priority is to promote dialogue between the parties, as it is the local representatives who must sit at the negotiating table and come to a common agreement. External condemnation of one actor will not benefit from this process.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Although the motion for a resolution makes a number of good recommendations on EU priorities at UNHCR sessions, I voted against the resolution as a whole because I do not agree with its basic assumptions on m.in. EU policy on the global application of the death penalty, affirmation of LGBTI rights, attempts to extend the use of full reproductive health services and increase pressure on EU Member States on migration.  Furthermore, it is unacceptable that the text of the resolution does not take into account expressis verbis human rights violations in Russia, Iran or China.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that today we are comprehensively discussing human rights issues in the world. Unfortunately, the regularly included current points confirm that the human rights situation in the world has not improved recently. I consider the report to be positive, but given some vague and questionable wordings, I had to abstain.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) is a part of the United Nations General Assembly support body, established to assess the human rights situation in all member states of the organization.  In order to achieve full understanding of the human rights situation in all member states, the UNHRC has a Universal Periodic Review mechanism. The review asstakes the situation of the parties, advising the General Assembly on promoting and safeguarding human rights, on the one hand, and makes specific recommendations to member states, which are intended to print real changes on the ground, on the other. Despite the recommendations contained in the Universal Periodic Review, some members of the Human Rights Council are among the most serious human rights offenders. To this end, and in order to be able to follow up on the RECOMMENDATIONS of the UNHRC, the rapporteur calls on the European Union and its Member States to explore ways and means of implementing the UNHRC recommendations. Having said the above, I voted in favour of this Resolution of the European Parliament, which reaffirms the universality of human rights and, as well, the obligation to enforce it.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fully respects and is supportive of the work of the United Nations. However, we object to the EU's attempt to develop foreign relations and to interfere in the work of international institutions. As such we voted against this resolution.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. This report expresses deep concern for human rights and democratic values (such as freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion), as well as the fact that public space for civil society is increasingly small and that an increasing number of human rights defenders are the target of attacks around the world. The report was voted in favour as it calls on the EU and the Member States to redouble their efforts to put human rights and democratic values at the heart of their relations with the rest of the world, and reiterates the importance of ensuring greater coherence between the EU's internal and external policies.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Saudi Arabia, Burundi, Cuba, Maldives, Venezuela... These are all countries that violate human rights in a blatant and widespread way and are among the 47 countries on the UN Human Rights Council. Ironically, it is this intergovernmental body, established in 2006, that has the responsibility to strengthen the promotion and protection of human rights around the globe. In short, this Council is a pantnade and would justify a reform from top to bottom! This is the main reason for my opposition in the final vote on the resolution adopted this afternoon by the European Parliament on the European priorities of the Human Rights Council for 2016. There is also reason to wonder about the bias that prevailed in the establishment of a subjective list of countries: why does Rwanda find itself in the infamous list without any word of encouragement for all that President Kagame has put in place? Why not Zimbabwe, the Maldives and so many others? Why again Israel and the Middle East, without even deploring the stabbing killings of Israeli civilians. A guilty subjectivity which does not honour this European Parliament.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the priorities of the European Union for the sessions of the Human Rights Council (HRC) in 2016. The HRC is a strong contributor to international efforts to promote and respect human rights and it is therefore important to support its actions.  Among the European Parliament's priorities are respect for civil and political rights, including the regular holding of free and legitimate elections by universal and egalitarian suffrage; freedom of the media, civil society organizations and human rights defenders; The safety of humanitarian workers; the abolition of the death penalty; freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief; respect for human rights in resolving the migration and environmental crisis; coherence of the Union's internal and external human rights policies. Finally, I would like to recall the importance of the Universal Periodic Review, which assesses the human rights situation in all UN Member States. I hope that the Union will do everything in its power to ensure that the recommendations are implemented in the countries concerned.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. Members of the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) must be elected from among states that advocate respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy.  UN Member States should promote performance-based criteria on human rights as a condition for a State to be elected as a member of the UNHRC. We are concerned about human rights violations in some newly elected UNHRC Member States. Hence the importance of universaluniversaluniversal universality of the Universal Periodic Review (EPU) in order to achieve a full understanding of the human rights situation in all UN Member States.  This examination also needs to ensure the participation of a wide range of stakeholders, including civil society.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I supported this joint motion for a resolution by which Parliament sets its priorities for the sessions of the UN Human Rights Council. With it, Parliament welcomes the appointment of Ambassador Choi Kyong-lim as chairman of the HRC for 2016 and insists that the recommendations of the Special Rapporteur on contemporary forms of racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and related intolerance be implemented to combat the spread of hatred and incitement to racial, ethnic and xenophobic hatred. It also condemns the permanent harassment and deprivation of liberty of human rights defenders and opponents in several third countries. It also prioritizes the fight against terrorism, social and economic rights, children's rights, women's rights, LGTBI rights, migration and refugees, the death penalty, press freedom or climate change. It also insists that Member States strengthen their coordination in the UN. As for countries under universal periodic review, Parliament focuses on Georgia, Lebanon, Mauritania, Myanmar/Burma, Nepal, Rwanda, South Sudan, Venezuela, Syria, Burundi, Saudi Arabia and Belarus, and the Middle East peace process.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which expresses concern at the revisions of the constitutions, undertaken by some countries to change the maximum number of presidential terms, a subject which, in some cases, has led to acts of violence linked to elections.  The text also recalls that freedom of expression, as well as a dynamic environment conducive to an independent and plural civil society, are indispensable conditions for the defence of respect for human rights.  The adopted text condemns the continued harassment and detention of human rights defenders and opposition figures by government forces in a number of third countries. It also reaffirms the European Union's zero tolerance for the death penalty, as well as its long-standing opposition to torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment in all cases and in all circumstances.  It also stresses the importance of the European Union continuing to promote the moratorium on the death penalty as a first step towards its abolition and that absolute equality for minorities in third countries in all areas of economic, social and political life should be encouraged.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution, of which I am one of the signatories, concerns the European Union's priorities for the sessions of the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in 2016, as this document is a plasma in a way that I consider very relevant the current issues with regard to the full exercise of our fundamental rights. From the outend, the importance of the full enjoyment of our civil, political, religious and even economic rights - such as our right to vote, assembly, press or freedom of faith; also the importance of protecting women's rights and especially children's rights, the end of the death penalty and also migration and the massive volume of refugees currently in transit a little across the globe, but especially in Europe. Although they are themes that are on the agenda, they do not always take the heart of political agendas - that is why I consider it absolutely essential to act in the defence of these principles at all meetings within the UNHRC. Thus, because I consider it extremely important to include the uncompromising defence of human rights in the Union's external action, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote since the analysis put forward by many of the countries did not share it. Moreover, according to this report, the idea is to go to the UNHCR conference with its own agenda, and then see how to implement it in our policies, without the capacity of European and Member States to be influenced on the agenda.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the proposal for a Joint Resolution on EU priorities for un Human Rights Council sessions in 2016 (2015/3035(RSP)) because, while there are important issues mentioned in the Common Resolution on Mechanisms for the Defence of International Law and Human Rights, I do not agree that the European Union should have a growing role within the United Nations, which would lead to a diminishing national sovereignty of the Member States. On the other hand, I do not share at all the analysis of the situation or the condemnation of Venezuela, as well as the instrumentalisation of human rights by the European Union, which prevents me from supporting this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution will highlight the state of play of the Universal Periodic Review for 2016 of Georgia, Lebanon, Mauritania, Burma, Nepal, Oman and Rwanda, and what’s particularly important is the situation of human rights in critical areas like Syria, the Yemen, Saudi Arabia and Burundi. I join the call on Member States of the EU to actively oppose any attempt to undermine the concept of universality, indivisibility and interdependence of human rights, and I underline the need to keep special procedures and preserve the independence of and adequate funding for the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, as well as sufficient funding for the regional offices of the OHCHR.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution seeks to set the UN agenda at the Human Rights Council by speaking as one EU voice on migration, climate change, LGBTI rights, Russian aggression and the Middle East peace process (amongst many others). The resolution had such a strong liberal agenda I was unable to support it, as this would have meant voting for sexual and reproductive health and rights. Sovereign Member States should all have their voice at the UN and not be diluted into one EU position.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Promoting respect for human rights and protecting the universality of human rights is part of the EU's ethical and legal framework. In addition, the UN Human Rights Council aims to monitor the extent to which individual countries in the world are taking a approach to their implementation. I therefore support the independence and integrity of the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, as it is absolutely crucial that he can fulfil his mandate effectively and impartially. I also welcome the initiative of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, who pushed for change and supported the creation of eight regional centres for direct cooperation with partner countries. Especially in the current migration crisis, it turns out that the humanitarian situation of refugees is often not in line with their fundamental rights, and cooperation with third countries is the way to change this. The severity of the humanitarian crisis experienced by refugees requires effective and coordinated international action to address current and future migration challenges. It cannot be forgotten that migration must also be approached from the point of view of human rights precisely because there are also women and children among marginalised and disadvantaged migrant groups. The strategy for tackling migration must be linked to humanitarian and development policy, and if we are talking about the return of migrants, it is necessary to think about respect for their rights and sufficient protection in their country.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Respect for, promotion and protection of the universality of human rights is part of the EU's ethical and legal order and one of the cornerstones of the European Community and integrity. The human rights situation in the EU Member States has a direct impact on the credibility of its human rights policy abroad.  I agree that respect for human rights must be enforced in all areas relating to peace and security, development cooperation, migration, trade and investment, humanitarian aid, climate change and the fight against terrorism.  The motion for a resolution concerns regular meetings of the UN Human Rights Council. These meetings contribute to international efforts to promote and respect human rights, democracy and the rule of law. In the first place, the motion for a resolution reiterates the EU's position that the members of the Human Rights Council should be elected from among the countries that maintain the highest standards of the enforcement and protection of human rights, the rule of law and democracy. The motion for a resolution sets out some EU priorities for the UN Council meeting. As such, I can list the cooperation between the EU Member States and the Human Rights Council, the area of civil and political rights, social and economic rights, the importance of indigenous peoples' participation, migration and refugee issues, climate rights, women's rights, etc.  As I agree with the priorities listed, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 On the European Parliament resolution on priorities for the UN Human Rights Council, I, like most of my colleagues in the PPE faction, have decided to vote against it. Unfortunately, the motion for a resolution contains conflicting provisions and therefore I cannot agree with its final form. On the one hand, the achievement of a feasible two-state solution is accentuated, on the other hand, this idea is all confronted simply by the assertion that Israeli settlements are illegal under international law. The situation in the Middle East has been very serious for several decades. As an experienced rapporteur from war zones, I am well aware that achieving a peace process between two countries always requires years of hard work on both sides, going hand in hand with balanced cooperation and the help of above-state institutions. If such superstate institutions are to help the parties to the peace process seek a two-way solution, they should act and act impartially on their own. This should be something that the European Parliament, as well as the Council, the conclusions of which the resolution refers to, should be aware of this when drafting opinions. Efforts to amend the resolution in the form of disparaging bilateral solutions and the application of unilateral provocative provisions must be condemned in this context, and I very much hope that the European Parliament will learn from the situation in the future.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Disregard for human rights and lack of legitimate democratic participation leads to instability, the demise of states, humanitarian crises and armed conflicts. Most African countries have undergone a transition from an autocratic way of rule, to multiparty democracies. Unfortunately, the latest trend is a decline in democratic standards in individual countries. That is why I want to highlight paragraph 9 of the resolution that tosses on the more frequent revisions of the constitution in developing countries so that the ruling structures circumvent the set limits on the duration of the president's term, and such actions often result in civil uprisings and violence. Such conduct is contrary to Article 21 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states that the will of the people is the basis of state power and expresses this will in occasional genuine elections conducted through universal and equal voting rights.   Also, in countries where elections are held, the legitimacy of them is questionable since the ruling structure got them with 100%. I would like to point out that corruption, tax evasion, mismanagement of public goods, closed state institutions contribute to human rights violations, as this reduces the available funds for investments in much-needed public services such as education, basic health services and other social infrastructure, thereby prolonging population poverty.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted against the resolution on the EU priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council. I cannot agree with the statements about the Middle East peace process that Israeli settlements under international law are illegal and have a negative impact on the realisation of a two-state solution. Blaming Israel for not taining a two-state solution is irresponsible. We would prefer to pay greater attention to the financing of quasi-civilian and non-governmental, but in reality terrorist organisations with European Union money.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We abstained in the vote on the report, although we support the actions of the UNHCR in providing assistance and support to refugees, because we do not agree with the EU's analysis of the political and social situation in several countries. We also do not share the view that the EU should attend the UNHCR summit on its own agenda.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Let the EU finally stop dealing with the internal affairs of third countries because - when influential Member States are serially involved in unjust and illegal wars, - when, illegally, they have authorised their security forces to kidnap citizens and imprison them without trial in detention centres on other continents, - when, en masse and indiscriminately, most governments in the EU illegally monitor their citizens , - when the same governments introduce en masse into the territories the "refugees" and migrants who have become Europe the continent of rape and abuse of women, - when in Greece there is innumerable evidence of pre-trial circuits, interventions by politicians in justice but also of rigging electoral processes, how can the EU invoke the Republic or its principles and values?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, agreeing with the priorities set out in the report, reflecting the indivisible and universal nature of human rights, which are a guide for european Union representatives to their activities in the UN Human Rights Council this year. In addition to the protection of human and civil rights in the traditional sense, the detailed resolution also applies to women, children and other groups particularly vulnerable to infringements, as well as to economic and environmental aspects. For my part, I particularly welcome the emphasis placed on the two most serious challenges facing the EU and the international community at present, the refugee crisis and terrorism, and their many human rights implications. In considering this subject, I have taken into account the unfortunate fact that, due to the behaviour of some of its Member States, the European Union, in its current political state, is under-suited to the global guiding and norm-setting role it traditionally plays in the enforcement and protection of general human rights. Thus, the government of my own country has made the inhumane treatment of refugees, the discriminatory and repression of our own minorities and poor, or even the severe restrictions on the fundamental human and civil rights of the population, under the pretext of the terrorist threat, an integral part of its policy. I trust that this guiding EP decision will also contribute to the eradication of such practices in the Member States, thereby restoring the EU's political and moral credibility.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This year's European Parliament resolution on the European Union's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council raises a number of important human rights issues around the world, such as the abolition of the death penalty, religious freedom, civil and political rights, counter-terrorism and the migration and refugee crisis. However, despite negotiating the compromise text of the resolution in the final vote, I could not support this document because of the paragraph on the very complex issue of the Middle East peace process.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's priorities for human rights council meetings in 2016 as it contains all our demands, such as combating the criminal phenomenon of land grabbing. Even today, fundamental rights are under threat in the world on various fronts: terrorism, executions, attacks on co-operatives, the arrest of political opponents, numerous and continuous violations against migrants fleeing war and the effects of climate change. The resolution also stresses the importance of the Beijing Platform for Action on Access to Education and Health as a fundamental human right. Universal access to health services, including sexual and reproductive services, as well as easy access to contraceptives, are important elements in saving women's lives, even when they are victims of rape, and in reducing infant and maternal mortality.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Participation of the European Union in the United Nations Human Rights Council is an expression of the importance that the Community institutions attach to this subject. Respect for human rights is an essential condition put in place by the EU in relation to third countries. In the context of this event, the issue of countries under universal periodic evaluation (EPU), such as Georgia, Lebanon, Mauritania, Myanmar, Nepal, Oman and Rwanda, will be addressed, as well as countries where the human rights situation is at a critical stage, such as Syria, Burundi, Yemen and Saudi Arabia. It will also discuss the specific issues that persist in various countries, including civil and political rights, social and economic rights, business rights, immigration, climate change, women's rights, children's rights, sexual minority rights, death penalty and freedom of the press. What needs to be highlighted is the universality of human rights and their indivisible character. EU participation will provide an opportunity to express a common position, which will help to increase the EU's visibility and credibility as a global player, encouraging EU action in various parts of the world. For these reasons, this resolution deserves to be upheld.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal. It is crucial to preserve the independence and integrity of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, to ensure that it can continue to exercise its mandate effectively and impartially.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Yearly, and ahead of the participation of Parliament’s Committee on Human Rights delegation in the March UN Human Rights Council session, Parliament adopts a resolution concerning the EU priorities for the UNHRC sessions. The resolution strongly condemned the continued harassment and detention of human rights defenders and opposition figures by government forces. The resolution specifically referenced the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, raising great concern over this Gulf kingdom’s ‘systematic violation of human rights’. The EP resolution also reaffirmed its ‘zero tolerance policy’, on the death penalty and supported continued efforts to establish a global moratorium on this practice.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. Due to high international instability and wars fought in Africa, the Middle East and European soil, human rights are highly threatened. However, many countries that do not respect the rights set out in this resolution will be equal to the European Union during the debate on these rights at the UN Human Rights Council session. Although I support some parts of the resolution, I think it is too focused on increasing the rights of various minority groups, while the rights of the individual, as the most vulnerable minorities, are still neglected., So I voted abstaining.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I rejected the motion for a resolution on the European Union priorities for the 2016 UN Human Rights Council meetings, as the indent that could potentially lead to conflict between nations, crucial to the EES, was rejected. Freedom of religion and intolerance towards it because of the current migrant crisis comes to the fore. In 2016, it would therefore be particularly necessary to conduct an interfaith dialogue, as this would enable us to better understand the differences and, consequently, strengthen tolerance and peace between nations.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote since the analysis put forward by many of the countries did not share it. Moreover, according to this report, the idea is to go to the UNHCR conference with its own agenda, and then see how to implement it in our policies, without the capacity of European and Member States to be influenced on the agenda.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this report, and I hope that in the future the UN will put in place mechanisms to prevent countries like Saudi Arabia from giving lessons to others on human rights at the same time that they undermine them in the domestic sphere.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Each State has a duty to ensure respect for human rights, regardless of race, origin, gender or colour; reiterating its insistence on the indivisiability of human rights, be they civil, economic, social or cultural rights, which are interdependent. Each State has a duty to respect the fundamental rights of its population and to take concrete measures to promote these rights at national level and to cooperate at international level to remove obstacles to the enforcement of human rights in all areas. I supported the S&D position summarising the priorities.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ We secured an unusually critical line on EU and Member State behaviour in Geneva, notably calling for a more principled and non-selective engagement of the EU Member States at the Human Rights Council, secured entire new paragraphs on sports and human rights, indigenous peoples, counter-terrorism and human rights (respect for human rights is the foundation for successful CT policies), minorities, and the ICC. The resolution included positive language in support of the UN and the Human Rights Council, and strengthened language on civil society and human rights defenders.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against the proposal for a Joint Resolution on EU priorities for un Human Rights Council sessions in 2016 (2015/3035(RSP)) because, while there are important issues mentioned in the Common Resolution on Mechanisms for the Defence of International Law and Human Rights, I do not agree that the European Union should have a growing role within the United Nations, which would lead to a diminishing national sovereignty of the Member States. On the other hand, I do not share at all the analysis of the situation or the condemnation of Venezuela, as well as the instrumentalisation of human rights by the European Union, which prevents me from supporting this joint motion for a resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted for this resolution. The UN Human Rights Council has an important role to play in defending human rights at a global level. This resolution seeks to draw attention to the violations of these human rights: the migration crisis, the threat to human rights defenders, the abolition of the death penalty, and so on. Moreover, this report highlights the critical state of human rights in conflict zones such as Syria, Yemen and Burundi.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The annual report of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights contains very positive aspects such as the points on the economic crisis and its consequences on peoples, especially those contained in the 2015 report: "the growing inequalities and political, economic and social exclusion of marginalised groups attack the dignity and rights of peoples in many States and are , to a large extent, responsible for the emergence of the above-mentioned problems and conflicts. Economic, social and cultural rights, as well as the right to development, have suffered from austerity policies which, together with corruption, have disproportionately affected the poor and the marginalised. It is therefore the time to look into the European Union where the practice of wanting to teach the world prevails when, within it, the rights of peoples are not respected and democracy is repeatedly disregarded.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The catalogue of demands contains ideological assessments that contradict my views. I reject the development of European influence in national affairs and further paternalism. I am therefore voting against this motion.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: , in writing – This resolution highlights the priorities needed to improve the protection of human rights, including: – reassing the EU's zero tolerance for and long-standing opposition to the death penalty and torture; – reminders that freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief is a fundamental right recognised by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and calls for concrete action in the protection of religious minorities; – the challenges of the biggest humanitarian crisis since the Second World War. We are witnessing an ever-increasing number of people at risk of persecution, armed conflicts, general violence, who are forced to leave their homes and risk their lives in search of safety and a better life; – calls for effective and coordinated international action to address the root causes of migratory flows; – Incentives for all states to combat gender-based violence against women and girls and the importance of developing a migration policy that takes gender specificities into account. Nevertheless, I could not support this resolution as a whole, because it emphasises universal access to sexual and reproductive health services, family planning, which also includes abortion, contraception and artificial insemination, and emphasises gender ideology.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because it was a resolution that I had co-signed with my colleagues at the time of its tabling.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Human rights are inalienable and I consider their observance, regardless of race, religion or origin, to be automatic in all states. It is precisely in the light of the ongoing humanitarian and migration crisis that respect for human rights must be supervised, especially for disadvantaged populations such as women or children. I am in favour of intensifying the support of the Member States of the Union in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in putting greater emphasis on the protection of minors and children. I consider it necessary to share best practices between states in breaking up very well organised networks of traffickers. I also agree with other motions for resolutions on the PPE Group, such as the need to respect political, social or economic rights.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament is adamant that respect for civil and political rights is an indicator of a democratic, tolerant and pluralistic society. As President of the EP Delegation for Relations with Belarus, I am working to speak about violations of human rights and democratic values in belarus in the widest possible forum. I am therefore pleased that this resolution also makes reference to the situation in Belarus. The European community was relieved to receive the news of the release of political prisoners in Belarus in August 2015. We look forward to their full rehabilitation and the restoration of their civil rights. Together with international observers, we watched the presidential election in October 2015. Unfortunately, a number of irregularities have been observed. Free, universal and equal elections should be a fundamental right for all citizens. We therefore expect that the upcoming parliamentary elections will be conducted in compliance with international standards, which will result in the presence of opposition parties in the Belarusian Parliament.  Furthermore, I would point out that Belarus is the only country in Europe to apply the death penalty. The European Parliament has consistently expressed its opposition to the use of the death penalty, torture, inhuman and degrading treatment and punishment, and stresses that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to the strengthening of human dignity. I therefore call on the Belarusian authorities to join the moratorium on the death penalty, which will be a first step towards its complete abolition.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the motion for a joint resolution on the European Union's priorities for the 2016 UNHRC meeting. The proposal covered a very broad and diverse area of the European Union's human rights interests and touched not only on general human rights issues, but also on situations in specific countries. Among other things, the proposal addressed current migration-related challenges and challenges, but also topics related to technological progress, such as the use of drones. Although I agree with most of the issues included in the report, I could not support the report, particularly in view of a number of sensitive topics, such as LGBTI access to all legal institutes or the issue of universal access to sexual and reproductive health services.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The UN Human Rights Council plays a key role in geopolitical processes, so it is important that the European Union comes up with a sacrotic proposal on priorities. Unfortunately, the final form of the European Parliament resolution on EU priorities was not balanced, which is why I did not support it in the vote.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I participated in the debate on the report of the Committee on Petitions. There, too, I said that the case of hungarian foreign currency creditors had been closed with a half-page, highly primitive document, which was a 15-page thorough petition, drafted by lawyers. I have been a lawyer for 30 years, and I am convinced that if the doorman had been given that 15-page petition to judge him, he would have written a significantly more sophisticated, significantly higher-quality response than the commissioner of the Committee on Petitions. I have come to know the European Union from a new side, the side of black humour, in this report, when it says in point (d) that petitioners are generally citizens committed to improving the situation of our society and its future prosperity. The experience of citizens managing their petitions can be decisive for the development of their views on European integration. They are absolutely right about this, they have a disd nastling opinion on the work of the Committee on Petitions and a disd nastling opinion of the whole European Union – more and more.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, since We can we have always made a full defence of citizen participation. With our vote in favour we welcome the right of petition, but above all we welcome the great involvement of European citizens in the political debate. I would like to make special mention of two facts: the first, that Spain is the country that sends the most requests (449 in 2014), which reflects the social empowerment experienced after the '15 M', and secondly, the high number of applications on environmental and energy issues, especially on fracking and energy prospecting in the Canary Islands.  However, we do not give up on our complaint that the current European institutional architecture is openly undemocratic. Only three of the thirty-one European citizen initiatives have come to fruition, and of them, for the time being, only one has succeeded in getting the European Commission to move. In every corner of Europe people have said this: we want to build a more democratic and fully participatory Europe among all. It's possible, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to say two things as coordinator in the Committee on Petitions for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. Firstly, I am, of course, pleased with the great support that the report has received in the European Parliament. This is a good sign that encourages us, including for further work. Secondly, I must honestly admit that I was annoyed by a motion – and this was also approved by a narrow majority. And that is what was the motion, where it was quite loosely called for us to recruit more staff to the Committee on Petitions. Not that I do not grant this to the Committee on Petitions, but I am simply annoyed that we are then asking for more staff, especially for a committee, detached from all the expertise and also from the problems that exist in other committees. That is not fair, nor is it effective.  I would have liked to have had a thorough discussion at this point, if we really want to, and also for a thorough consultation with the members of the European Parliament who represent the other committees. This vote should also have taken place.  As a result, I was a bit annoyed at the point. Nevertheless, the joy of the great approval prevails.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The aim of the Committee on Contracts is to examine petitions by citizens of the European Union which coincide with those of the European Parliament. It must be said, for example, that fewer petitions were received in 2014 than in the year before, but on average the number is still increasing. This cannot be uneasy and can only be evidenced by the progressively increasing awareness of what the European Parliament is doing about the opportunities and work of the European Parliament. However, account should be taken of the fact that around 40 % of the petitions received were assessed as inadmissible. This may mean that it is not only a case of low awareness, but also of the widespread – I would say – misunderstanding of what the European Parliament is doing. Consequently, we can only welcome the promotion of the European Parliament in the eyes of citizens and increasing awareness, and the call for citizens to petition the European Parliament. Support.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Annual Report of the Committee on Petitions provides a comprehensive view of the work carried out, thanks to the processing of data and statistics on the number of petitions received and the issues addressed. The 2014 petition rate is just under 30%, with a strong interest in the fields of the environment, fundamental rights, health, justice and the internal market. That is why we want stronger cooperation with governments and local authorities in order to improve, simplify and speed up the system of petitions by increasing the use of this instrument of participation. This will enable each citizen to feel more involved in European choices and policies, mitigating the perception of remoteness from the institutions. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a good reflection of the activities that the Committee on Petitions carried out during 2014, since many of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group have been adopted, significant issues have been contained that were the subject of numerous requests: the rejection of TTE and the opacity of the negotiations, citizen opposition to fracking or the complaints that moved dozens of Europeans and Europeans to EU migration, trade and foreign policies. I also consider it positive that the report contains a number of express requests to improve the treatment of requests, such as: increased resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, increased involvement of the European Commission in analysing requests or improvements to the web portal so that petitioners and petitioners can have up-to-date information on the processing of their requests. Finally, I consider the report's call for a review of the Regulation governing European citizens' initiatives to be truly an instrument that allows for greater participation of citizens in the European decision-making process.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution to approve the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014. Indeed, it should be noted that its activity is down compared to 2013, on the one hand, and that the subjects of petitions remain the same, on the other hand: it concerns exclusively environmental law, fundamental rights, discrimination and immigration.  Moreover, giving ever more rights to migrants seems to be the ultimate struggle of this committee as well as that of all parliamentary committees, instead of defending the interests of European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report provides an update on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2014. While he congratulated the Committee on its work, it was clear that the Commission's activity had decreased by 6% compared to the previous year. In addition, it selects only petitions that it likes. In short, only politically correct, immigrationist and tender petitions with the pharma-industrial lobbies are treated. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlighted the ‘opaque’ negotiations carried out by the committee and calls for transparency. It also highlighted the concerns that European citizens have regarding TTIP.    However, I abstained on this report because it calls for increased expenditure and staffing using British taxpayers’ money.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this annual report for 2014, which aims to review the activities of the Committee on Petitions. Statistics show that the majority of citizens contact the EP to help with issues relating to justice, the environment, the internal market or fundamental rights. Some petitioners are calling on the European Parliament to come forward with proposals for the development of EU policies, while others are appealing against decisions taken by national authorities, as well as appealing against decisions of national courts. Some citizens complain about incorrect application of EU legislation. In 2014, the EP received 2714 petitions. This figure decreased by 6 % compared to 2013 . The European Commission declared 2014 the European Year of Citizens and paid particular attention to the European elections, which took place on 22 and 25 May. The Committee on Petitions is an important tool for citizens to be more involved in the Democratic Process in Europe, it stimulates debate, informs EU citizens and helps them exercise their rights.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Petitions Committee received 27,114 petitions in 2014, double the number in 2009. However, this is not enough if we take into account all the citizens of the European Union. Topics covered include fundamental rights, people with disabilities, the internal market, etc. It should be noted that the Committee on Petitions stresses the concerns and rejection of citizens regarding TTIP and the opaque negotiations in which the Commission participates. These concerns have been expressed in numerous petitions received and the Commission is invited to urgently implement the recommendations made by the European Ombudsman in this regard. This demonstrates once again the growing popular discontent with both the content of TTIP and the conduct of the negotiations. I approved this annual report.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains the main activities and data highlighted from the requests received. I would like to stress the special value and significance of the Committee on Petitions, as it is the real window open to citizens. That more than 500 million Europeans can directly move their demands to the House and set the political agenda has a unique value. It is worth attracting attention to countries such as mine, Spain, which is at the forefront year after year in terms of petitions (as well as infringements and sanctions received) for non-compliance with European legislation. The Government must take good note as it is largely responsible for this.  Finally, I stress paragraph 21, in which we regret that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has not been adopted in all Member States and that its implementation is confusing. I also regret the strict interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter, under which the European Commission repeatedly declares it incapable of acting in the field of fundamental rights. We must enforce the Charter and take a new approach to its interpretation, since, by definition, fundamental rights must be defended above any obstacle.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Geringer de Oedenberg report today. The text presents an overall picture of the work carried out by the Committee on Petitions in 2014, in particular outlining the successes and critical points related to the petition mechanism. The year in question saw a sharp drop in the number of petitions sent, raising the view that citizens were not fully aware of the scope of this right, as enshrined in Article 227 of the Treaty of Lisbon. While the number of inadmissible petitions also remains high, it is important to stress that citizens' attention seems to be focused mainly on the issues of justice, the environment, fundamental rights and the internal market. In general terms, we must acknowledge the important work carried out by the committee, which, despite the difficulties arising from a staff restriction, has effectively managed to act as a point of coordination between citizens and institutions, enabling Parliament's legitimacy and responsibility in the decision-making process to be strengthened.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. There is no doubt that the European Citizens' Initiative, commonly known as the 'petition', is an instrument that promotes representative and participatory democracy by giving citizens the opportunity to participate more directly in the development of European policies. However, one should be concerned that only 29.1% of the nearly 2000 petitions filed in 2014 were declared admissible and followed up. There is a real tendency within the Commission to obstruct investigations into the merits of many petitions by imposing restrictions on procedural grounds only. This has been the case with thorny and awkward issues concerning shale gas, forced adoptions of children or, more recently, the transatlantic treaty. The Commission, as guardian of the treaties, should, rather than systematically close these files, promote thorough investigations into admissible issues, hold public debates and meetings on these issues, and provide specific and up-to-date responses to petitioners. The Commission's institutional credibility is at stake.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2014 but I have disagreed with my group on two votes. I voted against Amendment No Four of the Verts/ALE Group because, in my opinion, the original text is more appropriate, since it considers that Parliament has an obligation to ensure that an unjustifiably long period of time does not elapse to declare unreasonable or to archive requests not accepted for processing. Furthermore, I supported paragraph forty-four, which refers to the visit made to this committee by a delegation from the Scottish Parliament, as such collaborations can improve the exchange of good practices.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, with great concern, dares to congratulate itself on the activities of the PETI Committee in the European Parliament, even though it has the lowest productivity, which is constantly declining. For example, the PETI commission received 2,714 petitions in 2014, a decrease of 6% from 2013. On the other hand, while the right to petition can be welcomed as a genuine democratic tool for citizens, the decisions of the PETI committee are mostly made via an ideological reading grid full of political correctness, even to the detriment of the reality of what the Peoples of Europe are currently experiencing. That is why I could not approve of this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Geringer De Oedenberg's report is balanced and contains ideas that I fully support, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Committee on Petitions acts as a bridge between European citizens and institutions. The Treaties of the Union guarantee all European citizens the right to write to the European Parliament to address the different problems they may face in their daily lives, provided that the issues raised fall within the competence of the EU. It also plays an important role in so far as it helps to identify the problems that arise in the practical application of EU law. The European Parliament has an obligation to ensure that all the rights and opportunities generated by European law become a reality and benefit all the citizens of Europe. The report details the activity carried out by this Commission and has had my vote in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which gives an overview of the 2014 The committee on petitions. Citizens or residents of the European Union, whether natural or legal persons, have the right to petition the European Parliament, individually or jointly with other citizens or persons, on any matter falling within the eu's fields of activity and having a direct impact on them. Petitions are therefore a tool to enable citizens to express to Parliament their concerns about the impact on their daily lives of various EU policies and provisions of EU legislation. Annual statistics show that the majority of citizens apply to the European Parliament to help with issues relating to justice, the environment, the internal market or fundamental rights. Some petitioners are calling on Parliament to come forward with proposals for the development of European Union policies, while others are appealing against decisions taken by national authorities and appealing against decisions of national courts. Some citizens complain about inadequate application of EU legislation because legislation has been incorrectly transposed, EU standards are not being properly implemented or violated. The European Parliament stresses that close cooperation with the Member States is essential for the functioning of the Committee on Petitions and therefore calls on the Member States to submit their own-initiative responses to petitions relating to the implementation and enforcement of EU legislation.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed annual report on the review of the work of the Committee on Petitions for 2014 and the accompanying programme of activities. The latter is being 100,000 people who, by exercising their right to petition with the European Parliament, express their concerns about the various political and legislative areas of the EU. The report provides a comprehensive picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions, which contains statistics on the number of petitions received, the countries from which they originate and the topics referred to by petitioners. The European Parliament received 2714 petitions in 2014, which is 6% less than in 2013. Petitions remain an important tool for European citizens to draw attention to a particular issue, and Parliament must address them with extreme discretion.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on the Activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. I believe that this is a good report that was further worked on in the Committee by investing amendments, of which 12 compromise amendments were adopted by all groups on the Committee.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions is a fundamental instrument of democracy and that the data relating to its work in 2014 demonstrate the need for greater efforts on the part of national and local authorities and european institutions to provide it with greater support to enable citizens to be brought closer to the Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This text gives a positive assessment of the activities of the Committee on Petitions in the European Parliament, even though it has very low productivity. It received 2,714 petitions in 2014, a decrease of 6% compared to 2013. While, at first glance, we can welcome the recognition of the right to petition as a genuine democratic tool for citizens, the reading grid that is emerging is suitable for political correctness. When, for example, is a petition calling for a definitive end to the policy of mass immigration? I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014 were reflected in the annual report, which provided a precise and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions. Citizens can express their concerns about the different policies of the Union and its legislation by exercising their right to petition the European Parliament. It is therefore an instrument that allows citizens to convey to Parliament their concerns about the impact of the various European Union policies and legislative provisions on their daily lives.  The results of this report are an important quantitative tool for assessing the work of the committee. Some 69,5 % of the petitions received in 2014 were resolved at the beginning of the procedure, thus noting that the decision to send information to the petitioner and resolve the petition in the first phase of the procedure is significantly increased compared to 2013 (by 11.3 %). I was in favour of this report because I believe that it is extremely important to use these instruments to guarantee the right of free expression of the citizens of the Member States on matters relating to the areas of the Union's work and which concern them directly, while also appreciating the progress made in the work of the Committee on Petitions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Despite the excellent emphasis on the positive results of the work of the Committee on Petitions and a general call to increase the number of staff dedicated to the completion of the files (without specifying whether this can be done through new recruitment or internal reorganization of EP staff), we nevertheless believe that the committee on petitions is an instrument to be protected; The report also contains specific and critical references on aspects of Community legislation (GMOs, TTIP, TISA, etc.) on which we are strongly opposed.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Parliamentary Committee on Petitions is a symbol of the European Parliament's desire to get closer to citizens. Petitions of European citizens are examined and debated in order to properly discern the issues of certain situations and to bring the voice of citizens directly within the Union's legislative bodies. This annual report provides an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions. It highlights the improvements that need to be made to make the system more efficient and more representative of the will of our fellow citizens. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2014 annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions. The right of petition to Parliament is a key element of European citizenship, enshrined as a fundamental right under Article 227 of the Treaty of Lisbon. Any natural or legal person residing in the Union may petition the European Parliament individually or in association with others on a matter falling within the scope of the Union's activities. This tool therefore makes it possible to establish a close link between institutions and citizens, and to monitor and deepen the impact of different EU policies and legislation on people's daily lives.  The work that the Committee on Petitions is doing to make it possible for EU citizens and residents to participate in the defence and promotion of their rights is crucial. However, as the report states, improving institutional coordination with the institutions at EU, national and regional level and with other bodies is essential in order to address the issues raised by petitions in good time. This would also strengthen the legitimacy and responsibility of the European Parliament's decision-making process.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is a straightforward report on the Committee on Petition’s activities. The report summarises the main issues pointed out by petitions received from citizens during the 2014, as well as remarks and recommendations on the Committee’s activities, its regular collaboration with the European Ombudsman and its prerogatives dealing with the European Citizens Initiatives. In particular, I voted in favour of including text highlighting the European Citizens’ Initiative against TTIP last year in the final text, as well as rejecting the Investor-State-Dispute-Settlement (ISDS) mechanism.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a clear and comprehensive analysis of the activities of the Committee on Petitions. I particularly welcome the fact that it emphasises the importance of the European Citizens’ Initiative and its role played in the promotion and implementation of participatory democracy in the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines the work of the Committee on Petitions and provides highly acceptable ideas for ensuring a better exercise of the instruments of direct democracy by European citizens. The general approach of the report, which stresses the importance of the right to petition and reports on the issues on which a large number of citizens have expressed their concerns (such as, among other TTIP, fracking for the extraction of gas and oil from the subsoil, forced adoptions and international abductions of minors), is certainly to be welcomed. The recommendations are also interesting and acceptable. These include, in particular, the call on the Commission to ensure that the petitions sent by Parliament respond more quickly over time and to provide more concrete answers to citizens' demands. Finally, the report calls for more structured cooperation both with the governments of the Member States and with their national parliaments. The final text is therefore to be considered quite positive and, also in the light of the acceptance of the numerous requests raised by the 5 Star Movement, I voted in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as there are parts related to the TTIP negotiations which do not reflect the approach adopted by the Commission during these negotiations. The text adopted reiterates concerns which are not based on the real state of play of the negotiations.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the vote on the annual report with an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions for 2014. The Committee on Petitions is an important tool at the disposal of the citizen in order to broaden his participation in the European democratic process. The Committee on Petitions also encourages dialogue and informs and supports European citizens in relation to their rights. The Committee on Petitions offers citizens a direct link with the institutions and ensures that the practical problems of citizens are heard by them.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to support the vote on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. I believe, in fact, that the instrument of petition is an extraordinary means of democratic participation for European citizens. As set out in Article 227 of the Treaty of Lisbon, the submission of petitions to the EU is a fundamental right that represents an instrument that brings citizens even closer to the institutions and the decision-making process, guaranteeing them a role of direct participation. In this respect, the peti committee's initiatives must be aimed at raising awareness and informing citizens about the forms and ways in which petitions are used.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Petitions carries out essential work in the relationship between citizens and the EU institutions. The EU treaties give all European citizens the right to go to the European Parliament to report various types of problems they face in their daily lives, provided that the issues raised fall within the scope of the Activities of the European Union I support this annual report, which I consider to be of great importance, as it offers a precise and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions , allowing knowledge of the number of petitions received, closed or handled by the committee, or of the countries or issues concerned, being an important quantitative tool in the evaluation of the committee's work.  This tool allows Members and European entities to be closer to citizens and to the possible non-correct application of European law by Member States.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the report's calls for more active cooperation with the Council and the shortening of the response period. We still have to work on this together with the Commission. The Committee on Petitions provides our citizens with a direct platform to defend themselves against discrimination or the violation of their rights. Here they are heard. The Committee on Petitions promotes debate, informs and supports citizens and provides a direct link with the institutions.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to petition is a fundamental element of participatory democracy, but unfortunately most European citizens do not know the existence of the right to petition or its potential usefulness as a means of attracting the attention of the institutions or members elected by them. Furthermore, there is still a great deal of confusion about the areas of activity of the European Union, so a large number of petitions are inadmissible.
