I felt I had to vote in favour of this report because I believe that many structural and organisational shortcomings linked to the functioning of this Commission can be overcome, firstly by ensuring effective and timely processing of petitions for reasons where they are inadmissible and by providing the Committee on Petitions with a fully operational web portal that will effectively allow petitioners to register. , submit a petition, upload accompanying documents, support admissible petitions and receive information on the status of your petition, as well as be notified of changes in the status of the petition via automated e-mails, be able to directly get in touch with officials of the EU institutions for clear and direct information on the progress of the matter of interest.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee on Petitions provides European citizens with an easy and informal process that enables them to seek justice. It is important that this process is strengthened, thereby making it more accessible as well as more efficient and effective. The report makes a number of important proposals to strengthen this process with which I am in agreement. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report aims to give a precise and complete view of the work carried out by the Committee on Petitions, providing a set of data and statistics on the number of petitions received and the issues dealt with, and proposing several recommendations. In 2014, just under 30% of petitions were declared admissible and actually dealt with. The most raised issues were: justice, the environment, the internal market, fundamental rights, health. The report contains a number of positive aspects. These include: the reference to the importance of the right of petition and the usefulness of petitions; criticism of the European Commission's particularly flawed responses to european citizens' initiatives of over one million signatures (Right 2 Water, One of Us, Stop Vivisection); the reference to the dozens of petitions expressing concern about TTIP and the use of fracking for the extraction of gas and oil from underground; the issue of child welfare, on potential abuse by administrative and judicial authorities in some Member States, international abduction of children. The report expresses the desire for more structured cooperation with national governments and parliaments. This seems to me to be a good report, which is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a good reflection of the activities that the Committee on Petitions carried out during 2014, since many of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group have been adopted, significant issues have been contained that were the subject of numerous requests: the rejection of TTE and the opacity of the negotiations, citizen opposition to fracking or the complaints that moved dozens of Europeans and Europeans to EU migration, trade and foreign policies. I also consider it positive that the report contains a number of express requests to improve the treatment of requests, such as: increased resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, increased involvement of the European Commission in analysing requests or improvements to the web portal so that petitioners and petitioners can have up-to-date information on the processing of their requests. Finally, I consider the report's call for a review of the Regulation governing European citizens' initiatives to be truly an instrument that allows for greater participation of citizens in the European decision-making process.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The annual report of the Committee on Petitions aims, inter alia, at examining ways to improve procedures and relations with other institutions. I supported the amendments to this report, which refer to the procedural guarantees for the handling of petitions laid down in the previous report and bring forward the work of the Committee on Petitions. It is about the elements of the administrative reform introduced by the Secretary-General of Parliament in 2014 concerning the Committee on Petitions, such as replying to citizens within a reasonable period of 9 months. This is in the interests of EU citizens with the right to petition and increases confidence in our institution. In addition to these guarantees, the report also shows every year the breakdown of petitions received in the Member States, which shows that the right to petition is not equally used by citizens in all regions. Central European Union citizens still need more information on EU rights and related opportunities. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Committee on Petitions is an important tool made available to citizens so that they can participate more fully in the democratic process at EU level, and it fosters debate and informs and supports citizens on their rights. The aim of the Committee on Petitions is to provide citizens with direct contact with the institutions and to ensure that they find someone to listen to their specific problems. After hearing the report, I decided to vote in favour of the document.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Petitions Committee Annual Report, in which the committee aims to give a precise and full view of the work carried out in 2014. The report presents statistics and analysis on the number of petitions received, closed and dealt with in 2014, the countries concerned and the matters raised. The report also suggests possible improvements in procedures and in relations with other institutions and national and regional authorities.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, which goes far beyond a summary of the Petitions Committee’s annual activities and instead seeks to direct to Member States what their actions should be in areas that clearly remain the competences of national governments.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report takes stock of the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. Since the Lisbon Treaty came into force in 2009, the Charter of Fundamental Rights has had binding legal value. As such, the right to petition is recognised as a fundamental right (Article 227 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) and allows citizens to alert the European Parliament to problems related to the implementation of European policies. In 2014, 2,714 petitions were filed (6% less than in 2013) and 1607 were deemed admissible. About 80% of the petitions were processed during the year and some triggered infringement proceedings before the Court of Justice. The majority of petitions concern justice, fundamental rights, the environment and the internal market. The main objective of this report is to clarify the rules for the admissibility of complaints, in order to offer citizens better protection of their rights when the Union has jurisdiction. Considering that the right to petition is an important element of the rule of law, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which summarizes the work of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions in 2014. I support the right of every European citizen to be able to file a petition to challenge the institutions. This tool thus contributes to the transparency of European legislative decisions and is a fundamental right of European democracy.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Not only does the Committee on Petitions seem more concerned with defending the rights of migrants than with EU citizens themselves, but it seems to be supported by the European Commission, which is shown by its lack of willingness to listen to the voices of citizens. Considering that within the European Union, as at all levels, there is a fundamental difference between citizens and non-citizens, I believe that the PETI Committee is not acting in the general interest of the Union. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Petitions is the committee closest to European citizens of all committees in the European Parliament. There, everyone has the right to vote and can submit their complaint or recommendation. There are many subjects that could be discussed in this report and I am rather interested in what are the main things affecting the citizen, what is the percentage of citizens who have petitioned by nationality, are there statistics on this. What I have found, however, is that the report focuses more on an opinion on whether or not it is right for some Member States to be given the opportunity to choose whether to be part of something or not and that, note, the principle of subsidiarity is too strictly interpreted by the Commission. I cannot agree with such opinions, so I rejected this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The work programme of the Committee on Petitions is not linked to the Commission's legislative programme but is determined by citizens, who, by exercising the right to petition the European Parliament, communicate their concerns about various EU policies and legislation. It is therefore a tool that enables citizens to put before Parliament their concerns about the impact of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives. The criticality of this tool can be seen from the diversity of issues raised in citizens' petitions, such as fundamental rights, human rights, the rights of persons with disabilities, the internal market, environmental legislation, industrial relations, immigration policies, trade agreements, public health issues, child protection, transport and animal rights.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. According to statistics, in 2014 the European Parliament received 2 714 petitions, down 6 % from the 2 891 submitted in 2013. This annual report aims to provide a precise and complete picture of the work of the Committee on Petitions by presenting statistics on the number of petitions received, closed or dealt with by the committee, or on the countries or issues concerned, which are an important quantitative tool in the evaluation of the committee's work. The annual statistics show that most citizens turn to Parliament to ask for their help in matters relating to justice, the environment, the internal market and fundamental rights. Other petitioners seek to make their proposals heard on the implementation of Union policies and others still turn to the European Parliament to challenge decisions taken by national authorities and to complain against judgments of national courts. Others also denounce deficiencies in the application of European legislation, either by defective transposition of the legislation, by non-application of Community rules or by violation of them.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the Committee on Petitions has a subjective reception of the petitions received.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to petition is, together with the European Ombudsman, to deal with cases of maladministration by the EU institutions or national institutions in the context of the application of EU law. It often coincides with the simultaneous filing of a complaint with the European Commission, which may lead to the initiation of a failure to file a complaint for failure to fulfil obligations or an action for failure to do so. In 2014, 1 887 petitions were closed, of which 1 070 were declared inadmissible. These figures correspond to an increase of around 10 % compared to 2013. The most worrying issues addressed in the petitions concern environmental legislation (water and waste management, exploration and extraction of hydrocarbons and major infrastructure and development projects); fundamental rights (in particular, the rights of children and the rights of persons with disabilities); free movement of persons, discrimination, immigration, negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP); animal welfare, the application of justice and the social inclusion of persons with disabilities. Despite the indisputable fairness of most of the underlying causes of many of the petitions, we do not follow several of the observations and recommendations contained in the report or some aspects of the philosophy of this instrument.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The right to petition in the European Union is one of the fundamental pillars of European citizenship and, at the same time, a fundamental right which stipulates that every citizen or person residing or having its registered office in the European Union has the right, individually or jointly with other citizens or persons, to submit a petition to the European Parliament on a matter falling within the european Union's sphere of competence or directly affecting it. Most citizens ask the European Parliament for help in the area of justice, the environment, the internal market or fundamental rights. As stated in the 2014 report of the Committee on Petitions, 2714 petitions were received by the European Parliament, representing a decrease of 6% year-on-year.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Committee on Petitions' 2014 work programme because it enables citizens to put before Parliament their concerns about the impact of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives. The criticality of this tool can be seen from the diversity of issues raised in citizens' petitions, such as fundamental rights, human rights, the rights of persons with disabilities, the internal market, environmental legislation, industrial relations, immigration policies, trade agreements, public health issues, child protection, transport and animal rights.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important to give a precise and full view of the work carried out in 2014 by the Committee on Petitions. Statistics on the number of petitions received are an important quantitative tool in assessing the Committee’s work. I believe we have to strongly focus on the needs of citizens, who were especially concerned by matters related to the environment, internal market or fundamental rights. It is important to explain how EU policies should be developed and to object to decisions made by national governments if the citizens ask for it. Identifying the problems that organisers of European citizens’ initiatives encounter is also an issue that has to be addressed. We must ensure correct application of EU legislation by national authorities, to avoid legislation being poorly transposed or failure to apply EU legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the rapporteur, I believe that it is important for the Commission to proactively monitor the development of planned and published projects which, on the basis of well-founded evidence, can be assumed to be in breach of EU law and, in such cases, take timely preventive measures.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions, a Commission where European citizens exercise their right of petition before the European Parliament, thereby expressing their concerns about the different policies and legislative measures of the Union. It is vitally important to respond to citizens' requests and concerns, which must be felt and seen by the EU institutions responding to their daily problems.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014 today, but I would like to emphasise one thing above all: I welcome the committee's continued priority on petitions concerning the behaviour of German youth services and to intervene here in the interests of the fathers and mothers concerned.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Petitions are an important medium for citizens to draw attention to social grievances and wrong developments. I am therefore in favour of further support for the Committee on Petitions in its work.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the importance of the Committee as a bridge between the European Parliament and citizens.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Committee on Petitions plays the fundamental role of bringing citizens closer to the European institutions. It is Parliament's front office, it is the PETI Committee that makes Parliament a truly democratic institution. It is important to improve its performance as well as to prioritise the requests submitted by citizens

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the report, in addition to reviewing the citizens' petitions received in 2014 by the Committee on Petitions, stresses the importance of this form of citizen participation and the need to provide more means to better meet the demands of society and to reach more people, as well as the importance of the European Commission's collaboration , the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the EU's operating system, we support any work aimed at increasing control and citizen participation in the political debate. We also welcome how the report highlights and gives voice to the large number of requests on issues of great importance such as: citizen rejection of TTE and its opacity; rejection of fracking and oil exploration; reporting the problems and rights of persons with disabilities; the fight for children's rights; and all the problems of migration, hot returns, refugees, etc. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I vote in favour of a report which seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the S&D Group, I voted in favour of this report. The report is an overview of the Petitions Committee’s 2014 activities. The report focuses on the petitions received by the Committee and the actions taken and it stresses the importance of the Committee as a bridge between the European Parliament and citizens.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We supported the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014 because important amendments were adopted and included in the final text voted on. In particular, our positions on the need to highlight important political issues related to the Commission's activities, such as THE IP and migration policies, have been adopted, on the need for more transparency and more improvements in order to facilitate greater involvement of citizens with petitions. In addition, we should note the need for better management at all stages of the petitions process, for the establishment of petition committees in the parliaments of the Member States and for strengthening the Commission Secretariat with additional human resources.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it recognised that the right to petition is an important tool for which citizens of the EU may exercise a greater political involvement. It also recognised that there are a number of shortcomings, many of them procedural, which may limit involvement. It was noted that the persistent backlog in the treatment of petitions, stemming from a lack in human resources available within the Committee’s Secretariat, had the potential to undermine and harm the credibility of the European Institutions in the eyes of concerned citizens. The report also notes the highly important role of the Commission with regard to the proactive monitoring of petitions which claim breaches in EU legislation. The report calls on the Commission to conduct thorough inquiries of admissible cases and to provide accurate and updated answers to petitions in writing. The Commission should also strive to uphold its transparency and cooperation in dealing with other EU institutions in order to achieve this. It recommends the standardising of laws to create well-functioning petition committees in national parliaments, which would increase the effectiveness of cooperation between the Committee on Petitions and the national parliaments.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this report in response to problems relating to major issues such as calls for the implementation of the revised petitions administrative procedure in the EP and ending the practices of politicising the PETI Committee in time of national elections. The number of petitions received is modest when compared to the EU’s total population, which indicates that the vast majority of EU citizens are not yet aware of the right to petition or of its possible usefulness as a means of drawing the attention of the EU institutions and the Member States to matters which affect them and about which they are concerned. Even though some EU citizens are aware of the petition process, there is still widespread confusion about the EU’s field of activity, as is shown by the high number of inadmissible petitions received (39.4 %). The proper treatment of petitions throughout the whole process is crucial to ensuring recognition that the right to petition is respected. Petitioners tend to be citizens engaged in the improvement, and the future wellbeing, of our societies. The experience of these citizens with regard to how their petitions are treated could determine their future opinion on the European project.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome the work undertaken by the Committee on Petitions and the right of citizens to monitor, defend and promote their rights regarding the legislative mechanism. The Commission should be strongly engaged in the process of petitions. The Commission should conduct investigations concerning the cases submitted to it and provide swift and accurate replies to the petitioners.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014, as it is this Committee that is the point of contact for citizens, which promotes European citizenship and at the same time strengthens the visibility and credibility of the European institutions, and is in contact with thousands of petitioners and their legitimate complaints every year. Better cooperation with institutions at European, national and regional level is certainly needed, as well as with other authorities of critical importance for the area concerned if they are to quickly address the issues of petitions. While there is plenty of room to improve the work of the Committee, I certainly believe that it is also significant for EU residents, so I voted for this Report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report gives the Committee on Petitions a good undeserved point for its 2014 activities. However, the commission's activity decreased by 6% compared to the previous year. In addition, it selects only petitions that are pleasing to it. In short, only petitions that pamper migrants and do not heckle the pharma-industrial lobbies are treated too much. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee.  UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons my colleagues and I have abstained.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Lidia Joanna Geringer's annual report from Oedenberg on the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2014. In 2014, the European Parliament received 2,714 petitions, many of which were inadmissible because they were not under the Union's jurisdiction. In the face of this high figure, the increase in the secretariat's resources becomes urgent to make treatment less slow, as well as simplifying and clarifying the process of submitting European petitions. The European Parliament also wants to strengthen cooperation with national authorities. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the use of petitions by European citizens in 2014. This important instrument for direct democracy in Europe remains underutilized and often misunderstood. It is therefore necessary, as this report prescribes, to better inform European citizens of their rights.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is a very good text, calling for greater involvement of citizens and calling on the Commission to take account of the concerns expressed by the people on controversial issues. If we want to get rid of the impression that Europe is merely an elite project, the work of the Committee on Petitions must be strengthened, which is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is simply an overview of the Petitions Committee’s 2014 activities stressing the importance of the Committee as a bridge between the European Parliament and citizens.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. – The activities of the Committee on Petitions 2014 shows the myriad concerns presented to the Committee by citizens. One concern was consistently voiced by citizens: the TTIP negotiations and the nature of any final agreement. The European Labour Party will judge the final text according to our demands to reject the ISDS, to include a full carve—out of public services and to guarantee the protection of workers’ rights. On the ISDS, we believe that the European Commission should hear the case made by the supporters of the European Citizens’ Initiative that was dismissed. Furthermore, we have called for increased transparency standards, similar to those found at the WTO trade agreement negotiations, with regard to the negotiating texts and the offers made by each party. The European Ombudsman has made an important proposal in this respect, which must be fully implemented by the European Commission.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the activities of the Committee on Petitions during 2014. I support its activities and annual work. The Committee allows also an involvement of citizens in decisions on important political issues (such as the TTIP and the ISDS). I voted in favour of this report in order to support the Committee’s activities.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it gives a satisfaction to the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014. However, this commission has activity down 6% compared to 2013. In addition, it systematically processes petitions it receives politically correctly, particularly on immigration, where it wants to give migrants more and more rights.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The purpose of this motion for a resolution was to approve - and welcome - the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. I voted against this text, which congratulates a committee with unsatisfactory results: a 6% decrease in activity compared to 2013 and a doctrinal treatment of substantive subjects. Thus, fundamental rights, discrimination or immigration are legion in the scope of the petitions studied, and always bear the seal of political correctness and the prism of immigrationist thought that characterizes the overall work of the commissions in the European Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a good reflection of the activities that the Committee on Petitions carried out during 2014, since many of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group have been adopted, significant issues have been contained that were the subject of numerous requests: the rejection of TTE and the opacity of the negotiations, citizen opposition to fracking or the complaints that moved dozens of Europeans and Europeans to EU migration, trade and foreign policies. I also consider it positive that the report contains a number of express requests to improve the treatment of requests, such as: increased resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, increased involvement of the European Commission in analysing requests or improvements to the web portal so that petitioners and petitioners can have up-to-date information on the processing of their requests. Finally, I consider the report's call for a review of the Regulation governing European citizens' initiatives to be truly an instrument that allows for greater participation of citizens in the European decision-making process.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it calls for an increase in administrative expenditure and meddies in national affairs, condemning the fact that not all states (Poland, Britain) have adopted the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It must be the law of the nation-state not to join any treaty.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Under the 2009 Lisbon Agreement, it ensures the right of all citizens and residents of the European Union to be involved in the protection and promotion of their rights. Compared to the total population of the European Union, the number of petitions is still modest and even decreasing, as evidenced by the fact that in 2014 almost 6% fewer petitions were received compared to 2013. A big problem is the processing of petitions. Such delays are not acceptable as it is aimed at ensuring superior service, such an approach also calls into question the credibility of the European institutions. I did not support the Proposal on the Activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014 by Lidie Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg due to the full range of ambiguities that arise in the functioning of the Committee, which is indicated by a very high percentage (39.4 %) unauthorised petitions received. There is too much gap in the legal interpretation of the eligibility of petitions, which leads to their over-rejection, therefore a number of amendments need to be made and the legal definitions of the Rules of Procedure clearly cannot be edied.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the vast majority of citizens are unaware of the existence of their right to petition the European Parliament. The petition is proving to be a very effective way of drawing the European institutions' attention to personal cases related to problems in the application of European norms. On the other hand, the percentage (39.4%) inadmissible petitions shows that there is ambiguity as to the limits of the Union's competence. Therefore, the right to petition must be clearly explained and widely promoted. I welcome the active civic position and to give voice to specific problems in the application of EU law. For the European Parliament, petitions are also a source of valuable feedback on gaps in the legislation that we as MEPs prepare and vote on.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – Petition law belongs to fundamental political rights and represents one form of direct democracy. It emphasises citizens' sovereignty and is also a good communication tool between EU citizens, institutions and bodies. In its proper functioning, it can help to solve many citizens' problems and can also be an incentive for a legislative initiative. However, in some countries, there is a need to raise awareness and awareness of this right of citizens and about the possibilities and ways of using it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014 for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 21 January 2016 and also because it is a full and documented report.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. It "validates" the work of the PETI committee for 2014, a commission whose activity was modest: only 2,714 petitions in 2014, a decrease of 6% compared to 2013. Moreover, the handling of these petitions remains very politically correct, even on sensitive subjects that could benefit from more picky responses.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon confirmed the right to petition the European Parliament as one of the cornerstones of European Union citizenship and as a fundamental right under Article 227 of the Treaty, which provides that citizens or residents of the European Union, whether natural or legal persons, individually or in association with other citizens or persons , have the right to address a petition to the European Parliament on a matter which comes within the European Union’s fields of activity and which affects them directly. This tool allows citizens to bring before Parliament their concerns about the impact of various EU policies and legislation on their everyday lives.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 As the only democratically elected European institution, Parliament must make an extra effort to follow up its citizens' petitions. As stated in the report, however, the Union must do more to better inform European citizens about the procedures for submitting petitions and their role. I hope that in the year 2016 we can continue to hear and discuss the petitions of the citizens we represent.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The Committee on Petitions plays an important role in allowing EU citizens to intervene directly and make it easier for us to deal with all those issues of concern to them and to implement participatory democracy in the EU through the right of petition. I support the report on the activities of this Commission in 2014, in which nearly 3,000 requests were received, which shows that its work is of great importance. That is why, from this Parliament, we also call on the European Commission to be fully involved in the petition process in order to make us more successful in responding to the demands of the public.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report calls for greater citizen involvement. It also calls on the Commission to take seriously and take into account the concerns often expressed, particularly with regard to TTIP. I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because petitions submitted by European citizens are an important tool for enabling them to participate in the EU decision-making process. The report sets out the lines of action of the Committee on Petitions and the areas for improvement that will allow people to fully exercise their right to petitions. Annual statistics show that the majority of citizens turn to Parliament to help with issues relating to justice, the environment, the internal market or fundamental rights. Some petitioners are calling on the European Parliament to come forward with proposals for the development of European Union policies, while others are appealing against decisions taken by national authorities, as well as to appeal against decisions of national courts. I am convinced that the proposals set out in the EP report on the work of the Committee on Petitions will help to ensure a more effective and urgent examination of petitions.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European petitions system serves as a democratic showcase for a European Union that continues to trample on the democratic rights of peoples and the sovereignty of their states. In 2014, the Committee on Petitions registered a total of 2,714 petitions, of which only 790 were found to be admissible. As such, the report challenges the Commission's refusal to accept the European Citizens' Initiative against the transatlantic agreement, even though it has received more than 3 million signatures.  But under the guise of giving more powers to citizens through petitions, in reality it is a matter of strengthening the control of the European Commission, a democratically illegitimate body, over the Member States and speeding up the implementation of the 'internal market law'. In view of the economic, social and political context, real democratic improvements are not to be sought in improving on the margins of a right to petition that has so far not proven its effectiveness against austerity. I am voting against not encouraging this absurd gas plant which does not lead to any concrete consideration of the demands of the peoples, other than those accepted by the Union under its treaties.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report gives the Committee on Petitions a good undeserved point for its 2014 activities. However, the commission's activity decreased by 6% compared to the previous year. In addition, it selects only petitions that are pleasing to it. In short, only petitions that pamper migrants and do not heckle the pharma-industrial lobbies are treated too much. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon confirmed the right to petition the European Parliament as one of the pillars of European citizenship and as a fundamental right provided for in Article 227 of the Treaty. It is important to know and get to know citizens' concerns about different EU policies and legislation.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ As Vice-Chair of this Committee, I am proud of the work we have carried out in 2014. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines that the right to petition the European Parliament is a vital tool for our citizens to voice their concerns and is one of the most direct channels between Parliament and the citizens.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The effective exercise of the right to petition is the indispensable corollary of European citizenship. The insertion of this right to Article 44 of the Union Charter is symbolic of its importance, as well as its status as a fundamental right. It is therefore to be welcomed that more than 2,714 petitions were received in 2014. Aware of the need to promote this citizens' initiative in order to participate in the strengthening of the European democratic ideal, the Union must do everything possible to ensure the effectiveness of the exercise of this right and its outcome on concrete and material political achievements. To do so, collaboration between all relevant institutional actors must be increased. Thus, the Committees of the European Parliament, in the respective areas of their competence, must be involved in the "petitioning" process. The same is true for the European Ombudsman, as well as for the Member States, whose committed participation is necessary for the democratic transparency of the Union and for the appropriate monitoring of the requests of all our citizens.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – I consider the work of the Committee on Petitions to be very beneficial. We also see the importance of his work in the present report, which gives us a deeper glimpse into the problems of ordinary citizens of the European Union. By submitting a petition, citizens show their opposition to the circumstances or activities of the authorities in a particular area and draw attention to violations of their rights. Most of the petitions submitted concern the areas of justice, the environment, the internal market and fundamental rights. We can therefore see these petitions as a mirror reflecting what really bothers people. At the same time, this report must also be approached responsibly and the fact that it follows must have been considered, namely that many of the petitions had to be declared inadmissible because they invoked assistance from the European Parliament, even though this one could not help them in the area. This shows a lack of awareness among citizens. For this reason, I fully agree with the rapporteur that a one-stop shop should be available to citizens at European Union level to guide them in finding a solution to alleged violations of their rights.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Petitions is an outstanding tool available to citizens in terms of participation in the European democratic process, which facilitates debate, informs European citizens of their rights and helps them to enforce those rights. The 2014 report provides an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions, provides statistical data on the work received by the Committee on Petitions – since then closed (70.9%) (28.1%), the number of petitions, the countries concerned and the topics covered by the petitions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution gives a satisfaction to the work of the Committee on Petitions for 2014. However, its activity was modest, as it received only 2,714 petition requests, a decrease of 6% compared to 2013. In addition, the commission treats these petitions in a politically correct manner, especially on immigration matters. So we're voting against it.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution gives satisfaction to the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014. However, the activity of this commission is modest. It received 2,714 petitions in 2014, a decrease of 6% from 2013. Moreover, their treatment remains politically correct. The main topics of the petitions concern environmental law, fundamental rights, discrimination and immigration. The fact is that the PETI committee treats its subjects in the way other parliamentary committees do, particularly on immigration (giving migrants ever more rights).

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which focuses on the petitions received by the Committee and the actions taken. It also stresses the importance of the Committee as a bridge between the European Parliament and citizens.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions in 2014. The purpose of this text is to present an analysis of the petitions received and to study the improvements that could be made to the procedure. In particular, I have approved the provisions calling for a better understanding of the Union's areas of activity among European citizens, in order to reduce the number of inadmissible petitions. In fact, 40% of the 2,714 petitions submitted to Parliament in 2014 were declared inadmissible. This situation needs to be addressed, which leads to unnecessary congestion in the PETI committee secretariat and, therefore, additional expenditure.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we wanted to provide an overview of the work of the Committee on Petitions, which plays the fundamental role of addressing all the issues, relating to the different policies and regulations of the Union, which are of concern to European citizens. Indeed, thanks to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the right to petition the European Parliament remains a key element of European citizenship and a fundamental right. The new web portal, operational since November 2014, has certainly improved the previous system for the online transmission of petitions. What we are now asking for is for a one-stop shop to be made available to citizens, capable of directing them in the search for solutions to the alleged violations of their rights. This is an extremely important objective. The Commission's initiative to combine formal and informal reporting mechanisms in the 'Your Rights in the EU' section of the www.europa.eu website may represent a significant step in this direction. However, the distinction between formal mechanisms (complaints to the Commission, petitions to the European Parliament, complaints to the European Ombudsman) and informal mechanisms (SOLVIT, ECC-Net, FIN-Net, etc.) needs to be clarified and further explained. Citizens need to know where they can find the kind of information they are looking for.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Unable to be present at the votes held on Thursday 21 January, I would like to express my support for the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014, which reaffirms the right and the need for EU citizens to speak directly about the work of the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the adoption of the 2014 report, as I believe that the work in the Committee on Petitions is insufficient. From the outset, it has been noticeable to me that the Socialist rapporteur is trying to minimise dialogue and cooperation with the members of the EdP committee and is instead looking for opportunities for cooperation with the Greens, the GUE and the EFDD. This was also visible at the only shadow cabinet meeting that took place two days before the committee vote. Furthermore, I do not support this report because the politics that have been going on in the Committee on Petitions lately are not focused on achieving the stated objectives, but rather on meeting the national election campaign objectives of each member.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The 2014 annual report will provide an overview on the activities and work done by the Petitions Committee. I have voted in favour of this report, which will provide statistics on the number of petitions dealt with by the Committee, the matters raised and the countries concerned.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is critical of the issue of TTIP. The report contains very good approaches and calls for greater involvement of citizens in the negotiations. The Commission is encouraged to take into account the often expressed concerns about TTIP.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report analyses the petitions submitted in 2014 and discusses what could be done better. It is important to encourage dialogue between the different levels of power and civil society and representative and participatory democracy. The Committee on Petitions is an important tool made available to citizens to participate better in the Democratic Process in Europe. It encourages debate and informs and supports EU citizens on their rights. The Committee on Petitions wishes to provide citizens with direct contact with the institutions and to ensure that the specific problems of citizens are heard.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As an MEP but also as a European citizen, I think it is useful that every individual, being represented by the EU institution, which they directly elected, can, through a petition, draw attention to the representatives he has elected. May this petition also strengthen communication between the European Parliament and the citizens of the Union. No less important, it must be the evaluation of the petition that will be dealt with in a careful, efficient and timely manner. A reply will then be delivered as soon as possible about the measures taken or, if so, the petitioner will be informed as to why the petition was declared inadmissible. The citizen's dialogue with the European Union must be encouraged, which is why I would say that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Petitions provide a way for European citizens to be more effectively involved in the democratic process at EU level. I support the report, which calls on the Commission to respond to requests for investigation in three months and to keep the Petitions Committee informed of developments in infringement proceedings directly linked to petitions.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I believe it is necessary to strengthen cooperation with national parliaments and their respective committees, as well as member state governments, and to encourage member state authorities to fully transparently transfer and implement EU legislation. In order to make it clear to citizens at what level and to which instances they can address their petitions, a common approach by the European Parliament, national parliaments and lower-level authorities in Member States with the relevant appellate bodies is very important.  I believe in the importance of working with the Commission and the Member States to protect citizens' rights more effectively and transparently and to encourage the presence of Member States' representatives in meetings. I also consider it important that representatives of the Council and the Commission attend committee meetings and hearings where the content of the issues under discussion requires the involvement of those institutions.  I support this report because I think it is essential that the Committee on Petitions strengthens its cooperation with other Committees of Parliament by asking them for opinions on petitions, inviting their members to discussions relating to their areas of competence, and as a committee giving opinions on the implementation of certain reports and in particular reports on the correct transposition and application of Union law in the Member States, to participate more in their work.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ All citizens or residents, whether eu natural or legal persons, have the right to petition the European Parliament, annual statistics show that the most petitions are related to the judiciary, fundamental rights, environment and internal market. Parliament received 2,714 petitions in 2014, down 6% from 2,891 in 2013. Of these, 29.1% were assessed as admissible and accompanied by further steps. The number of petitions received is modest compared to the total EU population, showing that the majority of EU citizens are still unaware of the right to petition.  I therefore join calls for a common approach by Parliament, national parliaments and lower-level authorities in Member States with the relevant appellate bodies with a view to transparent clarification to citizens at what level and to which instances they can address their petitions. The right to petition is a key element of participatory democracy, with a view to addressing irregularities in the implementation of EU law, which is why I support the work of this committee and the Report on its activities.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Article 227. The Lisbon Treaty affirms the right to petitions that allow European citizens and anyone residing in the European Union to contact the institutions in an easy manner in order to express their claims or objections. This right serves as one of the most important instruments that brings European citizens closer to the institutions and the entire system of the European Union. EU citizens use it to petition in the areas concerned such as fundamental rights, the environment, the internal market, health, consumer rights, animal welfare and many others.  Some examples of petitions that have been registered are: (1) Scandal "Equitable Life", United Kingdom, (2,) Railway Tunnel Lyon - Turin, (3rd) Non-compliance of valencia urbanisation law, in Spain, with EU law , (4) M30 motorway project in Madrid and (5th) Petition 'European City Guide': resolution on misleading 'directory service companies'.  The importance of this report is that it calls on the Commission to respond to requests for an investigation within three months and informs the Committee on Petitions on the development of breaches of the procedure directly related to petitions. Likewise, the report calls on the authorities of a Member State to participate more actively in the meetings of the Committee on Petitions.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Any citizen or resident of the Union, as well as any natural or legal person having its registered office in a Member State, shall have the right to petition the European Parliament on a matter which falls within the scope of the Union's activities and which directly concerns it. It is an instrument that allows citizens to bring their concerns about the impact of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives to Parliament.  The 2014 annual report aims to give a precise and complete picture of the work carried out by the Committee on Petitions. In 2014, the European Parliament received 2 714 petitions, indicating a decrease of 6% compared to the 2 891 received in 2013. 2014, the European Year of Citizenship, highlighted the European elections that took place from 22 to 25 May.  I hope that the committee will be able to continue to offer European citizens direct contact with the institutions, ensuring that they listen to their specific problems.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report contains a number of good provisions against forced adoption of children (m.in. Jugendamt). Polish citizens abroad also face this problem. Unfortunately, the report also makes reference to the fact that all states should be members of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, of which Poland is not a member and does not intend to be. This did not allow me to vote in favour of the report, which is why I abstained.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the wording of the part of the resolution which arbitroves that the citizens of the Member States reject the TTIP free trade agreement under way between the EU and the USA. In my opinion, its principle is right, because it can bring new jobs and economic growth. Of course, the EU cannot discount some of its values, which, according to the information so far, it is not even trying to do. Among my constituents in the Czech Republic, I do not see a negative opinion on TTIP, or a number of Czech citizens support the principle of the treaty.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The right to petition the European Parliament, already provided for in Article 227 of the Maastricht Treaty, has been confirmed as a pillar of European citizenship and as a fundamental right to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. It is an instrument that allows a simple means available to citizens who wish to address the Institutions of the Union and who, on any matter concerning the areas of their activity, wish to submit a complaint or request. The 2014 annual report aims to present a summary of the work of the Committee on Petitions and pictures its work by compiling statistical data on the number of petitions received, closed or processed by the committee, or on the countries or issues concerned. In the light of the provisions, I supported with my vote the rapporteur's conclusions, considering that they are an indispensable descriptive and quantitative tool in the evaluation of parliamentary work.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the report on the work of the Petitions Committee. UKIP cannot endorse the work of the Committee because of the more overtly partisan political stance it has taken when it should be dealing with petitions on an impartial basis and judging the merits of each petition rather than judging them from an unashamedly political perspective. Citizens of Member States can have little faith that their petition will be dealt with objectively if it in any way runs counter to the norm, especially if it runs counter in any way to the political enthusiasms of the Committee. In addition, the Committee clearly wishes to expand, without adequate or proper justification its role and staffing levels, both of which will be injurious to the taxpayer.  Whilst we are conscious of the Committee doing some good work on instances of maladministration (which should be its focus), we deprecate the attitude of the Committee towards anyone who raises their voice about migration (which concerns many tens of millions of ordinary citizens of Member States), whilst showing support for politically-correct petitioners such as those who complain about fracking.  For those reasons we have abstained.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Any citizen of the European Union or resident in a Member State may, individually or in association with other persons, petition the European Parliament on matters which fall within the scope of the activities of the European Union and which directly affect it. This was a huge opportunity as a result of the Treaty of Lisbon. The annual report on the Committee on Petitions aims to provide a precise and complete picture of the work by presenting statistics on the number of petitions received, closed or dealt with by the committee, or on the countries or issues concerned, which are an important quantitative tool in the evaluation of the Commission's work.  According to statistics, in 2014 the European Parliament received 2714 petitions, a decrease of 6% compared to the statements made in 2013. For 2013, there were several changes to the list of countries of origin of petitions in 2014, with Spain still in first place. Justice was the main matter referred to in petitions made in the two years. For the commitment and quality of the work presented, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The number of petitions received in 2014 amounted to 2714, representing a decrease of around 6% compared to 2013, when Parliament received 2885 petitions. 790 petitions were considered admissible and followed up, 1070 were considered inadmissible, 817 were declared admissible and closed and 37 had their recommendation challenged. The aim of this annual report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions is to present an analysis of petitions received in 2014 and to discuss possible improvements in procedures and relations with other institutions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. In 2014, 69.5% of the petitions received (1,887 petitions) were closed at the start of the proceedings, either because they were declared inadmissible (this was the case of 39.4%), or because, although admissible, they were closed immediately after the disclosure to the petitioners of information, or after being forwarded for information to another parliamentary committee responsible for the matter (30.1%).  As for the followings given to petitions, it can be seen that the follow-up for information has increased (up 13.6%) and that further advice to other parliamentary committees decreased (-3.6%), as did requests for advice from the European Commission (-8.8%).  Finally, justice remains the main area of concern for petitioners in 2014, followed by the environment, the functioning of the internal market, fundamental rights and health. It should be noted that the number of petitions concerning property restitutions has decreased sharply compared to previous years.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the right to petition the European Parliament has emerged as one of the pillars of European citizenship and as a fundamental right that allows Union citizens to submit petitions to the European Parliament individually or together with other citizens. This right, which now allows any issue that is part of the Union's fields of activity and concerns it directly to be reported to this Institution, is a key tool that allows citizens to express their concerns about the effects of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives, as well as to act as a proactive mechanism for the initiative of European citizenship. This report calls on the European Commission to respond to requests for investigation in three months, together with the PETI Commission. Furthermore, it calls on the authorities of the Member States to participate more actively in their meetings, raising not only public debate and scrutiny, but also highlighting the importance of the European Citizens' Initiative as a new tool of participatory democracy at EU level, with a view to public exposure to possible anoinous, irregular or illegal situations. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the activities of the Committee on Petitions for 2014.  During 2014, the European Parliament received 2,714 petitions, a decrease of 6% from the 2891 petitions submitted in 2013. 39.4% of the petitions received were inadmissible.  The majority of petitions received concern fundamental rights, justice, the environment, animal welfare and disability.  Through this report, the European Parliament calls for increased cooperation with national authorities, for the European Commission to fully engage in the petition process, and for the human resources available to the secretariat to be increased. Finally, Parliament deplores the fact that the Charter of Fundamental Rights has not been adopted in all Member States and underlines the important work undertaken by the Committee on Petitions in the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the report, in addition to reviewing the citizens' petitions received in 2014 by the Committee on Petitions, stresses the importance of this form of citizen participation and the need to provide more means to better meet the demands of society and to reach more people, as well as the importance of the European Commission's collaboration , the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the EU's operating system, we support any work aimed at increasing control and citizen participation in the political debate. We also welcome how the report highlights and gives voice to the large number of requests on issues of great importance such as: citizen rejection of TTE and its opacity; rejection of fracking and oil exploration; reporting the problems and rights of persons with disabilities; the fight for children's rights; and all the problems of migration, hot returns, refugees, etc. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I vote in favour of a report which seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. Since the Lisbon Treaty, Europe has moved closer to its citizens. Today, the right of petition is a cornerstone of European citizenship and confirmed as a fundamental right. All EU citizens can raise their concerns about EU legislation to the EP through the right of petition. And, as the latest report by the Committee on Petitions shows, this right would be used almost 3,000 times in the previous year. In my view, three things are problematic: firstly, at 40%, we still have too many petitions which do not fall within the competence of our committee. This shows the still great lack of understanding among the population of how the EU works and what institutions it has. On the other hand, we are dealing with a massive politicisation of the Committee on Petitions. For example, petitions are often only allowed out of tactical calculation, for example in an election. We therefore need clear legal criteria in the Rules of Procedure of the Committee on the Treatment of Petitions. Thirdly, we must limit the sometimes very long length of proceedings. It is not acceptable for some petitioners to have to wait four years for a decision. Overall, however, I was able to vote in favour of the report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a good reflection of the activities that the Committee on Petitions carried out during 2014, since many of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group have been adopted, significant issues have been contained that were the subject of numerous requests: the rejection of TTE and the opacity of the negotiations, citizen opposition to fracking or the complaints that moved dozens of Europeans and Europeans to EU migration, trade and foreign policies. I also consider it positive that the report contains a number of express requests to improve the treatment of requests, such as: increased resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, increased involvement of the European Commission in analysing requests or improvements to the web portal so that petitioners and petitioners can have up-to-date information on the processing of their requests. Finally, I consider the report's call for a review of the Regulation governing European citizens' initiatives to be truly an instrument that allows for greater participation of citizens in the European decision-making process.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report of the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014 as it focused on the petitions received by the Committee and the actions taken, and I am satisfied that the Committee is functioning well and providing a much needed service to the European Parliament, providing a bridge between the European Parliament and the citizens of the European Union.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the Petitions Committee report contained very inspiring comments and proposals for solutions that, on the one hand, would ensure citizens' access to law and justice within reasonable time limits and, on the other hand, the effectiveness of this committee. At the same time, however, the resolution adopted calls for a broader interpretation of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which would have the effect of extending the EU's competences to the detriment of the Member States. Such an approach is totally unjustified, which is why I voted against it.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the right to petition in the European Parliament to be one of the fundamental pillars of European citizenship and the fundamental right of every citizen or person residing or having its registered office in the Union to submit a petition to the European Parliament on a matter falling within one of the areas of competence of the Union or directly affecting it. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur for the report that has been presented, which, on the basis of a detailed analysis, not only evaluates the work of the Committee on Petitions for 2014, but also comes up with many own-initiative proposals and measures that offer opportunities to address existing problems in this area. Although there was a slight decrease in petitions in 2014 compared to 2013, it is pleased that the majority of petitions (80 %) it is closed in the year following their processing and recognition of admissibility, and only a tiny number of petitions remain pending for more than four years. In view of the total number of petitions received and the number of inadmissible petitions received (39%), I consider it extremely important to inform European citizens more intensively about the existence of the right to petition and its possibilities, how they can draw the attention of the European institutions and the Member States to the problems that concern them.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2012, 2,714 petitions were received, almost 6% less than in 2013. Of these, 790 petitions were found to be admissible and further considered. The number of petitions received is quite modest compared to the eu population as a whole. This information clearly shows that the vast majority of EU citizens are not sufficiently aware of the right to petition or its potential usefulness as a means by which the European institutions and The Member States can draw attention to matters affecting or concerned about them.  The report underlines that the Work Committee enables EU citizens and residents to cooperate somewhat in protecting and promoting their rights and monitoring the correct application of Union rules. Citizens express their concerns in petitions and their legitimate complaints are resolved within a reasonable time.  I think it is worth pointing out that the report calls, inter alia, on the Commission to participate fully in the petitions process, in particular by carrying out thorough investigations into the admissible matters which have been referred to it. At the end of the procedure, the Commission should provide accurate and up-to-date written replies to the applicant.  As I believe that the proper treatment of petitions throughout the procedure is decisive in order to ensure respect for the right to petition, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The petition allows citizens to express their concerns about the actions of various policies, but also their concerns that are present in everyday life problems. Petitions also serve to foster dialogue at all levels of society, especially at political level. In 2014, 6% fewer petitions were sent to the European Parliament compared to 2013. Although some petitions and their resolution remain open for several years, it should be easy about improving the terms of petitions, which means their process of implementation, but also resolution. The petition is a collective request of citizens and for this reason it is much more effective to create better conditions, and therefore I supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which provided an overview of the Petitions Committee’s 2014 activities. Labour MEPs believe that the Committee is an essential tool at the hands of EU citizens, as it acts as a bridge between them and Parliament.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted against the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014. The report points to the successful work of the Committee on Petitions, but there are still many reserves. I miss that the rapporteur did not seek dialogue with the shadow rapporteur of the European People's Party.  I also believe that a quicker distinction must be made between admissible and intolerable petitions and petitions for which we do not have the authority. This will give us time to engage intensively with the petitions for which we are responsible. I also miss greater transparency and less politicisation of the petitions under consideration. There are also reserves in improving cooperation between the Committee on Petitions and the Committees on Petitions of national parliaments.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report because it not only contains a list of the committee's activities but also contains important proposals for greater involvement of citizens in decision-making and for greater transparency in procedures.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The work programme of the Committee on Petitions is not linked to the Commission's legislative programme but is determined by citizens, who, by exercising the right to petition the European Parliament, communicate their concerns about various EU policies and legislation. It is therefore a tool that enables citizens to put before Parliament their concerns about the impact of different EU policies and legislation on their daily lives. The criticality of this tool is evident from the diversity of issues raised in citizens' petitions, such as fundamental rights, human rights, the rights of persons with disabilities, the internal market, environmental legislation, industrial relations, immigration policies, trade agreements, public health issues, child protection, transport and animal rights.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The possibility of petitioning the European Parliament is one of the fundamental rights of every citizen of the European Union, and importantly also for companies, organisations and associations established in the European Union. The work of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions is extremely important as it enables civil society to draw Parliament's attention to any violation of their rights by a Member State, local authorities or the institutions of the European Union. The number of petitions submitted also indicates that eu law is still not being duly implemented or respected in many places, which is important information for the European Commission, which upholds the EU Treaties.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the annual activities of the PETI Committee in 2014 gives a complete view of the work carried out by the committee in 2014. The report ends with a series of recommendations for activities. We have therefore voted in favour of the report, which includes many important points for the Movement. For example, the importance of the right of petition, to be understood as an exercise of a fundamental power of scrutiny and democratic control on the part of the citizens, is underlined. Some of the European Commission's inaccurate responses to the most important european citizens' initiatives, such as Stop Vivisection and Right 2 Water, are also criticised.  Reference is also made to the numerous petitions concerning TTIP and the ISDS clause, fracking and the non-ratification by some Member States of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We voted in favour because in the report it hopes to cooperate more and more quickly and transparently with national governments and parliaments, with regional and local authorities and also with the European Commission, which has too long a response time to certain urgent issues that require more rapid reaction time.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The right of European citizens to petition on various issues of interest is one of the guarantees provided by the European institutions in order to ensure the widest possible participation in the decision-making process and to reduce the democratic deficit. How this right is harnessed in practice and the extent to which it translates into concrete decisions at European level indicate the degree to which citizens exercise their legitimate rights.  The year 2014 marked certain trends in the European petition ing, which are part of the trends of recent years.
