Thus, the number of petitions addressed to the European institutions decreased, but the number of rejected and settled petitions increased. The most common countries of origin include Spain, Germany, Italy and Romania, a confirmation of the trend from previous years. Among the topics that petitioners have addressed include justice, the environment, the internal market and fundamental rights, where there appear slower problems appear to exist at Member State level. Petitions by e-mail are also beginning to become predominant over paper petitions. What is worrying is the increase in the share of outstanding petitions, which indicates some rigidity of the European institutions. The problems identified by the report must be addressed by increasing interinstitutional cooperation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted positively on Mr Geringer's proposal. The Committee on Petitions, as a point of contact for citizens, the European Ombudsman and the European Citizens' Initiative form a set of fundamental instruments to achieve greater political participation of citizens, to which these instruments must be ensured to be easy, appropriate and transparent.  These instruments have a responsibility to promote European citizenship and to strengthen the visibility and credibility of the Union's institutions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Petitions Committee is essential to ensure the link between EU citizens and the EU institutions. According to the Treaties, all European citizens have the right to write to the European Parliament on the various types of problems they encounter in their everyday lives, as long as the issues fall within the field of activity of the European Union. In this respect, the work of this Committee is extremely important, and the work achieved there is of high quality. Having said that, I decided to oppose this report of the plenary as some of the wording, especially on TTIP, did not reflect my views on the topic. I believe that TTIP is an important opportunity for Europe to have more clout on the world stage.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I strongly supported the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions. It should be made clear that the Committee on Petitions aims to enable citizens of the European Union to defend and promote their rights and to monitor the correct application of Community rules. The petitions submitted can understand what citizens are most concerned about and find solutions to the problems raised over time. Better cooperation between the Institutions of the European Union, national and regional authorities is of great importance for the rapid resolution of problems. That is what the European Parliament is seeking for better cooperation in this report. Today's decisions will bring more benefits to those who make petitions or complaints and to seek help from the Committee on Petitions. Europeans deserve much better protection of their rights. This is also the case in the report.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against this report, although I believe that the Committee on Citizens' Petitions represents a very important link in the chain linking the institutions of the European Union with citizens. The democratic process does not end with the election winners being declared, but it is important that the voice of the citizens is heard at all times and that their problems and concerns are addressed in a timely fashion. This importance of the work of the Committee on Petitions comes to the fore. However, this report attempts to promote certain ideologies using petitions from citizens and therefore I have not supported it.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I confirmed the report of the Activities of the Committee on Petitions in 2014, as I believe that the report summarises well what is happening in 2014 in this area. The data presented can be a very good tool to infer and evaluate the work of individual national authorities and European institutions and to figure out the topics that need to be ed over in the future in a particular country or at Union level. The Committee allows EU citizens to exercise their basic right to express their opinion and to be involved, which we must certainly continue to support.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The right to petition is one of the few tools our citizens have to bring violations of European law to our attention. It is therefore of particular importance that petitions are handled as fast as possible. A failure to respond in time can result in more injury incurred on the person, especially in cases of violations of fundamental rights and civil liberties. Time is even more of the essence in situations where children are involved: forced adoption, parental child abduction, closed adoption or custodial problems need to be dealt with instantly. Discriminatory treatment by social services towards parents with a migrant or minority background which results in forced adoption is not uncommon in the European Union. At the moment, cases of emergency are handled in a special way; however, this does not guarantee that the petition will be handled without delay. The reality is that the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions does not have the resources it needs to ensure a timely response.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the report, in addition to reviewing the citizens' petitions received in 2014 by the Committee on Petitions, stresses the importance of this form of citizen participation and the need to provide more means to better meet the demands of society and to reach more people, as well as the importance of the European Commission's collaboration , the Member States and the Ombudsman. Given the democratic gaps in the EU's operating system, we support any work aimed at increasing control and citizen participation in the political debate. We also welcome how the report highlights and gives voice to the large number of requests on issues of great importance such as: citizen rejection of TTE and its opacity; rejection of fracking and oil exploration; reporting the problems and rights of persons with disabilities; the fight for children's rights; and all the problems of migration, hot returns, refugees, etc. Therefore, although the inclusion of participation in the European institutions is insufficient, I vote in favour of a report which seeks to give voice and improve this type of participation.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, and particularly the good practices of the Scottish Parliament in its visit to the European Parliament in order to understand better the petition mechanism.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. ‒2,714 petitions were received in 2014, a 6% decrease from 2013. These figures are almost twice as high as the number of petitions received in 2009. The number of public servants handling petitions has not increased in proportion to this. I supported the report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I am extremely satisfied with the report adopted in respect of the Committee. After many years of ideologically fighting, being almost the sole voice against an extremely conservative approach towards petitions, we seemingly managed to win the cultural battle in this term and built a majority within the Committee that broke the big coalition. This is reaffirmed by the aforementioned fact that we won 35 out of 37 amendments, with the two ones we lost not being essential.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a good reflection of the activities that the Committee on Petitions carried out during 2014, since many of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group have been adopted, significant issues have been contained that were the subject of numerous requests: the rejection of TTE and the opacity of the negotiations, citizen opposition to fracking or the complaints that moved dozens of Europeans and Europeans to EU migration, trade and foreign policies. I also consider it positive that the report contains a number of express requests to improve the treatment of requests, such as: increased resources of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions, increased involvement of the European Commission in analysing requests or improvements to the web portal so that petitioners and petitioners can have up-to-date information on the processing of their requests. Finally, I consider the report's call for a review of the Regulation governing European citizens' initiatives to be truly an instrument that allows for greater participation of citizens in the European decision-making process.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. The Committee on Petitions is essential to ensure the link between EU citizens and the EU institutions. According to the Treaties, all European citizens have the right to inform the European Parliament of the different types of problems they face in their daily lives, as long as the problems fall within the competence of the European Union.  The right to address petitions to the European Parliament is one of the most direct channels between our Parliament and the people.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the annual report on the 2014 activities of the parliamentary committee receiving petitions from European citizens. These cover a wide range of areas, including the environment, fundamental rights, employment and TTIP. Together with the European Ombudsman and the European Citizens' Initiative, these are tools for citizens' political participation.  They are very imperfect but have the merit of existing and reflect the demands of a number of citizens. This text highlights a number of difficulties: delays in the processing of petitions, insufficient explanations of decisions of inadmissibility, etc. Proposals for reforms are being put forward, such as the more regular holding of public hearings, and I welcome that. Even if all this is just a short time to fill the democratic deficit in the European Union, I voted in favour of this resolution, including because it contains a paragraph calling for the rejection of any arbitration instrument in the TTIP.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to petition is, together with the European Ombudsman, to deal with cases of maladministration by the EU institutions or national institutions in the context of the application of EU law.  In 2014, 1887 petitions were closed, of which 1070 were declared inadmissible; these figures correspond to an increase of around 10% compared to 2013. The most worrying issues addressed in the petitions concern environmental legislation, fundamental rights, the free movement of persons, discrimination, immigration, negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), animal welfare, the application of justice and the social inclusion of persons with disabilities. The report points to persistent delays in the handling of petitions, which is due to the limitations of human resources available in the Secretariat. We support any deepening of citizens' participation in the democratic life of the EU. We do not allow this to hide its deeply undemocratic character in what is essential and which involves the freedom of each country to be able to choose its own path of development.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report calls for greater citizen involvement. It also calls on the Commission to take seriously and take into account the concerns often expressed, particularly with regard to TTIP. I therefore support this report.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This annual report aims to give a precise and complete view of the work carried out by the Committee on Petitions, providing a series of interesting data and statistics: in 2014, 2,714 petitions were registered, of which only 790 declared admissible and actually processed. The report contains a number of positive aspects. I would like to point out, among other things, the reference to the importance of the right of petition, to be understood as an exercise of a fundamental power of scrutiny and democratic control by citizens; criticism of the European Commission's particularly flawed responses to european citizens' initiatives of more than one million signatures; the reference to the dozens of petitions expressing considerable concern about TTIP, the use of fracking for the extraction of gas and oil from underground, the failure of some Member States to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and international child abduction. The desire for more structured cooperation is expressed both with national governments and parliaments and with regional and local authorities, in order to have faster and more detailed responses and also in order to reduce the perception by European citizens of opacity and lack of transparency.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, 1 887 petitions were closed, of which 1 070 were declared inadmissible. These figures correspond to an increase of around 10 % compared to 2013. The most worrying issues addressed in the petitions concern environmental legislation, fundamental rights, the free movement of persons, discrimination, immigration, negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), animal welfare, the application of justice and the social inclusion of persons with disabilities. We understand that the vast majority of the problems raised by petitioners are fair and deserve full resolution. However, we do not recognise the European Commission or the European Union's legitimacy to monitor Member States, including infringement sanctions. On the one hand, the EU is not and has never been a guarantor of democracy. On the other hand, many of the policies that petitioners complain about are imposed by the EU itself. We will not take responsibility or whiten the role of the EU.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the activities of the Committee on Petitions because I believe that it has comprehensively presented the committee's work review and the statistical analysis of the petitions received in the previous year and the progress of their follow-up.  Petitions provide valuable feedback for legislators and enforcement authorities at EU and national level. On the basis of this information, concrete measures should be considered to further improve this instrument and strengthen its level of representation.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on EU citizens – in particular Italian, Estonian and British citizens – detained in India (2016/2522(RSP)).

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Author. - On the resolution to be considered today, the Group of the Greens tabled proposals a year ago, but then the other groups did not consider it necessary to support. Better late than never. And I hope that our decision will provide support both to the European External Action Service and to the governments of the Member States so that this incident is to be put to an end. The Greens were the only ones who did not start to link the Seaman Guard Ohio case to the Case of the Italian Marines, convinced that ultimately linking different cases would not help anyone, rather creates additional problems. I am pleased that Estonian ambassadors from the EPP and ALDE groups finally understood this fact. And I would like to thank my colleagues from Italy – Lara Comi, Massimo Castaldo and Mr Panzer , who understood and took into account the views of the Greens. I can assure you that, in turn, they can count on my support if the problem of Italian marines comes before Parliament. And I would also like to thank the Head of the Indian Delegation, Geoffrey van Orden, who has been actively looking for a solution to the problem in relation to his profession, and Nirj Dva for his help in obtaining information from India.  For the reasons set out above, the Greens did not join the compromise resolution, but also asked to leave to the vote their own text, which is free from unnecessary praise for the specificity of the Indian judicial system (unfortunately, such phrases are found in the joint resolution). We in This Parliament are not in diplomatic service, where, in some cases, polite phrases and flatterment are appropriate, our resolutions must state the facts, otherwise they will have no desired effect.  As far as the joint resolution is concerned, point two is just funny. India is a country with a population of 1.2 billion, with 1.2 million inhabitants in Estonia. And our 14 ship protectors can't possibly pose a threat to a country this big. In prisoner exchange terms, this would mean that Estonia would have to arrest 14,000 Indian citizens. That is why I would call on my fellow Members to be in favour of the text that will be put to the vote first, an old and considered text that can have a positive impact on resolving the situation. And I would also like to think that the british and Estonian ship protectors are, above all, people whose release and return home is much more important than one or the other text.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank my group, which has today supported a resolution in this House aimed at supporting a major national issue in my country, Italy. Freedom for the two Navy riflemen, one of whom is still detained, imprisoned in India and both still sub judice, pending the results of an arbitration procedure, with results not very close, which however see the solution to their story still a long way off, is thought even beyond 2018. The President-in-Office of the Council of our country says that Italy is a great country, quite right! I also pay tribute to this statement. But a large country defends its soldiers, especially if they are prisoners abroad and I do not think it can be said objectively that more has been done, if not a weak and in some cases cumbersome and bungled defence. In this whole delicate affair, however, there is a power which, if possible, appears even weaker and more disastified, european power. In the case of the two maròs, too, the question arises: 'but where is this Europe?' It should defend us against Isis and it seems that it is unable to defend two soldiers, who are, among other things, engaged in the fight, which involves us all, against the crime of international piracy. And I would say that you should also defend another very important point, that of their military honour, because these accusations violate their military honour. There is a doubt that this is precisely what can be the reason for the lack of commitment, perhaps because the military honour of its citizens is of little interest to the European Union. This aspect must also be considered. On such a long-winded affair that only now, laboriously, has it taken the path that perhaps could have been the main route of international arbitration. The voice of Europe, dear High Commissioner Mogherini, seems feeble, in any case very ineffective, given the results, when it might be, the fate of those who, like our marò, defend a fundamental principle of freedom on the seas, should be very important. Well, I believe that the Commission must reassess all EU-India relations, starting with the suspension of all ongoing negotiations with India, first and foremost the free trade agreement. Long live the Italian Navy, its values and the honor of its Navy riflemen!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I apologise for the fact that the author is not here and has not been able to be here for commitments that cannot be fulfilled.  Once again, the European Parliament is called upon to give its opinion on a violation of human rights. This is the case with the arrest and sentencing of 35 British and Estonian citizens. As my colleague said earlier, this is also the case with the two Italian marò. In this respect, I think it is right, as well as right, that the Member States should today show the same cohesion that they have shown in the past. Coordinated action by the entire international community could have encouraged and facilitated a rapid and satisfactory solution to the situation for some time. In this regard, I call on high representative Federica Mogherini to take action as soon as possible.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: author. – Mr President, the most effective response to piracy has proved to be the use of on-board security teams. These teams tend to live on what we might call mother ships, which are in effect floating armouries from which teams of guards are sent to join ships which require protection. The motor vessel Seaman Guard Ohio was just such a floating armoury and on 11 October 2013 it was apparently in Indian territorial waters when it was intercepted by the Indian Coastguard and escorted to the port of Tuticorin. Subsequently all 35 members of the crew, including 14 Estonians and six Britons, were charged, and they are the subject of this resolution. After some legal arguments and to our great consternation they were eventually brought to trial and given the maximum sentence of five years’ imprisonment. Throughout this period of over two years they have been held in custody in India.  I have to say we respect India’s sovereignty over its territory and waters and the fact that it has a fine legal tradition. We know also that India has suffered from atrocious terrorist attacks, some mounted from the sea. We therefore understand very well Indian sensitivities. However, in this case the personnel concerned were no threat to India and carried out no acts of violence against Indian interests. On the contrary, they were engaged in counter-terrorism. These men, British and Estonian and others, have had to endure a difficult imprisonment and now have an uncertain future. Their families are in distress. We ask the Indian authorities with all respect to allow these men to return home, pending completion of the judicial processes and for a rapid and benign conclusion to this matter.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Nirj DEVA
text: blue-card question. – Mr Van Orden, do you accept that it is quite absurd for the Indian authorities, in sentencing these people, to treat everyone the same? On a ship the captain directs the course of action. He told the crew to get diesel from India, and the crew had to obey. If the crew had disobeyed they would have been shot for mutiny. If they obey, they are imprisoned by the Indian authorities, who do not seem to understand the distinction between a group of people obeying orders and not. Would Mr Van Orden agree with this?

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: Author, blue-card answer. – You make a very fine point: I think we have seen some rather indiscriminate arrests going on, and it appears that the men concerned were not actually doing anything themselves that was offensive. They were caught up in circumstances outside of their control, as you rightly point out. For all these reasons, we ask for a rapid conclusion to this matter.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, first of all, I would to like to thank my colleague, Mr Van Orden for his constructive and balanced attitude to preparing the text of this resolution. It was not easy, it was complicated, but we have reached this stage. I would also like to express my sympathy to two Italian seamen who are in a similar situation. Most of our Italian colleagues have insisted that their case should be separated from today’s discussion, but our sympathy and solidarity go to our Italian colleagues as well. This is about the fate and future of 20 EU citizens – 14 Estonians and 6 British – who were engaged in anti-piracy operations and whose ship was detained, as my colleague Mr Van Orden mentioned, as long ago as October 2013. What is interesting is that they were not accused of robbery, armed attacks or illegal trade. Twenty EU citizens have been accused of entering Indian waters, having arms on board – which is natural for men engaged in anti-piracy operations – and buying gasoline from an unofficial source. That is all. I think it would be fair to assume that clearing up such accusations could have taken a few months. Instead, our co-citizens have waited nearly two and a half years, having been cleared from accusations by one Indian court and due to be sentenced this month by another court to five years’ imprisonment. We are not here today to question India’s sovereignty or legal system, but this is a gesture of goodwill, in an atmosphere of mutual friendship and sympathy, to relieve the desperate situation of 20 men who have spent nearly two and a half years away from their families. I do not think standing up for the fundamental rights of EU citizens is anything extraordinary. It is a sacred right and the duty of Members of Parliament to voice the tragedies and concerns of our fellow citizens. Supporting and protecting our citizens should never become dependent on diplomatic schedules or timetables.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, 14 Estonian and six British citizens, EU citizens, have been caught in an unfortunate situation in India for more than two years now. After being cleared of all charges in 2014, an appeal was lodged against that decision. Last week, in a sudden turn of events, the men were sentenced to five years rigorous imprisonment, effective immediately. A shock to everybody. The point of this resolution is to draw the attention of India, as well as the EU, to this matter, so that a positive solution to this case can be found. We understand India’s concerns and sensitivities. But we ask India to understand our point of view. The men were engaged in anti-piracy duties, and on-board protection teams are currently the only effective measure against piracy. They were simply doing their job and are now facing imprisonment, being deprived of their freedom and kept far from their families. We are simply asking India to help us get our men home.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would not like the presidency's bureaucratic rigidities to somehow produce unpleasant ambiguities and mis-readings. We are talking about a resolution which, in the title, refers to Italians, but in reality the resolution does not in any way mention Italians, because the part relating to marò has been deleted. Therefore, I would like to see, at the end of this debate, what we approve also changes the title, because I understand that communications may not have been effective, but today we are simply talking about the security guards of the Seaman Guard Ohio patrol ship, including 20 European citizens: 14 Estonians and 6 British. So I would like to make that clear. This resolution is not intended to be an act against India, a country that we respect and which has ancient democratic traditions, but we want to recall the need after having verified the length and contradiction of judicial decisions, that first and foremost the citizens who are detained should be treated with full respect for human rights and that, as part of the process of cooperation between the European Union and India, positive solutions can be found to this matter.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, I believe, in view of all the information that has already been said, that the citizens and sailors concerned did not pose any danger to India and that, during those months and, in fact, years ago, this issue could have been clarified a long time ago. That is why I consider India's action completely unacceptable. And to some extent, it stands in contrast to the way the European Union is doing. I must recall that between 2010 and 2013, the European Union allocated EUR 470 million to development aid to India with a focus on health, education and the implementation of the objectives of the Joint Action Plan. In view of India's approach so far, I think that we should also rethink this negotiation. I firmly believe that we should not support, even materially, regimes that treat European citizens so disgracefully.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to express my sincere in/ 20 – Thank you, Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, colleagues. Indeed, I am pleased that all the groups have decided today to stand in solidarity with those sailors whose fate is of great concern to all estonian people today, as well as the fate of not only Estonian citizens, but also the fate of italian and British citizens. We talk a lot about solidarity, we talk about solidarity between members of the European Union, we talk about solidarity in big things, but solidarity is only credible if it applies even at the level of the most specific one– every individual person! This decision, which we are making today, is actually very much symbolic. It shows that every citizen of the European Union can believe in the European Union as a defence of solidarity, it can also be believed that every citizen of the European Union is equal and equally worthy of the protection of the European Union.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Mr President, may I gently point out that I do not think we are in a quorum while the debate is taking place. However, I have already said in this discussion, in answer to Mr Van Orden’s speech, that what has happened in India is a bit of a travesty of justice. What is even more important is to help the Indians to modernise their legal system. For two years the people who have been arrested have been on bail, without any financial assistance, some of them very ill and in poor shape. It has taken the Indian authorities two years to bring this matter to trial. The Indian legal system is groaning under the weight of numbers of cases, some of which have been ongoing for 20 years. You cannot have a democratic country with a justice system that does not function properly. If there is anything we can do to help India it is to modernise India’s legal structures.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank – The difficulties – which estonian and other countries have faced – clearly show that any European can be in such a difficult situation in a developing country. We like to call India the largest democracy state in the world, but we must not forget that the mere existence of democratic procedures alone does not guarantee that human rights will be respected, nor, alas, guarantee a fair trial. I do not want to make an assessment of the correctness of the application of these local laws to the Indian court, but I would point out that, under international law, the procedure has been too long. At the same time, the living conditions of estonian and other seafarers were very difficult. Not being entitled to work, at the same time, sailors were practically in debt, and this situation put their families in a very serious state of financial gain. This situation also showed that the possibilities for consular services in European countries are very limited, despite the need to help Europeans who find themselves in the millstones of a similar slow-grinding judiciary outside Estonia. So we obviously need to understand this signal and make sure that our consular assistance is a broader reach. Thank you!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I have the greatest possible respect for the Indian people and the Indian Government. I fully respect the sovereignty of India, and I recognise the difficult and unusual situation which gave rise to the current cases. We must not undermine the good relations between the UK and India, and in that spirit of cooperation I feel that it is appropriate for us to make certain requests. I recognise the Indian Government has legitimate concerns over illegally held weapons and I understand their reasonably held worries since the events in Mumbai in 2008, but as far as I can see the British citizens involved – including Nick Dunn from my constituency in Ashington – also had a reasonable belief: they believed that they were acting in accordance with the law. They believed that they were fighting against piracy, working for an American company. They did not believe they were doing anything contrary to the law or to the best interests of India, nor did they even necessarily know that the weapons were illegally held. In such a case, I really wonder whether their continued imprisonment really serves any public interest. I therefore call upon the Indian government to review this case and to free those British, Italian and Estonian citizens who have been caught up in a situation not of their making.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year has passed since we adopted by a very large majority a resolution on the case of the Italian marò Latorre and Girone, who were arrested in India in 2012 and for whom there is no sign of an end to this long nightmare. In view of the hearing in The Hague before the arbitral tribunal, it was decided not to include the case in the resolution. I would have preferred us to have talked about it, because I do not want this decision to be interpreted as an act of weakness on the part of Europe. In the resolution we voted on a few months ago, we made it clear that their detention without charge is 'a serious violation of human rights'. For italian marò, as well as for all European citizens detained in India, the European Union is called upon to honour its commitment to the full and concrete protection of fundamental rights. I call for greater determination to resolve the dispute. India must know that whatever decision it wants to take, this decision will have an impact on relations with the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I know you're trying very hard and want to approach everyone in their own language. Please, when addressing representatives from Croatia, do not use the word deputy, because it means deputy. That's not the right term and an MP should be said. Please refer to us in the word "representative." I want to emphasize the absurdity of this situation in which people really wanted to protect themselves and others in anti-pirate, practically antiterrorism jobs, and in the end they themselves got hurt. They got hurt in the worst possible way so today they're languishing in a dungeon, maybe they'll stay there for five years if we fail in our diplomatic actions. The second thing I wanted to emphasize is that due to the possible counterproductiveness from the title, we remove the issue of italian Marines, because they are not mentioned at all in the resolution, therefore there are none in the text of the resolution. I don't think it's good for them to be listed at all, because there's another way to help them.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Although I am one of the so-called EU skeptics or EU realist members, as a criminal lawyer, I am very pleased that, if a citizen of a European country is caught and prosecuted in a third country, perhaps in a remote country far, far away, the European Union will also protect him – not just his or her traditional consular protection. I will also draw the attention of my fellow Hungarian citizens or compatriots to this. At the same time, I must argue with Mr Deva that we could set an example for India in that pre-trial detention would be used as intended in all EU countries. Now, for example, I have a Hungarian compatriot, István Beke, who, together with a partner, has been in pre-trial detention for the third month in a while, obviously for political reasons, in Romania without any evidence being produced against him by the authorities during that time. Or you can't keep in touch with your relatives because they're applying pre-trial detention as a form of pre-trial detention. So there is room for progress within the EU! (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Nirj DEVA
text: blue-card question. – Will you accept that, in modern times, to keep people incarcerated for two years without bring them to trial is not acceptable? That is all I am saying: that it took two years for the Indian authorities to bring these people to trial and to sentence them, and I made the point that some of them should not have been sentenced because they were carrying out orders and if they had not carried out those orders they would have been shot for mutiny. Would it not be correct to say that, under habeas corpus and other matters, they should have been brought to trial sooner?

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Blue card answer. – I fully agree with my fellow Member Deva. It is intolerable to keep people in pre-trial detention for two years. In that time, there should be plenty of charges. A very important principle is "habeas corpus". I have merely said, and I regret to say, that there are countries within the European Union and there are legal case where we find that European citizens are in pre-trial detention for two years or more – which I find outrageous and I feel that something needs to be done about it. And I feel, and I think, that we agree on that. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Ms Morvai, you said that you are a criminal lawyer, and you talked about a Hungarian who is in prison in Romania. Do you know what charges this citizen faces? At the same time, there is an agreement between Hungary and Romania, as European Union states, to cooperate on these kinds of issues. It is not the same thing as European Union citizens being detained in India.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Blue card answer. "I am aware that the charge is preparation of an act of terrorism. And this makes it all the more outrageous that these people have been in pre-trial detention for the third month in a while on such serious charges, without the Romanian authorities producing any evidence during that time – point one. Point two, no matter how serious the charge is against someone, in Europe you should have the right to keep in touch with your relatives. Given that pre-trial detention cannot be regarded as a pre-trial, pre-imposed sentence.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for their contributions to this discussion leading up to the European Parliament’s resolution today. We share the concerns raised by many of you. Two years of uncertainty have contributed to the agony of all involved. We have followed closely the situation of the Estonian and UK security guards, liaising with the Estonian and UK authorities, as it pertains to the protection of EU citizens.  This case has been raised by the EU with Indian interlocutors several times over the last few months. This case has a negative bearing on the global fight against piracy at a time when we, the international community, should foster cooperation and focus on countering new threats.  We have recently learned that a Tamil Nadu court has sentenced the guards to five years in prison and a fine, reversing the lower court’s acquittal. We understand that they are now considering an appeal to the court’s decision; this came as unexpected news. Allow me to fully subscribe to what the Estonian Foreign Minister, Ms Marina Kaljurand, has said: ‘From a human standpoint, I was undoubtedly hoping for a positive outcome, but regardless of the verdict we will continue to act in the name of returning the men home’.  A solution must be found at the earliest. We will continue to liaise with Estonian and UK authorities in the coming weeks, during the next phases of the judicial process. As regards the case of the two Italian marines, while fully respecting the content and scope of the European Parliament resolution to be voted on today, I wish to reiterate that a solution must be found at the earliest. The European Union has been regularly raising this issue for the past four years at all levels with Indian interlocutors, always with the same message, advocating a rapid and consensual solution in respect with international law. Respect of international law means not only full compliance with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), but also with the UN conventions on human rights. The decision to initiate an international arbitration in the framework of UNCLOS is consistent with international law and a step in the right direction.  You can rest assured that we will continue to monitor the situation of all EU citizens under detention in India and coordinate further actions with the Member States.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Ethiopia (2016/2520(RSP)).

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Author. – Mr President, first of all I would like us to congratulate ourselves on the degree of consensus we have reached in adopting this resolution. It is true that this is a long and complex resolution, and that is inevitable when we talk about Ethiopia. There is a very clear starting point, which is what we want to denounce here: the government crackdown on peaceful demonstrations by farmers and herders protesting the attempt to expand the municipality of Addis Ababa, an attempt that fundamentally affected their way of life and exposed them to leave them in the open. These demonstrations were savagely suppressed and, according to the testimonies of human rights defenders, caused at least one hundred and forty dead. That's the urgent point that brings us here today. But it was inevitable, too, and that is why the extension of this Resolution, to contextualize, to talk about what is going on, in general, in Ethiopia. And what is Ethiopia right now? A country with a failed democracy, hijacked by a single party regime. A country where repression of various ethnic groups, such as the oromo or the Ogadén, is systematically practiced. A country full of displaced people, refugees, many of whom flee to our Europe. A country where counter-terrorism laws are applied that coerce freedom of expression, where arbitrary arrests are made, where members of NGOs are persecuted and where citizens of the European Union are also imprisoned. It is true that it plays a key role in the region, but that should not serve as an excuse for our position, the position of the European Union, which must demand attention and compliance with all the human rights provisions that are in Ethiopia's own Constitution. Ethiopia is also one of the poorest countries in the world. Those of us who have been there have seen levels of misery that I don't think can be overcome. And the European Union is the first aid donor in Ethiopia. We must use this role to force the Ethiopian government to fulfil its human rights commitments. If not, we will be giving up one of the fundamental roles of the European Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of expression is a fundamental right and must be protected as such, as provided for in the African Charter and the Cotonou Agreement. We all care about respect for the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, without which there can be no real democracy. We therefore call for an inclusive and transparent political dialogue between all political representatives, civil society and the people immediately. The African continent is a wonderful continent, rich in resources, but paying for the savage colonial exploitation. The European Union should commit itself to helping African countries free themselves and emancipate themselves from trade policies, without falling into new forms of neo-colonialism, all too often disguised as economic and free trade agreements.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Ethnic groups, such as the Oromo and the Amhara, are hard hit by their opposition work in Ethiopia. They are the target of organized violence. The East African country may be among the better pupils of the African class in terms of economic growth and human development, but the human rights situation is anything but rosy.  So state-led growth clearly has a downside. The government hardly tolerates participation and free journalism is not an easy subject. Ethiopia is a semi-open prison for opposition members and journalists. Reforms are also being implemented without much regard for the impact on the population. An example of this is the "Addis Ababa master plan", a blueprint to expand the capital in the Oromiya region. Peaceful protests broke out, which brutally hit the security forces, with 140 dead. Under intense pressure, that plan was put aside. Calm has returned, but the situation will remain precarious if there is no room for political freedom. If Ethiopia is to guarantee its economic advance and be a legitimate donor to the European Union, change is desperately needed!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Author. – Mr President, on the part of our faction, I would like to join this motion for a resolution. We are discussing the issue of human rights in this state, in Ethiopia, again here in plenary after a few months. This action has triggered what has happened in Ethiopia over the last two months, which has been mentioned here by my colleagues. In short, at the end of last year, over one hundred and forty people were brutally killed in peaceful demonstrations in Addis Ababa. These people, members of the Orom ethnic group, peacefully protested against the change of Addis Ababa's zoning plan, so that they would lose their pastures and be expelled from their territory. It is clear that the human rights situation in Ethiopia is constantly deteriorating, which is why we have this point here and we need to discuss it, say, as an institution that deals with the human rights situation in the world. It is quite clear that, at the moment, the European Union must protest against the ethiopian government's handling of the political opposition, how it imprisons political leaders, how the Ethiopian Government handles independent media, where the state and the right to free expression are clearly suppressed. Ethiopia is among the 10 countries where journalists' rights in the world are most suppressed. In this way, we could talk about the non-profit sector, about ordinary, say, activists who are also imprisoned, and the legislation in this country is that you can more or less not carry out a non-profit, non-state activity here.  On the other hand, there are 700 000 refugees in this country, there is a huge climate problem and this country needs help. It needs help from us, from the European Union, but we must, and this is my call to the Commission, link this assistance to the human rights situation and the state of democracy in this country. That is, aid does, but on condition that the government begins to improve the human rights situation in Ethiopia.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, while the States of the European Union, with more than 500 million citizens, resign themselves to not being able to distribute 160 000 refugees, Ethiopia, an impoverished country with 96 million inhabitants, is already home to more than 700 000 refugees, mainly from South Sudan, Somalia and Eritrea.  At the same time, Ethiopia is a key country in the flow of migrants arriving in Europe.  This puzzle can only be solved if we focus it and act together on the origin of the causes of immigration. This is understood by the Commission, and I welcome the agreement reached last November on the European Agenda on Migration, financed mainly by the Trust Fund for Africa, which will provide EUR 253 million for ten key actions for the Horn of Africa, but there is one issue I am concerned about, Mr Mimica: what role will Parliament play in the development of this programme? On the other hand, in this resolution we denounce ethiopia suffering serious problems from human rights violations. Between 2014 and 2020 alone from the European Development Fund we will reach 745 million euros. Could you, Commissioner, confirm to me whether you are going to develop a tool so that European funds do not help to sustain the violation of human rights by those who allow it?

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, this is the first resolution on Ethiopia in ten years, which explains its length. Yet, since 2009, Ethiopian power seems to be sinking into a repressive and liberticidal climate. NGOs talk about systematic abuses: arbitrary arrests, illegal detentions, torture, criminalization of LGBTI people and even extrajudicial executions. The repression against the Oromo community, which is revolting because it is threatened with expulsion from its territory, the most fertile in this country, under the guise of major industrial and urban projects, is symptomatic of this drift. In addition, Ethiopia is preparing for the largest drought in 50 years due to climate change. A humanitarian catastrophe is looming. Ten to fifteen million people are reported to be in need of food aid this year, including five million children. The country is also home to more than 800,000 refugees. It is representative of the migratory evolution of the countries of the African continent, all of which become more or less countries of origin, reception and transit.  The European Union wants to make it, through the Khartoum process, one of the key partners in the new migration policies. I have, at the very least, concerns that development aid will be diverted to the European obsession with sending back migrants, with Ethiopia serving to receive the rejected from the European Union from other countries in the Horn of Africa. Any partnership must involve advances in human rights, including for migrants. There can be no development without progress towards more democracy.  Yes, there is an emergency for Ethiopia. Yes, the European Union must play a role in promoting full respect for the cultural and religious diversity of the Ethiopian people, which is one of its greatest assets.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for some months now, the inhabitants of the Oromia region in Ethiopia have been demonstrating against the plan to expand the municipal borders of the capital Addis Ababa within their territory. A repeated expansion, which in the past has already caused problems for local farmers, forced to leave their lands and live in absolute poverty. Since the protests began, the situation is critical: 140 demonstrators have been killed and many more injured by security forces in what can be considered the country's worst humanitarian crisis since 2005. For all this, we call for an immediate end to this latest wave of violence and human rights violations, torture and political intimidation. Finally, while aware of Ethiopia's commitment, which we recognise, to cooperation with the European Union on the issue of immigrants and refugees, however, also considering the huge funding enjoyed by the Ethiopian Government, it is necessary to monitor the use of funds and prevent them from facilitating human rights violations, as in the cases we have raised.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, the repression of oromas demonstrators in Ababa, which resulted in at least 140 deaths, is just the latest evidence of the brutal policy of silencing any opposition or criticism by the Ethiopian Government: a government that keeps the people under oppressive surveillance, which manufactures terrorism charges to arrest and torture journalists , peaceful opponents, students and protesters; a Government that cuts off external funding to human rights and development organizations to force them to close, which approves megalomane projects to forge statistics, which organizes land ownership to expel communities without respect for their rights, whether in Oromia, Gambela or Ogaden.  All of this is the case with the support and collusion of the African Union, the United States and the European Union and its Member States, which continue to contribute substantially to the budget for this oppression, on the pretext of ethiopia's role in the stability of the region. For this policy is not sustainable – it betrays our values and principles and, in fact, it fosters instability, because it leads to injustice and despair, and can lead the Ethiopian people to a violent insurrection.  Lessons need to be learned from the Arab Spring of 2011. We know how to exert our tremendous influence to maintain relations with the government, but really help those who fight for democracy and respect for human rights in Ethiopia while it is time.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. President, the list of anti-democratic activities of the Ethiopian authorities is too long. We regret that it is one of the poorest countries in the world, but on the other hand this list includes the abuse of antiterrorism law in such a way that by using this law there is a repression of the opposition, over journalists, speaking generally over the public. Everything that seems to be minorities in Ethiopia cannot be called democratic moves. Also, it should be emphasized precisely the fact of the so-called development masterplan of Addis Ababa, which actually aims to take the land from the Orom area.  Therefore, I call on the Ethiopian authorities to dialogue with us and with the United Nations so that we can continue the necessary donations to Ethiopia because we wish good to this country and its people.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all I thank the groups for their joint work in condemning the repressive actions of the Government of Ethiopia and for alerting them to the social and economic worsening in the Horn of Africa, which is causing the refugee crisis — more than seven hundred thousand – in the region. It is necessary to work together to bring this situation back, free political prisoners and ensure full respect for human rights. However, European responsibility has to go beyond these urgent appeals. First, there are economic responsibilities. Ethiopia's-dependent inclusion in global trade and multinationals in the region are consolidating inequality and lack of access to land. The majority of the population is being condemned to poverty and the absence of social rights. I would like to warn European governments not to use third countries as prisons while refusing to assume their international human rights obligations. We are concerned that development funds are earmarked for internal security objectives and not for improving social and economic conditions in the region. It is these social and economic conditions that have to play a priority role and not a mitigating effect, as the Commission intends.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, Ethiopia represents one of the most ancient and culturally rich civilisations. Its diverse ethnic and religious community, which has managed to live through millennia side by side, was something to admire not so long ago. In the last few decades, however, the situation has strongly deteriorated, with numerous human rights violations severely hampering social, economic and political progress in the country. The recent events surrounding the expansion of the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, have become just another example of large-scale civil rights violations. Harassment of opposition, crackdowns on protesters, limitations on civil society and the media, the political under-representation of most ethnic groups and internet censorship – this is, most regrettably, the current reality in Ethiopia.  The EU is a major financial donor and provider of assistance to Ethiopia and must step up its efforts, effectively addressing this issue by using every available instrument at its disposal. Ethiopia has the potential to become considerably more than it is today and our task is to lend a helping hand. The current situation, however, is no longer beneficial and it has to change as soon as possible.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I believe, together with my colleagues, that the repression applied to the civilian population, to political prisoners, to journalists, to general misery, is really not a good calling card for the Ethiopian Government, and there are a number of other consequences for our continent as well. The refugee crisis may be the culmination of these problems, and I think it would be appropriate for us to remind the Ethiopian Government very strongly that it should be the government of a democratic state and that the time of the Abyssinian Empire may have passed long ago. I would very much like there to be a voice here today, which I think is coming from all of us speaking out, that these actions by the Ethiopian Government certainly do not find our support and should also be reflected in our development aid.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, in the last two months the Ethiopian Government has murdered 140 demonstrators peacefully protesting the Government's plans to expand the capital, indiscriminately expropriating agricultural land owned by the Oroma ethnic group, the largest in the country. This brutal repression is the culmination of the persecution that oromas have been undergoing since 2011, and which motivated the ethiopian political leaders in December last year, following the deaths of 75 students, who were also peacefully protesting against this urban plan, High Representative Federica Mogherini urged Ethiopian political leaders to constructivedialogue between the parties and the peaceful resolution of this conflict. Following the numerous pressures it has been under, the Ethiopian government currently in power announced last week that it would withdraw this urban plan as a way of restoring social peace in the area.  Ladies and gentlemen, we must not be fooled by this so-called goodwill of a Government which does not avoid using all the means at its disposal to oppress its citizens. Now, more than ever, the European Union must strengthen all the mechanisms at its disposal to denounce this policy of extermination of the Ethiopian Government.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the European Union and its Member States have a regular and frank dialogue with the Government of Ethiopia on issues related to democracy and human rights. Our consistent message is that economic and social development must go together with political and human rights to make it sustainable.  A strong civil society and freedom of expression, association, and peaceful assembly are crucial for creating a more prosperous, secure and more economically successful country. In that context, the European Union is following recent unrest in Oromia, triggered by the urban expansion plans for Addis Ababa city, closely and with concern. There were also ethnic clashes in the Amhara region, which received less attention from the media but which also resulted in casualties.  On 23 December 2015, the European External Action Service spokesperson called for a peaceful resolution of the disputes. These events show the importance of constructive dialogue to address grievances. We called for clarity on all acts of violence and abuses perpetrated against protesters, as well as accountability for such violations. We have raised these concerns with the Ethiopian authorities in Addis, and most recently in Brussels when the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Dr Tedros Adhanom came to visit High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini on 13 January. He recognised the situation and informed us that the Addis Ababa expansion master plan had been discarded.  Ethiopia is facing many other challenges, where we are also working with the government. The population has grown dramatically in recent decades, now reaching over 100 million people. This is a challenge in terms of job creation, service delivery and poverty reduction. The effects of two consecutive droughts and of El Niño have left 10.2 million people in need of food assistance, in addition to eight million already benefiting from government programmes.  This endangers the social and economic development of the country. In this context the European Union provides, and will continue to provide, political and financial support for improving the human rights situation in Ethiopia, but also for supporting, in parallel, efforts by the government in terms of poverty reduction, economic and social development and humanitarian issues.  Ethiopia is the biggest beneficiary of the 11th European Development Fund’s bilateral development envelope of EUR 745 million, complemented by regional and thematic programmes and Emergency Trust Fund operations for stability and addressing root causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa.  Despite these immense needs, Ethiopia has an open door policy and is the largest refugee-hosting country in Africa, with over 700 000 refugees. In the EU, we shall provide support on this issue through the Regional Development and Protection Programme for the Horn of Africa, as well as through the recently signed Common Agenda on Migration and Mobility.  Ethiopia is an important partner for the European Union in many areas – migration, climate change, regional peace and stability to name but a few. We enjoy a constructive engagement on all these aspects that are important to Europe, to Ethiopia and to the region. In the same vein, the European Union will resolutely continue to stress the importance of human rights in Ethiopia and support the country in respect of the fundamental freedoms of its citizens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, what you are doing is an absolute breach of the rules, and I wonder: we are about 40-45 people out of the 751 Deputies here this afternoon. Could you please enlighten me, Mr President, why those of us who take the effort to stay here are not allowed to speak under the catch-the-eye procedure? If, for whatever reason, you decide not to give us the floor, do you not think that it would be a minimum level of collegiality to tell us in advance of the procedure and how you decide to give us the floor or not? What is your principle on that?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Madam President, i would like to thank you very much I think I am the President who always tries to give you a voice and you should not complain about me. You have spoken several times, if I have not seen your name on the list, I apologise to you very much for that, and of course this will not happen again. There was no bad will here, and I think you never judged me for bad will or judged me. Once again, I apologize.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. I consider the human rights situation in Ethiopia, which has been repeatedly violated by the security forces, to be extremely serious, responding violently to peaceful protests by citizens against government policies. The Ethiopian authorities themselves, which are supposed to guarantee the rule of law, are abusing power in their own hands by arresting dissidents, including many journalists and members of opposition political parties. I am very concerned about the fate of all those who are persecuted for their ideas.  I wonder how it is possible that Ethiopia, africa's second most populous and booming country, can tolerate such violations of the inalienable right to freedom of expression. In view of the aid that Ethiopia receives from the European Union and the international treaties on respect for human rights signed by the country, the situation is unacceptable!  The Commission has a duty to urge the Ethiopian authorities to respect freedom of expression and to release the detainees, whose only fault is to think differently from the government's line.  I believe it is essential for the Eu ropean Union to pay more attention to the present and future negotiations with Ethiopia, so as not to compromise with a country which, to date, does not guarantee respect for human rights.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven resolutions on North Korea (2016/2521(RSP)).

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to apologise to my fellow author, who could not be here. So, nuclear bomb: the word alone makes me shudder, we cannot fail to strongly condemn the nuclear test of 6 January, clearly it is a provocative act. The problem, however, is that in order to be credible here in Europe too, we should dismantle our weapons and close all trade with countries where there are conflicts. Only by good example, by example, can we be credible. It is recent news that the United States has decided to embark on a programme for the modernisation of nuclear weapons and the programme will also cover Italy, in fact 70 atomic bombs will be replaced at Aviano, at the Aviano and Ghedi sites. They are new generation atomic bombs that also destroy the subsoil. It is therefore right, quite right, to point the finger at the regime in Pyongyang, but the European Union should do the same with regard to the various Member States and partners, starting with the United States.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: author. – Mr President, I speak as the Chair of the Delegation for the Korean Peninsula, and it is with a very heavy heart that I get up this afternoon to talk about what is happening in North Korea. I was so upset and sad to hear that a bomb had been exploded by the North Korean regime at a time when the European Parliament and my delegation had been working extremely hard over the last year to build a relationship between the North and the South, to the point that we had been invited by both sides to write a peace treaty between the North and the South , something that – as you may know – does not currently exist.  What does exist is an armistice signed some 63 years ago, and the entire construct of the Republic of Korea and the DPRK is built on an armistice. In my understanding an armistice is a break in a war, but not a peace treaty.  My intention has been to write this peace treaty with the help of the United States, China, Russia and all the other parties involved. That is what we have been doing. I want to keep our relationship with North Korea open even though they are playing some a dangerous game, which is not of any value as I see it, either to themselves, or to global peace. They cannot create economic structures by building nuclear weapons when their people are hungry and their economy is one of the least developed. We need to keep the door open, and I intend to do that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Deva, you know that we were together in Korea and we tried, you are right, to help reconcile the two Koreas. I ask you directly: with your experience, do you think that we, as the European Union, can really influence bring about the unification of the two Koreas? Because I spoke to the Minister of Unification in South Korea and it seemed to me that he did not have a concrete programme.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: Author, blue-card answer. – I am very grateful to you for asking that question. If you look at all the interlocutors on this particular issue, we, the EU, are the only people who do not have an axe to grind. This is an English expression, which I am sure you will understand. We do not have a particular set of goals. We want peace. We want reconciliation. Once we get that understood by the Chinas, the Japans and the North and South Koreas and the United States, then we will make progress. So we have a unique position and a role to play here.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. Mr President, this debate on North Korea is very important for a number of reasons. First of all, it is part of the condemnation movement after the recent nuclear test that North Korea has boasted about. This test was conducted in violation of all UN Security Council resolutions and represents a very serious threat to the stability of the Korean peninsula.  The second main reason is that this year there was a Korean candidate for the Sakharov Prize. Reverend Hyeon, who has devoted his entire life to defending human rights in North Korea, has unfortunately not been formally nominated for lack of support. Awarding the Sakharov Prize to a North Korean human rights defender would be an essential step in the fight for respect for human rights.  The impact of the Sakharov Prize on the countries concerned has yet to be proven, it has in the past revived the debate on the issue of human rights and encouraged civil society to become more involved. That is why I would like to take this opportunity to invite our colleagues who really want to help North Korea support such an approach this year. No one from North Korea has ever been at least an official candidate for the nomination and that is absurd, because it is one of the last totalitarian countries. The award has been given to important people, I think we must also take this step towards North Korea. It is important that Parliament sends a strong message to Korea, and that these human rights situations remain a priority for foreign policy. In this sense, we call in our resolution, Mrs Mogherini, to closely monitor the situation in this country and to maintain constant pressure on this regime. I wanted to put North Korea back on the agenda of our resolutions, because I refuse to associate myself with the pessimism about North Korea's capacity for change. The people of North Korea deserve a constant commitment from us, the regime will not undertake any reform on its own initiative. It is up to the international community to seize the right opportunities to act sustainably.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, the hydrogen bomb test that North Korea performed in early January has been condemned by the Council and the UN Security Council. We, too, strongly condemn the test, which is a direct threat to stability and peace on the Korean peninsula. Further provocations should be avoided at all costs by abandoning nuclear and ballistic missile programmes, and an end should be sought to the provocations through the six-party talks, which should be resumed. Another key point of concern to us is that the human rights situation and the humanitarian situation are very, very dire. People face systematic repression, and the Commission of Inquiry has established that crimes against humanity were perpetrated. We need more concrete international action to end the impunity and to bring the perpetrators to justice. We should also consider more targeted sanctions. It is essential for the international community to convince the Chinese Government to use its influence, both economically and politically, to push North Korea to de-escalate. It should also make an effort to accept refugees from North Korea.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There are conflicts and developments in the world where one wonders why the political reason of the world community does not manage to bring it to a political solution. For me, the conflict on the Korean peninsula is one of them. We know its roots, its historical course, its participants and their rhetorical templates. We know the rituals by which the conflict is organized: this eternal pendulum between pushing forward and rowing back, confrontation and dialogue, opening up and walling in. The overall situation is reminiscent of the time when the block confrontation had clearly reached its limits and yet everything was somehow in a balance, in a kind of balance, where the war was not a real political option, but always a rhetorical one. This is exactly how the situation is today. Even after North Korea's latest nuclear test, everyone is already back to their routines, everyone is talking about destabilizing effects, but no one is really acting. Even the UN Security Council, with its unanimous resolution 2094 of March 2013, has virtually been working on a stockpile of sanctions for the latest nuclear test. I wonder if there is speculation that the social system in North Korea has fallen out of time in such a way that it will have to collapse. This would be a serious mistake, because the CVR, despite all sanctions, has high economic growth, is on the verge of self-sufficiency in food, and is far from excluded from international world economic processes. Let's see: The apps on our i-Phones are produced in North Korea. Where you simply shoot political opponents from your own family, you cannot talk about human rights. Where political power can be inherited, there is no democracy. Where work is brutally expropriated by the state, pathos may be centrally organized, but never preserved social participation and legitimacy. However, as long as our resolutions do not develop a political solution, only insights remain. I believe that we must develop the guidelines that were also called for in the resolution and define the new EU strategy towards the KDVR for resolving the processes on the Korean peninsula.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we strongly condemn the nuclear test that North Korea conducted on 6 January and call on the Government of North Korea to re-sign and ratify the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, from which it withdrew its signature in 2003. We also call for further sanctions to be strengthened by the UN Security Council, because we are concerned about the human rights situation in the country. The Government of North Korea does not allow any political opposition, the judicial system is submissive to the state while the death penalty is in force for a wide range of crimes against the state. And we need to talk about unspeakable crimes for which North Korea should be called before the International Criminal Court to answer for these abuses. It is therefore our duty, in the resolution, to also call for the abolition of the death penalty, the release of political prisoners and the allowing of its citizens to travel freely and, given the seriousness of the food situation facing the country, we nevertheless call on the Commission to maintain its humanitarian aid programmes.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, the situation in North Korea is really serious. I personally visited North Korea ten years ago with a delegation from the Czech Chamber of Deputies. And I've seen an authoritarian regime that lies to its own citizens and shuts itself off from the world. Unfortunately, nothing has changed in that time, as the UN Commission of Inquiry notes in 2014. It is very sad that people in North Korea continue to suffer from hunger, while their government finances research and production of nuclear weapons and security services to monitor and persecution their own citizens. Negotiations on disarmament, nuclear disarmament and respect for human rights are blocked by North Korea. At the same time, I must say that this is a beautiful country with natural riches and gifted people, and it could be as rich, as developed as South Korea, which is not giving up hope of joining. For mr. Scholz: the solution is not on South Korea's side, the solution is in the hands of north Korea's authoritarian government. South Korea is closely monitoring North Korea's development and also has the best understanding of how its development can be influenced. That is why I recommend, and the European Parliament resolution also mentions this, so that the European Commission should use the expertise to produce the European Union's strategy precisely by South Korea, which has these expertise. So, in the face of north Korea's closedness, I think it is very important that we deal with this situation.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, since the proliferation of nuclear, chemical, biological and technical means poses a threat to international peace and security, I strongly condemn the nuclear test carried out by North Korea on 6 January, as it constitutes a serious breach of its international obligations, UN Security Council resolutions and the non-proliferation regime.  It is paramount to suspend all activities related to the ballistic missile programme and to completely abandon existing nuclear programmes. At the same time, the North Korean authorities must fulfil their obligations, cooperate and ensure that humanitarian organisations and the UN special rapporteur on human rights have access to its territory.  The Commission has a duty to maintain channels of communication with North Korea and existing humanitarian aid programmes. It is also the duty of the North Korean authorities to ensure that all need-based citizens have access to food and humanitarian assistance.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – North Korea did indeed literally and figuratively shake the world two weeks ago with its hydrogen bomb test. What is going on in the head of that great leader Kim Jong-un?  North Korea is synonymous with colorless tristesse. The few objective reports from that open-air prison show the slave status of the North Korean people and the enduring human rights violations. No one has been granted an opinion or freedom. Political opponents suffer the horror, well-conceived and gradually through deliberate starvation, forced labour, summary executions and inhuman brutality. The hydrogen experiment was also condemned this time by neighbor and ally China. On human rights, of course, Beijing was silent in all languages. Just like Russia, by the way. The two countries are, of course, in the same boat; speaking about North Korean violations would be hypocritical. But the Union, Commissioner, must not remain silent! We owe it to those hundreds of thousands of innocents, the hungry children with no future, the lost North Korean generations. We owe it to ourselves, too, looking away would be all too easy.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, North Korea is the urgency that never ends: every month there is another report of a new person unjustly imprisoned, another execution of some top government official or more reports of common Korean citizens dying from unnecessary hunger in order to feed a military machine.  To say that North Korea is a Kafkaesque state is an extreme understatement. From announcing that they had an H-bomb two weeks ago, I understand that the big announcement this week is that they had cured hangovers. Based on what we have seen, I believe it would be pointless for me to ask the North Korea regime to do anything. Instead, let me call on China to end its support for this regime.
