Supporting North Korea is a drain on the Chinese economy, a waste of its natural resources and a shame on Chinese honour. The days of the Cold War are over. Supporting this regime does a disservice to both regional and Chinese security. Only a united Korea at peace can finally bring security to Northeast Asia.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, like most People’s Democratic Republics in history, North Korea is not a republic, it is not democratic and it does not act for its people. Communism in North Korea, like every other regime ever to try it, is rotten and corrupt to the core. They execute someone every four hours, they grow more drugs than they grow food, and there is serious malnutrition, rationing and utter ruthlessness towards dissidents.  I am sorrowfully reminded that, only a couple of months ago in the British Parliament, Labour’s Shadow Chancellor approvingly pulled out and quoted the Little Red Book of China’s Chairman Mao. Mao’s version of communism butchered tens of millions of his own people. We should hang our heads in shame that such extremism was ever seen in the British Parliament. We must fight and reject the politics of North Korea. We must fight the ideology that gives birth to it every bit as much as we fight that which spawns organisations like ISIS.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in paragraph 3 of your joint motion for a resolution, you state your desire to find a diplomatic solution with Pyongyang. Now, in the next paragraph, you are demanding new sanctions against that country, when North Korea is already the most isolated country on the planet. If I have no kind of sympathy for this terrible communist dictatorship, I do not believe that its provocations should be responded with new sanctions, which can only aggravate the paranoia of its leaders. Yes, they are paranoid, but it must be recognized, alas, that the lies, inconsistencies and volte-faces of the Western chancelleries all too often provide credible arguments for North Korean propaganda. Let us simply remember the myth of Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction, which served as a pretext for the second Gulf War, a calamitous intervention that is at the origin of the infernal chaos that now reigns in the Middle East. While Mrs Mogherini can be recognised for certain diplomatic skills, the european Union's ongoing interference makes conflicts much worse than it solves them. It is up to North Korea's neighbours and traditional interlocutors to find a solution to the real problems facing North Korea today.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my strong support for this motion for a resolution, which strongly condemns North Korea’s nuclear test conducted on 6 January 2016 – another nuclear test conducted by this country, which is again posing a serious threat to regional and international peace and security. These nuclear tests violate the United Nations Security Council resolutions. The pursuit of illegal nuclear and ballistic missile programmes constitutes a challenge to the international nuclear non-proliferation regime and risks aggravating regional tensions. North Korea has increasingly isolated and impoverished its people through its pursuit of weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery, and should instead return to the six-party talks without preconditions.  We must continue to closely monitor developments in the North Korea nuclear dossier and its regional and global implications. I expect a further strengthening of sanctions by the United Nations Security Council, and I call on North Korea to choose, in the end, a constructive path by engaging with the international community.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I also want to join in supporting this proposal for our text. It has already been said, North Korea is now the country that probably suppresses human rights the most in the world. A communist dictatorship that murders thousands of its citizens every year, hundreds of thousands of people are locked up in concentration camps, and more than half the population is starving and many are even starving. It is a country with which, unfortunately, some international dialogue has recently failed. Nevertheless, I think it is a good thing that we will adopt this resolution today. I want to make one comment, which was also made in the debate. I find the part of the resolution that is very important, where we call on China to help us put pressure on North Korea. I personally believe that China is the only country that has any authority over North Korean officials, and China can thus be crucial in trying to change the regime in North Korea and lead the regime to respect at least fundamental human rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, North Korea remains one of the most isolated countries in the world as a result of provocative acts, such as tests carried out with a hydrogen nuclear bomb on 6 January. For sixty years, this country has been threatening to invade and destroy its southern neighbours and the United States. It is too easy to dismiss North Korea's latest ads and attitudes as mere skirmishes. This time the danger is serious and comes two months after North Korea's third nuclear test led the UN Security Council to approve new sanctions against the North Koreans, who follow those previously approved. North Korea must refrain from taking further provocative action and immediately comply with all international obligations. The time has come for the international community to take concrete action to put an end to this situation. The major international players and the Government of the People's Republic of China in particular are exerting all their influence and political and economic leverage over North Korea to ensure that the situation does not escalate further. Let us work together to restore world peace.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, the problem of North Korea can only have a serious and lasting solution if it is found in the framework of multilateral contributions – it cannot be just the European Union and/or the United States, whether or not it is in conjunction with Japan and South Korea, it is necessary to involve all countries that can make positive contributions to the issue, namely China and Russia, which have been, in the past, important allies of North Korea.  Ignoring or antagonising China and Russia does not help solve the problem – but it can even aggravate it. The problem of North Korea's nuclear weapons is not solved with rhetorical proclamations, concrete action is needed.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, I stress that the Communist regime is committing human rights violations in North Korea. Once again, it is a communist regime, this regime threatens not only the Korean peninsula, but also the future of democracy in the world, including Europe. I would like to point out, ladies and gentlemen, that the Communists are seeking a new internationalisation of communism. For example, the Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia makes no secret of its ambition to become the frontman of the international communist movement and to create something like a new communist international. Their strong partner is the North Korean Communists, who regularly participate in international communist meetings in Prague.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, North Korea is a country that is a signatory to most international human rights treaties, which it regularly violates. That is why calling for compliance with Security Council resolutions, as well as our calls to respect the rules of international public policy will certainly not help.  Unfortunately, it will not help and calls to make China its influence over North Korea, because China will do so in accordance with its interests and not in accordance with our calls. The only real solution is a coordinated joint international diplomatic action, of course, which is absent because neighbouring Countries of North Korea are having a hard time agreeing on this. Nevertheless, I support this resolution and call on the European Parliament and the European Commission to monitor the human rights situation in North Korea as well as the state of threat to international peace by North Korea.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I sincerely wish you well as soon as possible. And now I turn to the Representative of the Commission here. Point 4 of the report is about the European Parliament calling on the international community to stop tolering the crimes of communist dictators and to get justice for the culprits of the dictatorship as soon as possible. I would like to ask the Representative of the Commission to remind me whether I remember wrongly: many former Communist countries are represented here in the European Union. I do not recall that, either during the accession negotiations, which directly followed the so-called regime change, the European Union would have since called on either these countries or the associated countries to bring to justice at least the perpetrators of the worst communist crimes, the communist culprits who were still living in large numbers at the time, and to punish them severely. Do I remember correctly or do I remember wrong? Is this about some kind of double standard?

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Thank you! Basically, we could talk about North Korea at every point of human rights violations in our plenary session, and so for years, which shows that this is an extremely complex problem, of course, above all for the people of North Korea itself, but the signs show that this threat is also increasing for the countries around us. Unfortunately, you can learn from recent years how the world has missed a number of problems – in the sense that if intervention had been made in time, there would have been no greater trouble. I fear that it may be the same as the discussed, the talk, but those who could exert real pressure on North Korea are modest. I am thinking, above all, of China, to a certain extent also of Russia. Of course, the European Union and other countries in the world must learn from the mistakes of recent years and the dingesting of the last few years and not let the same accident happen to North Korea, so that it is already much more difficult to deal with the consequences in hindsight.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the European Union is watching with great concern the serious violations of human rights in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, as documented, among others, by the UN Commission of Inquiry’s report in early 2014. The situation calls for urgent systematic and structural changes in North Korea. This is a moral and legal imperative, but also a very practical necessity.  The situation as it stands is a recipe for long-term regional instability. I would like to recall that some of the findings of the Commission of Inquiry even point to possible crimes against humanity. For that reason, the European Union has supported the recommendation that the UN Security Council refers the situation in North Korea to the International Criminal Court. The European Union has been and will remain at the forefront of keeping this dire state of affairs at the centre of attention of the international community. Our work at the UN is clear testimony of that. But the EU’s goal is not securing headlines or condemnation; our prime objective is achieving concrete improvements on the ground. That is what matters the most. The European Union is already financing a number of food security, health, water and sanitation projects in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea that are of direct benefit to some of the most vulnerable people in the country, including some children in care institutions, the elderly, people with impairments and vulnerable farming communities.  The European Union is ready to do more and to cooperate further with North Korea, but only if it starts to address credibly and substantially its major and serious human rights deficiencies. If North Korea decides to follow the path of real engagement on human rights, starting with full cooperation with the UN Human rights mechanisms, then it will manage to secure a real, effective security in ways that illegal nuclear weapons will never provide. But recent actions by North Korea – the illegal nuclear test that it conducted on 6 January – show that we are not yet on a positive path and our ability to cooperate remains severely limited as a result. North Korea should focus on the much-needed human rights reforms that its citizens require, not on destabilisation and illegal actions that create an insecure and threatening environment to the detriment of all.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – I strongly condemn north Korea's fourth nuclear test. North Korea violates four UN Security Council resolutions (from 2006, 2009 and 2 from 2013) that fully prohibit any nuclear or ballistic program. It is lamentable, but especially dangerous, as North Korea shamelessly defies the security and peace of the world. With the violation of Security Council resolutions, North Korea is violating its commitments and posing a serious threat to peace in the region. Moreover, North Korea violates human rights in a "unparalleled" way in the contemporary world. The latest Human Rights Watch report in 2015 mentions a vast network of camps, where about 120,000 people are being closed. These abuses can be equated with crimes against humanity. Countermeasures taken must target tougher sanctions than ever before. I call on the North Korean government to choose dialogue over nuclear tests that endanger an entire world.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the vote. (Results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the vote.
